Is chapel held in the main building or in the boys' dorÂ­mitory? The programs of the last few weeks have shown a deÂ­cided improvem: ent which seems to indicate that we are in tune with Doc Coue's often- quoted aphorism. Some of the numbers which have been of especial interest were a stirring declamation, " Spartacus to the Gladiators," by Clarence DarÂ­nell; a talk on the great operas of the world, with opera recÂ­ords, by Hubert Overall; and two subjects dear to the heart of every normal student, " Who's Who on Open Nights?" and " Spring and the Campus Course," by Ben Chrisman and Paul Burton respectively. . ' We believe that it is fundamental to include interest and variety in our programs. We believe it is requisite to study and discuss subjects around which centers the culture of an educated man. We believe that we are united for a purpose, that it is our duty to offer our members material which will both entertain and profit them so that they may Â· be richly reÂ­paid for the time invested. We are now preparing to complete our year's work. Our debaters against the Claxtons for commencement week are Paul Eayes and C. M. Clark. The play selected to be given in collaboration with the Murfrees is " A Pair of Sixes." This THE NORMALITE 37 is a play of unusual merit permeated with genuine humor and motivated by a well- knit plot. Standing at the threshold of our departure from this year's work, we may now look back in retr~ spect. It is. an irony of life that all things must pass; but thIS very tranSIenÂ­cy in itself lends the charm to objects ~ nd conditio~ s under its influence. We, the Gradies of 1923, wIll soon be dIsbanded. We trust that our influence has not been for naught. We trust that our society and school may have been made better by our presence and work. We trust that we hav~ lived uP. to the true Grady ideals and that we have helped m advancmg those ideals. We know that we have profited by being united as Grady members, and we will always be in spirit with the Gradies of the coming years. I t is in your hands, you Gradies- to come, to carryon our work. It is with you that in the future we leave our soÂ­ciety. And may you always put forth the best efforts in the endeavor to accord with the highest principles of Gradyism, to advance those principles, and to be actuated by the resolve to continue to make of the greatest value and brotherhood the Grady Literary Society. Claxton Society The Claxton Literary Society has come to the close of anÂ­other successful year. We have not reached the mark of perÂ­fection- if that were true there would be no room for imÂ­provement. New me~ bers hav~ been added to the list of membership constantly . These as well as the old members have show; n much interest in preparing their part when placed on program. The attendance during this month has necessarily been lessened, due to the fact that several of the boys go out each evening for baseball practice. The preparation of the annual society debate, and the Claxton- Dromgoole play has taken . considerable time; not only of those who participated but those who have willingly given their assistance. As a society we wish to express our sincere appreciation to Messrs. Fred Arnold and David L. Manier, who have been so zealous in the preparation of the affirmative side of this question: " Re- THE NORMALITE T. E. Clark, Editor. Grady Literary Society , .......... 36 \..~... solved that the United States should adopt a cabinet system of government similar to that of Great Britain." The debatÂ­ers of the Grady Society are taking the negative stand. Now, at the close of this year it is well to make some reÂ­mark to the newstudents. We have four lively literary socieÂ­ties in Middle' Tennessee Normal, two of which are for the girls, and two for the boys. No newstudent can make a misÂ­take in joining one of these literary societies. The Claxton Society extends a hearty welcome to the young men, and the young ladies we wish to invite to visit our sister- society, the Dromgoole. One of the things which these two societies prize themselves for, is the congenial atmosphere which preÂ­vails. You are a stranger only once with us. Murfree Society The approach of spring has given to us new pep and zeal to m'ake the many tasks which are before us a success. Already a great deal of enthusiasm is being manifested in the essay contest which will soon be here. Thpse who are to represent us in the contest " try- out" have already been seÂ­lected and are each trying to attain the high honor which is sought. The society broke the monotony of the chapel exercises one day not long ago by presenting a very interesting proÂ­gram to the faculty and student body. We are all very much interested in the Murfree- Grady play, " A Pair of Sixes" which is to be given May II. The Society is glad to welcome many new members this term and are also glad to have many of its former members back, and we wish to assure them that there is always a place and a hearty welcome for them in Murfree Hall. Dromgooles The DrOnigooles came to a close of the year with a feel Â· Â· ing that this has been a banner year for us. Its membership has greatly increased and a number of interesting and inspirÂ­ing programs have been features of the year's work. Each member Â· has worked diligently for the betterment of the Society, but our work is not yet finished~ Our girls are busy on their essays and every member must do all that Windrow says M. T. N. has Peabody beat for pretty girls. We wonder if he was thinking of the rest of the fel-lows. she can to support them. Enthusiasm is now running high and w'e expect a great victory. Miss Will Allen Drom~ goole visited us in March and we hope she can be with us again the night of the essay contest. . Miss Dromgoole is writing an autobiography and will present it to the society to preserve. / THE NORMALITE J9 Thus bees work from morn' till night And then from night tm early morn. But it doesn't really seem it's right, Since by this their life is soon gone. When night has come most creatures rest. But night for bees is not that way, While little birds sleep in their nest, Bees preserve what they've made that day. Thus' bees work the whole day through. No drones in their home do abide; For their queen is good and true, And in her reign all drones have died. TO THE HONEY- BEE And so, here's to the honey bee! The greatest worker. in our landÂ­Thou dost not stop to think of thee, But givest thy sweet life to feed man. - ED GARR. Oh! just to be a' honey- bee And kiss the flowers in the spring, Then fly with mates to our lone tree And leave the nectar that we bring. President Lyon had a birthday recently and the other members of the faculty found it out and remembered it apÂ­propriately. The senior members of the faculty said to him " Cheer up Friend, we all have to have them" and the junior members and the student body said " Friend, it was a good day for this cold, gray world when you gave it a birthday." At the beginning of the term some one saw Mrs. Ogden and remarked, " Oh, what an attractive new student." 42 THE NORMALITE THE NORMALITE 4J In a for: m'er issue of the NORMALITE the statement was made that Miss Schardt and Miss Fontaine had made a purchase of ear- rings at Woolworths. The ladies in quesÂ­tion wish to explain that they wear the ear- rings not with any idea of beautifying themselves, but only with the desire of hearing Miss Monohan's free lecture on the " Age of SavÂ­agery" and " Relics of Barbarism." When things grow dull at the teachers' table they don their ear- rIngs and stir up a series of caustic remarks on women of prehistoric ages and cave dwellers, etc, etc., etc., ad infintum. Windrow-" There are no fools in our family!" Manier-" Sir, you forgot yourself." Harvill tells of a man who lost a tooth fiftten years ago found it later, replaced it and has a good tooth today. Those who eat at the dining hall should be thankful that they are not on an island for that is the chief difference as we see it. Hannah Graham Belcher, Editor With the arrival of the Senior rings and pins everybody very suddenly realized that Commencement was not far disÂ­tant. Plans for new white dresses and vacation trips are being made rapidly. A recent lyceum number was presented by the Peabody Entertainment Com'mittee. It consisted of music by a mixed quartette, readings by Miss Wilkes, and a scene from the popular opera, " Martha." On Friday, April the sixth, the campus' was the scene of the County Athletic Meet. Representatives from all parts of the county were present. It is said that the Normal had nevÂ­er before witnessed such an array of blue, red, and white ribÂ­bons ' as was presented that day. On the twenty- fourth of March the girls' physical eduÂ­cation classes gave an exhibition in the gym. An interesting feature was the series of reiays between the " peanuts" and the " popcorns." Dr. J. A. Sample, State Chemist, recently made a visit to Mr. Belcher, and after an inspection of the laboratories, pronounced them first class. One of the interesting events, during April was the apÂ­pearance of the Coffer- Miller Players. They gave a matinee and evening performance, presenting the two comedies, ( A couple of old codgers got into a quarrel and landed beÂ­fore the local magistrate. The loser, turning to his opponÂ­ent in a combative frame of mind, cried: I'll law you to the circuit court." " I'm willin'," said the other. " An' I'll law you to the supreme court." " I'll be thar." " An' I'll law you to ' ell!" " My attorney will be there," was the calm reply. - Boston Transl ri1 t THE NORMALITE 45 Louise McKnight, Editor. Bladys Bond, ' 23, completed her work here in the winter term. She is doing work this quarter at Peabody. Frances Blevens, ' 22, is teaching in Chattanooga. She visited Margaret Ward during the Easter Holidays and was a welcome guest at M. T. N. Laura Davis, ' 22, is teaching in Tyner School, ChattaÂ­nooga. Hobart Massey, ' 22, who has taught in Chattanooga the past year, recently married. Pansy Brier, ' 22, a sister of our " Judge'" Brier, is teachÂ­ing in Jamestown, her home town , this year. Adina Golden, 22, is teaching in Walling, Tenn. Rebecca Hill, 22, and her sister, Katherine Hill, ' 21, are both teaching in their home town, Sparta. Gladys Robinson, " 20, is teaching in Chattanooga. Wayde H. Rucker, ' 20~ a graduate of the agriculture Course is now studying at Vanderbilt. Foster Swann, ' 20, is. teaching at Bethesda, Tenn. L. R. Wheeler, ' 20, is teaching at Ashland City, Tenn. J . E. Windrow, ' 23, completed his three years work here last term and has gone to Peabody this quarter. Lillian Beesley, ' 17, who has taught in the Public School here for several years, is to be married to Mr. Thomas Hud- THE NORMALITE " Gam. mer Gurton's Needle," wand " The Imaginary Invalid," very creditably. However the Middle Tennessee Normal is not dependent on Moliere or professional players for its entertainment, for it holds within its walls a master playwright and actors of limitless ability. Proof - of thi" was riven on the evening of April 20, when Mr. Mankin's . most recent production, " WiseÂ­acre's Debut," was presented by a picked cast. It w2.~ a comÂ­plete success as was evidenced by the insistent calls for Uauthor." : Miss Williams and eleven Y. W. C. A. girls spent the week- end in Nashville attending a Y. W. conference at which Peabody and Vanderbilt were joint hostesses. There were representatives from several colleges, and the meeting was a big success. An unusual event occurred on April 30, when the faculty forgot they were the faculty and enjoyed themselves hugeÂ­ly in giving a stunt program. We discovered many things about our teachers that we had never even dreamed of. Miss Lumpkin, a char Â· ming and forceful Y. W. worker, was here several days giving help and inspiration to the Y. W. girls. Mrs. Fertig entertained the Y. W. C. A. members at her home April 24. Mrs. E. L. Atwood entertained the Baptist girls at the Normal on April 27. 44 A LAMENT THE NORMALITE 47 Geraldine Grigsby, Editor It is needless to mention the apparent zeal and action of the new cabinet, ~ ho will serve the remainder of this year and until March of the year following. It seems that each one has grasped her work, and has already gone to work in her field, with a ready and willing spirit, cumbined with a complete comprehension of the task set before her. No one would ever even dare to doubt that they had served as Y. W. cabinet members for months past. Already a Rummage sale is on foot, and at the present time quite a number of articles, various in size, shape and fashion have been collected for this purpose. We are ever ready to receive any donation; nothing ever arrives too late, as it is an easy task to store any article away until the next opportunity for sale. Seems as though the boys might be inÂ­terested in donating some of their perfectly good cast aside apparel. Think this over boys, al1d let us hear from you. Miss Lumpkin, active in Y. W. work, has been with us for a few days and through her efforts any number of girls ha. ve become interested in the Blue Ridge Conference. If posÂ­sible we want a delegation of at least ten for the Y W. C. A. Blue Ridge Conference in June. In our vast student body it seems that we have talent of every imaginable description. The latest proof of this ! act is a play of which Philip Mankin is the author. Friday mght THE NORMALITE J ohnny Jones and his sister Sue Studied Psychology- I did too. But Johnny and Susie got out light They ate a peach and died one night! Children up in the proper way. That's what I lived and did- but say! When my paper came back to me The grade I got- O hully gee. I had no peach, I did not die, I merely lived to answer why Knowledge of instincts was the thing To use in a schoolroom, and to bring Johnny Jones anc.; his sister Sue Studied Psychology- I did too; Now they're in heaven, cool and free, And I am continuing Psychology. Mr. Lyon ( in chapel)-" It m" ight be an interesting expet=" Â­iment for all the students, especially the boys, to quit smokÂ­ing for a month." dleston, a jeweler of Murfreesboro. The wedding has been set for May twenty- fourth. Mrs. W. W. Harmon, ' 23, one of our three year graduÂ­ates is working on her degree at Peabody this year. Mattie Ida Hoover, ' 15, is now Mrs. Johnny O'Brien, and lives at Christiana, Tenn. Charlotte Forgey, ' 20, is teaching in Columbia. Lennie]. Sanders, ' 20, is teaching in Richland City, Tenn. Martha Moon, ' 20, is teaching at Christiana this year. Nell D. Watkins, ' 20, is in Davidson county, teaching. Elmer Dounum, ' 16, is now a resident of Kentucky. He has made quite a financial success in the oil business. 46 The prospects for base ball at M. T. N. are exceedingly bright this spring. Coach Miles has quite a number of felÂ­lows out, and he hopes within a few days to turn out a smooth. working team. We Â· are very fortunate this time in having a number of r(> liable pitchers. In Duck and Phillips we have two veterans.. Last year they both pitched fine ball and they should win some games this season. Gray and Kennedy look very good and all the indications are that they are due to win. In BratÂ­ten, the Nashville boy, Coach thinks he has a real pitcher who can deliver the goods. There are many contenders for positions in the infield. Delay seems able to take care of the catching, with Moffitt an able assistant. Phillips IS playing a fine game at first. Joe Davis has been shifted from second base to short stop. He plays that position with the same old pep that he displayed last season at second. At third we have a good man in Frank Bryant, though at present he is out with a broken ankle. Parks seems to be the man for the keystone position. He is also out at present. Other likely contenders for positions on E. P. Eaves, Editor. THE NORMALITE Advantages of Studying Poultry Here's a concrete illustration of the advantages of studyÂ­ing poultry: Angle who owns no poultry gets two eggs each day and has one hen sitting. Can you beat it? " What do you call it when a man has a number of wives?" " Polygamy." " Oh, yes! And what is it when he has only one wife?" " Aw, that's monotony." Prof. Davis insists that plain and plane spell ' plane, or plain whether or not it is plain or plane. Mr: Mankin staged his lat~ production with an all star cast, consisting of M~ ssrs. Cyrus Dement, Paul Burton, Carl BranÂ­dun, Ernest Setc1iff and the. author himself; Miss Katie By-yom was the heroine. Of all the entertainments or features of the year, the crowning one is yet in store. At some time in the near fuÂ­ture we have succeeded in securing the promised services of our faculty who will render a program very similar to our annual stunt. night. Just for example: Mr. Davis will very ~ fficiently play the part of the city dude. With his' high topÂ­ped hat, long tailed ~ oat, and walking cane he will announce the various features of the evening. For a more detailed acÂ­count of the performance, you will have to be present to enÂ­joy it all. Both this entertainment and the one last Friday night have been given over to the Y. W. C. A. THE NORMALITE Correct this sentence: Prof. Woodward took me to town in his Monroe. Mr. Lyon says human nature is the same the world over, but it is more so in chapel. Shippey says the difference between land and the ocean is the degree of moisture. It took coach exactly three minutes to find that twentyÂ­five thousand is one tenth of two hundred and fifty thousand. the infield are Osteen and Price. They are both showing up well. In the outfield Harvill is the o~ ly regular of last year. The " old man" is still able to hit the ball. Cy Miller is playing a great game in center field. Charlie Joe Woodson is making Coach take notice and , is trying to show him that a little felÂ­low can play ball. Other outfielders are Duck, Miles, Smith, and Brumbaugh. Nonn~~ Vand~ bilt3 The first game of the season was played with Vanderbilt Freshmen on the local field. After a hard fought game the Blue and White conquered the Vandy boys in the tenth inning. I Final score was Norma' 1 4- Vandy 3. At the beginnig of the ninth inning the score was 3- 1 with our boys holding the litÂ­tle end. It was in this inning that the boys did some work. After Moffitt had walked, Delay hit a home run scoring MofÂ­itt ahead of himself. The score being tied, we were able to win in the tenth by way of Phillip's three bagger. Gray and Kennedy pitched fine ball. Gray struck out twelve batters ic seven innings while Kennedy whipped three in three innings. Kennedy allowed only two hits for the time he worked. M. T. N. 3- Bryson 3 On April 20, our boys journeyed to Fayetteville to battle the Bryson College nine. - The ga'm; e resulted in a 3- 3 tie afÂ­ter- twelve innings of hard fighting. Bratten showed what he could do by holding the Bryson boys to six scattered hits for the twelve innings. Harvill hit a home run, and you can judge for yourself how far the baH must have gone for the " o'ld man" to make a home run. We have a fine schedule which includes several games ~ t home as well as on the road. The boys make their usual KenÂ­tucky trip, playing S. P. U., Bethel College and Kentucky Normal on the trip. The preps have - games scheduled, but as yet they have not gone forth into battle. THE NORMALITE 51 Mary Hill King, Editor. As ~ his , is our last issue of the NORMALITE, we desire to thank each of our exchanges and to compliment them onÂ­their good work of the year. We have received exchange publications from thirty different schools, which have been 1Â­pleasure and an insp. iration to us. We hope to have each of these publications on our exchange list next year. One of the best spurs, to real honest- to- goodness hard work and conÂ­sequent success, in any line is constructive criticism and comÂ­mendation. We have received both from our exchange list and just to show our appreciation for what others have said about us, we are pleased to print the following comments: The Columns- Congratulations to Middle Tennessee NorÂ­mal on the NORMALITE- it's dandy. The _ Echo- NORMALITE- One of the best exchanges we have received. Peabody Volunteer- The NORMALITE is certainly origÂ­inal and entertaining. Every organization and department of your school is represented, which makes it an interesting paÂ­per to all. The Hillbilly- The NORMALITE is one of the b. est rnJagÂ­azines we have - received. Your literary department is good and your jokes are very interesting. The cuts and cover de' Â­signs are fine. so THE NOR' [ ALITE WANTED- Another girl. See Roy Jakes. A reward has been offered to the man who catches Huffman not singing. THE NORMALITE 53 MURFREESBORO, TENNESSEE AT BUTLER, HOOPER & McCORD, Inc. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Miss Mary Hall interview: East Main Street entrance
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hall, Mary
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Bullen, Bob, interviewer; Nunley, Joe, commentator
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mary Hall discusses how Middle Tennessee got an entrance at East Main Street. President Cope had meetings with teachers and asked what he could do to help them. One physical education teacher requested a front entrance, and President Cope went out soon after with the Highway Department to make it happen.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dedication of the Murfree, Forrest and Todd buildings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Printed invitation to attend a dedication ceremony in the Alumni Memorial Gym on March 25, 1958 for three campus buildings. Accompanied by audio clips of remarks about the history and significance of each building made during the dedication ceremony.

Audio clips: 1. Dedication of the Bettie Avent Murfree Language Arts Building -- 2. Dedication of the Nathan Bedford Forest R.O.T.C. Building -- 3. Dedication of the Andrew L. Todd Library Building -- 4. Tribute to Andrew L. Todd.

The Tennessee State Board of Education and faculty of Middle Tennessee State College cordially invite you to attend the dedication of The Language Arts Building to be named in honor of Bettie Avent Murfree, The Reserve Officers' Training Corps building to be named in honor of Nathan Bedford Forrest, The Library Building to be named in honor of Andrew L. Todd. Tuesday, March the Twenty-Fifth at ten-thirty o'clock in the morning, Nineteen Hundred and Fifty-eight, Alumni Memorial Gym, Murfreesboro TN

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Buchanan Players, 1956
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Buchanan Players theater group; from the Midlander yearbook, 1956

The Buchanan Players was a campus organization that provided a workshop environment for students in the theater arts. They performed new plays and also produced and directed their own plays to obtain parts not available in main stage productions. The purpose of the club was to train students in dramatic production and to prepare members for the national dramatic fraternity, Alpha Psi Omega.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Administration building, 1955
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Administration building and the words of the Alma Mater, from the Midlander yearbook, 1955

Built in 1910 and for years called the Administration Building, Kirksey Old Main was the first building on campus. Initially the building housed the administrative offices, classrooms, auditorium, gymnasium, bookstore, and the post office. Old Main underwent major renovations in 1961, 1964 and 1965. In 1978 Old Main was renamed in honor of Howard G. Kirksey, an administrator who had served in many roles over the years with the institution.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Vet Village : the "Little MTSC City"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Vet Village, housing for families of veterans and married students; image from the Midlander yearbook, 1955

Vet Village was organized immediately after World War II to accommodate veterans and their families who were attending school. Attempting to meet housing needs, in 1946 Congress gave $78 million to move buildings from military bases to college campuses. Middle Tennessee State College also received federal funds to erect small apartments for married veterans and their families. Later, not only veterans but anyone could live in the apartments and trailers that made up Vet Village as long as at least one member of the family attended the college. Vet Village was practically a city within the campus; it had a laundry house, grocery store, and even a mayor.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Civil Air Patrol maneuvers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Civil Air Patrol maneuvers, from the 1952 Midlander yearbook

The Middle Tennessee State College Squadron of the Civil Air Patrol was organized in July, 1948, under the supervision of Major Elmour Meriwether, Commanding Officer, and Capt. Miller Lanier, Executive Officer. Approximately seventy-five percent of the members of the Squadron were pilots trained at the College Airport. The organization received state-wide recognition for training maneuvers they carried out, especially in search and rescue missions and patrolling and locating forest fires. A well-equipped ground school provided opportunity for instruction in other areas of the CAP work, such as communications, first aid, cadet training, and supply.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States--Civil Air Patrol; Airplanes; Middle Tennessee State College

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Children playing at Vet Village
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Children playing at Vet Village from the 1952 Midlander yearbook

Vet Village was organized immediately after World War II to accommodate veterans and their families who were attending school. Attempting to meet housing needs, in 1946 Congress gave $78 million to move buildings from military bases to college campuses. Middle Tennessee State College also received federal funds to erect small apartments for married veterans and their families. Later, not only veterans but anyone could live in the apartments and trailers that made up Vet Village as long as at least one member of the family attended the college. Vet Village was practically a city within the campus; it had a laundry house, grocery store, and even a mayor.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Veterans--Housing; Children; Middle Tennessee State College;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Training school staff, 1952
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Training school staff, from the 1952 Midlander yearbook

The School has had many names--Demonstration School, Training School, and Campus School. In 1985, the name officially became Homer Pittard Campus School in honor of Homer Pittard, a Rutherford County educator who had served as principal at McFadden School and Central High School and as Director of University Affairs at MTSU. The original purpose of the Campus School was to serve as a teaching laboratory for aspiring teachers. Prospective teachers meet children in real situations in an effort to give the children and the college students the best and latest in content and procedure. Campus School endeavors to make its classrooms, its various activities, and its daily routine as real-world as possible.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Library, 1952
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The library from the 1952 Midlander yearbook

The first library at the institution was housed in the Administration Building. Bettie Avent Murfree was employed as the first librarian in 1912. The first library building opened in the fall of 1926, and in 1957 the building was named for Bettie Avent Murfree to show appreciation for her significant contributions to the institution. The Andrew L. Todd Memorial Library, named in honor of a local businessman who was instrumental in the founding of the institution, was dedicated in 1958. The current library, the James E. Walker Library opened in 1999.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Administration building, 1952
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Administration building, from the 1952 Midlander yearbook

Built in 1910 and for years called the Administration Building, Kirksey Old Main was the first building on campus. Initially the building housed the administrative offices, classrooms, auditorium, gymnasium, bookstore, and the post office. Old Main underwent major renovations in 1961, 1964 and 1965. In 1978 Old Main was renamed in honor of Howard G. Kirksey, an administrator who had served in many roles over the years with the institution.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Buchanan Dramatic Club is Cultural Influence on Campus"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Jones, Frank
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Frank Jones, a twenty-five year veteran at the State Teacher's College, wrote this short history of the beginnings of the Buchanan Dramatic Club in 1936. He discusses the nature of the club's first plays and follows the club's evolution over the years of Rebecca Buchanan's tenure.

BUCHANAN DRAMATIC CLUB IS CULTURAL INFLUENCE ON CAMPUS - It was during the year 1925 - 1926 that the Dramatic Club of the State Teachers College was first organized with Miss Rebecca J. Buchanan of the Department of Speech as director. Prior to that, dramatic work, under Miss Buchanan's guidance, had been done in the literary societies, but with the passing of the societies the need was felt for an organization devoted entirely to dramatics. Among the presidents who have served the club are Marion Capps, Elizabeth Stevenson, Katherine Brown, Esther Talley, John Oliver, Ed Bell, Roy Dowdy, Katherine Chambers, Edwin Tarpley, Cecil Webb, and Owen Griffin.The first play produced by the Club was Booth Tarkington's "Seventeen". Among the outstanding productions of the Club, under Miss Buchanan's direction were Oscar Wilde's " Lady Winder-mere's Fan" in which Perry Williamson and Katherine Brown played with notable success. A memorable event in the history of the Club was the staging of R. C. Sheriff's " Journey's End"@( with Ed Bell as Stanhope, Roy Dowdy as Osborne, and Albert Gore in the role of Raleigh. The difficult stage setting was handled with signal success. Another colorful and pleasing production that lingers in the memory of S. T. C. plagoers was " Milestones" by Knoblett and Arnold Bennett in which the work of Katherine Chambers, Florence Betz, and Roy Dowdy was most gratifying. In a lighter vein, but most pleasing, was " The Patsy" featuring Dorothy Gwinn, Katherine Chambers, and John Oliver. In 1932 Miss Buchanan because of illness was obliged to resign the directorship of the Club, and for more than a year the organization continued without any definite leadership, putting on a series of one- act plays. The Club suffered a decline during this period but in 1934 under the leadership of Cecil Webb, Edwin Tarpley, Jane Mankin and others, it was revived and with Mrs. Marion Edney ( the former Miss Dorothy Bachtel of the Science Department), the Club took on new life and began an ambitious series of plays which it has continued since. " Little Women" in which Martha Moore Gracey starred as JO, was a signal success; the spectacular " Hunch Back of Notre Dame" with Cecil Webb in the title role was a feat in staging. Following Mrs. Sadney'J resignation as sponsor of the Club, Mrs. Marshall Burns was chosen sponsor, With " Candida" in 1935 and " Ghosts" in 1936 the Club ventured into the realm of serious drama. Both of these plays were ably directed by Miss Esther Licker who brought to her work a wide knowledge of play production. The effective stage settings by J. B. Peyton, the art director of the Club, have been a notable feature of the productions of the past two years. Time fails to tell of the many who have made the work of the Dramatic Club a success. Its achievements have been due no less to the work of those who have played the leading roles than to those who have sustained the high level of the Club's presentations in the minor roles, to those who have borne the brunt of the technical side of production, and to the rank and file members whose interest and loyal support have kept 2 Â· ' 3 the Club a live and growing organization. It was in 1934 that it was decided to name the Club for its beloved founder and director for many years, Miss Rebecca J. Buchanan. Miss Buchanan, who had been a member of the faculty from 1913 to 1932 as teacher of speech and a member of the Fnglish department, received her training at the famous Boston - Sc h0 0 1 0 f Expre s s ~ n~ n de r 0r. S. S. Cur r y . Prio r t 0 com i ng t 0 S. T. C. she was a member of the faculty at Belmont College. Though no longer active in directing the work of the organization, she continues to inspire and influcence its endeavors and the Buchanan Dramatic Club in the sincere and effective work which it has done has sought to live up to the high standards which she set for it. By FRANK JONES S. T. C. - 25 YEARS OF SERVICE Friday, June 5, 1936

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: MTSU Buchanan Players present "Aâ€¦ My Name Is Alice"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A program for the MTSU production of "Aâ€¦ My Name Is Alice," a musical revue conceived by Joan Silver and Julianne Boyd. The show depicts scenes from women's lives through monologues and songs

The Buchanan Players was a campus organization that provided a workshop environment for students in the theater arts. They performed new plays and also produced and directed their own plays to obtain parts not available in main stage productions. The purpose of the club was to train students in dramatic production and to prepare members for the national dramatic fraternity, Alpha Psi Omega.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Administration Building, Middle Tennessee State Normal Back
Administration Building, Middle Tennessee State Normal
Administration building, Middle Tennessee State Normal
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postcard from Ella to her sister. The front of the postcard shows the Administration Building at Middle Tennessee State Normal School.

Built in 1910 and for years called the Administration Building, Kirksey Old Main was the first building on campus. Initially the building housed the administrative offices, classrooms, auditorium, gymnasium, bookstore, and the post office. Old Main underwent major renovations in 1961, 1964 and 1965. In 1978 Old Main was renamed in honor of Howard G. Kirksey, an administrator who had served in many roles over the years with the institution.

Dormitory, Middle Tennessee State Normal
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postcard from Agnes Gilbert to Bro. Albert at 1414 DeSoto Ave., St. Louis, Missouri.

Dear Bro. Albert: I guess you think I've forgotten you, but I haven't and I think of you every day. How are you getting along? I hope you are well. This is a pretty little town - 5 schools here for young ladies. It has been pretty cold since we came here and I haven't got to go around much. With love, Agnes.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Reminiscences of MTSU Library, 1935-40
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Freeman, Isa Lee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Typescript of a brief memoir written by Isa Lee (Sherrod) Freeman to describe her five years as a librarian at Middle Tennessee State Teacher's College between 1935 and 1940. It describes her relationship with Bettie Avent Murfree, who organized the first library after the founding of the Middle Tennessee Normal School, and her relationship with other faculty on campus

REMINISCENCES OF MTSU LIBRARY 1935-1940
In a central location of the State Teachers College campus stood the library. Easily accessible to all other buildings, it was considered by many of the faculty and administration to occupy a central place of importance in the academic life of the college â€¢
In January 1935 when I came as an associate librarian, it was a rather new building. The library, formerly located on the second floor of the Main ( Administration) Building, wben I arrived, stood at the site of the present Peck Hall building. P.A. Lyon was college president, and Mrs. Bettie Avent Murfree was librarian. She had organized the library in the early days of the Normal School, and most of the time she served alone, except for student assistants. She was about five feet tall and took quick short steps as she hurried, almost raced, about the two- storied building from 8: 00 until 3: 00 daily except Sunday. Mrs. Murfree was a delightful person, with an optimistic attitude, a vibrant personality, and an eagerness to help all who needed it. After the library hours were finished, she worked in an antique shop of which she was part owner. Both of us handled all phases of library activities. Usually Mrs. Murfree took care of the mail, the periodicals, order work, and supervised the circulation. I was responsible for cataloging and classification, for reference work, for teaching "How to use the library" to freshmen English classes, supervising the student assistants, and for about four years I taught library science classes. Dean J. C. Beasley gave me permission to plan a curriculum for training teacher-librarians who would be qualified to serve as part- time librarians in elementary and small high school libraries. My classes consisted of six courses, were open to sophomores, juniors and seniors, and included enough credit for a minor in library - p. 2'- science. Two courses were offered per quarter. From these classes, the second year students and I organized libraries in a few Rutherford County schools which did not have libraries. Among those where we worked as volunteers were Training School ( now MTSU Campus School), McFadden two times ( the school burned, and we returned to the new building), Walter Hill, and Kittrell. The work was rather crudely done; there was almost no money for necessary materials. But the books were classified by Dewey Decimal system, cataloged and processed, and arranged attractively on the shelves. Library Science students put into practice what they had learned in class, the schools were shown that the college was interested in them, and library service was emphasized.
At the college Mrs. Murfree was chairman of a Library Committee composed of the head of each department plus the two librarians. About three times a year the committee met to make book selections. Any teacher or student could make book requests, and order cards were made for each request. Professional library magazines were studied for possible orders, and each department head made a list of books needed by his department. Then at the committee meeting the book budget was divided into percentages for each department, plus a percentage for general use. The final order was prepared, submitted to book jobbers for bids, and the books were ordered. The library consisted mainly of books, a fairly good magazine collection, a depository of all goverbment documents, a rather good vertical file collection, a few recordings, but no other audiovisual materials. These were the 1930' s: money was still scarce, salaries were small, students were paid about 35Â¢ perhour, and the Depression still prevailed in state schools. - p Â· 3 - But they were fun- years! The faculty and student body were small. We all knew each other. Social life was warm and friendly. All the faculty members were expected to attend chapel twice a week, and at intervals we were asked to be responsible for speakers or other programs. We were expected to attend athletic events, all receptions given at the President's home, all faculty meetings, all lyceum numbers presented in the college auditorium, all school dances. We all marched in the lines for graduation exercises. The library was not open at night or on Sunday. During part of school vacation periods we took inventory, went through the dormitories searching for lost or stolen books, and in general, prepared for the next school term. At least half of the student assistants were athletes. The only scholarships provided were for work, and since the library needed twenty to thirty helpers, most of them were football players. Of course the boys were not particularly happy about working in the library, but there wasn't much choice. A few of them made excellent workers, but some were. just killing time until the bell rang. On one occasion I remember Mrs. Murfree's asking me to reprimand a student who came to work with his shirttail out. lilt didn't look nice", she said, and also it embarrassed her to have to mention anything that personal. So I had to. The boy was probably 20 or 21, and I was 22 at that time! The library had closed stacks. I'm not sure why, but that's the way it was when I arrived. I guess students weren't to be trusted, so the circulation desk workers had to locate and bring all requests to the desk where they were checked out. Faculty members, however, had stack privileges. It was quite private in the stacks, and on several occasions - p.4 - Mrs. Murfree and I found Mabel Baxter and Homer Pittard, both student library assistants, doing their "courting" in a remote corner. Others enjoyed the privacy also, but these two became Mr. and Mrs. a little later. Mrs. Murfree always opened the Iibrary in the mornings, and I locked up at 5: 00 ot 5: 30. On gloomy winter afternoons, electric lights were needed everywhere. That much use of power at the same time, frequently blew a fuse. By that hour of the day it would be â€¢ impossible to locate a campus electrician ( we had no telephone), so something had to be done in a hurry. I had heard that a dead fuse would work if a copper penny was placed behind it. It did work; the lights came on, and the building didn't catch on fire. I don't know why! Just lucky, I guess. Housed in the basement of the library were bound periodicals, government documents, a collection of state adopted textbooks, and a small apartment in which a married football player lived. As far as I can remember, he was one of the very few married students enrolled in the college, and all other married students were much older than he was. The basement was damp, and practically all books were mildewed. At one time I taught library science classes in the basement, but later we moved upstairs. Things were never dull in the library. We worked hard and had long hours, and when extra work was needed, we worked overtime without feeling imposed upon. The work was rewarding, and fellowship with other faculty members and with the townspeople brought joy and a feeling that we were part of a big family. I never felt that any library job was unimportant, but I did dread teaching and supervising the book repair. Not much of the budget could be spent on binding, so it was necessary to carryon
- p. 5 -
a continuous mending program. I really loathed that tedious job, but it had to be done, and I did it. There were some outstanding girls who worked as library assistants, and we became close friends. I enjoyed them, amd they liked library work so much that they went on to Library School to become professional librarians. Perhaps one third of these women student assistants continued in the library field. Q. E. Smith was president of the college during my last three years. He was exacting and sometimes demanding; no special privileges were available for anyone; but he knew all faculty members personally; he knew what contributions each made; he commended work which he considered well done; he considered the library important in the total campus program; and the two librarians enjoyed full faculty status. President Smith was an excellent administrator. Of course faculty and student enrollments are much greater now, and the former friendliness and fellowship are no longer possible. Much progress has been made and should have been been made, and the University influence and outreach is much greater than it . used to be. But with progress a few sacrifices have to be made. I am glad that I was a part of MTSU at the time I was. They were happy years, we were made to feel important, and we were appreciated. I don't recall any professional jealousy in the entire college. We were free to do our jpbs as we wished; we were encouraged to use initiative; we could attend any professional meetings that we desired, of course paying our own expenses. If an employee did not measure up to what was expected by the administration, he was warned and advised, and if that didn't work, he was fired. Because Mrs. Murfree was interested in art, the library had many beautiful paintings and sculpture pieces. Perhaps they were hers personally, since I'm sure the book budget couldn't be spent for "frills".
- p. 6 -
But the library was always lovely and had a "homey" look. I am glad. that I had the privilege of working with "Miss Bettie". My decision to resign in July 1940 was a very difficult one for me to make. I had married three years earlier and felt that homemaking should now be my career, but it took a long time to give up the job that meant so much to me. Someone has said, " Nothing is work if you really enjoy doing it", so I can truly claim that my five and a half years as librarian at Middle Tennessee State College was happy interlude. Isa Lee ( Sherrod) Freeman (Mrs. Lawrence Freeman)
RECEIVED APR 1 1976 M. T. S U LIBRARY

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Murfree Building : snow scene
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of a snow covered Murfree Building, with Jones Hall to the right

The Murfree Building stood on the present-day site of Peck Hall. This was the first building constructed on campus to serve as a library, replacing room 69 of Kirksey Old Main. The building opened in the 1926-27 academic year but was not dedicated as the Bettie Avent Murfree Building until 1958, after the death of Mrs. Murfree. At the same ceremony its larger and more modern successor was dedicated as the Todd Library Building. Bettie Avent Murfree managed the library from the school's opening in 1911 until her retirement in 1945. The Murfree Building stood until construction of Peck Hall began in the mid-1960s.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Library automation: the early days
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Library employees Wilma Marable (left) and Mary Pugh (right) work on two of the first computer workstations used by the library to automate cataloging tasks. The workstations were located in the cataloging department of the Todd Library

The first library at the institution was housed in the Administration Building. Bettie Avent Murfree was employed as the first librarian in 1912. The first library building opened in the fall of 1926, and in 1957 the building was named for Bettie Avent Murfree to show appreciation for her significant contributions to the institution. The Andrew L. Todd Memorial Library, named in honor of a local businessman who was instrumental in the founding of the institution, was dedicated in 1958. The current library, the James E. Walker Library opened in 1999.
Wilma Marable, Mary Pugh

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Card catalog : finding books the old way
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two students consult the old card catalog in the Todd Library.
Maintenance of the card catalog was discontinued when the library implemented an online catalog in the 1980s, and the card catalog was discarded when the Library moved to its new building in 1999.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Faculty and administration photographic directory, Fall 1986
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Middle Tennessee State University, Photographic Services; Middle Tennessee State University, Publications and Graphics
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A directory of university faculty and administrator portraits for the fall semester of the 1986-87 school year. Diamond/ 75th anniversary issue

Middle Tennessee State University Faculty and Administration Middle Tennessee State Normal School Faculty and Students 1911 PHOTOGRAPHIC DIRECTORY FALL 1986 ~ Diamond Anniversary + 1911- 1986 As part of the celebration of our 75th anniversary, this directory of faculty members and administrative personnel is provided by Photographic Services and Publications and Graphics with funds from the Office of Vice President for Academic Affairs and with the support and encouragement of the 1985- 86 Faculty Senate. Extensive efforts were made to obtain up- to- date photographs and to be accurate in the listings. Much appreciation goes to faculty members and administrators who graciously responded and cooperated. The personnel included reflect the best information available in late summer; however, changes occurring after that time will not be reflected. Plans are to produce an addendum of the new faculty members and administrative staff each fall. The inclusion of telephone and box numbers was requested by 1985- 86 Faculty Senate President Earl Hinton as a convenience for users. Publications and Graphics regrets any changes or inaccuracies which may have occurred in that information. Photographs are by Jack Ross and Mark Hay of Photographic Services. Compilation of information was coordinated by Diane Stewart; type and page design and layout were done by Mitzi Brandon; cover design was by Judy Hall, all of Publications and Graphics under the direction of Suma Clark. The directory was printed at the Print Shop, Tony Snook, director. MTSU is an equal opportunity, non- racially identifiable, educational institution which does not discriminate against the handicapped. Sam H. Ingram University President Cart; ext. 2622 Mitchell D. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Directory of administrators and faculty at the University in the fall semester of the 1980-81 school year

Middle Tennessee State University This directory of faculty members and administrative personnel is provided by University Publications. a part of the Office of Public Relations. Photographs are by University Photographer Jack Ross and Pat Casey Daley. Layout and design work was done by student Bill Ray under the direction of Suma Clark, Publications Coordinator. Special thanks for their help and cooperation go to Bob Arnette. Director of Personnel, and toJim Booth, Director of University Print Shop. Extensive efforts were made to obtain up- to- date photographs and to be accurate in the listings. Much appreciation goes to those who aided and cooperated. Some changes in personnel which occurred during the last stages of production may not be reflected in the

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Group V Aerial View of Campus Oficers of Administration Department Heads Officers of Special Services Second College Song Tangerine Bowl Team viii Following Page 24 Introduction The old man and the boy each jerked one last ear from the stalks, pitched them on the high mound in the wagon bed, a:nd\ climbed to the seat. The horses, stinging from the sharp bite of the end of the lines, strained forward and the wagon began its slow descent from the high swell of the field. It was time to go to the barn, Dusk was settling and there was the smell of a storm in the air. In the west the sky vibrated sporadically with dazzling white flashes. Theô€˜ô… ®.,bobbing ears of the team and cupola of the courthouse, two miles m:!?ay, appeared in rapid silhouettes. Then came a roar of angry sound as if a thousand cannon were shelling the woods beyond Murfreesboro .... But storms pass n,nd are forgotten, except perhaps by the mô€™ô…¥´teorologist. Storms, unfortunately for the wayfarer, are no 1'eÂ­specters of ,time. They may appear in a 1'ush creating havoc for those in their paths. They may grow almost methodically, slowly but inevitable, rising ultimately to a wild crescendo of SWirling fury. ix

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 11
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Since the time of the old man and boy other storms have swept this landô€…¢ô†ˆ perhaps not altogether of the nativity of Nature, but of man's emotions. These too have sampled both the preÂ­cipitate and the calculated. But it is certain that the old man and boy had experienced great spans of tranquility and rewarding moments on the land east of the city. There was the time of the plowshare and the probing of the soil. Then there came the churning and the sifting for the seedbed, followed by planting time. The gentle pull of the sun and draughts from the heavens created the green land and great expectations for the future. The climatic moment came when the empty wagon moved lightly and quickly through the gate into the field of full harvest. In retrospect, an examination of nature's log descriptive of this evolutio'nary period will reveal entries fraught with atmospheric inequities, storms, and the voice of Thor. Of greater importance are those entries that record the great periods of serenityô€ƒ„ôŒ the warmth of the sunô€ƒ„ôŒ and the progress of the great sea of growing plants. On this land of the old man and the boy was planted a college. It grew in the sun and leaned sô€…£ô†Œº:ongly and resolutely against the storms that came its way. There were moments when Â«the barn" appeared as the only haven but the sun came again. Then there was always the harvest. On August 19, 1961, Middle Tennessee State College comÂ­pleted its first fifty years of service. Created along with three other normals by the General Education Bill of 1909, it opened its doors for business on Monday morning, September 11, 1911, as Middle Tennessee State Normal School. Organized as a fourÂ­year high school and a two-year college, the fanfare attending its emergence was extremely modest. Beyond the Normal campus there was little rejoicing for this rather ungainly new partner at the educational trough. On the contrary, the dire misgivings and forebodings of disaster emanating from many public school leaders in Tennessee were refrains more easily recognized. But x there came a period of toleration followed by acceptance. AcÂ­ceptance led to the expected role of educational leadership. SubÂ­sequent events indicate that Middle Tennessee State College did not default in the many obligations imposed on it by the area that it serves. Fifty years bring maturity to an institution. It is obvious that many of the events occuring during this time have elements lending themselves to institutional immortality. These may be alÂ­luded to as traditions . The recognition of these, the expressions of appreciation to those of certain bases for future growth and service are focal points for commemoration. In order that these first fifty years might be properly recogÂ­nized, President Quill Cope during the fall of 1960, appointed a committee of eleven State College personnel to formulate comÂ­memorative plans for the year of 1961-62. This group composed of Dean N. C. Beasley, Dr. Clarence Greever, Ann Farris, Dean Belt Keathley, Dr. Francis Riel, Eugene Sloan, Neil Wright, Margaret Wright, Joe Smith, and Homer Pittard was superbly led in its deliberations by Lane Boutwell. This group met severÂ­al times during the latter weeks of 1960 and the early part of 1961. On February 13, a formal report was made to the PresiÂ­dent. At this time, the key events for the year were selected and certain other activities were planned to augment and publicize the larger programs. These programs'jncluded the following : 1. A Homecoming Alumni. Luncheon was scheduled for October 21, 1961, as a preliminary activity to the Hoô€„žô¹¥eÂ­coming game with the University of Chattanooga. Past Presidents of the State College Alumni Assocô€Œ‡ô€¡ation, past student body presidents, and presidents of local alumni clubs were invited as honor guests. 2. A Semi-Centennial Convocationô€…¡ô†„ with Dr. Charles A. Bucher, Professor of Education, New York University, as speaker was planned for the morning of N ovem ber 14, xi

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1961. State College faculty and administration in addition to a large number of special guests and the College musiÂ­cal organization comprised the list of active participants. This formal occasion was designed in part to depict the colorful pageantry of the first fifty years. 3. A Mid-State Appreciation Day, scheduled for March 15, 1962, had as its objective the recognition of friends and supporters of the College in the Middle Tennessee area. Activities included open-house for all key buildings on the campus, a banquet in the Tennessee Room at the StuÂ­dent Union Building, and a special public program durÂ­ing the evening. The services of the San Francisco Ballet, one of America's best-known and talented organizations in the entertainment field, was retained for the proÂ­gram. 4. An Alumni-Faculty-Senior Banquet was placed at the traditional date, May 18, 1962, on the calendar of comÂ­memorative events. Special emphasis was placed on enÂ­cOUl'aging members of "first" classes ô€‰£ô†Œ®.o return in addition to the vast number of alumni whose convocations came during the intervening years. Programmed for the ocÂ­casion was the recognition of retired and retiring faculty members, the first faculty members ( 1911-12), three o.utÂ­standing Alumni and other personnel associated with the instructional and administrative progress of the instituÂ­tion. Additional activities planned for the 1961-62 college year inÂ­cluded the publication of special editions of the Sidelines ( stuô€Œˆô€ dent newspaper), The l11.id-Stater ( Alumni bulletin), and MidÂ­lander ( college yearbook); the designing and production of a colÂ­lege banner or flag; the production of a color sound film descripÂ­tive of campus activities and physical facilities; the composition of a new Alma Mater to replace "M. T. S. C., All Hair'; the ô€ƒ˜ô¡³stabÂ­lishment of a museum and archives; and a great number of sus-xii taining features such as speCial Golden Anniversary decals, broÂ­chures, stationery"and postal cancellation stamps. The compiling of this volume, ambitiously entitled The First Fifty Years, was also an activity planned for the Golden AnniÂ­versary years. It is supposed that the material in the pages ahead suffers from omissions as well as certain overemphasis of relaÂ­tively unimportant events. Since he is obviously the only one to do so, the writer assumes full responsibility for the choices found in the text and refuses to stand on the amateur historian's fifth amendment which begins : "Space does not permit . . . . ." The writer, as a boy, first saw Middle Tennessee State Normal School on N oevrnber 11, 1918. He was traveling in a buggy along the Hall's Hill Pike on his way to the Armistice celebration. At the time he had no idea that a professor by the name of Dr. Fertig and a Gargantuan president roamed the hallways of the building lying beyond the fields. Also, he was unaware that a kindly army officer militarily known as Lieutenant Greenley ( and privately by more picturesque sobriquets) was drilling a comÂ­pany on the green sward to the south. The fact is the compiler was not even acquainted with the name of the place, and "N orÂ­mal" had no more significance than "Kerr's Store" at Hall's Hill. But he vividly remembers the "rooster" ventilators atop the AdÂ­ministration Building. In 1931 he was introduced to the other side of the building'whose rear he had viewed during the more callow years. As an enrollee he was often guilty of failing "to see the school for the books". but gratefully received the end blessing of toleration four years later. In 1956, probably during one of the mellow periods of tIle administration, he returned aô€Œ‰ô€¤ a teacher. The recitation of the foregOing saga must not be interpreted as an attempt, lame or otherwise, by the writer to surreptitiously insert something of himself. Rather of more importance and of more truth, is the indication that nine years of intimate associÂ­ation with the institution and many additional years of interested xiii

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 13
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: sideline observation have revealed much of the character and soul of Middle Tennessee State College. The evaluation at the close of the first fifty years, allowing some small subtraction for bias, is eulogic in nature. Somewhere between the fledgling twoÂ­year normal of 1911 and the 1961 four-year state college with a graduate program the answers can be found in profusion. The pages ahead record some of these. Undoubtedly one of the predÂ­icates upon which has been erected this claim to greatness as an institution has been the quality of faculty personnel. If this volume were imposing enough and did full credit to Middle Tennessee State College, a readily acceptable dedicatory object could be found in the golden scroll immortalizing the master teachers. There would be several among the eilgible such as, Miss Ann Ordway, English teacher from 1920-46. Her culture, warmth, and her great love for those whom she served so unselfishly, fully epitomize the spirit of the institution. The writer does not cite her case simply because she rescued him from embarrassÂ­ment during a bungling, stammering class report on ( of all perÂ­sons) George Santayana; or because she thoughtfully brought him a smile and a basket of fruit once when' he was immobilized by an athletic injury. Moreover, the allusion to Miss Ordway is made because her years on the campus were filled with similar atÂ­tempts to edify the ordinary and to inspire excellence of achiô€ŒŠô€©¶veÂ­ment in so many who had been content too long with the c t v This is not a dedication but a reminder to those seven thousand graduates scattered over the land that each, whether or not he is cognizant of it, has been uniquely touched and inÂ­fluenced by one or more campus personalities. The passage of years and the weight of events will never obscure the entwining of emotions incepted by four years of attendance. The First Fifty Years endeavors to record in sequence many of the events of the first half century ( 1911-1961). Pictures and a few human interest stories gallantly attempt to relieve the strain on the reader. As a matter of fact, the rash of multi40ld xiv unusual campus tales involving students and faculty would have made a very respectable volume of themselves. For example, the moving narratives' commonly referred to as the "chicken tales" and related with much clarity and devotion to detail by O. L. Freeman ('28) and Bob Abernathy (,29), would have consumed much of the space. Another story of classic proportions is reÂ­counted with almost identical attenti<?n to detail by these same two minstrels of the colorful past. It concerns a prominent TenÂ­nessee educator during his student days at the Normal and his prankish, imaginative welcome to the new coach, Guy StephenÂ­son, during the early fall of 1924. But these stories will live and grow and each re-telling will increasingly test the credulity of the listener. Relegating them to print would be akin to composing their obitua!ies. Therefore these have been thoughtfully and tastefully omitted. xv
