oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 15
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Intentionally Left Blank CHAPTER ONE Conception W HEN THE MIDDLE. TENNESSEE State Normal School was crô€…†ô„™¡ated on paper by. the. . provisions of the General Educatô€…‡ô„œ¿?n Bill on March 4, 1909, -forty-four sister states had preceded Tennessee in t4is important business of teacher-ttain!.ng. Strong men in the past, usually in solo roles, had made vigorous atÂ­tempts to prdvide systematic training programs at state expense, but these generally were cries in the wilderness as conseciItive legislatures turned deaf ears and calmly tightened the rawhide purse strings. 1

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 16
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 2 â€¢ The First Fifty Years When Tennessee entered the Union in 1796, there was little educational precedence from the territorial years to guide the new state. Early institutions were of the academy type and wenô€••ô…” operated and controlled privately. They were supported in the main from tuition charges, but auxiliary funds were obtained from gifts, from donations, from authorized lotteries, and froln the proceeds arising from the Congressional Land Grant of 180(3. Academies mushroomed in almost every community. Some ô€•–ô…™¸xerted a great and lasting influence. Many were ill-formed and of short duration. From the first academy, chartered in 1789, to 1889, when the last one of these institutions was legally created, approximately five hundred operated by legislative sanction. The Congressional Land Grant of 1806 appeared to be a great boon fqr Tennessee education. The procedure was very simpleÂ­on the surface. Tennesô€•—ô…¥ee>s vacant and unappropriated land, were to be sold, and a portion of the proceeds from the sale of the lands was to be utilized for the financing of one academy in each county and for the esta blishment of two collegesÂ­one each in eastern and western Tennessee. The federal governÂ­ment had overlooked what proved to be one very important factor. There were Hsquatters" on the land-Hsquatters" of long duration-and they had no inclination to leave or to be disÂ­franchised. A bill of sale paled to insignificance as the long balTels of flintlocks were contemplated. Successive legislatures deô€•˜ô…¡©ised many elaborate strategems to fulfill the provisions of tlle compact, but prospective landlords dwindled in number and finally the plan was abandoned. ' For the next half century Tennessee legislators studiously avoided any plan to provide a system of higher education <It public expense. Legislative acts of this period were balTen as a desert in reference to a plan of action. Something in the form of a clarion call came on October 27, 1855. On this date, RepreÂ­sentative Robert Hatton of Wilson County introduced a bill in the lower House to establish a state normal school to be Conception â€¢ 3 located at Lebanon.' revoluÂ­tionary for the times that the representatives sat in shocked silence as Hatton presented his petition. In addition to fifty thousô€•™ô…¥®nd dollars required for grounds and plant, textbooks and tuition were to be free. As a final note of the deatll knell for the bill, it was stipulated that each pupil ô€•šô…©¶vas to receive five cents per mile for the distance required in going to and from the school! Eight years later Hatton fell at Seven Pines, but he had planted a tiny oasis in the desert. War and reconstruction and their impelling problems oblitÂ­erated any plans for education during the next several years. State Superintô€•›ô…­®ndent John Eaton, Jr., an Himported" educator from the North, made this unhappy report in 1869: The revenue officers of the state assured me that they have had no moneys in the b'easury . . . That there have been no schools in operation to call for the money; it has been in the State's distress, used like other revenue to liquidate the indebtedness of the State. The Comptrô€¾ô‡¹¬lIer assured me he could not see how the money for school purposes could bô€†·ô‹œ spared. Yet, despite financial discouragements which plagued TenÂ­nessee in 1869, Superintendent Eaton was able to wax almost eloquent in his tributeô€•œô…°¬,ô€•ô…µ¯o the teaching profession. This quotation from his Report typifies his feelings: , Ancients and moderns p ut in his hands the secrets of the future of the young. 'He 'ô€•žô…¹´ tands in place of the parent. 'The orator, the poet, thy., artist, and the historian celebrate his influence alike upon their personal attainments and upon the destinies of their nations and epochs. The teacher is the indispensable actor and necessary part of every system of culture. This "indispensable actor" alluded to by Eaton received some succor a few years later in the appearance of Dr. Barnas Sears on the Tennessee educational scene. He was the Southern agent

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 17
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 4 â€¢ The First Fifty Years for the Peabody Education Fund. At first, the legislators at N ashville viewed Sears with a jaundiced eye. This was 1873 and the man was from the North. However, suspicions were gradually allayed when it was discovered that the bag he carried contained U. S. currency-possessing a high degree of negotiability. The sum of six thousand dollars on an equal matching basis was proffered to the Legislature in 1873 for the purpose of establishing a normal. For reasons not clearly defined, the offer was rejected. Sears' offer, among other modest largesses, provided funds for the establishment in 1874 of ten:teachers' institutes. By 1875, the man from the North had successfully crossed the threshold of acceptance and was allowed the freedom of the legislative halls. In that year his offer was accepted. The act embracing acceptance provided for a normal school and a State Board of Education. The new State Board almost immeÂ­diately" busied itself with the task of activating the provisions of the legislation. After several policymaking sessions, a plan for selecting the site was announced. This plan was simple enough in that the normal would be located in that community providÂ­ing the best propOSition. In other words, the institution was placed on the auction block, thereby creating a frustillting precedent that strictured the locating. of Middle Tennessee State Normal School some thirty-five years later. Several communities cleared the deck for action, and after a few scorching weeks the ofer from the University of Nashville was accepted. The combining of the newly created "trick of the trade" normal with the staid academic University was in some ways a rather strange marriage. The State Board andÂ· the University trustees exercised equal control but somehow prospered under the cumbersome administrative arrangement. The new designation, "The Peabody Normal School of the University of Nashville," appeared on the diplomas as did a plethora of signatures assuring neo-ascendency at the convocations. Conception . 5 Tennessee at this point had only a timid foot in the teacherÂ­preparation door. In 1883, the State Legislature inaugurated a scholarship program for the Peabody Normal. The administraÂ­tion of this system was attended by misunderstanding and political interference, but many worthy recipients benefited from the legislative action. Also, dui'ing this . period one-week teacher institutes, commonly referred to as "Peabody Institutes," and summer "normals" at the University of Tennessee flourished in the miasma of the teacher-preparation dilemma. FragmentaÂ­tion and lack of perspective epitomized this period. Aggressive one-purpose leadership was needed. Concerted action gained momentum shortly. after the turn of the century. 'Strong men, this time of the same era, dedicated to the same purpose and minus the frightening lone-pioneer comÂ­plex, inveigled, cajoled, and pressured the reluctant lawmakers to the historic climax of 1909. This inexorable achievement was the result of a few men; yet their energy and volubility gave the impression of greater numbers. Really, the success of these efforts resided in the grass-roots approach. Seymour Mynders, Sidney Gilbreath, R. L. Jones, P. P. Claxton, and the others made no attempt to cull the speaking potential. County courts, women's organizations, parÂ­ents' groups, civiô€•Ÿ ô€††ôˆ˜ clubs, granges, literary clubs-all felt the impact of their fervent oratory. R. L. Jones once competed with a Saturday preacher in a .courthouse yard. P. P. Claxton put in an appearance, unannounced, at a rural pie supper and delivered the message. The legislators rode this wave of aroused interest to Nashville iï¿½ January of 1909. All of this welded effort probably wa,s triggered six years earlier by the action of State Superintendent Seymour A. Mynders in March, 1903. On that date he issued a circular letter to the county superintendents of Tennessee, inviting them to attend an educational conferô€†·ô‹®nce at Peabody. College in Nashville. This call was made within two weeks after Supe;intendent Mynders had taken' office and

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 18
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 6 â€¢ The First Fifty Years for all practical purposes was the beginning of the educational campaign which was carried to the people of Tennessee for the next three years and into those beyond. Objectives of the campaign were to secure: (1) better schools through increased revenue, (2) more efficient supervision and administration, and ( 3 ) improved library facilities. The Southern Education Board financed the campaign almost in its entirety, and Superintendent Mynders and P. P. Claxton assumed the responsibility for adminÂ­istering the funds. The campaign began in earnest after Governor James H. Frazier's address to the Legislature in 1905 in which he recommended appropriations for: better schoolhouses, teachers' institutes, continued aid to Peabody College, and the establishÂ­ment of a school of technology at the University of Tennessee. Prioô€• ô†€¬, forensic safaris over the state had proved so rewarding that the speakers renewed their efforts in 1906. It was estimated that over 100,000 people heard the educators discuss the schools and their needs. Favorable action of the Legislature of J907 to many aspects of the state's educational program caused the new State SuperÂ­intendent, R. L. Jones, to call another educational conference in Nashville in 1908. The purpose of the meeting' was to plan another speaking campaign. Participants were organized'Zinto small groups and assigned to certain counties. As has been preÂ­viously indicated, the legislators who convened in Nashville in January of 1909 were not unaware of the pulse of the electorate. It was an imposing array of forensic talent and a vast accumulaÂ­tion of expressive documents that faced them when the chaplain intoned the prayer of divine guidance on January 5, 1909. Years later, the Tennessee Education Association was to borrow, with some success, these persuasive techniques. From the efforts of the educators of the state and from the written sentiments which they had collected came the General Education Bill that provided for normal schools. Although Superintendent Jones, Mynders, Gilbreath, and others lent C oncepUon â€¢ 7 strength and aggressive leadership to this impOltant school legisÂ­lation, it was probably Philander Priestly Claxton who was reÂ­sponsible more than any other individual for the effective preÂ­legislative campaign and the successful routing of the bill through the Legislature. Dr. Andrew Holt in his definitive study of TenÂ­nessee education, 1903-1936, describes in detail Dr. Claxton's diligence in following the measure in each step of its journey through the Legislature and his fight for its enactment. Despite efforts to postpone action for another year and despite several attempts at unique and time-honored political maneuvers, supÂ­plemented by objections from the bankers' bloc and the ProÂ­hibitionists, the bill was enacted into law March 4, 1909. The General Education Bill of 1909 favored many aspects of the public schools of Tennessee. ô€†¸ô‹ ±10st important, in respectÂ· to a systematic and expanded program for teacher-preparation, was the section providing for a system of normal schools. Its opening paragraph specified the plan for financing the brand new educaÂ­tional obligation. It directed that "thirteen per cent of the General Education Fund provided by this act may be used for establishment and maintenance of normal schools solely for the education and professional training of teachers for elementary schools of the state as herein provided." One school for white students was to be located in each of the three grand divisions, and. there was ari additional provision for an agricultural and industrial normal for Negroes.> Other rather detailed directives specified the minimum age for entrance, the plan for the esô€•¡ô†…¡abÂ­lishment and administration of a laboratory school, 'dutiesô€•¢ô†ˆ§' of theÂ· faculty in, respect to teacher institutes, the differentiation between temporary and permanent teaching ceitificates offered by the instit1tions, the curriculum, and the plan for locating the four normals. In order to assure close adherence to the purposes initiating the normal school movement and possibly to allay the suspicions of a very practical legislature, the authors of the 'bill made this inclusion:

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 19
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 8 â€¢ The First Fifty Years, No person shall be admitted to either of the Normal schools for white teachers who does not first sign a pledge to teach in the public or private schools of the State of TenÂ­nessee, within the next six years after leaving the school, at least as long as he or she has attended said school. It is very obvious that this was only a pledge since its enÂ­forcement would have been attended by' a maze of clerical inÂ­volvements. There is no record that any enrollee was ever brought to the seat of accounting for having carried his nmvÂ­found skill to another state or for having blithely entered a nonÂ­teaching field. This pledge was lô€•£ô†¥eligiously ignored until 1939 when it -disappeared from the state school laws. Middle Tennessee State Normal at this point was a name only and not many days removed from the engrossing clerk's office in the Capitol. First, a site had to be found, and then for a body, a heart, and a soul there had to be buildings, a faculty, a philosophy, traditions. This took time, and it was inevitable that time would bring many high moments of victory, of exhilÂ­arating pride, and heartwarming nostalgias. Yet time was' not a respecter of institutional tranquility. Almost inevitably, fifty years would bring its concomitance of disharmony, of economic illness, and things better buried than said. But these diametrically opposed elements somehow had in time a way of combining in aÂ·Â· pattern that eliminated both the puritanical white and the abysmal black. The result became an entity of character and aggressive strength. The half century ahead was to be filled with both of these diverse elements. It was a happy story and a sad story-these fifty years of the Middle Tennessee State Normal School, the State Teachers College, and the Middle Tennessee State College. But happiness and sadness as an admixture gave institutional realism and an optimistic outlook for the' future. But as has been said, it still remained in 1909 a name. The first step beyond was to find a foundation, a place for a body and a soul to develop-in short, a site. Intentionally Left Blank

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 20
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Intentionally Left Blank CHAPTER Two Birth AT ITS MEETING ON JUNE 3, 1909, the Tennessee State Board of Education decided that a committee of three should be appointed to prepare rules and regulations outlining the method of procedure on the part of the Board. An additional duty was to formulate a uniform, plan of action for all bidders for nq!.ma] sites. Committee members were R. L. Harned, R. L. Jones, and A. L. Todd. Jt was "agreed that all bids should be In the hands of the Board by September l. On October '15, 1909, it was recorded that a visitation of the prospective normal sites had been initiated on Wednesday, September 8, and completed at Clarksville on October 14. At the same meetings, in the office of Governor Patterson, action was deferred on the immediate 9

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 21
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 10 â€¢ The. First Fifty Years location of the sites. Discussion of the various proposals from the communities interested in securing the normals came before the Board again on November 30. The advantages and disÂ­advantages of each were thoroughly discussed. It was finally agreed that the East Tennessee Normal would be located at Johnson City, Washington County; Middle Tennessee Normal at Mudreesboro, Rutherford County; and West Tennessee Normal in Memphis, Shelby County. The committee's report, indicating the three lucky comÂ­munities that had been tapped, was prefaced by a brief sumÂ­marizatioq of its activities during the preceding four months. The following excerpt from this report is a masterpiece of underÂ­statement relating to the difficulties in selecting the sites: Each (community) had its particular merits considered and the "responsibility of deciding between rival claimants has been very great, as each competing place possessed some merit and all were intensely interested in obtaining the school. There have been differences of opipion among the members of the Board as to where the normal schools should be located and our final decision has been reached after full consultation and consideration and after each member has expressed himself fully as to the merits of the places applying, it being necessary, in order to reach an agreement at all, for the members of the Board to act, in a spirit of harmony and compromise. With these difficulties and embarrassments under which we have labored, and appreciating fully our responsibilities to the people and the objects of the Normal schools, and bearing in mind, so far as we could, all the elements to be considered, the following decision has been reached by a majority of the members. Competition for the location of the site for j\1iddle Tennessee was very intense, to put it mildly. Clarksville and Cookeville were the two most aggressive rivals of Murfreesboro. Clarksville conceded early but the enthusiasm generated by the community Birth â€¢ 11 leaders never languished, and in 1927 Austin Peay Teachers College was established in that city. Cookeville was different. No concession was ever given. Todd, the "founding father" of the Murfreesboro school, led the fight for the fourth institution at Cookeville. Since no satisfactory explanation of the origin of the intense rivalry between Middle Tennessee State College and Tennessee Tech has ever been given, it is logical to assume that its incepÂ­tion came during the hectic months of 1909, long before either dreamed of fielding a football team. N ear the end of its tom- of inspection, the State Board Selection Committee came to Murfreesboro. The people turned out in circus style; business was suspended, and the buildings around the public square were hung with bunting. The committee was conducted on a tour of the several available sites which included the Richardson addition, the homestead of the Keeble family on South Church Street, grounds in Westvue, and a parcel of land at the eastenl limits of the town. That night a "jam-packed" meeting was held at the Opera House at which the committee was given the assurance that the sum of $180,000 would be given by the county and city to purÂ­chase the land and to assist in erecting the buildings. Appearinô€•¦ô†˜ on the rostrum that evening were many of the prominent anô€•§ô†œ influential citizens of the communty. As might have beer expected at the meeting, Todd became the central figure of thE Birth â€¢ 13 occasion and, caught in the excitement of the evening, rose to his feet several times to extol the virtues of his home community. Oratory, however, did not turn the tide, but the thirty-six days consumed by the committee in traveling over the state and listenÂ­ing to Todd sing the Murfreesboro refrain probably exerted conÂ­siderable influence in the final decision. In the early afternoon of November 30, 1909, a long distance call from the State Capitol announced that Murfreesboro was the successful bidder. That evening when the night b'ain, with Todd as a passenger, chugged into town, it was met at the station by an enormous crowd and a brass band. This was followed by a parade uptown and a "big time" speaking on the square. This coritinued far into the night, and surviving citizens at the half century _ milestone compare it favorably with the November 11 celebration coming nine years later. In preparing the groundwork for the offer of $180,000 to the State Board on September 1, 1909, the City Council of MurfreesÂ­boro met in special session and unanimously voted its share of $80,000. In the County Court there was opposition, and at first it declined to vote its share. At the July term in 1909, the matter was introduced again and considerable discussion ensued. For some time it appeared that the court might follow the pattern of an earlier court that had, eighty-four years before, refused to vote five hundred dollars to move the state records from Nashville to Murfreesboro. -The transference of these records might have established - Murfreesboro as the perrnanent state capital of Tennessee. THE SETTING Although Murfreesboro became the location of one of the normals, principally through the persistent efforts of A. L. Todd and other prominent local citizens, the town had already been conducive to the establishment of other institutions of higher learning. In 1905, there had been established in Murfreesboro Birth â€¢ 15 a four-year liberal arts college for women, Tennessee College. Prior to this and serving as a predecessor on the same property had been Union University, with its cornerstone being laid in 1849. From the time of the incorporation of the town on October 17, 1811, to the beginning of the twentieth century, other instituÂ­tions, now non-existent, had borne the name college. Among these were Eaton College and Soule College. The latter instituÂ­tion was probably the most prominent during the early years, but it became rocked in a scandal which ultimately led to its dissolution. Besides the atmosphere of intellectual activity that served as a background for the normal, there were other events of the past that loomed large in the memories of the citizens. In 1813, James K. Polk had come to Murfreesboro and had attended Bradley Academy for two years. A few years thereafter he married Sarah Childress, a young lady whom he had met during his school days in Nlurfreesboro. The town had been the capital of the state from 1819 to 1825. From December 31, 1862, to J anuray 2, 1863, there had been fought a sanguinary Civil vVar battle, Stone's River. In 1909, many of the homes still bore mutilations from Federal occupation, and a system of well-preserved earthworks sprawled at the western limits of the town. In Nl urfreesboro, in, kô€•«ô†­¥ eping with its historical and educational background, there had heen considerable literary activity. Nlary Noailles Murfree, writing under the pseudonym of Charles EgÂ­bert Craddock, had received ' some national acclaim for her stories _ô€€¬ô‚°®. of the Great Smoky Mountains and the Civil 'iVar. 'iVill Allen Dromgoole had served as-' literary editor of the N as hville_ Banner for several yearô€•¬ô†° and had published books of poetry and literary criticism. Several active literary groups were in existence, and efforts of the members appeared frequently in the local newsÂ­paper. , In 1910 the population of Murfreesboro, legislative seat of Ruthedord County, was 4:679. It was obviously a typical south-

So impressed was a writer of one of the early normal bulletins that this eulogistic description was given of the town and its environs: The most charming view that can greet the admiration and wonder of the true lover of nature is the bluegrass fields dotted here and there with the majestic oak and graceful hfckory where graze and browse the Jersey, the charming little dairy queen, the heavy built Durham and the whiteÂ­faced Hereford upon the grassy sward of some rippling, bab bling brook as it dances merrily and cheerily along its pehbly bed to the deeper and more placid waters where spo,rt in festive play the leaping trout and the succulent red-eyed black perch with which our waters abound. SELECTING T HE SITE On February 10, 1910, the State Board of Education met at ô€•®ô†¸±1urfreesboro to select a site for the Normal. Andrew Todd served as the host of the occasion, and, after an orientation meetÂ­ing in his law offices on East Main Street, the Board prepared to tour the available tracts. His choice was the Hanison-Black property which lay eastwardly just beyond the town limits. Property owners supporting the Keeble homestead and the grounds in Westvue had conducted a private campaign by letters to the Board and by personal contacts. By far, this was the most aggressive group. Mr. Todd, being cognizant of this and the somewhat favorable attitude of the Board, demonstrated again the shrewdness that was later to carry him to the speakership of the Tennessee State Senate and to a rough and tumble campaign against Cordell Hull for the United States Senate. Loading the Board into his Lincoln, he pulled out from his law office, circled the public square, and began the precarious descent down Maple Street into the "Bottoms." Now the "Bottoms," later obliterated by a government slum clearance project, probably had the most deplorable assortment of hovels and dilapidated structures for a town of comparable size anyÂ­where. Through the middle of the basin coursed a creek known interchangeably as Lytle's Creek and Town Creek. During the season of heavy rains the little stream was pushed out of its banks, and some of the nearby shacks were partially submerged. Also, along the banô€‰½ô‡µ³s, ranged a line of outhouses that were usually torn from their moorings and transported to new locaÂ­tions during these deluges.-It so happened that February 10 was one of those times. By common consensus, Mr. Todd took a sharp turn to the left and headed his Lincoln in the direction of the Manchester Pike and on to the Harrison-Black property. The ultimate choice was the property owned jointly by Tom Harrison and Joe Black. It lay just beyond the eastern town limits on a gentle swell of land. A depression ran through the southern one-third of the property and later separated the principal : building sites from the spot used for the President's home. This depression was a wet-weather channel for Sinking Creek, which was to create difficulties both for the Normal and the property owners to the west. The land was almost completely free of vegetation, and the section later used for the original ' structures was one large field that had been tilled the previous fall. John Zumbro, class of 1926, as a young farm laborer culÂ­tivated this area for several years. In fact, open fields stretched from the original site to the Tennessee Collô€•¯ô†½§ge property several hundred yards westward. Zumbro, at the half century, recalls very vividly his labors on the pre-Normal property and the high fertility of the soil. He recalls that for several years bumper crops of cowpeas had been grown, and the growth had been particularly luxuriant at the spot now occupied by the adminisÂ­tration building. It was somewhat apparent, from the language of the proposiÂ­tion presented to the Board by Harrison and Black, that the location would be the focal point for real estate development. Contained in the written communication were the following stipulations and agreements: 1. Eighty acres of land, free of cost, would be donated. 2. The tract would have 500 foot frontage on Main Street and extend north to the Halls Hill Pike. 3. Eighty acres would be in one body of land. Birth â€¢ 19 4. The State Board should construct a macadamized road from Main Street to the Halls Hill Pike. 7. The Board should construct, or cause to be constructed, extensions of certain streets perpendicular to the property. One verbal agreement reached by both parties was the plan to lay out a tree and grass plot in the center of the road running from the Main Street to Hall's Hill Pike. This never materialized since the Board and the property owners could never quite remember which of the parties had the greater responsibility for the construction. In a letter dated March 12, 1910, the State Board accepted the terms. It was indicated, also, that the Murfreesboro authorities had been notified concerning the extension of the streets and sewer lines, and the county had been notified relative to the building of the macadamized road. This was in line with the original "bid" proffered by the town of Murfreesboro and the Rutherford County authorities. The macadamized road borderÂ­ing the Normal property was designated as North Tennessee Normal Boulevard and' retained this name on town maps until the changeover to State Teachers 'College in 1925. With the completion 6f these stipulations, the Board was now--Â­ready to proceed with the construction of the plant. A bid for the East Tennessee Normal was accepted, while those for Middle TennÂ­essee were rejected because they were in excess of the appropriaÂ­tion. Architects were instructed to modify their plans to come within the limits of the appropriations. All bidders were asked to submit new estimates. In the case of C. K. Colley of Nashville, architect for Middle Tennessee Normal, orders to modify his plans came as a great disappointment. Colley had spent many long hours in creating what he regarded as the ideal educational institution. The main building, for example, in the original water color perspective was surmounted by ornate masonry, and the parapet immediately above the eight Ionian columns was capped by a large stone facing bearing a flagpole." East and west enÂ­trances carried columned porticoes. Heartbroken, Colley went back to his drawing board and trimmed away what he regarded as the creative aspects and presented the modified version to ô€•±ô‡…¨he Board. The interior specifications for the buildings have been lost, but copies of the exterior renderÂ­ings for the administration building and girls' dormitory can be found in the early catalogs. When the new bids were received, George W. Moore and Son of Nashville was awarded the contract for the erection at Murfreesboro of the main building, girls' dormitory, kitchen and dining hall, and power house. The accepted bid was $137,855. The plumbing and heating contract for $25,564 went to T. J. Moore and Company of Nashville, and lighting for $2,115 went to Herbrick and Lawrence, also of Nashville. Almost immediately actual construction began, and the Middle Tennessee Normô€•²ô‡‰] Birth â€¢ 21 was the first of the ' three institutions completed. Todd, W. N. Billingsley, and R. L. Jones. W. N. Billingsley, at the time a member of the State Board and of the Tennessee Textbook Commission, became a member of the first faculty. Shortly after the awarding of the building contract, Rutherford County opened a road from East Main Street to Halls Hill Pike; and, although it remained in a deplorable condiÂ­tion for some time, it provided a thoroughfare for incoming building supplies and equipment. The road scuffed out for practiÂ­cal purposes from the Normal Boulevard to the sites of the dormitory and main building ultimately became the access to the campus until it was closed during President Q. M. Smith's administration. An additional task assigned to the Middle Tennessee ComÂ­mittee was that of securing plans and specifications and awardÂ­ing a contract for the construction of a home for the President. The contract was ultimately awarded to Henry Brothers of Nashville for the sum of $10,000. . There appears to be no evidence that the founding fathers of the Normal had any pattern of arrangement in mind for future construction. As Originally noted, the campus roads came into being largely by chance. In 1921, when the boys' dormitory was constructed, it was laid east of the main building - and faced the front of the girls' dormitory to the west. This arrangement had all the appearance of the first step in a quadrangle scheme so popular at other institutions of higher learning. This was later somewhat modified by the location in 1927 of the first librarv building at a spot one hô€•³ô‡®ndred yards south of and faCing toward the m1hn building.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 28
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 22 â€¢ The First Fifty Years Why the library building was unschematically located at this spot has many versions. From the academic viewpoint, it was easily accessible to both male and female sleeping quarters and to the scholars in the main building. Since all activities at the time were concentrated in the main building and no visions of departmental dispersions had become manifest, this seemed a logical and practical location. One of the most popular stories relating to the location of the first library came from the visit to the campus of the State Board BUilding Committee in 1926. The purpose of this visit was to locate a site. The procedure used is reminiscent of Andrew Jackson's plan for locating the U. S. Treasury building in WashÂ­ington. In the Board's company was Governor Austin Peay, not a member of the committee but a kind of ex-officio traveler. Muffled in' their overcoats and surveying the campus from the top steps at the front of the main building, the committee memÂ­bers suggested several spots. Governor Peay, obviously anxious to justify his ride from the capital city, broke into the conversaÂ­tion and waving his hand in the direction of the ultimate location suggested, "Why not out there?" The committee members were amazed that they had not thought of this very spot and complimented the Governor on hiô€•´ô‡ site-locating acumen. Subsequent administrators have often entered their nocturnal slumbers hoping that a miracle would greet them when they entered the campus the following morning. This miracle would have moved the "Peay inspiration" to a spot in the quadrangle pattern that was set at the half century. Smaller wooden structures to house farm equipment and animals came into being concurrently with the main plant. The original acreage provided little opportunity for the campus of wide vistas of later years. The original plot of one hundred acres resembled a top hat with the long brim of eighty acres resting on the Normal Boulevard from East Main Street to the Halls Hill Pike. Compressed within the twenty acres of the "bowl" Birth â€¢ 23 of the hat were all of the first buildings. TIns was in keeping with the original agreement. Consequently, the bam was conÂ­structed near the main building at the site of the present Jones Field. Commuting students came by horse and buggy, and many of them used the barn as a shelter for their animals. The original plan for campus buildings did not provide dormitory facilities for boys. This has never been explained except by circumstances that existed when the state reluctantly agreed to accept financial responsibility for a teacher-education proÂ­gram. When M urfrees bol'O was accepted as a normal site for Middle Tennessee, the sum of $180,000, contributed by the city and county, had been a significant factor in the final decision. To supplement this, the state made a biennial appropriation of $75,000 for the 1911-1912 period. This aggregate of $237,000 was just sufficient for building needs and equipment. Too, the principal emphasis in normal school programs of the times was the training of elementary teachers. Elementary teachers were primarily women, and the decision to provide on-campus living quarters was a natural consequence. Also, the coming of the Normal to M urfrees boro occurred at a time when sheltering and overprotectiveness of women, particularly in their younger years, was not considered prudish and old-fashioned. Of the two large structures on the campus the women's dormiÂ­tory was only slightly ' less imposing than the main building. It. too, had been modified -from the original, more ornate plans of C. K. Colley. Despite changes to a more modest structure, it was described as: . . . 162 feet long, 42 feet wide and three stories in ,height. Contains 56 , rooms, two double parlors and quarters for a matron. Heated by steam and lighted by electricity. Each bedroom has a lavatory with hot and cold water. Bathroom provided for each eight students. Every room in the building is an outside room, all sanitary arrangements are modem. Each room is furnished with shades, a rug, table, dresser,

Twenty boys lived in this building during the first year. Robert White and Max Souby, two of the first faculty members, were placed in charge. The campus was easily reached from the rear of the Kittrell home by a well-worn path across the Harrison property to the east of the main building. In the ô€•µô‡•©idst of the wide fields beyond the eastern limits of M urfrees boro, the new s chool began to take form. However, that was long before the mule teams began hauling construction steel down Normal Boulevard. DETAILS PREPARATORY TO OPENING Construction was progressing on schedule and all indications were that the Normal would open in the fall. Meanwhile, PresiÂ­dent Jones was absorbed with the many duties attending the opening of a new institution. It seemed that no detail was too insignificant. For instance, in the January meeting, the State Board went on record as approving the purchase of a typewriter for the Normal. Later the same body approved a requisition for the purchase of a Rotary N eostyle mimeograph machine in the amount of $45.00. Also, at this meeting, the President was given authority to employ janitors and engineers subject to the approval of the Board. Caution appeared to be the watchword. At the April 8 meeting authorization was given to proceed in the preparation of a bulletin. In the meantime Jones had moved to Murfreesboro from Nasl;lÂ­ville. His temporary residence was a two-story brick house, now the property of Richard Stickney, on East Main Street one-half Birth â€¢ 25 block west of the Tennessee College campus. His first office was in the building occupied by the Andrew L. Todd law firm on the corner of Spring Street and Main Street. Here he began the preparation of the first bulletin and organized for recruitment. He was assisted in this by his son, Horace, and Robert White. His principal assistance in preparing the bulletin came from the latter. White, after a stint at "selling Vanderbilt" at a time when the Methodists and a university lawsuit had developed conÂ­siderable sales resistance, left for points north and entered the graduate school at the University of Chicago. After completing a winter and spring term he was notified that he had been elected to the faculty of the Middle Tennessee State Normal School. He then came to Murfreesboro and secured quarters with President Jones. On the eastern edge of Murfreesboro the labor pains were loud and distinct, but in the Andrew Todd office at the corner of Spring and Main the creative pains were equally excruciating. The bulletin was being prepared. President Jones had never prepared a catalog. Bob vVhite had never taught a day of school in his life. A great number of courses of study and bulletins had been collected from other normal schools. These were spread out on the tables and chairs in the room. Mr. Jones paced and dictated while White pecked out the copy on the Smith-Premier typewriter, probably the first tangible movableÂ·Â· property of the Normal. Jones' vast experiÂ­ence in practical school matters < obviously was a great asset in preparation of this forty-eight page document. At all times ô€‚ôˆ´€ô€‚Žôˆ¸ kept a weather eye out for the restrictions and guidelines found in the bill of 1909. Prefacing the specifics was the . statement permitting some flexibility. This part reads as follows: The course of study and the rules and regulations shall be the same for all the said Normal schools, with such minor modifications for any school as may be required by local conditions; provided, that such courses of study shall in-' elude instruction in ;ordinary English branches, in vocal

Preparation of the bulletin consumed approximately three weeks. Most of the twenty-five hundred copies printed were sent to high school graduates in the Middle Tennessee area. Another very important chore was that implied by the legislaÂ­tive directive for the provision of practice schools. The section of the bill relating to this is included in the following paragraph : Each: school established and maintained under the proÂ­visions of this section of this act shall have connected with it ( one or more practice and observation schools, in which shall be taught at least all of the subjects prescribed for the primary schools of the state; and the County Board of EducaÂ­tion of any county, or the District Director of any school district, or the Board of Education of any incorporated city or town having a special school system under the provision of its charter may, and the same is hereby empowered to, contract with the State Board of Education to provide for the teaching of children of public-school age in such practice and observation schools, and to pay to the said Normal school:' all or any portion of the public-school fund belonging to such county, district, or incorporated city and town, and the State Board of Education, as in the case of consolidated schools under the provision of the State school law. To provide facilities for a practice school the State Board entered into an agreement with the Murfreesboro City Board of Education for the use of the city schools for practice and observation. Completion of the terms of the contract was conÂ­tingent on the city limits being extended to encompass the Normal property. Besides providing for a teaching laboratory in the town, plans were also made for a practice school on the Normal campus. On July 6, 191 1 , the State Board heard recom- Birth â€¢ 27 mendations from President Jones for staffing the practice schools. Although the Murfreesboro City Board of Education had emÂ­ployed the staff for its school, by virtue of the contract existing between the two boards, formal election of these teachers went through the formality of State Board action. The staff for the campus school also received formal action and approval . The list of these teachers and school assignments was as follows : Model School Eliza Emery . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . Substitute, Second and Third Grades General rules and regulations for operation of the Normal were passed by the State Board' at its regular meeting, July 6, 1911. N one of these were particularly unique on the surface, but the actual implementation had some rather interesting results. They contained the following stipulations : 1. Students would be charged $1.50 room rent in advance per week. 2. Board in the dining hall would be served at actual coô€‰¿ô‡½´t. 3. Purchases of food ô€Š€ôˆ®nd necessary equipment for tJ:le dining hall and kitchen would be under the direction of the bursar

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 31
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 28 â€¢ The First Fifty Years and the matron. 4. The President was authorized to issue an annual catalog and not more than three bulletins, after proper advertising for bids. 5. The President, with the approval of the local committee, was empowered to fill faculty vacancies. 6. The President of the school, together with the heads of the departments, was authorized to prepare itemized lists of equipment, apparatus, or supplies needed in the various departments, advertise for bids, and let contracts, subject to the approval of the Board. 7. Any "two members of the local committee, appointed to supervise the general administration and operation of the Normal, were empowered to act legally on any matters during the interim periods of the State Board. The first two regulations relating to expenses were a boon to the bulk of the Normal population. Most of the enrollees came from the rural areas and, in many instances, not too prosperous sections of Middle Tennessee. Lodging could be obtained in the dormitories and in the Murfreesboro homes opened to early Normalites for six dollars per term of twelve weeks . The first registration fee was set at two dollars. In addition, the early catalog advertised that food costs would not be less than ten dollars and never more than twelve dollars per month. This comforting note was added : "Board is being furnished now at $10 per month, and it is believed that next year's board can be reduced to $9 per month ... The faculty will give special attenÂ­tion to the expenses of students, to the end that all may be comÂ­fortably cared for at a minimum cost." Maximum term expenses then, aside from textbooks, materials, clothing, and recreation, aggregated forty-four dollars, which to say the least were modest even for 1911. As to the catalog and bulletin regulation, the policy followed during the next several years was the issuance of one catalog Birth â€¢ 29 annually which carried the faculty roster, rules and regulations, types of diplomas, and courses of study. Information and public relations bulletins were then issued intermittently. In later years "catalog" and "bulletin" lost their significance, and the terms were used interchangeably in designating the standard publicaÂ­tion of the school. Items "5" and "7" bore heavily on the patience of the President. What these two regulations really created was a small mobile State Board that breathed heavily down his neck at every move that he made. Frequently, in activating the regulation perÂ­taining to faculty selection, the order of procedure was reversed. On more than one occasion strange people, carrying officialÂ­looking mandates to teach, wandered into his office at the corner of Main and Spring. For a while it was a kind of touch and go between the local committee and the big, jovial, diploÂ­matically- inclined President. The original committee composed of Jones, Billingsley, and Todd was changed because of Jones' ascendency to the presidency and Billingsley to faculty status. Harry Luck was then appOinted to serve with Todd. This committee acted as the local committee beginning on November 11, 1910. It is evident from the State Board Minutes that most of the energies and efforts _ o! the Board and the new President, from July to the proposed opening date, were confined to problems of securing equipment and Â· its prompt delivery. As the Board used a rather tedious process of advertising for bids, requiring. a review of materials from' agents involved and then a closed session for examinatioil' of bids, the equipment moved very slowly into the, completed sections of the new plant. In July, President Jones was authorized to employ members of the faculty to canvass for students. The Board, never one to authorize a spending binge, allowed $600 to cover necessary expenses of travel and salaries.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 32
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: CHAPTER THREE Staffing The School ROBERT LEE JONES, while serving as State Superintendent under G?vernor M. R. " Ham" Patterson from 1907 through 1910, lô€•¶ô‡™¡ad engmeered several progressive changes in Tennessee educaÂ­tion. One of these was the abolition of the obnoxious district schô€•·ô‡¯ol bô€•¸ô‡¡¡ards aô€•¹ô‡¥¤d . the ô€•ºô‡©µubstitution of the county board plan. Also, durmg hIS admmistratIOn a law was passed providing that oneÂ­fourth of all revenues of the state should be devoted to public schools. A third significant achievement, created with the assistÂ­ance of other prominent Tennessee educators and the Governor was the inception of the plan for four normal schools. Jones haa 30 Stafing The School â€¢ 31 a rare capacity for living in harmony with both of the principal political parties of the state. Prior to holding the state superinÂ­tendency he had been a successful Democratic candidate for Superintendent of Schools in Hamilton County, a Republican stronghold. Later he was defeated by John B. Brown, a future State Superintendent, but the two remained close friends through the years. In fact, Jones returned to Chattanooga as Cit.y SuperinÂ­tendent in 1919 upon the recommendation and through the inÂ­fluence of Brown. When the smoke, slightly tinged with sulphur, had cleared from the General Education Bill of 1909, the State Board set about the task of selecting a president for the proposed MurfreesÂ­boro institution. Jones was not an open applicant, but he raised no serious objections to the solicitations from his board members and influential educators and citizens of the state. It 'was pointed out that his great services to the teacher-education plan entitled him to a prominent role in the direction of one of the new instituÂ­tions. Also, of utmost importance, a new governor would be inaugurated in January of 1911. His great friend, Patterson, had suffered something resembling a violent political death. The first "sling and arrow" came during the aftermath of the raucous Patterson-Carmack gubernatorial campaign. Patterson was vicÂ­torious, and Carmaô€•»ô‡­«k was shot down on the streets of Nashville on November 8, 1908; 'shortly after the votes had been counted. Patterson's manner of disposition of the assassins, in his role as chief executive, placed him in disfavor with many citizens of the state. In the wake. of' the agitation for prohibition created by Carmack, Pattersori"" vetoed a temperance bill introduced in the Legislature of 1909. Its strange companion, the General Education Bill, was favorably received by both Houses as was the temperance bill, for the veto was overridden. Patterson's political days were numbered. In 1910 an alcoholic split in tp.e Democratic Party electe.d Ben Hooper as the new govô€•¼ô‡±²rnor. At the regular meeting of the State Board on November 10,

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 33
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 32 â€¢ The First Fifty Years Jones was selected as first President of Middle Tennessee State Normal School. The following resolution was passed: Be it resolved by the State Board of Education that R. L. Jones be elected to the PreSidency of the Middle Tennessee State Normal School located at Murfreesboro, Tennessee, at a salary of $3,600 per year and a home; his term of office to be fixed at 5 years, beginning March 21, 1911. He immediately tendered his resignation to become effective at the close of the year as State Superintendent. President Jones was a man of considerable practical educaÂ­tional experience but was limited somewhat in formal education. He was born April 7, 1867, at Cedar Creek in White County, Tennessee, the youngest of eleven children. His parents, Zack and Mary Jones, resided on a farm. He attefided the White County schools for a time, Onwar d Seminary near Doyle, Tennessee, and Burritt College at Spencer. In the summer of 1900, he enrolled in the graduate school of the University of Chicago but was denied full enrollment status beÂ­cause of his lack of acceptable credits. Through his powers of persuasion, he was permitted to remain as a student until the close of the summer term. Because of his outstanding record during this period, he was offered a scholarship but he de: clined it. He was successively Superintendent of White County Schools, Superintendent of Hamilton County Schools, and State SuperinÂ­tendent of Public Instruction. As has been previously stated, he, with P. P. Claxton, G. L. Mynders, and others, was largely responsible for the General Education Bill of 1909, which created the normal school program. The President brought to his new position a wealth of experiÂ­ence and personal and professional respect of Tennessee educaÂ­tors. It is probable that some of this respect was generated in contemplating the physical enormity of the man. He was deÂ­scribed as standing well over six feet six inches and weighing Staffing The School â€¢ 33 two hundred and eightY pounds. Students who were confronted with this mountain of a man for the first time were awed and frequently forgot the purpose of their journey to his office. However, like the tug of the ear in "A Visit from St. Nicholas," the President's smile and deep warmth soon dispelled any fear generated by his physical greatness. One of the more poetic feminine Normalites referred to him as personifying Lamb's "Gentle Giant." One incident at least, during the early years, reveals the very human side of his personality, if not an occasional urge on his part to work in collusion with the students. One day after the bell had rung terminating exchange of classes, a male loiterer was caught in the hallway by Dr. James Fertig. To compound the crime, one of the boy's cheeks had an ominous protrusion indicating that he was using tobacco. Since the use of tobacco in any form on the campus was something approaching a capital crime during the first years, the culprit was quickly convoyed to the office. One of the common -practices among the young addicts when near apprehension was to swallow the quids and live for a time with nausea rather than face retribution in the big office. Unfortunately in this particular case, Dr. Fertig, as was his habit, darted out of his room and caught the victim from the rear. President Jones receiVed the young man in his office and asked Dr. Fertig to close the- door and leave. Sitting at his desk, he questioned the offender Jor several minutes; then he arose, came around to the boy and placed a huge hand on his shoulder. His next question -took an unexpected turn. "Son, what kind of tobacco do you use?'ô€•½ô‡´ "B-b-brown's :Mule, sir," he stammered, his face becoming more chalk -like than ever. " How about a chew?" asked the President as the boy's knees. buckled. After considerablp fumbling the tobacco was p:t;oduced and a generous helping was taken. As the boy was dismissed,

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 34
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 34 â€¢ The Fitst Fifty Years Jones gave a parting word of advice, "Don't ever let Dr. Fertig catch you chewing tobacco again." The oversize brass spittoon that stood near the President's desk was indicative of one of his few small vices. It was removed upon the ascendency of Mr. Lyon to the presidency. Upon occasions President Jones could explode in proportion comparable to his physical self. In November of 1916 when it was announced that Woodrow Wilson had defeated Charles Hughes in the very close presidential race, the Normal students were primed for a huge celebration. Most of them, with the exception of a few timid souls, left the classrooms and dormitories f<?r a parô€Šôˆ…¤de around the public square. It was a noisy demonsboaÂ­tion, and the celebrants carried banners and placards. President J ones waited for them to drift back to the campus; then he ordered a"special assembly. It is doubtful that any student body since that time has received a more severe or lengthy castigation . Jones, a. man of many strong personal and professional facets, was ideally tailored to the challenging task . of creating and nurturing a new institution. His innate ability had been honed in his position of State Superintendent. He was aware of many of the side trails in politics and how to reach quickly an objective through the magnanimous display of his great talent in human relations. Definitely he was almost without parallel in handling personnel, as was demonstrated prior to his assuming the presidÂ­ency and afterwards. At the beginning of the new year, Jones pulled the academic regalia over his fighting clothes, cleaned out his desk in the Capitol, and headed in the direction of Murfreesboro-in search of a faculty. THE FIRST FACULTY The impact of this first faculty on the minds of the students of those early years was indeed remarkable. After fifty years, many of those who sat at the feet of these early teachers recall with a minimum of difficulty vivid personal deSCriptions, illustra- Staffing The School â€¢ 35 tive stories, and the little eccentricities that humanize but seldom diminish the stature of an instructional staff. Also, those few of the faculty who survived the first half century render lucid acÂ­counts of what they term the "halcyon years." There is little doubt that out of the crucible of personal inconveniences, perÂ­plexing problems, and somewhat vague and imperfect blueprints for the future evolved strong bonds of friendships and cohesiveÂ­ness. Middle Tennessee State Normal School provided the enÂ­vironment for this. Enemies, garbed to resemble legislators and public high school inspectors, lurked from without, and the familiar spectre of plant and equipment deficiencies roamed within. The Beau Btummel of the campus was Phi Beta Kappan Harry Clark, instructor in English. He was young and handsome but unfortunately, insofar as many palpitating young ladies were concerned, married-and to a very beautiful wife. To add fuel to the "crushes," he and his wife were domiciled in the Women's Dormitory where they served as "co-matrons." It was a sad day when Professor Clark left the campus near the end of the first year to accept the superintendency of Knoxville schools. He was regarded, as one of the most versatile men ever employed by the institution; his particular forte, oratory, placed him in great demand in the community. An allusion to his forensic witchery appeared in the CarihiLge Courier on May 28, 1913, one year after his departure from the Normal. Referring to Clark's address at the graduation exercises of the local high school, the repott stated that "he held spell-bound for more than an hour an audience of more than iour hundred Carthage people .. Professor Clark is a most forceful and interesting speaker, ' and is a selfÂ­made man in every respect." Incidentally, the title of his remarks was inspired by Mark Twain's exhortation to the young: "Don't stare up the steps, but step up the stairs." The Clarks were succeeded in their donnitory chores by Mrs. W. G. Swindeil, who was listed in the June 1912 catalog as being "a teacher of

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 36 â€¢ The First Fifty Years successful experience and a lady of high culture." Science teacher Archibald Belcher, "Arch" to his associates, brought with him to the Normal twenty years of successful teachÂ­ing experience and a graduate degree from Harvard. He was bald, wittty, and a great favorite of the students. He was easily recognizable, even at a great distance, by his end-man shuffle and the clouds of dry summer dust created by his large, flat feet padding along the unpaved walkways of the campus. He lived with his wife, Hannah, daughter of former Tennessee Governor Peter Turney, in a pre-fabricated. house, a Murfreesboro first, two blocks .from the campus. As a classroom teacher he possessed many of the elements of greatness. Although at times guilty oô€Š‚ôˆˆ carô€ƒôµ¬les sness, which reflected his human facet, his slight touch of the martinet gave him a semblance of organization and kept his students close to their tasks. An incident in the laboratory one day is indicative of these qualities. He was berating his students for their apparent disregard in the care of equipment. He enumerated the expense involved in materials,,-, in the apparatu s necessary for experiments, and the difficulty in securing replaceÂ­ments. "For example," he continued, while holding for all to see a very impressive laboratory thermometer, "this piece of equipment waô€½ô‡´® . purchased at the astronomical price of seven dollars. Yet, most of you handle it like it grew free and abundantly on the pecan tree on the campus." Hardly had the last word escaped his lips when the thermomÂ­eter slipped from his fingers and shattered to pieces on the concrete floor. There was considerable silence for several seconds, but as he regained his composure, he added, "Now, that's what I mean." Other indices to his popularity were several good-natured references to him which appeared in the early publications. These invariably referred to his baldness. An issue of The Signal carried this jibe in the joke section : Staffing The School â€¢ 37 Mr. Belcher went into a barbershop and plumping himÂ­self down into the chair, said : "Haircut!" The barber looked at him a moment and replied : "Why, man, you don't need a haircut-what you want is a shine." The second issue of the 1924 N ormalite, May 3, 1924, anÂ­nounced the death of Mr. Belcher. He was the second and last member of the first faculty to pass away while in service at the Normal, Mr. Billingsley having been the first. The announcement had a mixture of eulogism for it stated that "With the passing of Professor Archibald Belcher there is in the hemt of each student and faculty member of Middle Tennessee State Normal a sense of deô€Šƒôˆ°p personal loss. Overshadowing the realization that the school has lost one of the most capable instructors it has ever had and that the community has lost a valuable citizen is the feeling that each of us has lost a friend. The warmth of his personality and the spirit of kindliness which he radiated have become a part of the heritage of all who have passed through the walls of M.T.N." In accordance with his wishes expressed several years before his death, the last rites were conducted in the Normal auditorium on Sunday evening, May 4, at eight o'clock. President Lyon presided and "first spoke beautifully of the life and character of this good man and ô€ƒœô°®.4is great worth to the institution and as an educator of power ô€†…ôˆ” and influô€Š„ôˆ‘®nce." The funeral services of one other faculty memper ô€¼ô‡±·were conducted in the institution's auditorium during the first ,Iifty yem's. This was in 1933 when similar services were pexformed for Frank Faulkinberry. Robert Hiram 'White, later Tennessee State Historian, came to the NormaL from the University of Chicago where he had been a graduate student. Prior to this he was traveling alumni secretary for Vanderbilt University. He had played some university football but terminated his

Her organizational talents and energy were evident early in the life of the young institution. Almost at once a chorus was organized, followed in 1913 by the first orchestra. The five assemblies, each week were highly dependent upon Miss Saunders' music activities since the administration at times was sorely tried in providing proÂ­grams for the daily thirty-minute routine. Her victrola, featuring the classics, made frequent appearances. For many years Miss Saunders was the music department, but her range of activities was tremendous. There was a sprinÂ­kling of assistants through the years. Rubye Taylor Sanders beÂ­came instrumental music instructor in 1928 and remained until her retirement in 1960. G. L. Valdez was employed as band director in 1937 but resigned two years later. The upsurge in wider curricular offerings and expanded faculty came with the Wright team, Neil and Margaret, in 1946. P. A. Lyon, instructor in mathematics, was a mature forrjÂ­three when he came to the Normal campus. His formal educaÂ­tional background was not noteworthy, but beyond his WinÂ­chester Normal days and a six weeks' turn at Vanderbilt UniÂ­v ô€ƒôµ²rsity he had some nineteen years of practical experience. Fifty years later, students remember him as a masterful teacher. Some aver that his strength lay in teaching rather than adminisÂ­tration, but his years as President during the turbulent depresÂ­sion seem to belie this. Mr. Lyon early had the feel for adminisÂ­tration, and he presided at staff meetings and assemblies on numerous occasions when the President was away. His graciousÂ­ness and consideration for his mathematics students were exÂ­ceeded only by well-groomed appearance, for he epitomized sartorial elegance in the eyes of the early N ormalites. One of the pleasing sights each morning on the campus was that of seeing Mr. Lyon riding in his "side-bar buggy drawn by a highÂ­stepping steed" and moving around the main road to the hitchÂ­bam to the rear of the main building. In the classroom he was witty with a reservoir of highly flavored stories that conveyed the points swiftly and sometimes hilariously to the students. Listed as the first principal of the Model School was W. N. Billingsley, immediate Past President of Burritt College at Spencer, Tennessee. He had also served as a member of the State Board of Education and the State Textbook Commission. St:ntimenfal, if not political, reasons probably weighed heavily il; the choice of Mr. Billingsley since President Jones was a Burritt graduate and had also been closely associated with him in State Board activities. Billingsley had an extremely interesting and varied educational background, but when he came to the Normal in 1911, he was in his middle seventies. Despite his autumn years he filled engagements at maIJY of the summer institutes as demanded of all Normal instructors by the Act of 1909. On these occasions when it was necessary to spend several days away from the campus, Mr. Billingsley and his associates usually bedded down at one of the small hotels in the communitÂ¥. Those who had been with him on at least one other safari were reluctant bedfellows, even to the pOint of refusing to occupy the same room with him. His snoring was devastating and awesome. Earlier in his life he had suffered a nose injury which, like a defective reed, gave a particularly distinctive quality to his slumbers. Mr. Billingsley was stricken in his classroom in the fall of 1912 and was carried in a buggy to his quarters in the Miles Hotel near the square. He passed away shortly thereafter. He was fond of Prince Albert cutaways, and a new one was delivere,d to him just two days prior to his death. This became part of his burial raiment. Staffing The School â€¢ 41 Logan Gillentine" instructor in English, was a quiet, unassumÂ­ing man from Lafayette, Tennessee, where he had served as Superintendent of Schools. Like Jones and Billingsley, he was a graduate of Burritt College, but in addition he had secured further training at Nashville Bible School, at the University of Tennessee, and at Columbia University. He received his master's degree from the latter institution in the spring of 1911 . His instruction was creditable, but he was somewhat eclipsed by his wife, who graduated from the Normal in 1913, served as critic teacher at the Model School, and in 1919 became instnlCtor in the education department. An aggressive, intelligent woman, she became the scourge of the carefree, unsuspecting students who wandered casually into her courses. Her patriotic and genealogiÂ­cal penchants truly warranted her designation as Â«Mrs. D.A.R." Mr. Gillentine quietly retired from the scene in 1917 and returned to his work with public schools. The Tennessee State Board Min,utes of January 18, 1911, listed W. E. Miller as dean and instructor in history. Miller did not report for duty, and the deanship remained in a nebulous state for two or three years. The duties usually ascribed to this office evolved on the Committee on Advanced Credits composed of Robert White, "Arch" Belcher, and P. A. Lyon. Actually the first dean of faculty wô€†·ô‹³s ô€‚Šôˆ¨ a handsome Latin scholar from Peabody College by the name 6f Eugene Tavenner. His appearance on the campus in January of the first year was something of a surprise to the President since he' Â·had not received notification of the election from the Board. Based on Board Minutes, Tavenner had been strongly recomme"nded by Board member Andrew L. Todd and subsequently added to the Normal faculty. Jones, a State Commissioner ' of Education turned President, and Todd, a very good politician turned school patriarch, had been bosom friends during the trying legislative battles and ordeals of plant copÂ­struction. Whether this incident was the beginning of the "coolÂ­ing- off" of relations befween the two fine men is a matter of

Tavenner's talents were not confined to the classroom, for he was in great demand as a speaker in churches and civic organizaÂ­tions in the area. Also, he played the cello on a near professional level. He was away from the campus on several occasions for extended periods while pursuing his doctorate at Columbia UniÂ­versity. His degree, conferred in 1914, carried the rather auspiciÂ­ous dissertation topic, "Roman Magic," a magnification of an obscure tr'}il in Latin. This mystical and detached subject was obviously in keeping with the pattern of the day set for research at this ' level of education. Tavenner is listed as dean in the December Bulletin of 1912, but the title bore no professional fruitage un 'til two years later. Dr. Tavenner resigned from the Normal in 1917 to accept a position in the department of languÂ­ages at Washington University in St. Louis, :Missouri. Here he remained until retirement as Emeritus Profô€†¸ô‹¡³ssor of Latin in 1947. In 1961 he was listed as a resident of Shoreacres, Booth Bay, Maine. Jeanette Moore King, instructor in physical training, was one of the unique personalities on the first faculty because, likô€†¹ô‹¤ President Jones, she was definitely a pioneer in Tennessee educaÂ­tion. In 1887, without any professional training, she began her teaching career on the Pima Indian Reservation in Socaton, Arizona. Two years later she entered the University of Nashville, where she had the distinction of being the first woman admitted to a course in general biology. Later she was one of the first women receiving a B. S. degree from the same school. In 1899 she was elected to the superintendency of schools in Rutherford County, Tennessee. Records indicate that she was the first member of her sex to assume a county superintendency, in the state. Her tenure was not without considerable activity, for in 1899 under the auspices of the Public School Officers she Staffing The School â€¢ 43 drafted a resolution requesting that a high school be located in every county. This was favorably received, in sentiment at least, by the Legislature. Just prior to her Normal years, she was director of physical training at Peabody College of the U niÂ­versity of Nashville. At the Normal Miss King introduced many strange new games and gymnastics in the improvised gymnasium located in the west wing of the administration building. Until A. B. Miles was employed, she directed all physical activities for both male and female students in the Model, high school, and Normal departÂ­ments. Not only did she direct, but she actively participated in the exercises and group games required of the students. This more than pa \ ssive involvement in her consuming interest in health and physical education probably aided her in retaining unusual vigor throughout most of her long life. She was the first instructor at a state normal to introduce classes in personal hygiene, social hygiene, sex biology, and community sanitation. Through her efforts during the fall of 1912 in securing fifteen nondescript uniforms, the Normal "fielded" its first football team. In 1922, Miss King resigned and again became the SuperinÂ­tendent of Schools In Rutherford County, thereby becoming the second member of her sex to serve as a county superintendent in the state. , . Katherine Monohan, with a master of arts from Peabody Normal, remained with the institution until her retirement on September " 1, 1945, thirty-four years after its opening. Prior to her initial year at the Normal she had been". a member of the Knoxville High School faculty for sixteen years. During the alÂ­most three and one-half decades as teacher of American history she became one of the most beloved teachers on the campus. Her great and lasting love for Andrew Jackson gave all of hel' classes, regardless of the century or topic at hand, a distinct Â«Old Hickory" flavor. Rarely a class period passed that Jackson's name was not a conversation piece, which is somewhat reminisÂ­cent of "Grandson Billy" in Dr. C. D. Lewis' education classes during the thirties. Miss Monohan's warmth and love for her fledgling historians frequently dimmed her powers of discrimination between stnÂ­dent sincerity and hoax. As a result there were always an impervious few who exploited this to considerable advantage. This story is illustrative. One day during the spring of 1927, Miss Monohan was experiencing some difficulty in creating what she regarded as the proper interest in one of her history Stafing The School â€¢ 45 classes. She was particularly irritated by the ad libbing conÂ­tributed by a senior boy from Sumner County. Finally, in one of her rare moments of disgust, she asked the boy to leave her class. With a martyred air he marched from the room, went to his quarters in Jones Hall, and after providing himself with an empty suitcase was soon standing in the doorway of Miss Monohan's classroom. What she saw when she discovered his presence there would ' have done credit to a Barrymore. Miss Monohan was impressed, for she came to the door and after thoroughly surveying him asked, "What's wrong, Jurd?" "I came by to tell you goodbye, Miss Monohan." "Goodbye? That's nice, just like my boys, but where are you going?" , ''I'm going home to see my folks and then I'm enlisting in the army." "Enlisting in the army? Who ever heard of such a thing?" "Yes ma'am. I had to leave your class. I can't graduate without history. I can't face the disgrace and the army is the best way out." Just after he said goodbye and turned to.-leave, Miss :Monohan caught him by the arm and almost forcibly escorted him to his old seat. She spent the remainder of the class period lecturing him and the others . o! the class on the virtues of completing the race once begun. Some of the class members even testified that the prodigal was promised a "B" if he would forego hIs military plans. Incidentally, this same student ran afoul of. Frank Faulkinberry, coach a'nd Jones Hall supervisor, later during the same year. Faulkinberry occupied a dormitory apartment on the first floor. , About 12 :30 one night he was aroused by an exceptionally loud and penetrating noise. As he listened he soon discovered that some rural boy was practicing the art of hog calling. He bounded out of bed and up the stairway to thô€Šôˆ´ second floor. Since dormiô€ŠŽôˆ¹¯ory supervisors were wise in t4e knowÂ­ledge of trouble spots, he went directly to a particular room

" "Yeh, but I didn't think they'd get here this quick," came the reply. Immediately the light was switched on, and there framed in the doorway was the massive figure of the coach. Student tenants of that day still swear that, before the thorough redecoration of Jones Hall many years later, there were deep ind entations in the plaster where Jurd tried to climb the west wall . . During Miss Monohan's years as a member of the faculty she resided on the campus, first at the Women's Donitory (later Rutledge ) and then at Lyon Hall. Shortly before she reached retirement" the girls on the campus honored her each year with a birthday party. On November 21, 1941, one hundred and fifty students gathered in her honor at Lyon Hall in recognition of her thirty years of service. It is recorded that among the activities of the evening were renditions of the songs: "When Irish Eyes Are Smiling," "Danny," and ''I'll Take You Home Again, KathÂ­leen," concluded by the honoree's favorite, "Blest Be the Tie." Verd Peterson, instructor in agriculture, came to th e N omiM from the State Normal School at Glenville, West Virginia. He replaced E. L. Davis, who resigned from the new school one month after its opening. Strangely enough, Peterson's first degree was based on a classical course, and he served as teacher and superintendent in various schools in West Virginia before his interest turned to agriculture. He graduated from West Virginia University with an A. B. in education, agriculture, and related sciences, in 1910. Of a diminutive stature and slightly crippled, he was anything but the prototype of the rugged outdoorsman usually associated with agricultural pursuits. Y yt his subsequent activities in organizing a very creditable farm and instructional program eliminated any doubt as to the energy and Staffing The School â€¢ 47 resourcefulness sorely needed by the new institution. His experiÂ­ence in demonstration work with farmers in West Virginia prompted him to organize a unique garden program at the Nonnal. In this program students in agriculture and science were assigned small plots to cultivate for scientific experimental purposes. Vegetables and fnlits that surV ived the young NonnalÂ­ites were used by the school cafeteria. Professor Peterson im plemented the landscaping scheme set up by Dr. Charles Heffer from the University of Tennessee. Peterson's classes scoured the wooded areas skirting the N onnal property for trees and flowering shrubs. Much of the older growth at the close of the first half century may be attributed to the energy of the early agriculture department. To speak in mere words-'pregnant though they be with meaning, fraught with significance-to set in living tongues a testimonial to the immortal memory of man, of any man-shall that be all? . . . What man crowds into this short space of time is his memorial. That humanity may pause and ponder and speak of him-not in hollow atÂ­tributes, in meaningless praise-but may say of him: ' He was given unto earth and went his way in righteousness; he gave of the fruits of his labor to the distressed, befriended the helpless, and the warmth and the fullness of his heart sheltered the dispirited and the lonely' . . . Three other faculty members were listed, but these appear to have made very little imprint on the early life of the institution since they faded from the faculty roster before the close of the first year. Weesie Griffith, supervisor of art and drawi ng, remained until the close of the second quarter, and Mrs. L. M. Russell left shortly before comÂ­mencement week. Mrs. Russell had made an exceptional record as a teacher in the Chattanooga schools and, in fact, was employed during R. L. Jones' administration in the city. Bettie Avent Murfree was employed as librarian in the spring of 1912 and for one year doubled as librarian and assistant bursar. In the fall of 1912 she became full-time librarian. Filling the eight double-tiered shelves in the large room on the third floor was a monumental task. The announcement in the bulletin of June, 1912, that "The library consists at present of about two thousand volumes, exclusive of pamphlets, all carefully selected to meet the actual needs of the students," is a classic overstate ment of promotion. An' examination of the accession list indicates that the bulk of the "carefully s"e lected" volumes were out-ofÂ­date textbooks and others that- would serve the same inteIIectuaJ purpose in the attics from which they came. Miss Murfree, with patience and dogged determination, devised many' unique methÂ­ods to acquire ,new and attractive books. In 1925 the library, in a new building of its own, had expanded . to sixteen thousand volumes. Miss Murfree's significant contribution to the instituÂ­tion was recognized when her name was given to this building in 1957 upon the completion of the new Andrew Todd Memorial Library.
