oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 50 â€¢ The First Fifty Years Horace Grady Jones, only son of the President, was not listed as a member of the first professional staff although he served as secretary, or more correctly bursar, for one year. In addition to this duty, he performed many tasks necessary to the opening of the school. He assisted in preparing the first bulletin and in the recruitment of students. The hitch barn, located at the site of the present athletic field, was his design as was the library shelving, an ingenious double-deck arrangement to conÂ­serve space. After the first year he left the Normal, was a surÂ­veyor for a time, attended Vanderbilt University for three years, and then taught automobile mechanics at the University of TenÂ­nessee. In' 1921 he returned as an instructor at the Normal, his pdncipal role during the next two years being the co-ordinator of a rehabilitation program for disabled veterans. In addition to the respect in' which he was held as a mathematics teacher, his contributions to athletics during the years ahead were most noteworthy. He probably had no parallel in recruiting talent for the athletic teams. The records of the teams of the mid-thirties stand as striking evidence of his successful sô€†¼ô‹±¬lesmanship. \lVhen football play was moved from the old field just east of the science building to the present site, the new area by popular usage became known as Jones Field in recognition of Horaô€†½ô‹µ¥e J ones' tireless efforts in the improvement of athletic facilities. It was never officially dedicated and many persons have enÂ· oneÂ­ously attributed the designation as honoring the first president of the school. It appears that the professional training possessed by the faculty was fairly adequate and comparable to the two-year normal faculty preparation of the day. It also appears that the state was very fortunate in obtaining that amount of experience and training at the salaries set by the Board. The average salary was slightly over sixteen hundred dollars with the ceiling of $1800 and a floor of $1000. One faculty member had an earned doctorate; seven, master's; three, bachelor of arts; one bachelor Staffing The School â€¢ 51 of science; four undesignated. The number of degrees and extent of professional training may be misleading when the names and types of institutions granting a portion of these degrees are examined, i.e., Winchester Normal, Burritt College. Without question, this first faculty was by far the best qualified of the three faculties at the state normals. The reason for this probably resides in the strategic position the President occupied just prior to his assumption of the Murfreesboro job. When the normals were created early in 1909 by the General Education Bill, a steady flow of teaching applications were unleashed. All of these came to the Superintendent's desk. Those close to him during that year frankly state that he sifted all of them and carefully selected and reserved the most attractive for Middle Tennessee Normal. Prospective instructors recommended to the Board in November of 1910 were of his own choice. In the main, those selected during the early months of 1911 were balustraded by political support, not the least being given by Andrew L. Todd. Of this faculty, two died while in the service of the instituÂ­tion; one later became President; ten resigned before teachers college status was attained, and three remained until the age of compulsory retirement. At the close of the first fifty years, two of these, Tommie Reynolds and E. Mai Saunders, arô€†¾ô‹¸ still living. Four of the facultY -'members who resigned are also living. They are Robert White, -Eugene Tavenner, Jeannette Moore King, and Margaret Webber Trevathan.

THE DEDICATION On September 11, 1911, the weather was excellent. FortunateÂ­ly the road was not the quagmire it resembled later during the winter months. Occupants of the buggies and carriages suffered little inconvenience other than from the enveloping clouds of dust that hung over the campus. Occasionally an automobile was interspersed in the long line of horse-drawn vehicles entering the main entrance on the Normal Boulevard. This was the day, September 11, for the dedicatory exercises, and citizens of the town came in large numbers to fill the auditorium in the main building. Many out-of-town visitors, as well as state officials, were among those present. Most of the audience stood since the opera chairs had not arrived, and a few cane-bottomed chairs accommodated the aged and the more imÂ­portant dignitaries. The initial number on the program was "America," which was sung "with zeal and fervor" by the audience, after which the inÂ­vocation was delivered by Reverend Mr. Gibbs of Murfreesboro. President R. L. Jones then introduced the Mayor of the city, G. B. Giltner, who . made the presentation speech for MurfreesÂ­boro. He was followed by A. L. Todd, who spoke for the counÂ­ty. At the conclusioI?- pf Mr. Todd's remarks, two musical numÂ­bers were rendered bi 'the students of Tennessee College. State Superintendent of fnstruCt.ion Brister accepted the N orÂ­mal plant on behalf of the State of Tennessee. His theme was a plea for practical education, and his remarks in part are as follows : The real test is whether or not you have any common sense when you get out of school and come to take your place in the rank and file of the masses. Brister of Tennessee arose to make his report on Tennessee schools at the Southern Association educational meeting in Houston, Texas, in 1911, he noted with some pride that: The most significant evidence of educational progress durÂ­ing the past year in Tennessee had been the actual beginÂ­ning of two state normal schools, one in the eastern section of the state, the other in middle Tennessee. Both schools opened with a gratifying attendance, which has steadily and satisfactorily increased. In 1911, at the time Middle Tennessee State Normal School officially operied its doors there were mixed feelings in the country as to the efficacy of a. normal program. There were doubts "in the minds of many that normal instruction, under the two-year plan, was adequate and would accomplish the high obÂ­jectives for which it was initiated. Criticisms emanated from many sources. The most sharply accentuated attacks came from university schools of education and from liberal arts colleges . The focal point of dissatisfaction was largely concerned with the preponderance of methodology and "tricks of the trade" apÂ­proaches, found in the normal curriculum, and a "studied avoidÂ­ance of academic scp.qlarship ." Possibly the origin of these critiÂ­cisms lay in the potential threat of the two-year institutions to student recruitment and revenue. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 58 â€¢ The First Fifty Years catalogues and occasional promotional literature. There. were some dead center hits, some near misses, and some that never quite touched any of the surface on the bull's eye. However, the adversities and failures cannot be directly attributed to the PresiÂ­dent and his staff. Bob White, first faculty member and now, fifty years later, State Historian, regards Jones as one of TennesÂ­see's greatest state superintendents. His organizational ability, zeal, and great practical experience were brought in full bloom to the Normal. Mistakes were as natural as the early awkward explorations of a youngster. The organization of the curriculum of the Normal is given in detail in the next few pages. It presents a :rather good picture of the typical normal program of the era. It 'remained basically constant during the next fourteen years deÂ­spite several sharp modifications as the institution gradually evolved info teachers' college status. The purpose of the school was clearly defined in the General Education Law of 1909. This was declared to be "for the educaÂ­tion and professional training of teachers for the public schools of the state." This is more clearly defined in the specific purÂ­poses set forth in the first publication: 1. It is a special professional school for the training of teachers . "ô€„žô¸ô€„Ÿô¼ 2. It attempts to confer on those that attend it the educaÂ­tion, discipline, training and skill which will best prepare individuals for teaching in the public schools of TennesÂ­see. 3. It admits no student who does not come for the specific purpose of preparing to teach, and who does not agree to sign a pledge to teach in the public and private schools of the state of Tennessee, within the next six years after leaving the school, at least as long as he or she has atÂ­tended the school. 4. It recognizes the three principles of thorough scholarÂ­ship, study of education as a science, and practice in Early Normal Years â€¢ 59 teaching under expert supervision. For admission to the Middle Tennessee State Normal School, graduation from an approved high school of the first class, or equivalent scholarship, was required. Certain interpretations and considerations were given to transfer credits, but no degree was granted unless at least one year had been spent in residence at the institution. Five principal directives regulated admission : 1. It shall be open and free alike to white male and female residents of the State of Tennessee, but no person should be admitted who is under sixteen years of age and who has not finished at least the elementary school course preÂ­scribed for the public schools of the state. 2. Moral character-applicants for admission must present a certificate of good moral character from some responsible person. No one should think of becoming a teacher, and the State is under obligations for the professional training of none, who is not qualified to exert a wholesome spiritÂ­ual influence upon the lives of children. 3. Health-no applicant will be admitted who cannot furÂ­nish evidence of being strong physically, and free from chronic defects that would prevent satisfactory work as a student, or militate against success as a teacher. The reÂ­quirements of ô€…–ô…™¨hô€‚Šôˆ©¥e school room upon the physical endurÂ­ance of the teacher are great, and no one of feeble phyÂ­sique should seek to enter the profession. 4. Facilities are free ' to all Tennessee students . There are no ô€€¬ô‚°®. tuition charges, and the only fee collected is a registraÂ­tion fee of. two do llars for each term. Out-of-state stuÂ­dents arô€…—ô…œ charged a tuition fee of twelve dollars a term, in addition to the regular registration fee. 5. Scholastic requirements-for admission to the Academic Course the applicant must have finished at least the ele- , mentary public school course. Students who have ô€¹ô‡¥©inished high school courses of less than four years may be given , ô€†„ôˆ .

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 47
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 60 â€¢ Th.e First Fifty Years advanced credit, but not more than for two years. In the beginning, and for several years, the Middle Tennessee State Normal School operated a high school of four years and a normal of two years. The high school department was desigÂ­nated in the literature as the Academic Course. Purposes underÂ­lying an arrangement of this kind were to prepare teachers for elementary schools. The Academic Course was spread over a fourÂ­year period, each year operating for thirty-six weeks. At the completion of the course a certificate was issued to the student, and this served as a license to teach without examination in any public elementary school in Tennessee. Also, successful compleÂ­tion of these four years established eligibility for entrance into the N;ormal Course in any of the state normal schools. The minimum requirements for the completion of the Academic Course were 212 credits of which 164 were prescribed and 48 electives. SubÂ­jects were arranged in four categories and designated under the headings of "Prescribed Studies and Electives." In the program of preparing the students for the elementary classrooms of the state emphasis embraced four principal areas. Prescription required thirty-nine credits in English, thirty-seven in social studies, thirty-three in mathematics, and thirty-two in education. The remaining twenty-three prescribed credits ;were distributed among music, physical training, art, and science. Two methods courses and an abbreviated practice teaching requireÂ­ment were the extent of methodology. Other requirements in education were primarily those presenting broad overviews. It must be kept in mind that the Academic Course was faced with obligations : ( 1 ) to provide a high school education, and ( 2 ) at the same time to direct emphasis toward elementary teaching. Since many of the recipients of academic certificates left at the close of four years, the challenge of the situation was quite eviÂ­dent. The other department of the Middle Tennessee Normal School was that concerned with the two-year normal, commonly refer- Early Normal Years â€¢ 61 red to as the Normal Course. This was divided into two periods of thirty-six weeks each. Those eligible for admission to this deÂ­partment were graduates of the first-class certified high schools, city high schools approved by the State High School Inspector, or of the Academic Course of any of the state normals. The comÂ­pletion of the Normal Course entitled the student to a diploma with the equivalency of a life certificate to teach in any of the public schools of the state. Ninety credits were required, of which thirty-five were prescribed and fifty-five elective. PreÂ­scribed courses for the first year, or more correctly the Junior Normal, included general psychology, pedagogy, principles of education, practice teaching, reading, and speaking. One of the courses in speaking had the picturesque title of "Pantomimic Training." Its description is contained in the following language taken from promotional literature: In training the body, exercises are given for poise, freeÂ­dom and use. The two aims of this training are to secure normal adjustment of all the parts, and to fit the body as an agent of expression. Senior Normal courses were educational psychology, school adÂ­ministration, school sanitation, practice teaching, reading, and speaking. The student could choose from among thirty-nine electives in the areaô€…˜ô… 9f education, English, history, mathematics, science, languages, manual traning, and agriculture. The Normal Course was much more compartmentalized than the Academic Course. Comparatively' more education courses were required in the two-year period. Also, ' electives were restricted primarily to a choice from two departments. For example, if a student elected English and Il)athematics during the first year, this pattern was followed during the second year. In this manner at least thirtyÂ­six hours of credit were earned. Any additional courses were chosen from not more than two other areas. This was an evideô€…™ô…¥´t attempt to promote and provide the initial efforts at area conÂ­centration and certification in Tennessee. , "' ,

An indiÂ­vidual with one year of successful teaching experience, as certiÂ­fied by a city or county superintendent of schools and a chairÂ­man of the board of education, could attend at least one normal summer term and receive a license to teach for one year. Of course, renewal of this license was contingent on attendance at a subsequent term, usually a summer session. Because of this arÂ­rangement the summer term was the most popular for a number of years and was attended by the largest number of students. H. Clark. The types of committees listed here are, of course, run-of-theÂ­mill. The most significant aspect was that they were very active. President Jones was one of those rare administrators, unique for Early N onal Years â€¢ 63 this early period, who delegated considerable authority with a high degree of success. Take for example the committee of AdÂ­vanced Credits. In the absence of a dean during the first two years, this committee received and processed all applications for entrance. This was no small task. "Lightning normals," referred to by Superintendent Brister in his dedicatory speech on SeptemÂ­ber 11, existed in many Middle Tennesse communities prior to the coming of the state normal school system. The General EduÂ­cation Bill of 1909 sounded the death knell for most of them. These institutions conferred some of the most unique, if not biÂ­zarre, degrees upon their graduating classes. Usually after severÂ­al years of teaching and because of the increasing demands for additional professional training, many of these degree holders presented themselves for admission at the Normal. Unravelling and evaluating these highly impressive documents were major undertakings. One of the most unusual degrees accompanied a mature lady from Macon County. She had graduated with full honors several years before from Pleasant Shade Academy, from which she had earned a B. O. Degree. After the committee members had regained their composure and requested an interpretation, it deÂ­veloped that "B. 0." represented Bachelor of Orthography. In addition, the lady volul.lteered to demonstrate her eligibility for the degree. This the committee very courteously declined. THE CAMPUS 'ô€Š­ôŠ´ô€„¦ô‚˜ The first years at Middle Tennessee State Normal School were filled with activity typical of a new institution. Buildings, staff, and curricula were fairly well established but these did not withÂ­in themselves create the collegiate atmosphere. This atmosphere was not too long in coming as the early N ormalites, aided and abetted by a few of the more sympathetic faculty members, beÂ­gan the gentle clamor for more than just class attendance and study in the library perched above the main building entrance. Equipment continued to move into the three new buildings. Campus roads had not been surfaced, and when the rains came vehicles sank to their axles. Approximately three hundred yards south of the little cluster of buildings, and on a slight undulation, Intentionally Left Blank

The water spilled over the Normal property onto the Boulevard. As a consequence the thoroughfare became impassable. Students walking to offÂ­campus dormitories and to private homes were transported across the stretch of water by farm wagons. This situation was aggraÂ­vated by the water that poured of the vegetation-free campus during a heavy rain. It was very descriptively designated "Lake Unnecessary" by students. On one occasion a brace of mules pulling a wagon along the inundated Boulevard slipped and fell, and before one of the animals could be extricated, it was drownÂ­ed. Furthermore, large pools of water remained for months and became the breeding spots for mosquitoes. These descended in great swarms on the dormitory students at night. It was said that standard equipment for every room included a supply of the popular repellent, "Skeeter-Scoot." During the latter part of the first year, Dr. Charles Heffer" Professor of Horticulture at the University of Tennessee, came to Murfreesboro and began a systematic landscaping scheme for the campus. He returned at intervals during the next few years and supervised further plantings and developments of a long-range plan. . In the first issue of The Signal, the warning was issued that "If other teams don't watch out, Old Nan's gain' to get their goat this year. Several of our old players are back." Home games were played in the cramped study hallÂ­gymnasium where there was little room for spectators or in the tiny gymnasium of the Anderson School for Boys on East Main Street. In 1913 it was announced that the basketball season had beeô€•Ÿ a failure due to the lack of encouragement from Â· the adÂ­ministration and faculty. Girls' basketball teams were organized during the early years under the direction of Miss Tommie ReyÂ­nolds, but no formal schedule was played due to the diminutive size Â· of the play area. Comp etition was principally confined to an intramural program. An infonnal football team was organized in 1912, the coachÂ­ing duties being assigned to a student by the name of Lee Ellis "Mutt" Weber. There was no record of any interschool compeÂ­tition. In 1913 A. B. Miles, Rutherford Countian, was empl6;ed as instructor in biology and physiology with coaching as a secÂ­ondary consideration. He had been an outstanding athlete in 1910 at Murfreesboro School for Boys on East Main Street and at its successor, Anderson School for Boys, in 1911. In 1912 he attend.;. ed the N onnal School of Physical Training in Battle Creek, Michigan, and upon the inistance of Andrew L. Todd returned to Murfreesboro as a member of the Nonnal faculty. Miles reÂ­mained as coach of all men's athletics until 1924, with the exÂ­ception of two years in military service during World War I. In 1924 he accepted a position as physical education director at Vanderbilt University . where he remained until his retirement in 1960. Three of his brothers, Casô€• ô†€ Andrew, and Kenneth, played Early Normal Years â€¢ 73 under his tutelage. At least three of his athletes, P. V. Â·'PuttyÂ·' Overall, Jess Neely and Rupert Smith, became Vanderbilt gridÂ­iron immortals after completing the two years at the N onnal. During his Murfreesboro days, "Putty" Overall was a hulking giant of two hundred and seventy-five pounds who required custom-made uniforms. Jess Neely, a brilliant half-back and a handsome man on the campus, is remembered for his popularity among members of the opposite sex and for an incident that ocÂ­curred just prior to a football game with Southern Presbyterian in Clarksville. Miles had done an exceptionally good job in menÂ­tally preparing his team for the game. He climaxed the pre-game, locker-room exhortation with a soaring call for courage and deathless allegiance to "dear 01' Normal." Neely was greatly afÂ­fected by the words of his coach for he leaped to his feet and, roaring like an angry bull, led the team in a rush to the doorÂ­way opening to the field. He misjudged the extremely low enÂ­trance, and his head received the full impact of the strip of wall above the doorway. He was revived shortly before the kickoff, ' but he never quite knew where he was, frequently huddling and aligning himself with the enemy. Upon the assUlnption of his duties, Coach Miles prepared the first interscholastic schedule. Teams played included MontgomÂ­ery Bell Academy. of Nashville, Bowen School of Nashville, FitzÂ­gerald and Clark of Tullahoma, Vanderbilt Reserves, VanderÂ­bilt Meds and Dents, Tate School of Shelbyville, Morgan School of Petersburg, and Hume-Fogg of Nashville. As can be surmised, "Pedagogues" did not inspire its inclusion in school yells as the rooters were conÂ­tent to use "Mid State, Mid State" or "Old Norm" in their sideÂ­lines chants . As in basketabll, there were numerous , complaints lodged against the administration and faculty for lack of supÂ­port. As in many other instances these were reflected in the pages of The Signal. The boys on the gridiron have won the applause and challenged the admiration of the townspeople who are all moved by the exhibition of courage of the highest type. Not only did the boys receive hardly any encouragement and but very little support, but the odds seemed against them in . almost every case. The faculty nearly turned its back and most of the student body lent a deaf ear. They were left tremendously alone. This apathetic attitude, charged against the school in general, arose from the fact that the faculty was wrestling with the acaÂ­demic problems of a new institution, and oply a small segment of the student body had any concept of team games as embodied in the major sports. Despite this negative atmosphere the sports editor of The Signal was able to report that this engendered little discouragement in the minds of the athletes for "so, eager were the first picked eleven for foreign blood that when the whistle blew for the beginning of real battle nose guards were masticated as though they were real dormitory biscuits." The first football banquet, served in the domestic service deÂ­partment, was in the fall of 1914. Professor Max Souby was toastmaster. The faculty became alarmed in 1915 by the poor academic efforts of the athletes. A faculty committee was inÂ­structed to prepare an athletic standard and report at a later meeting. In an effort to correct the difficulties the committee presented the following resolutions : , l. That as competitive athletics afford a wholesome form of activity and at the same time provide one of the cheapest Early Normal Years â€¢ 75 and best means of advertiSing the school the attitude of the faculty should be that of encouragement rather than discouragement. 2. That when a member of any athletic team is found to have failed in regular or special examinations of the curÂ­rent quarter in two subjects, or to have failed in one and to have been conditioned in one, or to have been conÂ­ditioned in one, or to have been conditioned in two subÂ­jects, or to have "cut" any examination without a valid excuse, the same shall constitute grounds for submitting to the faculty assembled the question as to whether he shall be allowed to remain on the team. If the majority of the faculty so decide, he shall be removed. 3. That when the general attitude of a student toward his work, or toward the school is found to be bad or his inÂ­fluence on the team or among the student body unwholeÂ­some, it shall constitute grounds for the faculty by a maÂ­jority vote to remove him from school entirely. 4. That there should be no discriminatior either in favor of or against a student on account of athletics. 5. That no student should be encouraged by anyone in auÂ­thority to come to school merely for the sake of athletics. Probably one of the memorable characters who came to the (campus almost simultaneously with the dedication of the new school was Ed Turner. He was employed as a janitor but douÂ­bled as 'the self-appointed trainer and water boy for the athletic teams. Previously he had operated an elevator for a large deÂ­partment store in Nashville and had gained some little local recognition as the "singing elevator boy." a'his sobriquet came from his habit of identifying each floor in his vertical runs with a musical description of the items marketed there. He brought this same light-hearted and personable spirit to the Normal and for the next thirty-two years until his retirement endeared hiriô€•£ô†¥elf to both faculty and "his boys." It is doubtful that during the first fifty years there was a water boy more fleet of foot than Ed. N early everything he did before an audience had the touch of the theatrical. At rest periods during football games, his agility and speed in moving wath the water bucket onto the field and returning to the sidelines always amazed the spectators. Later in 1922, when the new gymnasium was constructed, his half-time cleaning activitiies inevitably carried with them the elements of a production. With skull-cap and push broom he gave unforgetÂ­table performances. Baseball was initiated in the spring of 1912, and games were arranged with Cumberland, Montgomery Bell Academy, Vander- Early Normal Years â€¢ 77 bilt Reserves, and' Castle Heights. This first team did not have a field coach but was supervised by Professor Max Souby. Souby, along with colleagues Bob White and Pat Murphey, did much to stimulate interest in interschool athletics during this early period and to counteract the apathy of most of the other faculty members who had been trained in institutions void of athletic inclinations. Coach A. B. Miles introduced soccer in 1913 but discontinued the sport ô€•¤ô†‘¨hen no opposition could be found. Miss Jeannette King conducted a number of classes in physical training includÂ­ing gymnastic dancing, German ball, military exercises, and basÂ­ketball. President Jones was responSible for the construction of a number of tennis courts in particular deference to the dormiÂ­tory girls. On one occasion the faculty was challenged to a basÂ­ketball game by two organized Normal teams. It is recorded that the matter was discussed at length with the following results : 1. The ladies accepted the challenge provided no men be admitted to the performance. 2. The men rejected the challenge. THE SCHOOL COLORS AND THE ALMA MATER During the eady spring of 1912, President Jones appointed two faculty members and a student leader to bring to the faculty recommendations , for school colors. The two faculty members were Jeannette Modô€•¥ô†•¥e King and Tommie Reynolds, and the stuÂ­dent leader was Q. :M. Sinith. They met in the east cornel' firstÂ­floor room of the women1s dormitory and after considerable disÂ­cussion reached consensô€•¦ô†˜®.s on the two colors, blue and white. <", The committee pointed out in its report to the President that blue and white more nearly approximated the wearing apparel colors of the early Normal students and "school affiliation and spirit could be displayed in a more economical and practical manner." The committee further stated that school colors emÂ­bodied in every-day ,apparel could be purchased < across the counter in any general merchandise store. The 1913 football team

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 78 â€¢ The First Fifty Years carried the first blue and white motif. The school song, "Hail M.T.N.," had its nativity in the spring of 1912. At the inistence of E. Mai Saunders, music inÂ­structor, William J. McConnell of Cynemid, Pennsylvl;nia, wrote the lyric. The meter pattern was designed to accommodate an old Russian hymn composed by Peter Tschaikowsky. McConnell, popularly nicknamed the "Little Parson," came to Tennessee in 1911 to attend the theological school at the University of the South at Sewanee. Since the congregation of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Murfreesboro had no pastor, he came to MurfreesÂ­boro to sô€•§ô†²rve as the lay leader. He also enrolled at the Normal, became manager of the football team and a substantial member of the Glee Club. Later, McConnell served in World War I and died of pneumonia in an army camp. This song remained esÂ­sentitally ., the same through the years although the title evoluÂ­tionized with the successive designations of the institution. And the students at half century are still content with a one-stanza expression of their allegiance-that is, those who are familiar with the initial verse. N ear the close of the first fifty years, a sequel to the case of the song that was rarely learned and consequently, rarely sung, occurred during the planning for the Golden AIilliversaryô€•¨ô† TBe decision was reached that a new refrain of collegiate endearÂ­ment was needed. It was pointed out that "Hail, M.T.S.C., All Hail" had become so obscure in its rendition that it appeared principally on only three occasions during a given year, at the two convocations and at the annual alumni banquet. The obÂ­servation was made that Neil Wright, music department head at the half century, had made several noble attempts to convert the old Czarist hymn into an arrangement of popular appeal. These results of his efforts usually appeared near the close of May and August graduation exercises each year .. Traditionally, Mr. Wright was assigned the task of leading the assembly in singing the Alma Mater. After the last diploma Early Normal Years â€¢ 79 was awarded, Mr. Wright would emerge from the wings and proÂ­ceed to the microphone at the front center of the stage. On cue the audience would rise and then in silence would observe the skillful gyrations of the leader and listen to the rich baritone solo issuing forth from the overhead speakers. On some occaÂ­sions, the older faculty members would hum the tune, but the vast sea of "new" alumni to their front was content with the creditable rendition from the speaker's platform. At the song's conclusion, Mr. Wright, flashing a stage smile, would disappear into the wings. Here, during the few minutes of solitude and reÂ­flection afforded by the recessional, his resolve to provide a new Alma Mater must have been strengthened. Anyway, during the Golden Anniversary planning sessions he became Â· one of the most avid protagoniÂ§ts for a new college song. As a result, a contest for writing the lyric and melody for a replacement was initiated during the early months of 1960. By July of 1961, nineÂ­teen entries had been received. The composition expressing most appropriately and simply the sentiments due the institution was that submitted by Douglas Williams, class of 1953. The song and a brief biographical sketch of Mr. Williams appear elseÂ­where in this volume. It appears that there will be few objections to serving this traditional link wit}:! . the past. Yet, in the future if there is a gentle tremor pervading the convocation audience after ZyÂ­koski receives his diploma Â· and Â·if an unusually strong gust of wind whips over the student section on Homecoming afternoon, the origin may not be gifflcult to fathom. It may be the slightly irritated shade of "Little Parson" McConnell. Partakers of her board remember vividly the Satur-day noon menu of soup and mince pie. . At five minutes of eight in the morning the official bell ringer for the school appeared on the front steps of the I!-ain building and announced the beginning of classes. Glenn McBroom, ô€‡œô°¢":ô€•­ô†µ³stuÂ­dent from Woodbury, served as official custodian of the farge brass bell during the first three years of the Norma!. The bell was found resting on the front steps of the administration building the next morning-ready for McBroom. Campus excitement was rare and occasionally outside events served as emotional outlets. Such an event occurred on April 14, 1912, with the sinking of the Titanic in the North Sea. That eve- Early Normal Years â€¢ 81 ning a pall of gloom 'hung over the campus and the girls in . the dormitory congregated in the lobby and conversed about the matter until far into the night. Mrs. Harry Clark, the matron, and the faculty members who had quarters there were very . underÂ­standing. In fact, they were in the lobby, also. Campus life ended for all official purposes at Â· seven o'clock when all students were required to be in their rooms. Mai Saunders and her Glee Club or by other campus organizations. Claxton, United States Commissioner of Education. The Redpath Chautauqua came to the Normal during the summer months, ofÂ­fering many of the country's outstanding artists and lecturers inÂ­cluding William Jennings Bryan. The students of Middle Tennessee Normal School were deÂ­scribed by one reporter as "coming from the mountain districts, where progress is slow; from the fertile fields, where prosperity flourishes; and from the towns where opportunities abound." AnÂ­other; description averred "a general tendency of Normal School life is a youthful spirit. The ages of the students range from ( fOUlteen to fifty, but the disparity does not affect the unity of the student activities." A more poetic description appeared in a special edition of The Signal. Our 'boys are a strange heterogeneous mass, Conlposed of specimens of every class, Stalwart youths, bachelors old, and men"somewhat bald, In sizes, they are varied-some low and some quite tall. Each is marked by various and peculiar traits, But some are common to all, hte main one co?ceit. , But tho they are puzzling and their faults many, We'll strive to see the good in them, for there is plenty. The sentimental swains, with an amorous look, hard to conceal, Clamor for a 'campus course' and with natural beauties to deal, Beauties composed of eyes, brown, black and blue, Golden tresses, raven locks, and hearts both tried and true. These students engaged in debates with other normal schools, worked in the school garden, went on long hikes over the counÂ­tryside, studied the surrounding communities as laboratory work, made the two-mile trek to M urfrees boro and back, pulled the usual pranks in their dormitories, and found time to complain to the faculty on a few occasions. In fact, it was described as the characteristic feature of the institution. Echoes from the students' effOlts in the NI odel School were embodied in the article, "Trials of a Practice Teacher." When you become a teacher you must discard all ornaÂ­ments of Â· any kind. You must wear high neck dresses and long sleeve waists and look as much like an old maid school teacher as possible. A middy blouse is a thing of the past. You mllst be quiet and dignified. Never indulge in frivoliÂ­ties, such as theatricals, or ball games, but stay at home and write lesson plans. You must never laugh at anything funÂ­ny in class. If you .see anything funny hide your sense of Early N onnal Years â€¢ 85 humor and pass it on. A teacher can never admit that she doesn't know anything. If a child asks you to pronounce a word you have never seen before, tell him any old thing, he will never know the difference. If he asks you a question you could never answer, tell him you want the class to find .. out the answer for tomorrow. It is apparent that the initial years of the Normal were ones of comparatively easy adjustment. They were smooth functioning almost from the beginning, and the minimum of distress and troubles that followed was an indication of the organizational and leadership abilities of President Jones as well as the coopÂ­eraVve spô€•³ô‡²rit among members of the faculty. Perhaps only one . incident occurred during the early years that could be classified as being of a really serious nature. During the first year domiciliÂ­ary accommodations for a few boys were provided at the Kittrell hollse on East Main Street. When the Anderson School for Boys discontinued operation in the spring of 1912, the two stucco dor.Â­mitories, each capable of housing twenty-five boys, were rented by the Normal and were renamed Forrest and Craddock Halls. These buildings also were on Main Street but in closer proximity to the campus. Verd Peterson, the very capable instructor in agriÂ­culture, was charged with the supervision of the halls. His perÂ­sonal quarters we..r,e in Forrest. The boys soon discovered that Peterson was an excep_tionally kind man, perhaps' too kind and considerate to deaô€•´ô‡ sternly with fifty carefree young men away f.r0m home and fireside ... To complement his kindly nature he was further handicapptW by his diminutive size. The occupants of the two halls . disregarded most of the dormitory regulations and made general nuisances of themselves usually far into the night. Finally the scr(3eches and loud night sounds so. irritated the residents in the neighborhood that a petition Â· was circulated reÂ­questing that the lease be revoked. Since the school year was alÂ­most completed, J?reï¿½;ident Jones asked that the Â· peation . be held in abeyance and promised more rigid supervision for the follow- I ô€†‚ôˆˆ .

Some three days later White identified the leading culprits, five boys, and they were immediately encouraged to terminate their career at the Norma!' An interesting sequel to this occurred shortly thereÂ­after. ô€•µô‡•®ne of the boys, a very handsome young man, was a great favorite of several of the young ladies on the campus. That after- , noon White found twenty feminine N ormalites bearing petition, . waiting for him on the front steps of Forrest Hall. The petition attested to the outstanding character of the young man in quesÂ­tion and observed that he had made considerable improvement since the preceding year. Since at least one half of the petitioners were in their initial year at the Normal, White was not impressed; nor was President Jones when he was faced' with the same docuÂ­ment later in the day. During the next few years of the existence of Forrest and Craddock, residents in the area slept well at night and were not shocked by half-clad bathers flitting betô€•¶ô‡™¥een the halls and the heating-plant shower room in the rear. In iact, they came to regard this tiny male community as a model for any college dormitory program to emulate. Before taking a two years' course in the Nonnal, the average salary received by those who had taught prior to their attô€•¸ô‡¡®nding the N ornal, was $270 for the year. Q. M. Smith was class president. Eleven were recipients of Academic Certificates. THE FACULTY AT WORK Faculty meetings were held weekly under the direction of the President. A unique plan was followed in presenting issues of a controversial nature. The President assigned both sides of a probÂ­lem to faculty members, and at a later meetipg they were disÂ­cussed in the fomi. of a debate. A typical problem involving the use of this technique was that of the choice of a marking sysÂ­tem. The number and letter plans were each ' presented Â·by two faculty members. A lively discussion ensued, and it was evident!),. stimulating to . the staff, as were other discussions of this kind. Because of the frequency of the staff meetings a minutiae of detail were always on the agenda. Much time was given to the problem of delinquent students. At one session forthright action was taken by the appointment of a committee to recommend penalties. The report was presented at the next meeting. l. A student shall be given zero for his class standing for each unexcused absence. 2. The faculty shall decide in regular meeting what shall constitute an excused absence. 3. When a student shall miss recitations equal to one-fifth the number of the recitations in any subject for one ten, Early N annal Years â€¢ 89 he shall thereby fail in that subject. 4. In case of sickness or unavoidable absence the student may be relieved of the above penalty by a three-fourths vote of the faculty. 5. vV hen a student shall miss more than one-fifth of his recitations in any subject during a term, the same abÂ­sence being excused, he shall thereby forfeit his right to attend school and shall be sent home. Other business at various times concerned the cooperation needed between the Normal and Model School, a course of study, possibility of a yearbook publication, plans for Saturday classes, meeting students at the depot, providing a temporary gymnasiÂ­um , Miss Buchanan's remedial class in English, school gardens, appointment of students as county correspondents, and other detailed matters that kept the faculty in session sometimes until after dark. One noteworthy attempt was made by the President in the direction of in-service training. Twelve copies of Frank McMurray's report of the New York Commission on Public Schools, Elementary School Standards, were purchased and served as a basis for several faculty discussions. On another occasion the faculty launched a survey of two mid-state counties, a basin and a rim county, for the purpose of offering recommendations for improvements in .t1!ose areas. These surveys were to be unÂ­dertaken by faculty men1bers conducting institutes in the two counties selected. THE- SUMMER SCHOOL During the Normal years the summer school was the most popular program of the ô€•¹ô‡¥£chool. Teachers came in large numbers for refresher co,:!rses, certificate renewals, and to prepare for exÂ­aminations. The summer enrollment was conSiderably out of proÂ­portion to that of the regular school year, and facilities of the school were taxed during this period. Donnitory space was the. most pressing problem, aô€•ºô‡©¤d arrangements for sleeping quarters were made with Tennessee College, which did not operate a sum- "' ,

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 90 â€¢ The. First Fifty Years mer session. The rooms were described as : . . . furnished with the best iron beds, steel springs, solid felt mattresses, feather pillows, dresser, wash stand, wardrobe, table, straight chair, rocking chair, brussels drugget, and crockery. This institute was three quarters of a mile away and in easy walking distance. Also, many private homes provided lodging for the summer deluge. Summer students were issued the followÂ­ing instructions : Keep your trunk check until you reach Murfreesboro, where xou will be met by the Normal wagon. The man with the wagons will take your check and deliver your tnmk promptly for 25 cents. This will avoid delay and loss of your trunk. Look for the wagons with the large red platforms. Particular emphasis was placed on a program for renewal of elementary and high school certificates. Requirements for the eleÂ­mentary renewals specified that an applicant must pass a satisÂ­factory examination in all public school subjeqts required to be taught in the elementary school and, in addition, pass an examiÂ­nation upon two reading circle books. Courses were provided to assist the applicant in complying with the requirements. The exÂ­aminations for a license to teach in a high school of the first clas were departmental, were arranged by the High School Inspector, and approved by the State Board of Education in the areas of mathematics, English, history, Latin, science, and home ecoÂ­nomics. For the renewal of an elementary or secondary certifiÂ­cate, students were required to enroll in and successfully comÂ­plete not less than three courses. At one of these sessions the first course in library work was taught. The instructor was Mrs. Pearl Veeley, Director of Library Extension for the State of Tennessee. Instruction included seÂ­lection, care, and use of a school library and the direction of reading. Coterminous with the summer school program for teachers, Early Normal Years â€¢ 91 the county superintendents met in a summer conference. These superintendents published each summer an issue of a Normal bulletin that included news of the mid-state area and discussions of practical school problems. The annual summer appearance on the lecture platform of the Redpath Chautauqua and certain well-known state and national educators made the summer months at the Normal very eventful and frequently exciting.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: CHAPTER FIVE II r r r I 1- ,Â­,- r ,- r fL0ô€€“ôŒ¢" ô€‚’ô‰ˆ ô€µô‡” Growth and Transition By 1916, THE ENROLLMENT HAD CLIMBED TO 625, almost double that of the opening year. Bulletins of the period described in detail the improvement of facilities at this point. It was anÂ­nounced that a "large barn had been built for the farm stock and also a new hitch barn for the students who drive in to school each day." Always alert in preventing attempts to exploit femiÂ­nine frailties, the administration announced that two large houses belonging to Harrison and Ridley and located on the Normal 92 Growth and Transition â€¢ 93 Boulevard just opposite the women's dormitory had been rented for the accommodation of young women. Each house had faciliÂ­ties for thirty occupants. The boys were still with Bob White in the "elegant dOlTIlitories" on East ô€…–ô…˜±1ain. The very remarkable school garden program was in the full bloom of activity. By 1916, four acres of the Normal farm had been set aside for what was described as "plot work." This acreÂ­age was subdivided into one hundred and fifty units, each six by twenty-four feet, which served as the laboratory for the deÂ­partment of agriculture and biological sciences. Besides serving as a practical training ground, the school garden program furÂ­nished fresh vegetables for the dining hall. Promotional pictures of the period show well-dressed students, boys in coats and ties, scattered over the garden, and very busily applying themselves to the hoe. Harry Purple Ogden, who succeeded Verd Peterson in 1915 as insb'uctor in agriculture, is always pictured in the foreÂ­ground in his exaggerated supervisory stance. The same year a band had been organized under the diÂ­rection of H. B. Golden. With the ChOlUS, a stand-by since 1911, and a Saunderian Orchestra organized in 1914, the musical atÂ­mosphere had reached a new high by 1916. In 1917, the enrollÂ­ment dipped to 501, an ominous reflection of the beginning of the war years. . . tHE DUNLAP BILL Since the General Education Bill of 1909 which created thc system of normals for the state, the high school administrators. and those others gener:ï¿½)ly ' opposed to any additional company at the financial trough kept telescopic eyes fixed on the activities of the normals .. These individuals with some reservations acceptÂ­ed the two-year college program but regarded the attendant fourÂ­year high school combination as an illegitimate member of the educational family. During successive legislahlres there were sharp floor fights when b\lls carrying normal appropriatipns were introduced for discussion.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 94 â€¢ Tbe First Fifty Years One of the first concerted attempts to derail the normals came in the Legislature of 1917. This bill, known as House Bill No. 395, sponsored by N. A. Link, R. S. Brandon, J. R. Hart, H. T. V. Miller, and E. C. Norvell, was introduced in the Housô€‡ô´ on JanuÂ­ary 25, 1917, and passed first reading. The bill proposed to amend Chapter 234, Acts of 1909, whereby "$120,000 of the GenÂ­eral Education Fund be appropriated for the maintenance of the Normal Schools and the Tennessee Polytechnic Institute, proÂ­vided the State Board of Education is empowered to determine what part of said amount shall be appropriated to the several in-. stitutions;" Three days later the bill passed second reading and was referred to the Committee on Education. At this point, the presidents of the four institutions involved and other aroused educators sympathetic to the normals descended upon the CapiÂ­tol and aemanded a hearing before the Education Committee. This was granted and on the evening of January 30 one of the most violent sessions in the history of the House Chamber was held. Proponents of the bill, composed largely of elementary and high school supporters, were heard also. As the hour apÂ­proached midnight, the tension grew and raw tempers exploded. Just past midnight when the contending parties were virtually at each other's throats and when several persons, including the huge figure of R. L. Jones, had mounted the chairs and tables in the chamber, the Education Committee reSignedly terminated the session. Next day this committee recommended that the bill be rejected. This marked the end of that particular effort to cut the throats of the normals. It will be observed that only $120,000 was to be available for distribution among the three normal schools and T. P. I. If the money had been appropriated equally among the above schools, each of the institutions would have had only $30,000 on which to operate. This paltry allocation would not have paid the salaries of the instnlCtional staff at :Middle Tennessee State Normal. The real object of the bill was not all conveyed by its caption. Growth and Transition â€¢ 95 This particular legislative venture was popularly referred to as the "Dunlap Bill." Porter Dunlap, its avowed author, was State Treasurer under Governor Tom Rye. It was common knowledge that Dunlap had high gubernatorial aspirations and was exploitÂ­ing every opportunity to court popular approval. The Normal route appeared to be the course of least resistance, for it was easily accessible and led far into the depths of common prejuÂ­dice in the state. A pictorial expression by a contemporary carÂ­toonist who portrayed four large hogs crowding a prolifera of emaciated pigs from the trough indicated that Dunlap might have had a prejudicial vehicle made to order. The four instituÂ­tions were receiving one fourth of the education funds as stipuÂ­lated by the General Education Bill of 1909. There was eviÂ­dence of some popular support for the bill as indicated by ediÂ­torialists and Forum writers. This "Letter to the Editor," appearÂ­ing in the Nashville Banner on January 31, is somewhat typical: The bill introduced in the State Senate taking from the appropriations for the normal schools and giving same to the elementary schools will be hailed by every elementary teacher in the state . . . It should go further in giving the elementary schools the money now being given to the exÂ­amining and grading committee . . . Give the money being paid to the gradipg committee to the county superintendÂ­ents. County superintendents receive a salary and have very little to do. . Another letter, also laden' with the Normal allergy and written by a disturbed legislator, was printed in the Carthage Courier during the same month.<" 'Not encumbered with editorial deletions and corrections, it appeared to have had an unimpeded route from the author's hand to the pressroom. The fact that Dunlap failed in his effort to ascend to the Governor's office over the wreckage created by the House Bill 395, was a tribute to a vigorous and somewhat militant minority group led by R. L. Jones. Political pawns, from the beginning and for several years, the normals nevertheless grew stronger with each new victory. In referring to politics during the period, 1911- 1924, one of the principal actors observed : Â«These were the wooly days." FIRST CHANGE IN THE CURRICULUM . ô€‡ô€ The battles on Capitol Hill had very little noticeable effect on the equanimity of the Normal personnel, with perhaps the exception of President Jones. He returned from his victorious legislative campaign determined to remove as many as possible of the obstacles that blocked public acceptance of the institution. Despite the fact that the curriculum was somewhat top heavy with vocational courses, Jones had at least one answer to those who charged the Normal as being a Â«den of educational imÂ­practicality." As early as the spring of 1915 he had presented the idea of an industrial academic course to the faculty as a deÂ­bate item. In March of 1916, a committee was appointed to formulate plans for such a course. From the impetus gained Growth and Transit'ion â€¢ 97 from his experiences in Nashville he pressed the committee to complete its work for presentation to the State Board. As a result, in the fall of 1917 the first major change was made in the curriculum. This change was the first of several in the next few years of existence of the Normal School. The Academic and Normal Courses were retained, but special arrangements were made whereby teachers could enroll in a course entitled Â«Industrial Academic." It was designed to prepare teachers for elementary schools in the lu ral communities, and as did Â· the Academic Course it operated for a period of four years, of thirty-six weeks each. The student electing the Industrial AcaÂ­demic Course could do so at the completion of the second year of the Academic' Course. Prescribed courses indicated emphasis on the practical areas. Beginning with the third year the AcaÂ­demic student, wishing to pursue the Industrial Academic Course, was required to enroll in a series of courses which were predominantly those in manual training, sewing, and agriculture. This type of curriculum would certainly mitigate the criticisms leveled by the high school agitators. The original Academic Course had two purposes in mind. The first was to provide four years of high school work, terminating in a certificate tantamount to a secondary diploma. The second purpose, and by far the ô€Š°ô‹¯ost important, was to provide training for future elementary teachers of the state. By emphasis in the practical subjects, as represented by rural sanitation, home ecoÂ­nomics, manual training, ' an4 agriculture, the Indush'ial Aca- ô€†€ôˆ€®. demic Course deviated froï¿½;p the course offered prior to this time. In 1917 credit requirements were announced for the three courses of study at the normal. l. Academic Course-'-240 credits, of . which 171 are prescrib-ed, and . 69 elective. . . 2. Industrial Academic Course-240 credits, 191 preSCribed, 49 elective. ô€…¿ô‡¼ 3. Normal Course-120 credits, 53 prescribed, 17 conditional, , ... .

The State Legislature passed the following regulation in January of that year: After September 1, 1918, no person shall be permitted to enter the Normal Schools for the training of white teachers who has not completed the work of the first year of the course outlined for the county high schools of Tennessee by the State Board of Education and after September 1, 1919, no person shall be permitted to enter said Normal SdlOOls who has not completed the work of the second , year in said courses of study; provided that the teachers of 21 years of age shall be permitted to attend the State N or-mals as special students. An '" examination of state normals on a national basis revealed significant progress had been made, not only in upgrading speÂ­cific teacher-training institutions in extension of the original twoÂ­year course and elimination of high school departments, but in appropriations, library facilities, practice schools, and other adÂ­vancements . In at least twenty states in 1918, state normal schools required four years of high school work for adô€•»ô‡­©ission, ô€•¼ô‡°®.?d the private normal schools required four years of hIgh school wô€•½ô‡µ²rk for admission. The private normal schools were also tendmg to establish such a requirement. However, in some normal schools students were still taken from the eighth grade. vVORLD WAR I YEARS The campus felt the impact of the world war in small enrollÂ­ments, a paucity of male students, disruption of campus rouÂ­tines, and certain curricula changes. Assembly programs were slanted to the war theme. Instead of the popular numbers of the day including "Pretty Baby" and "Red, Red Rose," the Glee Club rendered such patriotic numbers as "America," "Star-Spangled Banner," and "Marseilles." At one of the assemblies Chancellor Kirkland of Vanderbilt University gave an address, "The War Growth and Transition â€¢ 99 Years as it Affec'ts Us." The sentiments that he expressed near the close of his remarks gave further impetus to the exodus to the battle front and war industries. You ask when the war will end. It may continue for one or five years. It depends upon you and every American as to when it will end. It will end when America makes it end by her ardor and strength. The worst failure of this war, from an American standpoint, is the fact that every AmerÂ­ican is not in it heart, soul, and body. There are some few who apparently have nothing in Gommon with our ideals. The spirit should not, must not, and will not prevail. Every man, wOI?an, and child has a part in this great undertakÂ­ing, which, if well done, will materially aid us in gaining victory. The four literary societies also contributed their share to maintaining the national fervor in that each gave a play dra-matically slanted to the war theme. , Social life and student organizations were curtailed considerÂ­ably because fuel was available only for the main building and for the most necessary meetings. Several of the student organiÂ­zations ceased to exist because no assembly point was available. It was explained on several occasions that The Signal was late reaching its readerô€•¾ô‡¸®. ,because business managers and editors enÂ­tered the service as i' apiô€´ô‡… ô€•¿ô‡½¹y as tJley were elected. Upon ;J1e demise of this organization, this slightly caustIc annomicement appeared on the hallway bulletin board of the main building: OBITUARY Died, Fall Term 1917, the Student Council. Floyd, who stepped into the gap left by Coadi Miles' enlistment in wartime Y.M.C.A. work, had been on the Normal team in 1914. He was a Rutherford Countian, havÂ­ing mab'iculated at Old Mooney School at Murfreesboro and vVinth,rop School in Nashville. After one year on Miles' team he had enrolled in Vanderbilt University and had spent the next two years, 1915 and 1916, on the Commodore eleven. An interÂ­esting incident had occurred at the beginning of the football seaÂ­son in 1915. The Normal's opening game had been with VanderÂ­bilt. When the Normal team arrived in Nashville, Floyd was on the Vanderbilt Campus but had not enrolled at the time, al.: though school had been in session at least one week. The innovations that served the athletic program so well durÂ­ing the war years apparently were not applicable to the campus newspaper, The Signal. That pulse-meter of student life in the spring of 1918 at the completion of its second issue, volume six, quietly and somewhat nobly closed its operations and sucÂ­cumbed. The struggle had been too consuming, for there had been a constant stream of editors and business managers flitting through its editorial offices on their way to the battlefield. Too, potential contributors had faded away or were too much en- Growth and Transition â€¢ 103 grossed in observing the antics of the military unit on the campus. Finance, ahvays a vexing problem in early publiÂ­cations, became almost non-existent. Editor Mary Margaret Reams, keeping in. tune with the affairs of the day, had this to say in her final editorial: vVe do not feel that this last issue of the Signal would be complete unless we gave some space to our soldier boys we could not locate. The highest count we have been able to make was two hundred and seventeen . . . A few days ago a group of students was looking at the enrollment for the past years, and it seemed that more often than not someone would say, 'That boy is in France,' or 'This one is in camp.' 'Ve miss them greatly in all our school activities yet we are proud that so many of our boys are following the Flag. Our Alma :Mater would not be so selfish as to wish them to reÂ­main here but instead, if need be, she will gladly give all her noble sons for the interests that today stand higher than any individual claim could ever stand. In the same editorial, Editor Reams departed from the patriÂ­otic theme and extolled the beauty of the campus. It had been further enhanced, she stated, by a student-faculty project of treeÂ­planting. In selecting our ô€–ƒôˆ²rô€–„ôˆ‘¥es we're not forgetful of the life which always centers itself 'wherever the trees are growing and waiting. We thought of the boys and girls, the birds and animals, and provided for all, not only in the beauty of .Â­form and joy of shade, but in the fruit as well. For the sweet singers we plaÂ£ted berry trees; for the woodpeckers and squirrels, nut; and for the boys and girls, the men and women, who in the future shall come to M.T.N. and make our loved Alma NIater their own, Tennessee's three favorites - Walnut, Hickorynut and Pecan. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 70
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1 04 â€¢ The First Fifty Years Reams. This unit, designated as the Student Army Training Corps under the directorship of Lieutenant L. C. Greenley, was established at the Normal in 1918. Instruction was given in military science and tactics. Courses were open to all young men eligible to admittance to the school, excepting those who had some physical defect that would render them unfit for military service. Military instruction was given coterminously with educational methodology in an effort to preÂ­pare soldiers as well as teachers for the years ahead. All students were supplied, without cost, their uniforms and necessary trainÂ­ing equiI?ment. Negative aspects of the war years and the effects of the oampus military unit on shIdent morale and morals were reÂ­called by Dr. J. E. Windrow, 1921 alumnus of the Normal : Thos"e were the vigorous days! Their like have not been seen on the campus since. A company of boys (perhaps two ), victims of war hysteria and the emotional insanity which had completely enveloped the country by the fall of 1918, came to the campus to mix army and student life. They didn't mix. It was hoped that they would be assimilatÂ­ed by the regular students and even tenor of old M.T.N. would go undisturbed. But, alas! This was not to be . . ToÂ­the utter chagrin and dismay of the administration, exactÂ­ly the opposite thing happened. The S.A.T.C. boys did the assimilating. It is doubtful if there has ever been a more deÂ­structive influence on the scholarly pursuits of students than those student army training corps foisted upon the American education institutions of 1918. As I look back and think of those boys, I am sure that under normal conditions, they would have been considered a very wholesome group. But not so in 1918. After all, there is something psychological in a khaki uniform, a Russian rifle, and $30.00 per month. Timid boys who had never inÂ­dulged in vigorous language were forced daily to utter vio- Growth and Transition â€¢ 105 lent words in order to secure and hold the respect of the "hard boiled." Every few days, familiar faces would be missing and tô€–ˆôˆ¡¥e rumor would follow that they were enroute to Fort Oglethorpe or Camp Jackson. I do not remember one essential fact that I learned in the classroom during those restless days from the middle of September to November 11, 1918, I have vivid memoÂ­ries of reveille, Lieutenants Greenley and Tuttle, and an old hard-boiled sergeant whose name escapes me, the bugler, squads right . . . and squads left, drill, drill, drill, digging ditches, and filling them up again, police duty, peeling potat<;>es because an ambitious corporal had to report someÂ­thing, the influenza epidemic, the Red Cross nurses, the race riots and general disturbances downtown precipitated by the boys detailed to keep order and peace. However, despite the difficulties experienced by the presence on the campus of the men in khaki, the Bulletin, restricted to only eight pages in November of 1918, stated preCisely that the regular courses were given as listed in the catalog, that the prime purpose of the instruction was the preparation of teachers for the schools of the state, and that "this function has not been lost sight of during the exigencies of war." _ .rIVE GOLD STARS In 1917 James Ridley of Murfreesboro was granted permission by Governor Rye to organi;l'e a Rutherford County machine gun company. Although the unit never reached its full complement, it was cited several times for meritorious service in overseas comÂ­bat. During the fighting in France, Ridley was awarded the Distinguished Service Cross and shortly thereafter was cited again with the addition of the oak cluster. CURRICULA CHANGES IN 1918 Curricula changes in 1918 embraced the following types .ô€„›ô¬ô€„œô° of courses : 1. Academic Course-a high school course of four years and requiring graduation from an elementary school. 2. One-year Academic Course-designed to give one year of teacher-training beyond the high school and similar to the normal course originally instituted. 3. The N onnal Course-designed to give two years of teacher-training beyond the high school and similar to the normal course originally instituted. 4. Vocational Course for Teachers and Supervisors of AgriÂ­culture- designed to prepare high school teachers for voÂ­cational agriculture and operating for a period of four Growth and Transition â€¢ 107 years. Requirements for admission included graduation from high school. 5. Vocational Course for Teachers and Supervisors of Home Economics-designed to prepare high school teachers for vocational home economics and operating for a period of four years. Requirements for admission included graduaÂ­tion from high school. The purposes of ( 4 ) and ( 5 ) were to prepare teachers and supervisors to meet the requirements for giving efficient instrucÂ­tion in vocational agriculture and vocational home economics as provided by the Smith-Hughes Act passed by the Congress of the United Slates, February 23, 1917. Graduates of these courses were permitted > to teach without examination in any vocational school in 'the United States established under the provisions of the act mentioned above. The importance of the two courses as seen by the authorities at the Normal was contained in the folÂ­lowing words : vVith the great world war depleting our country of its manpower and with our population steadily pouring into the city, it can readily be seen that the problem of food producÂ­tion and food conservation transcends in importance all other economic questiol1s. Upon completion of his vocational degree, he taught in the Smith-Hughes programs in secondary schools for some time. Later he entered foreign servÂ­ice and died in Burma some hventy years later. C. C. Cravens received his masters degree at the University of Wisconsin, taught agriculture at Martin, Tennessee, and at the time of his death was in a teaching assignment in Arkansas. Wade Rucker forsook his Normal training to enter dentistry practice in SanÂ­ford, Florida. Clifford Stark, one of the most aggressive of the seven, became professor of agriculture at Cornell University and a few yÂ¢ars before reaching the compulsory retirement age manÂ­dat ô€–‘ô‰…¤d by that university returned to his Alma Mater, which had then become Middle Tennessee State College. After three years as head of the department of agriculture, he accepted a two year assignment in India and upon its termination returned to the State College as a teacher, principally in the area of agriÂ­culture. Earl Morgan taught vocational agriculture in various Tennessee schools after graduation. After 1920 the courses beÂ­came nonexistent because of failure to meet certain requirements and because of pressures to transfer this type of program to the University of Tennessee. In 1919 a radical revision in the instructional program *as made. It is apparent from a study of curricula changes that the first significant deviation from the original plans of 1911 began in 1917 and continued in a state of flux until the transition to State Teachers College in 1925. In 1919 curricula designations of "Normal Course" and "Academic Course" were supplanted by several types of "Curriculum." At this time in compliance with the Legislative Act of 1917, providing for gradual elimination of the high school department, the revisions excluded all training accommodations for students with less than two years of high school work. In all there were six types of curricula. They were designated as the three-year certificate course, one-year certifiÂ­cate course, two-year certificate, three-year diploma course, four- Gl'owth and Transit ion â€¢ 109 year vocational diploma (agriculture ), and four-year diploma (home' economics ). In two of the curricula, the vocational courses, the Normal was in 1919 operating a four-year college. Its traditional teacher-training program had reached the three-year college level, with provision for two-year and one-year terminals. JONES LEAVES At the close of the war years and at the very height of instrucÂ­tional revisions in the Normal program, President Jones resigned his position and accepted the superintendency of city schools in Chattanooga. The explanation for this move has been cloaked in some, degree of secrecy and obscure generalizations. OutwardÂ­ly, the ,accept,ance of the more lucrative position was a logical one and was in a locale where he had spent many successful years as a teacher and administrator. Yet, in the position of presiÂ­dent of a collegiate institution there was an element of prestige, and the Normal had reached the stage of rapid growth and of inÂ­creaSing status in the realm of higher institutions. Also, through his efforts, primarily, the critical battles over appropriations had subsided immeasurably, and Tennessee had begun to accept rather cheerfully, in a relative sort of way, her obligations to teacher-education. The fact remains that 1918 saw the tumultous gubernatorial race between Albert ., H. Roberts and Austin Peay, both DemoÂ­crats. StimulaÂ­tion for this was due largely to the sharp pressure exerted by the American Association of Teachers Colleges. During this periÂ­od the universities had relaxed their critical attacks on the normal schools and were subtly advocating conversion of the two-year institutions into four-year teachers colleges. Increased university enrollments and inadequacies of the education deÂ­partments of these institutions to accommodate the great influx of teacher-trainees greatly accelerated this change of attitude. Also, during this period the secondary school movement gained Growth and Transition â€¢ 115 momentum. On Â·February 22, 1922, at its Chicago Convention, the aforeÂ­ mentioned accrediting association offered the following resoÂ­lution : Be it resolved by the American Association of Teachers Colleges that the recognized necessity of more adequate preparation of teachers of all grades of school work demands that all state teacher-training institutions should raise their standards to that of the standard teachers colleges, and offer bachelor's degrees. The essence of the slogan adopted by this association for the ensuing years ,was to encourage the movement of normal schools toward converting them to technical, vocational teachers colleges with adequate standards. In addition to the enthusiasm generated by the possibilities of collegiate status and the upgrading of curricular offerings, this period at the Normal, from 1920 to 1925, represented significant expansion of physical facilities. The building program was an acÂ­tivation of the Legislature's plans of 1917. In this case an editorial, appearing in the Nashville Tennessean in late August of 1922, bore the flamboyant title of "i\fan the Life Boats!" It was written by Albert Williams, imÂ­mediate past State Superintendent of Schools, an occasional editorial contributor to the Nashville newspaper, and later editor of the same publication. Williams, who had no love lost for the Republican administration, particularly since Brown had superÂ­seded him, leveled his very capable big guns at the preo'retained plans for the Normal. Writing in a biting, hyperbolic style, he pictured the administration as a doomed craft nearing a reef and its journey's end. The crew members, Taylor's political afÂ­filiates, were rushing precipitately for the life boats. Brown was one of the first crew members to scramble over the gunwhale. There was also reference to "rats leaving the sinking ship." Taylor, being a Republican in a Democratic domain and realÂ­izing that his successful election was due to his residue of popuÂ­larity left from a much earlier day, evidently anticipated the efÂ­fect of the editorial and did what he thought necessary to reÂ­coup the flagging fortunes of his administration. LAST DAYS OF THE NORMAL At the time of Lyon's ascendency, the student body had reached some maturity, relatively speaking. Although the specÂ­tacle of first graders marching down the hallways on their way to the playground remained, the high school was just a memory. ( The Normal students were older and they began to smart under the restrictions that served the earlier years of the institution. Too, tHere were battle-matured veterans on the campus, and Horace Grady Jones was at work with a group of disabled stuÂ­dents with service records. One unpopular regulation that became more onerous with time was the one relating to uptown movie attendance with dates. As late as 1924, young men called at the women's dormitory, lined up in pairs with their dates, and marched in what was usually a very long line to ' the theater. Faculty members took their turns in convoy duty or in acting as "Officer of the Day." Strict attention was given to eliminate lagging or breaking in ranks. The later Normal years recall the smallpox epidemic that swept the campus in the spring of 1921. The "Gray Cottage," the G. 1. Bock home, located on Normal Boulevard just across from the campus, was converted into an infirmary for stricken and conÂ­valeScing students. The school was placed under quarantine and accesses to the Boulevard were closed. Every available physician in Murfreesboro was brought to the campus dining room for a mass vaccination program. During the early days of smallpox vaccination the technique employed was that of the semi-butcher. While the senlm was Growth and Transition â€¢ 121 running its course, the result was awesome and enormous scars were left on the arms. The young ladies, conscious of the beauty impairment, took their immunizations in the lower limbs. There were no mortalities resulting from this rampaging epidemic alÂ­though there was a death during the same year in the girls' dorÂ­mitory. :Miss Pauline Alsup of College Grove passed away from the effects of a mastoid infection aggravated by influenza. In her memory a marker was erected on the campus in 1923 by the Y.W. C.A. This memorial is now located near a walkway midÂ­way between the Student Union Building and the Murfree BuildÂ­ing. Change in status meant a transition in nomenclature and an escape from the opprobrious connotations accumulated about the term "Normal." From the inception of the normal school movement, private secondary school people had been a bitter foe; universities looked with some disdain upon the two-year instituÂ­tion, and scholars regarded it as an utter retrenchment in scholÂ­arship. There were also many who were thoroughly convinced that the average normal student was anything but the embodi- 122 New Status: Teachers College â€¢ 123 ment implied by ' the term and that the faculty was substandard. Tô€”ô…‘¥e flight into a new category portended respect and also proÂ­VIded the oppOltunities to expand and experiment in a fourÂ­year framework. The American Association of Teachers Colleges, at its meeting at Washington, D.C., in 1925, presented and adopted the folÂ­lowing requirements for admission to four-year status : 1. The quantitative requirements for admission to a teachÂ­ers college accredited by this association shall be at least fifteen units of secondary school work, or the equivÂ­alent. These units must represent work done in a secondÂ­ary school approved by the state department of public instruction of the state in which the college is located. 2. Equivalence for entrance units of secondary school work shall be determined only by regularly scheduled written examinations. 3. Experience in teaching shall in no case be accepted for entrance, or credit toward graduation, except supervised ' student teaching in the b'aining school. To these entrance requirements was affixed the stipulation that graduation should be contingent upon the completion of 180 quarter hours of credit. The purpose ô€Š¸ô‹¡¦fô€Š¹ô‹¤ the teachers college is contained in the folÂ­lowing statement from the Yearbook of the American AssociaÂ­tion of Teachers Colleges published in 1925 : Stripped of the essentials, the task of the professional schools for teacheJs is to take the young, inexperienced men and women and give them the knowledge, skill, habits, ideals, al).d attitudes of mind that will enable them to teach the course that is laid down by the state, and to teach it with skill and effectiveness.
