oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 124 â€¢ The First Fifty Years GUIDELINES FOR ACTION In 1925 the Teachers College began its task of recognizing the various facets of a program to meet the demands for a new fourÂ­year institution. Although at this time there was no affiliation with an accrediting agency, the blueprint for expansion had been established by the American Association of Teachers ColÂ­leges. During this year ten procedures were enumerated and these were used somewhat as bases for construction of an adeÂ­quate and acceptable program. These were as follows : 1. Securing and developing an educational policy 2. :Securing a loyal constituency for the institution 3. Securing adequate financial support 4. Developing the faculty 5. Â£electing new faculty members 6. Developing a teachers college atmosphere 7. Organizing student activities 8. Directing and supervising athletics '. 9. Organizing and directing agencies of publicity 10. Placing graduates in suitable positions The attempt of the Middle Tennessee State Teachers College to develop in relation to the foregOing ten guidelines is des'cribed in the actions of the first few years. Fulfillment of all of its deÂ­sires and plans was handicapped by the economic depression that followed a few years thereafter and by certain internal disÂ­tresses that appeared shortly after emergence from the war-time financial chaos. Although remarkable progress was made during the period of the teachers college, from 1925 to 1943, it is pm;Â­sible that the results would have been considerably greater if conditions had been more conducive to educational growth. Although attainments of the ultimate of these ten preSCribed procedures were spread over the eighteen years of the teachers college era, special emphasis is given to the initial attempts to establish satisfactory status. New Status: Teachers College â€¢ 125 OF FIRST IMPORTANCE : THE CURRICULUM The first significant change, of course, was that involving the curriculum. Sh01tly after being informed of the Legislature's action, two new curricula were introduced. Change in the inÂ­structional program was nothing new to the facuIty. Since 1917, reorganization had occurred almost every year. It was announced in 1926 that only two new curricula would be offered. These curricula, designated as Curriculum A and Curriculum B, were concerned with preparation of elementary and high school teachers and were spread over a four-year period, thirty-six , weeks, leading to bachelor of science degrees. The institution, recovering from the first flush of collegiate status, underwent a new examination of its program in 1928. Although the appearÂ­ance in the catalog of two clearly delineated four-year proÂ­grams seemed very desirable and evoked prestige, it was evident that the program must be designed to suit more nearly the needs of the area. A great preponderancy of the constituency still, retained the "nonnal complex" and preferred to acquire only the minimum training required by state regulations. It was perÂ­ceived that a gradual upgrading of professional requirements was imperative. In 1928 revisions included four general courses of inÂ­struction: 1. A one-year cQurse, of three quarters, for those desiring the four-year profeSSional elementary certificate. 2. A two-year course,-'of six" quarters, for those desiring the permanent professional elementary certificate, or the fourÂ­year professioô€”¬ô‚±¡al high school certificate, good in high schools below the first class. 3. A four;-year course, of twelve quarters, for those preparing for work in the field of elementary education. 4. A four-year course, of twelve quarters, for, those preparÂ­ing for work in the field of secondary education. To expel a student on second offense. It is evident that the plan adopted by the faculty was not an honor system in the usual interpretation but was a disciplinary device administered wholly by the President and faculty. NUMBERS AND DEGREES During the fourteen years of the existence of the Normal School, 452 students had received degrees. These included two-year and New Status: Teachers College â€¢ 127 three-year diplomas: Including those who attended for purposes of attaining maximum training and those who came for short courses, there were scattered through the years, 1911-1925, 14,522 who affiliated themselves with the institution. The largest group was those who swarmed to the campus during the six weeks' summer program. This latter group came mainly for purÂ­poses of renewing certificates and preparing for state teachers' examinations. THE QUESTION OF FINANCE Historically, the officials and supporters of the state normal schools faced vexing appropriation problems at each meeting of the Legislature. During the interims the presidents usually exÂ­pended much of their energies contacting legislators and influÂ­ential individuals in the state in preparation for the biennial meeting. Various strategic devices were used to secure needed funds. R. L. Jones appeared to be a master at wheedling necesÂ­sary revenue to operate the Normal. In 1917, in an effort to reÂ­lieve the crowded conditions in the girls' dormitory where there were at least four girls to a room with a measles epidemic raging, and in order to relieve similar conditions in the boys dormitory, J ones suggested what appeared to be a unique plan. He prnÂ­posed that the State Legislature pass permissive legislation allowÂ­ing the three state l).opnals to issue $600,000 in bonds. The only obligation to be assumed by the state was to serve as security. These obligations would btY fifty 'year bonds at four per cent inÂ­terest. Revenue derived from this source would be used for proô€”¯ô‚¼ viding dormitory space:. J Olles proposed that the bonds be retired from room-rental funds. This particular plan did not have a faÂ­vorable reception in the Legislature of 1917, but it did serve as an impetus for an appropriation measure that exceeded considÂ­erably the request by Jones. The terms of this bill did not come to full fruition until 1922. In financial matters President Lyon proved to be a wQrthy sucÂ­cessor to the first president. The most critical needs of the in- "' .

IN SEARCH OF THE COLLEGIATE ATMOSPHERE The change in nomenclature exerted a tremendous psychologiÂ­cal effect on the students and upon those entering for ithe first time. The campus in Normal days had been a center of educaÂ­tional activities. With the coming of advanced status, there was increased activity in professional affairs. The annual superinÂ­tendents' conference became virtually permanent on the campus. Lecture series, replacing the old Chautauqua and Lyceum proÂ­grams, were extremely popular during the summer terms. Donald Davidson in the summer of 1927 gave four lectures on English and American literature. CHANGE IN STUDENT ACTIVITIES The institution had been satisfied for the first . fourteen years of its existence to concentrate its student activity programs in four literary societies. There were, as has been indicated, a few other organizations such as the Y.M.C.A. Attendance at the weekly meetings of these groups was on a compulsory basis once membership status was attained. Importance of these orÂ­ganizations, particularly the literary societies, may be gathered from the Faculty Minutes in which on several occasions poor scholarship and erratic society attendance were alluded to with equal disfavor. The Midlander, colÂ­lege yearbook, was first published in the spring of 1926. The Middle Tennessee State Teachers College had only one reference to teacher-placement in its early literature : POSITIONS FOR TEACHERS The school authorities of the state are looking to the Teacbers College for assistance in finding teachers. Judd, had part-time teaching duties, the function was for the first time centralized, and interested educational ofÂ­ficials knew whom to contact when coming to the campus. It appears that Middle Tennessee State Teachers College adÂ­justed to its new position without too many difficulties and handicaps. It is true that with more planning during the initial stage later perplexing problems would have been somewhat minimized. Only a few years of prosperity and growth were enÂ­joyed before the economic depression almost closed the doors of the institution and similar ones in the state. LULL BEFORE THE STORM On the morning of October 24, 1929, when President LyOll New Status: Teachers College â€¢ 135 fished out his newspaper from under the forsythia at the PresiÂ­dent's home, he read the ominous headlines that millions over the nation were reading or had read. Some of those who had read or had heard from the frenzied radio dispatches had already taken the route of the utterly demoralized. . The shots that rang out from the penthouses and suites fringÂ­mg Central Park near '\" all Street and the wails of the disÂ­franchised heard from across the breadth of the land were inÂ­dicative of a great national calamity at hand. The stock market, that great barometer of economic equilibrium, had collapsed. It is possible that if President Lyon had allowed his newsÂ­pap. ers to accumulate under the forsythia and had unplugged his radIO he would have remained oblivious, at least for a time, to the gathering economic storm in the distance. The Middle TenÂ­nessee State Teachers College approached and entered the deÂ­pression with a sphit of normalcy. It was announced to the faculty in 1930 that, by action of the State Legislature, the official title of the institution had been changed to State Teachers College, Murfreesboro, Tennessee, for clarity in identification. " In anticipation of an on-the-campus evaluation by the Amô€”¼ôƒ±²rÂ­ican Association of Teachers Colleges, President Lyon sought aid from a group under the direction of Dr. A. L. Crabb of George Peabody College for Teachers. This group visited the campus periodically during the fall quarter of 1930. All aspects of the college program were critically appraised, and a mimeographed eighty-three page report resulted. Although the timing of the recommendations approximated the coming of the associational visit to the campus, some needed adjustments were hurriedly made, and the report served as a guide for further improvements during the next few years. It is not the purpose here to summarize the ramifications of the report, but the identification of a few of the deficiencies New Status: Teachers College â€¢ 137 found by the visitiilg committee will indicate how badly se1Â£Â­study and improvement were needed. It was evident from the reÂ­port that the administration operated largely "by ear." For exÂ­ample, five persons were purchaSing for the college. These were the President, dean, business manager, farm manager and direcÂ­tor of the cafeteria. No discernible coordination existed among them, and the President must have been breathless with anticipaÂ­tion, if not hopefulnes s, near the close of each fiscal year. A recurÂ­ring theme pertaining to the distance separating the Training School from the campus proper was a point of emphasis. The visiÂ­tors were at a loss for a corrective measure other than the sugÂ­gestion of constructing a building nearer the heart of the campus traffi c. In lieu of this, since the college had descended slightly below ground level into the depression, construction of a good connecting walk was recommended along with a plea for systemÂ­atic intervisitation. Comments in respect to the library carried a gentle touch of the satiric: The committee commends the quiet atmosphere prevail- , ing in this building, but adds that this is partially due to its lack of use. It . was observed that the students could be found in four places when not in class : the steps of the adÂ­ministration building, the auditorium, the gymnasium, and the tennis courts. , There was sharp critiô€”½ôƒµ©ism directed toward campus housekeepÂ­ing practices and, in particular, "the boys' dormitory. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 89
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: CHAPTER SEVEN Troubled Years I t was in the fall of 1932 that State Teachers Colleô€–”ô‰»; beÂ­gan to realize the gravity of the economic conditions facing the state. Prior to that time appropriations were sufficient to elevate salary schedules to a level compatible with regulations of the two accrediting agencies of which it was a member. A rather extenÂ­sive building program had been initiated and almost completed. Enthusiasm had been generated among the faculty members because of further accreditation, and the future portended adÂ­ditional growth and significant achievement. The pinch of the times began to be reflected in the actions of the student body. Many of the students moved from the campus 140 Troubled Years â€¢ 141 and set up housekeepng in nearby rental houses. Here their reÂ­sources were pooled and turns were taken at cooking. AutomoÂ­biles became a rarity; therefore, as a result of the rather close confinement to the campus, several efforts to escape boredom were attempted. One of these appeared in the fall of 1931 in the fonn of a little "publication" entitled "The Devil's WorkÂ­shop." It was obviously intended to challenge the authority of the administration and to demand modification in some of the college rules. Its copy consisted of an attack on the President, several uncomplimentary allusions to certain members of the faculty, and a few limericks-with the faculty involved in the meter. There was only one "issue" with perhaps one or two supplements. A brief supplement was glued one night to the top of a table in the basement of the administration building. Administrative investigations began almost immediately, and many students were questioned by the diScipline committee. The hearings and investigations were concluded near Thanksgiving, , but the verdicts carrying expulsion for several students were not made known until the campus had been cleared for the Christmas holidays. There was Â· obviously some fear that the student body might be quite sympathetic with those dismissed. Since the financial status of state schools was precarious and since there was sptlculation as to whether they might have to close, this precauti6ô€–•ô‰•¬lary measure was employed. Anything reÂ­sembling a student revolt or "incident" would possibly have been a clinching argument fo! legislators who were already glancing hungrily at the teachô€––ô‰˜®.rs colleges. RETRENCH1VIENT BY C01VIMITTEE At the time of this display of discontent and other manifestaÂ­tions of unrest among the depression-conscious students, the State Board of Education heard a report from a special commitÂ­te composed of its members. The First Fifty Years In regard to departmental organization, the report specified that when there were two or more instructors in any one departÂ­ment, one of these instructors should be designated as head of the department. When there was only one instructor in a departÂ­ment, this instructor should be compensated as a member of the faculty and not as a department head. The education department felt the paring knife also. Credits allowed should not exceed eighteen quarter hours. The purpose inspiring this limitation was that of requiring students to obtain more credit in content courses. Turning from instruction, the report concerned itself with room rent, board, activity and laboratory fees, and the other Inore mundane aspects of the program. Room rent recommended was a uniform rate of $6 to $8 per student per month. As a preÂ­caution it stipulated that all receipts from room rent should be kept in a separate account and should be withdrawn only for payment of janitor service, heat, light, water, repairs on buildÂ­ings, replacements of furniture, fixtures, and maintenance of dormitories. Receipts from board were to be withdrawn only for the payment of the cost of maintenance and operation of cafeÂ­teria and dining hall. The Retrenchment Committee, apparently determined to cut an impartial swath, recommended a reduction of 16% per cent in all salaries of $1200 or more and a ten per cent reduction in all salaries of less than $1200. T1'oubled Years â€¢ 145 The length of the school was to be confined to a period of forty-two weeks. This plan retained this summer program of six weeks in length. An instructor-student ratio of one instructor to each twenty students was regarded as being adequate. Although these were the principal recommendations, there were 'Others replete with a similar pattern of instructions and exhortative deÂ­tail. The committee was not striving to impress the Board. This was unnecessary, for the Board members were already using every strategem known to them to convince legislators and their constituency that the schools were not a burden. Perhaps these recommendations, which in retrospect appear somewhat mild for the times, might elicit co-operation and syinpathy from those in power. The report of the Retrenchment Committee evoked considerÂ­able discussion among the Board members, and particular obÂ­jections were directed to the phases of the report relating to, ( 1 ) the matter of restricting courses in agriculture and home economics, thereby monopolizing that training in the University of Tennessee, and ( 2 ) the limited amount of time given to the study of the committee. The recommendations of the Retrenchment Committee, exÂ­{ cepting some few modifications, were instituted as practice in the teachers colleges of the state. State Teachers College at Murfreesboro, in the fall of 1933, opened the school under the general plan of the Retrenchment Committee. Prior to this the first step in complying with the State Board's action was the reduction of ", the dairy herd on the college farm. Also, only seventy-five acres of farm land were reÂ­tained for experimentation and laboratory work. The remainder was released to private individuals. The reorganization , ô€•†ô„™¦f deÂ­partments indicated that the State Board plan had beeft folÂ­lowed. Agriculture, under . the department of biological sciences, retained two instructors ; but only one of these taught full time in this area. The maximum of two instructors was listed in home economics. Types of course offerings in these two areas followed closely the spirit of the State Board regulations. By permission, the maximum in education was raised from eighteen to twentyÂ­seven hours. Room rent, originally set at $6 to $8 per month, was reduced to $12 per quarter. Directives relating to laboratory fees were followed as originally made. The summer term was reÂ­tained by a very unique plan in keeping with the forty-two week stipulation. It was announced that the summer term would begin on May 1, the middle of the spring quarter. This proved very Troubled Years â€¢ 147 acceptable since most of the rural schools were dismissed by that time, and a majority of summer students were those teachers alÂ­ready in the field. The State Board action proved to be only a precursor of more drastic events in the harried lives of the schools. In 1933 the LegÂ­islature, in an effort to satisfy the popular demand for economy, attempted to pass several acts that would have greatly handiÂ­capped or sabotaged the teacher-education program. The colÂ­leges were faced with a battle to the death. In the spirit of the 1917 crusade against the Dunlap Bill, the college presidents and prominent individuals interested in the future of Tennessee eduÂ­cation converged on Nashville. President P. A. Lyon of MurfreesÂ­boro and Q. M. Smith of Tennessee Polytechnic Institute, of Cookeville, were prominent among the vanguard that led a wellÂ­organized and persistent lobby. One of the first legislative attempts was that deSigned to regulate teacher selection by making the employment of teach- , ers in the state a responsibility of the Legislature. This bill, House Bill No. 99, introduced by W. P. Monroe, representing Campbell, Claiborne, Hancock, Morgan, Scott, and Union CounÂ­ties, died in committee. Another bill, introduced by the same Mr. Monroe, proposed to abolish the state teachers colleges at Memphis, Clarksvillô€•‡ô„œ¬, Murfreesboro, and Johnson City; the TenÂ­nessee Polytechnic 'Institute at Cookeville; and the Tennessee Junior College at Mô€•ˆô„¡²rtin, Tennessee. It was estimated that this would result in a bienniô€…¨ô†¡¬l saving of $2,000,000. If not acÂ­cepted within a year, the properties were to be sold to the state, and proceeds placed in the general education fund. Senate Bill No. 60 and House Bill No. 343 of similar interest passed two readings in each chamber but died in committee. The lack of success of these measures attests to the vigilance of- those who labored with the education committee in the cafes, lobbies, and

Frequently funds were not available for faculty salaries. Sometimes months passed without payment being made. The President was able to retain his faculty intact by the doling of a small loan fund, thereby enÂ­abling personnel to purchase food and other necessities. When settlement was finally made to one staff member, for example, $2400 had accumulated in back payments. The local banks arÂ­ranged many loans, accepting "anticipated" warrants as security. Financial harassments were also the lot of the students. From 1930 to 1936, approximately $25,000 accumulated in student in- I debtedness to the college. This included credit extended for regÂ­istratio ô€Š»ô‹¬¬, room rent, laboratory fees, and meal tickets. By action of the State Board in 1938, the college was directed to initiate a plan for collection. As a result statements were mailed to all former " students involved. and notes were drawn up for those still in attendance. A total of $5100 accrued from these efforts. Generally there was a negative reaction, both in sense of obliÂ­gation and in spirit. Funds for maintenance were almost non-existent. For example, in 1933, $8000 was allocated for all phases of maintaining' the school plant including salaries for workmen. Only a small perÂ­centage of this allocation reached the college treasury. Worn and broken tools were replaced by the employees from their personal stock. William Hastings, long-time plant superintendent, moved his entire supply of power and hand tools into the college mainÂ­tenance shop. President Lyon's fann pick-up truck was marshaled into service after the campus vehicles were stored for lack of tires and repairs. INTERNAL TROUBLES In 1935 the State Teachers College at Murfreesboro had reached the first plateau of recovery. During the preceding years the college program had suffered, as was true with other instiÂ­tutions in the state and nation. It may be inferred that further progress toward normalcy would have been effected in the Troubled Years â€¢ 151 course of time if ' certain other circumstances had not developâ‚¬d at this time. , , There is no argument that denies that internal distresses imÂ­pede ,pJ;ogress and sometimes change the direction of a college. When these conditions are corrected, the victory, if it can be categorized as such, is usually Pyrrhic in nature. The institution is disturbed and divided by loyalties, and if a new administraÂ­ ô€ªô†©©ion. reô€©ô†¥µults, it requires ability of the highest order to place the ll1SbtutlOn back on the road to normalcy. In instances where difÂ­ficulties arise, especially in a relatively small community, the c.itizens are usually aligned in groups supporting or opposing facÂ­bons created by the schism. The students of such an institution are the individuals most handicapped by a situation of this kind. They may act and express themselves at times in a manner toÂ­tally foreign to normal prosecution of campus life. Also, disturbed feelings may spill over the boundaries of the campus and comÂ­munity and atb'act attention of state or regional proportions. Certainly during the early days of 1937, Middle Tennessee " State Teachers College was faced with the problems implied by the foregOing statements. It must be remembered that memories of the depression years were still sharp and many scars of rugged and exhausting battles for survival remained unhealed. But beÂ­fore total convalô€•Šô„©³sô€•‹ô„¬…ô€•Œô„±®nce could be realized another devastating blow struck the campus. It is not a pleasant story, but it is an integral part of the first fifty years. If the dark, dreary depression years represented something of a static period, or even one of-TeÂ­gression, the second yhase of the troubled years was equally as deterring and debilitating. The economic debacle was explainÂ­able. This uô€•ô„µ¦folding story is far more complex. It was evident that conditions on the State Teachers College campus had been worsening for some time. No indications had appeared in the press relative to the matter, nor had the two Murfreesboro newspapers, one daily, the other a .weekly, arÂ­ranged their battle lines in anticipation of an open break. The First Fifty Years street corner, drug store, and cafe conversation was generously spiced with stories about President Lyon and his estrangement with at least one of his staff members. The entire matter would have been of administrative interest only but for the wide inÂ­fluence of the instructor in question, Knox T. Hutchinson, head of the agriculture department. Origin of the difficulty has never been satisfactorily explained, although ' the validity of charges and counter-charges made later was accepted in whichever facÂ­tion loyalties happened to be ensconced. The matter came to the surface in 1937 by the introduction in the Legislature on May 2, of House Bill No. 1025. This bill, sponÂ­sored by Walter ( Pete ) Haynes of Winchester, specified that all presidents of white state teachers colleges be reqUired to have ' an earned degree. Supporters of President Lyon charged that this bill was designed to remove him from office. Lyon did not possess ' an earned degree, but an honorary doctorate from Southwestern University. The Rutherford Courier, judged from the editorial spirit and news stories about the matter, was eviÂ­dently aligned with Lyon in the struggle just gathering moÂ­mentum. On May 7, 1937, it gave the following view of the bill : The bill is earmarked at one man, because it includes only the state colleges, excluding even the University of Temi"esÂ­see. It is believed that the bill was drawn so as to include only the three state teachers colleges in order to avoid disÂ­qualifying the president of the colored state normal at N ashÂ­ville, who does not have a degree. . The article darkly hinted that Haynes introduced the bill at the insistence of local politicians. It was reported in the same issue that Governor Browning and Commissioner of Education "V. A. Bass both opposed the bill, but on May 1 1, the C ourie?' averred that the bill would pass and that Browning had changed his position and approved its passage. Passage of the bill seemed to be contingent on Lyon's resignation. The college newspaper, The Side-Lines, published a special edition on May 8, request- \ . \ Troubled Yem's â€¢ 153 ing the retention 0f the President and issuing the warning that if politics interfered with the school there was danger that it would be dropped from the Southern Association and the American Association of Teachers Colleges. It was reported in the same issue that a mass meeting of the students had been held and that mimeographed copies of a resolution petitioning the State Legislature not to pass any bill which would cause Dr. Lyon to be ineligible for his present office had been distributed in N ashville. The resolution in part was as follows : We believe that the election and dismissal of college heads should be left to the State Board, Governor, and the Commissioner of Education. We believe also that P. A. Lyon has served the State long and well, and has been a sucÂ­cessful president, well known and admired in education circles. He is the most capable man for the position at the time. Loss of his services would greatly impair the effiÂ­ciency of the State Teachers College. In an editorial on May 11, the Courier reiterated its belief in' the political involvements affecting the bill: LEGISLATIVE ASSASSINATORS 'Ah, but certainly a college president should have a colÂ­lege degree himself,' they say. Hutchinson maintained that difficulty lay not in the charge that he was seeking the presidency of the college but in fact that the private power interests were out "to get" him. He strongly implied, as did his supporters at the meetings, that the president was aligned on the side of the Tennessee Power Company and that Lyon was the agent through which the private power interest could accomplish their objectives. He cited what he termed a case ;in point when he charged that Mr. Lyon had influenced Negroes on the college farm to vote against T.V.A. at a referenÂ­dum. To complicate matters President Lyon was instructed to be present at this meeting, and the rather detailed recorded minÂ­utes ihdicated that the meeting face-to-face of the two principals produced unrestrained emotions and harsh accusations not conÂ­ducive to a settlement of any kind. The discussion progressed in this charged atmosphere until 4:12 p.m., when the Board went into executive session. A complete file of the case was in the hands of the Board. This included a re-instatement petition to the Governor, communications from the Young Democratic Club of Rutherford County, resolutions from the groups faô€•“ô…¯oring Hutchinson, communications from Hutchinson to the Governor, a complete transcript of the case, various letters, and newspaper clippings. It was the sentiment of the Board that there was nothing in the case that would warrant reconsideration of action previously taken. In summarizing the positions of each in this very unfortunate affair, available data indicate that President Lyon was conÂ­vinced that Mr. Hutchinson was an overt applicant for his job and that he was using the force of his influence, or at least was willingly acceding to the wishes of his proponents, to effect the change. On the other hand, Mr. Hutchinson, an avid supportÂ­er of T.V. A., was equally convinced that President Lyon was a Troubled Years â€¢ 159 supporter of private power interests and also that the President was unprepared professionally to preside over the affairs of a teachers college. As has been implied on more than one occasion in this affair, the documentary arguments supporting each are those that appear on the surface. The real purposes underlying the case, if there are others than those recorded, are far too comÂ­plex to unravel. The final chapter in this rather tragic story was written in the Legislature of 1939. In 1938, Mr. Hutchinson announced his canÂ­didacy for the State Senate representing Rutherford, Cannon, and DeKalb counties. On August 5, 1938, it was indicated that he was a successful candidate. THE NEW PRESIDENT The choice of Mr. Smith as the new president was mutually satisfying to the State BoanI-and to the new president. The State Board was cogently aware of the fact that the individual assuming the position would of necessity have to possess unique executive abilities. This person must be unswerving in his deciÂ­sions, he must ignore personal and professional attacks, for proÂ­ponents of both factions, previously described, were still active and raw ends of wounds were still unhealed; he must possess those qualities of administrative leadership that, despite existing conditions, would ultimately placate and mediate opposing Troubled Years â€¢ 161 elements. The Board 'was of the opinion that Mr. Smith was the individual best suited for the job. His administrative record of eighteen years at Tennessee PolytechniC Institute had been highly successful. Under his leadership that institution had made remarkable progress in new physical facilities and inÂ­struction. His first few years at State Teachers College bore out some of the more dire predictions of the State Board. Exceptions were taken to many of his early aô€–™ô‰¥­ministrative decisions. Some of these were interpreted as being based on personal dislikes and personality involvements. Some antagoÂ­nisms based on a rather long, tempestous athletic rivalry between the two colleges served as one of the bases for incitement by critics. As predicted, he was adamant in his prescribed course of action and proceeded under full authority and support of the State Board. Ultimately, disturbed feelings and antagoÂ­nisms gave way to a recognition of his educational leadership. It was with a degree of personal satisfaction that Mr. Smith returned to the ins titution where he had gained his first college experience. On September 2, on the day after he officially asÂ­sumed his new position, he expressed himself in this manner : I feel that I am .c9!ping back home. I have always liked this community and Â· I welcomô€–œô‰° the opportunity to come back. When I came hô€‡ôµ²re in September, 1911, a poor country boy, I never expected that someday I would become presiÂ­dent. <". Records reveal that he had been an outstanding student, havÂ­ing been the first editor of the Signal, a member of the debating team, president of the first senior class, and a member of the first football team. Also, he had been a leader in campus acÂ­tivities, having been chosen on one occasion "King of the CotÂ­ton Patch," at a Halloween festival. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 162 â€¢ The First Fifty Years J. S. Holmes, now deceased, and the first applicant to the NIiddle Tennessee State Normal in 1911, recalled the Nonnal days when Q. N! . Smith was his classmate: As to young Q. N!. Smith from Ruskin Cave, TennesÂ­see, I remember him as an outstanding student and a leader in the activities of the Old Claxton Literary Society. He was also first president of that society. There was no football team at the Normal the first year, but student Coach Mutt Weber had one in 1912 and the big gaJIle was with Bryson College at Fayetteville marking the beginning of a rivalry which lasted until Bryson closed down. Q. M. and all of us had a big day, but we did get beat-about 26 to 0, or 28 to O. Also, I believe he was the second student to make appliÂ­cation after me. Smith was born at Buffalo, Tennessee, May 11, 1891. In 1913 he graduated in the first class at Middle Tennessee State Normal school. His bachelor's and mastel s degrees were received at George Peabody College for Teachers in 1913 and 1927. He enÂ­listed in the United States Navy in 1917 and at the close of the war became Principal of Bradley County High School in .. CleveÂ­land, Tennessee. He continued his interest in the country's deÂ­fense program and rose to the rank of major in the Reserves. From 1920 to the assumption of his duties at State Teachers ColÂ­lege, he was President of Tennessee Polytechnic Institute. His record during nearly forty-five years of educational service is filled with many important assignments on a state and national level, services to the Tennessee Retirement Program, leadership in various education commissions in the state, and leadership offices in teacher professional organizations. On September 19, 1938, the new president was inb'oduced to the faculty. He expressed his desire to continue the democratic spirit of administration and expressed the hope that the adjustÂ­ment period would be a happy and profitable one. Subsequent TrOltbled YeaTs â€¢ 163 staff meetings were concerned with policy, particularly that haVing to do with the bookkeeping system of the college. One of his first official contacts with the Board in his new capacity was to report on plans for a student activity building at a cost of $200,000 . aô€•–ô…™¤d a gymnasium at a cost of $100,000. Although these bUIldmgs were not realized until several years later, the motive initiating the efforts toward increased physical facilities was .one idenô€ô…¹ying the President during the next several years. PreSident Smith presented the State Board with the problem of delinquent accounts of students on May 9, 1939. These had accumulated largely from the depression days. He was instructed to close many of the accounts and to draw up one-year notes on others. At this meeting the question of a registered bull on the State Teachers College farm was discussed. This animal had been one of the many items of controversy in the internal diffiÂ­culties previously described. It was then explained that the aniÂ­mal had been placed on the farm by Jersey Farms of NashviIIe. , President Smith had received a statement of $300 from MurfreesÂ­boro Bank and Trust Company prior to the Board meeting. His request that he be empowered to pay the biII from coIIege funds :vas granted. There were other efforts during his first few years II pursuing financial stabilization and other aspects of the colÂ­lege program that , st.aplped him as a sound administrator. During this period: a c?mmet:ce department appeared for the first time in the progô€•—ô…¡am of studies. Permission was granted for a Civilian Pilot Training program with ten trainees in the initial group. Already in progress were the National Youth AdministraÂ­tion and War Industries Training programs. Another developÂ­ment was a new contract with the Rutherford County Board of Education more clearly defining obligations of both state and county in operation of the Training School. CONTRACT BETWEEN STATE BOARD OF EDUCATION AND RUTHERFORD COUNTY BOARD OF EDU8ATION 1. The State of Tennessee wiII furnish the building, equip-

The County Board of Education of Rutherford County will pay the salaries of teachers in the elementary grades according to the state salary schedule for elementary teachers. The quota of teachers for the elementary grades will be determined by the policies of the State Board of Education. The most Significant development, having great impact on the future :of the college during this period, was the movement toward state college status. The first real indication of this in ' Tennessee was the Legislature's action in 1939 removing the Â«pledgô€…§ô†œ to teach" requirement as a requisite for graduation. Other events on the state and national level pointed to the inÂ­evitability of the multiple-purpose college. "

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: CHAPTER EIGHT New Status: State College S OME FIVE YEARS away from state college status, State Teachers College, Murfreesboro, Tennessee, was enjoying some semblance of prosp erity and a return to normalcy. The depresÂ­sion years were behind and the atmosphere was somewhat cleared of the turbulence created by the very recent internal strifes. Although there had been objections to Q. M. Smith's asÂ­cendency to the President's office-from certain community )eaders, from faculty memhers and from students caught up in the excitement of the widely publiCized affair-the fall quarter of 1938 . opened on a relatively quiescent basis. A dissatisfying football season that fall was not too conducive to elevating the school spirit. Too, there were rumors that Coach Floyd, who did not possess an earned degree, would be affected as Lyon was . Following the football season, a dismal baô€•©ô†¥¥etball performance inspired more than one dissenting editorial in the S'ide-Lines. But, as indicated in the previous chapter, President Smith entered upon his task determined to make the best of the situaÂ­tions that had been largely created by previous events. Possessing an unrelenting spirit complemented by his superb record as an administrator, he attacked the multifarious problems obviously without any intent of compromise or sacrifice of principle. He was aware of the ill-wishers in his official family and in the area beyond the campus. Apparently, the situation was one of waiting and watching for the tum of events. President Smith's administrative performance before this chilly audience was his answer. ASSOCIATED STUDENT BODY For some time students had voiced affirmative opinions rel- 166 New Status: State College â€¢ 167 ative to student government at the college. Their principal media had been petitions to the administration and editorials in the Side-Lines. Early in October of 1938, the President gave >,'his blessing to the move and directed that the current student body president, Charles Miller, call a mass meeting of the shldents to ascertain the extent of the sentiment. The Side-Lines, on OcÂ­tober 19, reported that this had been done. The three hundred and fOlty-twO in attendance at the previous Tuesday evening meeting unanimously endorsed the plan. President Miller imÂ­mediately appointed a committee to contact other colleges for samples of constitutions. Other student leaders in the movement were John Bragg, John Paul Gilbert, Everett McIntyre, Kathryn Meadows, and Charlie IVlorton. A Side-Lines editorial on DeÂ­cember 7 stated tersely that "The Students are Ready." ConfirmaÂ­tion of this was indicated by the results of a student body meetÂ­ing, January 11, 1939. At this time the constitution in its final form was read and approved and the Associated Student Body had become a reality. Dr. C. C. Sims and W. B. Judd gave asÂ­sistance in framing the document, while Neal Frazier suggested certain changes in language structure. First officers elected on February 8 were as follows : President, Charles Miller; ViceÂ­President, Kathryn Meadows; Secretary, Bruce Saltor; and Treasurer, Frances Brown. The first business to receive considÂ­eration was a measute to coordinate all campus organizations by filing a list of officers with the ASB secretary. Included also were a codification of -dormitory rules and other matters pertaip.Â­ing to assignment of penalties for infractions. In the spring of 19:39, Coach John Floyd ,tendered his resigÂ­nation. President Smith had made it clear that he wanted a teaching coach. Prior to this, Floyd had devoted his entire time to coaching duties and evidenced no desire to enter the classÂ­room. There is some question as to what his status would have been if he had agreed to teach physical education classes along with coaching. The Hutchinson bill had already eliminated sev-

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 168 o . The Fi1'st Fifty Yea1'S eral instructors from the teachers colleges of the state. Ernest Hercules Alley, University of Tennessee graduate and successful high school coach in Mississippi, followed as coach in the fall of the same year. After one year Â· and two victories he resigned to accept a position as end coach at Vanderbilt University. AssistÂ­ant coach and commerce teacher, Elwin Wilburn Midgett, was selected as the new head coach. Coach Midgett had been a brilÂ­liant athlete at Tennessee Polytechnic Institute while President Smith was at that institution. The new arrangement was proÂ­phetic of the ultimate in harmony. Except for three years when athletics was suspended during the war years, Midgett remained as coach. IIi the spring of 1947 he voluntarily returned to the ( classroom as department head in the Business Department. During that year Charles Murphy, versatile athlete during the Floyd regime, was employed. NE'iV TROUBLES FROM OLD Although President Smith had enjoyed two relatively calm and successful years, he was not entirely "out ofô€•ªô†¨±1:he woods." New anÂ­tagonisms or old antagonisms reactivated, or both, rocked the campus again, beginning in the early spring of 1940. The match was applied to the fuse when the President recommended the dismissal of Philip Mankin, one of the English instructors at.the college. Mankin was regarded as a superior teacher by many of his students and by graduates who had become acquainted with him during his thirteen years of service. Too, he was well khown in Murfreesboro and could claim a number of prominent supporters in his struggle to retain his position. In addition, the semi-dormant forces opposing Smith came to life, regarding this as a strategic time to move into the arena. The initial phase of the disturbance came on March 4, 1940, when the following letter from President Smith was delivered to Mankin : A survey of the course offerings and teaching load in the . language department indicates that it is possible and ad- New Status: State College â€¢ 169 visable to reduce the teaching staff of that department by one. This is to notify you that I shall not include your name on the faculty list nor budget for 1940-41 submitted to the State Board of Education at the May meeting and that I will recommend that your services as a member of the facÂ­ulty be discontinued after July 17, 1940. The implication of economy did not satisfy Mankin nor his supporters, and on April 22, 1940, he wrote to the State Board of Education requesting permission "to appear before you when my case is discussed to defend myself." This request was grantÂ­ed although the subsequent audience before the board failed to give Mr. Mankin any satisfaction as to what charges had been placed against him. Following this session an investigating committee from the State Board met in Murfreesboro on June 4 and 5. Among other things, at this meeting, formal charges signed by some seventy-five citizens were presented against President Smith charging him with dictatorial and autocratic " practices. Also, a number of "witnesses" composed of citizens, students, and former students were paraded before the tribunal. Within the admixture there were both proponents and opponents of the college administration. FollOWing the hearings the comÂ­mittee voted to sus ,tain the administration of the college and so recommended to the ' State Board at its meeting on June 17, 1940. The second and final phase of the debilitating affair came with the appearance on the scene of M. C. D' Argonne and A. J. Stanley, representing <"the American Association of University Professors. Aô€•«ô†­´ter three days spent in interviewing individuals in Murfreesboro and Nashville, this two-man team, a sub-comÂ­mittee on Academic Freedom and Tenure, made its written report to the A.A.U.P. The A.A.U.P. contended that the reason for dismissal based on economy measures was largely a diploÂ­matic gesture. There were other reasons indicated by the com- , ...

On the campus the students were aroused and, being divided in loyalties, held many extraordinary, stormy "nlmp" sessions in the dormitories and in the classrooms of the administration buildÂ­ing. Something resembling a mass meeting developed one eveÂ­ning in the auditorium. One student of oratorical propensities, speaking on behalf of Mankin, staged a classic filibuster that ran far past the curfew hour. Here it "'" remained until the fall of 1952. Opposition to the administration began to subside after it was apparent that the state would remain in full support of Smith's position. Since most people forget easily and quickly and qthô€•Œô„±²r matters supercede in importance and gravity, the school agam regained equilibrium. Cries of "State College, Yes-Teacher's College, No" could now be heard. And too, war clouds could be seen, high and menacing over the Pacific to the west. EFFORTS TO\VARD MORE "RESPECTABILITY" State Teachers College, Murfreesboro, Tennessee, served priÂ­marily an area composed of forty-seven counties. Other four-year institutions within the area included Vanderbilt University, GeorO'e Peabody College for Teachers, Belmont College, David Lipsô€Žô„¹¯omb College and Austin Peay State College. Besides these large institutions, there were a number of post-secondary schools offering varied types of special preparation, most of these in the . I New Status: State College â€¢ 171 metropolitan area of Nashville. On the periphery of the boundÂ­ary created by the NI iddle Tennessee counties was Tennessee Polytechnic Institute at Cookeville. It can be surmised that Teachers College received keen competition from these instituÂ­tions. George Peabody College for Teachers, long a leader in southern education, was the sb'ongest competitor for area stuÂ­dents preparing to teach. Also, many opportunities for specialÂ­i:.: ed training and the pursuance of a liberal arts education were provided by the many other schools in Middle Tennessee. In adÂ­dition, persistent demands were arising for a more varied curÂ­riculum by those in the area, at least by those evidencing no deÂ­sire to teach. If the above is a reliable criterion, Teachers College at Murfreesboro had valid reasons, perhaps more than the other state teachers colleges, to effect the transition. One of the most impelling forces behind the movement toward state college status was the student body at Teachers College . Much of this aggressive interest was reflected in successive isÂ­sues of the S'ide-Lines. One of the first editorials was a lively , condemnation of "teachers college" which appeared on June 23, 1941 : Last year a drive was started here in Murfreesboro to change the name of the Middle Tennessee State Teachers College to just plÂ§lin Tennessee State College. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 172 ., The First Fifty Years became imbued with the infectious spirit of the campus and initi:. ated a campaign of their own. A rash of letters and telegrams found its way to the desks of the board members, the ComÂ­missioner of Education, and the Governor. These were forceÂ­fully supplemented by personal contacts. The persistence of the students never abated, for the SideÂ­Lines editor, Jack Cunningham, included the following as one of the principal student objectives in the September 23 issue: "Abolition of Present Name-To many, the name, Teachers ColÂ­lege, sounds a sour note, there is a possibility that S.T.C. loses many students because of its name." Continuing on October 9, th ere appeared another sharp critiÂ­f cism of the one-purpose reputation of the college: We all know that the word, teachers, sticks out like a sore "thumb when the name of our . college is mentioned to many students. Understand there is no better profession in the world than the age-old art of pedagogy, but many a fine student who could have taken pô€•¬ô†°­-medical, pre-law, or some other course did not come our way because the name led him to think that if he came here he would have to become a teacher. During all of this agitation by students, President SmithÂ· did not sit idly by waiting for the students and community groundÂ­swell to subside. He himself was extremely interested in the move and, in fact, had been busy for some months generating a movement on the state level. He welcomed student petitioners in his office and was always in close contact with campus leaders. Perhaps at this point an administrative-student bond began to materialize. Through the years of state college status, graduate school, and other evidences of significant growth the bond grew stronger and respect was embraced by admiration. Students of the fifties still remember the tradition on the eve of the Homecoming Game when the student body at midnight each year paid a visit to the President's home. After a few yells, New Status: State College â€¢ 173 President Smith, di"essed in pajamas and dressing gown, would appear on the front porch. He usually began with a ringing pep talk and concluded by shifting into a cheerleader's role. Due to press of competition, to the formula of appropriations based largely on enrollments, to the wave of sentiment by stuÂ­dents and community leaders and the desire to retain its status as an important institution of higher learning, the first official move in the direction of State College was made on November 7, 1941. On that date Q. M. Smith and C. C. Sherrod of JohnÂ­son City recommended to the State Board that State Teachers College, Murfreesboro, and State Teachers College, Johnson City, be designated in the future as state colleges. These two presi.dents were instructed to prepare a bill and to request its enactment in the 1943 Legislature. The news burst on the campus and there was a celebration as spirited as that accomp anying a Raider victory over Tennessee Tech. There was also a triumphant note in the lead story of the 11" , Side-Lines: "It's a fine name!! It happens to be our new name .. Considerable discussion ensued as to the legality of the Board's action. Actually the Board did not, or pOSSibly could not, assign the name, "state college," to the institution. To eliminate all doubts, the official action was left to the 1943 Legislature, some thirteen months aWl1Y . During the interim, State Teachers ColÂ­lege, Murfreesboro, -Tennessee existed under the more or less unofficial aegis of "acting" State College. During this period there was speculation as to what turn the final designation would take. Would it,..be' simply, State College, prefaced by the usual geographic indicator, or should it by its name possess more originality and exclusiveness? In fact, several rather atÂ­tractive names were suggested. Among these were Stone's River State College and Murfreesboro State. Coach E. W. Midgett, with the athletic motif uppermost, came forward with the name, Forrest State College . â€¢ He explained that "Raiders" pould then be most appropriately identified with the institution that it -.

CHANGE IN FUNCTION In 1941, the college still retained the stated functions that appeared in the first state teachers college bulletin : Thô€•‘ô…„ General Education Law of 1909 made the legal function of the schools to be 'the education and profesÂ­sional training of the teachers of the state.' More specifiÂ­cally, the State Teachers Colleges attempt to prepare eleÂ­mentary and high school teachers, inshllctors and supervisÂ­ors of special subjects, principals, and superintendents of county and city schools. In 1942, one year before being officially declared a state colÂ­lege, an expanded program was announced : The major functions of the college are (1) to provide the best program our resources will permit for the training of elementary and secondary teachers, and (2) to provide f&' other students the best possible opportunities for general cultural, pre-professional and vocational training. In the same year, the departments of the college still retained the departmental designations that had been operative for the past several years. These departments were arts, education, health and physical education, home economics, languages, mathematics, science and social science. In 1942, a new feature in curricula organization was added. All course offerings of the eight departments were grouped under six broad areas. Here, for the first time, it was clearly indicated that teacher-educaÂ­tion would share with a wide variety of other interests. When the institution became a state college in 1943 a national emergency already existed.

Middle Tennessee State College began its program of selfÂ­evaluation on September 1, 1951. Prior to this date, President Smith ha:d secured in preparation for the program necessary data and materials including work-forms, procedure information, and other detailed instructions. Since the value lay primarily in self-examination and inevitable articulation among departments during a year long contact, seven basic committees were formed from the faculty. Because of the encompassing characteristic of each of the seven standards, constituency of the seven comÂ­mittees broke across departmental boundar4es and permitted contact among individuals of diverse interests and subject areas. It is probable that this situation proved one of the most valuable outcomes of the year's study since faculty members generally tend to gravitate toward comparbnentalization as a school gro s. In addition to the seven basic committees, organized in groups representing each of the seven standards, there was a further division of the faculty into subgroups to collect, classify, and analyze data from the entire college program. That year repreÂ­sented one of intense activity, of small committee meetings, genÂ­eral staff meetings, production of questionnaires, innumerable interviews, and close examinations of all facets of adm.inistraÂ­tion and instruction. MEETING THE NEEDS OF THE AREA During the period of national emergency, the Middle TennesÂ­see State College experienced little difficulty -in providing physiÂ­cal facilities and instructional services for the enrollment at the institution. Had it not been for the military contingents moving in and out during the cnlCial years its campus would have apÂ­peared practically deserted. Men out of uniform were rarities. Shortly after the cessation of hostilities, there was a renewal of the familiar collegiate atmosphere. By 1946, an enrollment of Post Wm' Expansion â€¢ 189 756 approximated pô€•Ÿ'e-war figures. The previous year, only 231 students sought enb'ance. Following 1946, there was a sharp inÂ­crease to an enrollment of 1076. Each succeeding year saw an increasing number of students seeking admission. Contributing to this were the veterans actuated by the provisions of the "G. I. Bill of Rights" and those others who had been released from defense industries. It was evident by 1949 that the existÂ­ing facilities would not adequately accommodate those presently enrolled and would permit little planning for the anticipated increases of the future. In 1949, President Q. 11. Smith announced tllat he would seek from the State. Legislature of that year the sum of $3,348,321.60 for the biennium, 1949-51. Of this sum, $2,150,000 would be utiÂ­lized to provide for ten vitally needed building and renovation projects. The sum of $101,246 would be directed toward the improving of teachers' salaries and the addition of needed inÂ­structional supplies. In this appeal he said that "there is a twenty-year lag" in building at the state colleges and that $435.80 was needed annually for each student. He listed the folÂ­lowing constructions of the projected building program in this order of priority : 1. :Men's Dormitory 2. Cafeteria and Union building 3. Fine Arts building fOJ: art and music 4. Library addition _ . 5. Enlarged women's dormitories 6. Modernization of ' men's dormitory 7. Combine oid gymnasium with auditorium 8. Family apartments for faculty and students 9. Driveways, walks, and landscaping 10. Campus maintenance shop These increased services and buildings, contemplated in PresiÂ­dent Smith's recommendations, were a part of an extensive postÂ­war expansion plan announced in 1945 and already implemented .. .

Lyon and a few other individuals is due much of the credit for withholding the teachers colleges from the auction block durÂ­ing the depression. The times created the situation, but the chalÂ­lenges were met forthrightly in types of leadership that Middle Tennessee had begun to expect from its presidents. President Smith became the third in the line of stellar adÂ­ministra( Drs. The institution did not face survival periods during his years, except perhaps to a degree during World War II. As will be recalled, enrollment had plummeted to 200 in 1944, the lowest in.history. Only the presence of the am1Y reserve students and an orphaned Rutherford County High School student body prevented the campus from resembling a prolonged Christmas holiday period. President Smith's significant achievements came in the form of a massive building program. ..' The times were conducive to building. Jones had a death struggle to keep open the three lone Normal buildings. Lyon had added a few structures, but economic conditions obstructed badly needed additions. Now the floodgates were opened. The expau'dÂ­ing need of education was a tune masterfully played by the third president. A long range plan for campus development began to materialize, for early in 1940 the Industrial Arts Building, COIlÂ­sbucted partially by W.P.A. labor, was opened for classes. This initial emphasis on industrial education was probably a sentiÂ­mental residue of Mr. Smith's previous tenure at an engineering school. His crowning achievement came in 1958, the year of his retirement, in the dedication of the Andrew L. Todd Memorial Library. This beautiful structure, named in hC?nor of the godÂ­father of the college, was constructed at a cost of $450,000. In recognition of the expanding personnel needs of the college, President Smith had in 1954 effected a re-organization and ex- Post YV ar Expansion â€¢ 199 l? ansion of the administration. While with the State Department of Education, his visitation program and wide Â· contacts with TenÂ­nessee high school principals and teachers had been eXh'emely successful and had gained him high respect among all levels of Tennessee education. His aggressive academic leadership at Middle Tennessee State College produced at least two signifiÂ­cant results. First, there was a gradual tightening of institutional requirements and upgrading of academic standards. Secondly, and more identifiable, there was a marked improvement in classroom instruction. This second ascendency received its greatÂ­est assist from the success in continuing efforts to secure outÂ­standing faculty personnel as the college grew. Post \Va r Expansion â€¢ 203 THE FOURTH PRESIDENT At the February meeting of the State Board of Education in 1958, Dr. Quill Cope, who had been Tennessee State CommisÂ·Â­sioner of Education since January 15, 195.3, was elected as fourth president of Middle Tennessee State College. Similar to the presiÂ­dents who preceded him, he was bulwarked by a great wealth of professional experience at many levels of education. The son of Rogers 'iV. and Dora Breeding Cope, he was born in Sparta, Tennessee, on March 28, 1912. Forty-six years of age when he came to Murfreesboro, he was somewhat in the age-range of the first three presidents at the time of their elections. He received his education at White County High School, Tennessee Polytechnic Institute, George Peabody College, and at New York University, where he was awarded the doctorate in Education in 1952. His first teaching experience was at Yankeetown, a small rural four-teacher school in White County. Between this first position at Yankeetown and the presidency of .Middle Tennessee State College, Dr. Cope spent five years as a social studies and English teacher at Sparta High School, served as County Superintendent of Education in \V hite County, was a World \V ar II Navy Air Force instructor, field representative for the U. S. Office of EduÂ­cation, White County High School Principal, associate proÂ­fessor of education at the University of Tennessee, and Tennessee Commissioner of Education.,: . Dr. Cope was an outstaô€ºô©¤ding undergraduate student at TenÂ­nessee Polytechnic Institute. While a student there, he won the history medal, was a member of the first intercollegiate debating team, was orat01:ical medalist, manager of the football team, a member of the' Tech Oracle staff, and held a variety of club and class offices. His subsequent varied experiences in Tennessee education and his administrative training in the doctoral program at New York University admirablY' equipped him for the TenneS"see comÂ­missionership of education, to which position Governor Frank - .

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 204 â€¢ The First Fifty Years Clement called him on January 15, 1953. During his administraÂ­tion as head of the Tennessee educational system, Dr. Cope saw - a reorganization of the administrative staff of the State DepartÂ­ment of Education, the total educational appropriations- increased by 71.7 per cent, the state salary schedule for a teacher with a B.S. degree increased by $878.00, and teachers were placed on a ten-month salary basis. Other notable achievements during his five years, 1953 to 1958, at the helm of the Tennessee School System included a free textbook program ( grades one through tewlve ) , inb'oduction of a program for severely mentally-retarded children, and an inÂ­crease in appropriations of over fifty-six per cent for higher eduÂ­cation. One of Dr. Cope's first administrative activities in his new poÂ­sition wa; to become personally acquainted with all of the adÂ­ministrative, instructional, and non-professional staff. ConseÂ­quently he arranged a long series of interviews that ran for sevÂ­eral weeks during the summer of 1958. Wises4n the ways of adÂ­ministration, he methodically surveyed and studied all aspects of the college program. In the offing he effected few changes, preferring to operate for the time being essentially within much of the framework that he had inherited. In fact, he welcomâ‚¬d the orientation counsel of President Emeritus Smith with the asÂ­surance that he favored several of the projected developments embodied in the "master plan." As a result of this kind considerÂ­ation given to his predecessor and the policy of proceeding with caution until he had gained full confidence from all college perÂ­sonnel and the community, the ease of adminisb'ative transition was most remarkable. Gradually his imagination, philosophy, and organizational talent were injected into all phases of the colÂ· lege program. If there was any feeling that the institution was approaching an era of complacency and status quo, it was soon dispelled. An indefatigable worker himself, Dr. Cope demanded an equal Post War Expansion, â€¢ 205 dedication from those whom he superintended. The reasons had a clarion note of immediacy. The future was prophetic of mushrooming enrollments and attending problems, not the least of which were finance and curricula adaptable to the frightening needs of the sixties. A dynamic and intelligent college program would obviously be a strong argument for lay support. During Dr. Cope's first three years as president, which were the last three years of the institution's first-half century of existÂ­ence, several important changes and additions were made. These involved physical facilities, departmental designations, curricuÂ­lum, and personnel. During the ô€»ô­°pring of 1958, the State Board of Education auÂ­thorized the state colleges and universities to make available to its faculty members a restricted number of grants-in-aid for adÂ­vanced graduate study. This program, primarily designed to asÂ­sist faculty members in completing doctoral degrees, was limited to three per cent of the faculty during the academic year and five per cent during the summer term. The generous terms of the grants-in-aid provided graduate study opportunities for six Middle Tennessee State College faculty members during the summer of 1958. Since that time, twelve additional grants have been made. In 1959 two domiciJô€¼ô±¡ary additions were made to Smith Hall. Art instruction, listed simply as "Drawing" in the early literature, gained department status durÂ­ing 1959. Heading the new department, designated as Art Education, was Dr. Clarence Greever of the college education department. The first three art courses offered by the 'Normal )n 1911 and taught by Miss Weesie Griffith had this objective :' ''T.fie drawing courses are adapted to the needs of the grade teachers, the technique will receive attention, but the objective will be to conduct the work in such a manner that it may be practically applied in the school room." In 1925, its name evolutionized to Department of Drawing; to Division of Art in 1926; and again to Department of Art in 1929. Fourteen courses were offered during 1929 and taught by a faculty of one! From this point art became submerged in a department variously referred to as Fine Arts and Arts. Here it remained until its emergence as an entity in 1959. In 1959, the college broke a tradition of forty-eight years and introduced the semester plan for the division of the school year. Prior to this date the academic year was divided into three periÂ­ods of three months each. Designated as "terms" for the first twelve years of the Normal, the name was changed to "quarters" in the fall of 1923. Sentiments among the members of the faculty for the semester plan were formally expressed at faculty meetÂ­ings during the spring of 1957. Although no action was taken durÂ­ing that time, Dr. Cope submitted the proposal to the faculty in 1958, and tht: response was favorable. After approximately one year of study and preparation, the college officially converted to the two-part division of the academic year. Principal values accruing from the change were those pertaining to adequacy of time blocks for courses, continuity of learning, and consoliÂ­dation of certain courses of similar nature. Dr. Cope's seven years as Commissioner of Education had sketched for him in bold strokes the highlighting and shadows of the Tennessee education picÂ­ture. He discovered the obvious but frequently overlooked factor, so important to the chief executives and legislators, that an education program identified by excellence and followed by good reporting stimulates generous support. The five images at the half century milestone have largely become the operating bases for the present and guidelines for the years aheô€•£ô†¤d. Expressed simply, they are as follows : l. A beautiful campus that will continue to be a source of pride to students, to alumni, and to those others whose role is that of sympathetic and active support. 2. An instructional program that will be symbolized by high academic standards and constant modifications to meet the needs of the area. 3. A loyal alumni that will spread the influence of the inÂ­stitution wherever their professional lives carry them and will always be sensitive to the progress and needs of their Alma Mater. 4. A friendly stuô€•¤ô†…ô€•¥ô†•®nt body and faculty that will always give priority to the needs ô€•¦ô†™®nd problems of the individual Â· rather than relegate- him to the statistical. 5. A people's college th,at will provide a wide variety of voô€•§ô†œ…ô€•¨ô† §' cational, professi9nal, and preparatory programs for the diverse needs of the area. The identifiable outlines of these images can be clearly perÂ­ceived at the close of the first fifty years. These outlines are so unmistakably sketched that full delineation and fusion will be sureties if those individuals concerned with Middle Tennessee State College continue ,their devotion during the second half of the century, The long roll of these personalities does not en-

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 128
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 214 â€¢ The First Fifty Years compass in isolation the current administration and faculty or those others who presently render services in the dormitories, on the wide stretches of the campus, and in the other areas upon which a growing academic community is dependent. This roll is not completed with the inclusion of the some seven thousand alumni scattered over the globe. Time will bring new administrations and faculties. The long line of students passing through succeeding convocations will create constant changes in the face of the alumni. To assure ultiÂ­mate image clarity and the development of new ones, the listing of devotees will of necessity be continuous and unending. . The use of the terms "close of the first fifty years," "end of the first half century", and "milestone" used in this summary of the first fifty years is probably misapplication. "Close" and "end" connote cessation. "Milestone" is symbolic of a pause or perhaps more so of a contemplative rest along the way. More accurately, Middle Tennessee State College's fiftieth year is one of restless activity and one of observing while in rapi-d transit the rich heritage accumulated during the many years past. The events of the present could be analogous to a spirited, swiftly moving aniÂ­mal with the bits firmly set in his teeth while the rider le:;t}1s from the saddle to glimpse the markers and guidelines to tl1e future. The road just traversed, beginning with a trail and exÂ­panding into a high road, now opens onto a broad highway. This route though clearly marked had desirable alternates, and there was always the possibility of a new exciting thoroughfare to be blazed. Middle Tennessee State College, although charged with treasuring the lessons learned and obligated to its historic purpose, must in addition innovate, expand, and experiment to meet the changing fortunes of the times ahead. It appears that only then will the first fifty years be truly significant and worth the effort of commemoration. The images, as projected by PresiÂ­dent Cope, obviously point to something more than the status quo. At The Half Century and Beyond â€¢ 215 A brief and final look at the college of 1961 reveals many pleaSing and somewhat startling developments compared with that when Reverend Gibbs gave the first invocation on that sulÂ­try September morning in 1911. The face of the campus, the inÂ­structional program, the alumni, the student body and faculty, and basic concepts of needs bear only a trace of yesterday. . The 1911 campus of three buildings, the President's home, one small tree, and one hundred acres of alternate dust and mud has experienced a most remarkable transformation. Today fifty-two buildings of all types are distributed over a campus that is just a small garden plot less than 706 acres, with a total evaluation of over $8,500,000. These buildings include administrative and inÂ­structional areas, dOmiciliary facilities, those utilized for other student services, maintenance, barns, farm houses, and other structul'es needed for the broad program of a growing institution. N ow accompanying the one living plant on the original acreÂ­age are large banks of shrubs, flowers and trees. One of PresiÂ­dent . Cope's early interests was that directed toward developing the front campus into a college "showcase." This included conÂ­struction of the access road from the Woodbury Pike and the initiation of a supplementary landscaping scheme. In 1960 he reÂ­tained the consultative services of Dr. W. H. Pelton, retired horticulturist from _ô€‹¸ô ô€„ô´ University of Tennessee Extension SerÂ­vice, to plan with college personnel in the locating of new plantÂ­ings near buildings and the new- driveway sweeping around the quadrangle. Several Howe! beds, planted with annual varieties, were placed at the c,9nfluences of walkways and roads. AdÂ­ditional "face lifting" included the "sand blasting" of the exterior walls of Rutledge and Lyon Halls. President Cope's thesis held that an individual's first impression of an institution was usually the one retained-expressed in another way: "A superb product without an attractive wrapper is a weight on the market." To minister to enginfering and maintenance needs in 1911, Clint Taylor and Ed Turner stood alone as the staff. Although .. .

Travis, an energetic seventeen year-old waterboy with the city of Nlurfreesboro maintenance department, had come to the institution in 1928. This was at the precise moment that the depression clouds were settling over the campus. During the next few years of scrip payments and furtive, inconsistent salary warÂ­rants, he became one of the most loyal and dependable emÂ­ployees of the college. In reality since 1935, ' when Julius Bayer returned; to farm management, the campus has largely become his d.omain. At the half century, sixty-five employees attend to the needs of the buildings and the intervening green lawns. In the process of maintenance and operation of the present plant, the consô€‹¹ô¥­mption of supplies and utility services approximate that of a large industry or perhaps even one of the small Tennessee municipalities. A sampling from a recent twelve-month period reveals that 150 gallons of paint, 3,469,000 kï¿½owatts of electricÂ­ity, 4,561,200 gallons of water, 1500 tons of coal, 13,400 gallons of gasoline, and 74,000,000 cubic feet of gas were used. The conÂ­trast is considerable when it is noted that the heatin-g needs of the opening years were filled by a few loads of the Overall aï¿½d Avent coal wagons. Refurbishing then was by dire need rather than plan. Consumption of water did not become a problem for several weeks after the dedication because plumbing fixtures had not been installed. The only gasoline on the campus was in the tank of Horace Grady Jones' Everett-Metz-Flanders parked near the administration building. The instnlCtional faculty of 1911 was composed of sixteen members, one of whom possessed the doctor's degree and six with less than the bachelors. By critical standards of the day it was a creditable staff. As the institution moved from Normal status to a four-year college, the growth was reflected in inÂ­creased professional credentials. This faculty of 1961 works within a framework of fourteen departments, including Military Science. The' sequence of degrees initiated by the bachelor of science was followed by the master of arts in education and the bachelor of arts. In 1959 the mitotic process created master's degrees in chemistry, biology, and general science. Already, by 1952, the one-cell education degree had segmented into units in .. administration, supervision, curriculum, and instruction. In 1960 a third unit in guidance and counseling was created. Another deÂ­partment- social science-offered the graduate degree in 1960, followed by the same offering in the mathematics department by 1961. At half century the requirements for degrees at all levels obviously have no ,pô€‹ºô¨ô€„ôµ´tensions for "Ivy League" status.
