At the close of the convocation in August of 1961, records in the Registrar's office show that 7132 have been recipients of degrees since the opening of the four-year college in 1925. During the fourteen years of the Normal, 1911-1925, 245 individuals, including two and three-year certificate holders, received the highest degree ofÂ­fered. Distribution of the four-year and above degrees, 1926- 1961, is as follows : bachelor of arts, 29; bachelor of science, 6400; master of arts, 703. Allowing for some repetition from bachelors to masters, the alumni in 1961, including 345 from the Normal cjays, should aggregate a number close to 7,000. One alumnus or more is found in every state of the union except three. Many have entered occupations that carried them into other countries. Life pursuits embracing practically every occuÂ­pation ana profession are represented by graduates of Middle Tennessee State College. Teachers, business men, clerical workÂ­ers, congressmen, chemists, clergymen, physicians, housewives, salesmen, executives, military personnel, college presidents, proÂ­fessional football and baseball players, coaches, engineers, proÂ­fessional entertainers, writers, and many others fonn the long gamut of :NIid-State graduates. In 1959, in recognition of the great importance of maintaihÂ­ing strong lines of communication with these alumni, the duties of the alumni secretary became largely the responsibility of one person. Homer Pittard, alumnus of 1936 and a member of the education department, became the new secretary. He succeeded Robert Abernathy, affectionately known as "Bob" to the thousÂ­ands of elder Raiders and Raiderettes. Mr. Abernathy requested relief from the position in order to devote more time to the multitudinous tasks associated with placement, recruitment, exÂ­tension, and other duties. In the fall of 1959, the first issue of the initial alumni publicaÂ­tion, The Mid-Stater, was mailed to nearly 5500 former students of the college. The bulletin, carrying a semi-tabloid format and At The Half Century and Beyond â€¢ 219 scheduled for quarterly publication, contained news items and photographic copy descriptive of the college and of the alumni in the field. During the period from 1959 to 1961, ten new local alumni associations were organized. Out-of-state units included Dade County, Florida, Washington D. C., and Huntsville, Alabama. Tennessee organizations included those in the counties of LawÂ­rence, Giles, Davidson, Wilson, Bedford, and Lincoln. An alumni group was activated in Oak Ridge during the winter of 1961 . For many years, the Hamilton County alumni held the distincÂ­tion of being the only formally organized club, aside from the general parenô€‹¾ô¸ organization. This strong local held its first meetÂ­ing in 1949. A program for recognition of distinguished alumni of Middle Tennessee State was initiated in the spring of 1960. The program called for the selection of three honorees each year and for the presentation of these at the alumni banquet. Nominations origiÂ­nated in their entirety with the alumni. Ultimate choices resided in a reviewing committee of alumni exclusive of State College personnel, appointed by the current alumni president. At the anÂ­nual spring banquet held on the campus in 1960 these three outÂ­standing alumni were honored: Frank Bass, a long-time execuÂ­tive- secretary of the .. rennessee Education Association; Albert Gore, United States Senator from Tennessee; and Quintin Smith, President Emeritus of Middle Tennessee State College. Those honored in 1961 were : ô€‹¿ô½²reston Overall, athletic director and former coach at TeIJPessee Polytechnic Institute; Randolph Wood, originator of Dot Record Company and highly successful Hollywood business man; and Dr. Clifford Stark, nationally acÂ­claimed authority in the area of dairy farming. The 247 Normalites who registered during 1911 presented an age range from thirteen to the grandfather level. Discipline was slanted to techniques appropriate for the elementary . and high school grades. For example, during the first year, one erring

Only the faculty member with highly telescopic eyes could have spied him. His education was abruptly terminated at this point, and he was soon riding the red farm wagon to the railroad station. During the fall semester of 1961, 2850 full-time students were recorded. Of this number 1775 were men and 1075 were women. In this group there were 217 married women and 328 men with marital status. Eighty-nine out-of-state students were registrants as were nine from foreign countries. Domiciliary facilities were available; for 600 women and 508 men. The remaining students either wei'e residents of Murfreesboro or traveled the high road to the campus each day from near and distant points. Although there remains a disparity in ages, the majority of the enrollees on the undergraduate level in 1961 are found<-- within the usually ascribed average age-range for college students. For worthy students availability of a college education was enunciated by State Board Freshmen Scholarships, by fedeô€Œ€ô€€ƒô€Œô€…¡al loan funds, and by numerous other plans principally of a d"e Â­paltmental nature. Avenues of finance for educational purposes are not innovations restricted to the present. Many Normal students defrayed a large portion of their expenses by serving as waiters and waitresses in Mrs . Barbee's dining hall. Yet the variety and generosity of the present plans are greatly expanded, thereby placing educational opportunities within easy access of deserving individuals. A last journey in the red wagon to the railroad station has not been totally abandoned. Some college youngsters will "smoke a forbidden cigarette' regardless of the anna domini, but the origin of the disciplinary force has been reversed. It now reÂ­sides within the student, and the administrative restraints that At The Half Centw'y and Beyond â€¢ 221 are imposed are those necessary to happy existence in a smoothÂ­functioning collegiate community. With the creation of a new service department deSignated as guidance, under the direction of Dr. James Aquilla Martin, and the reactivation of a former position, that of dean of women, further emphasis is being placed on student personnel needs. \Vhen Middle Tennessee State Normal School opened its doors in 1911 it bore all of the familiar features of a people's instituÂ­tion. Its bulletins carried program plans designed to improve rural conditions, to prepare the potential hous ewife for dOlnestic duties, to develop manual skills, and to assist in social adjustÂ­ments through, the literary society program. The primary purÂ­pose of the Normal was to prepare teachers. The pledge to teach, which remained technically in force until 1939, naturally restricted the scope of operation. State college status in 1943 opened new avenues of service, and by 1961 Middle Tennessee State College could play the role of a people's college more truthfully and effectively than ever. At the half century it can be expected that more than sixty per cent of the graduates will enter the teaching profession. It can also be expected that some of those who did not follow a direct path from the convocation platform to the classroom will do so after a very few years. Past performances are highly indicative of this. The historic purpose still has Significant attendance. The people's college designation is further implemented by various other curricular plans for developing skills to meet the many-faceted needs of those in the area. If there is any inference that creation of the image of a peoÂ­pIe's college is restricted in its entirety to those activities of the classroom, an examination of the heavy-laden extra-college calÂ­endar win result in a sharp denial of this. These structures are located in the area east of the science building. Girls' State, a seven-day training period in politics and democratic practices for outstanding third-year high school girls of Tennessee, has been held annually at Middle Tennessee State College since 1954. Those responsible for planÂ­ning the construction of the Student Union Building in 1951 obviously bore in mind the needs of the area served by the colÂ­lege- or in the image vernacular, "people's college." Although student and faculty-based in its program of utilization, the StuÂ­dent Union building has become an extremely popular and ac- At The Half Century and Beyond â€¢ 223 cessible assembly pOint for professional and civic groups. A section of the annual Education Conference for regional educators, in its eighteenth year, now conducts its meetings in the spacious Tennessee Room and in several of the adjacent areas. The flow of professional and lay activities to the campus is not channelled in totality or even primarily to this point on the west campus. The Memorial Health and Physical Education building has for many years provided facilities for basketball tournament play, including county, district, regional, and on ocÂ­casions, state interscholastic competition. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 226 â€¢ The First Fifty Years On May 27, 1947, a Sidelines editorial entitled "From Those Who Remain" summarized in part the feeling just expressed: "If you were to ask them what college has meant to them, what would their answer be? Would it be the new-found friends that they know will stick long after the college days have passed? \Vould it be the association in the classroom with both fellow students and the instructor? Would it be the pounding sensation that comes from the excitement of a basketball game? 'iV ould it be a quarterly dance, a junior-senior party, a club meeting? 'iVould their answer be any of these things? Yes, we think it would . .It might not be one, but all of these rolled into one happy memory that will go with them as long as they live." ( Another sentiment appropriately expressing the spirit of MidÂ­dle Tenpessee State College was that written by an alumnus of the class of 1941. It was a poem composed on the battle lines somewhere in the South Pacific. The author was Captain Roger Smith. TIle poem had no pretensions to greatness but its simplicÂ­ity reflected the nostalgia and the apprecicrtive spirit shared by thousands of other alumni. The poem appeared in the Sidelines of September 28, 1943. The concluding verse is as follows : "All that I have left is memories of those day's, When we had fun in so many different ways; I only hope that others at some future date May enjoy themselves as I did at Tennessee State." Just ten months later on the Island of Guam, July 23, 1944, Captain Smith lost his life leading a marine assault against an enemy concentration. The sentiment inherent in this simple creÂ­ative effort edifies these closing lines. iVIiddle Tennessee State College has now become of age. The body for the institution has been found and the primitive soul has reached refinement. Intentionally Left Blank

On the evening of December 31 , 1 959, the Raiders defeated Presbyterian College of Clinton , South Carolina. The s.core was 21 - 1 4.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 167
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Intentionally Left Blank r r r r r r 1 c-:J A,cknowledgments: , To compile a story: even of . unpretentious proportions, of an institution's first fifty years requires considerable research. Â·ô€”¿ôƒ½”The frustations of the writer 'in striving for accuracy are compounded by the thought that many hundreds ( optimism predicated on loyalty of alumni, faculty, and others ) will appraise it in the searchlight 'of their own experiences at the institution. The writer on more than one occasion, after he had contacted so many and found countless indecisions as to dates and identificaton of perÂ­sonalities, decided it :vould be a simple matter to .arrange the 227 ...

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 168
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 228 â€¢ The First Fifty Years material in an attractive manner, insert the dates indiscriminately to lend the flavor of research and let it go at that. After the pipe dreams had been wafted away, stark reality contended that the printed page has a disturbing habit of resurrecting obscure facts and dates in the minds of the readers. Fortunately there were many individuals who remembered and many more who generously provided invaluable printed materials for use i.nÂ­preparation of this volume. Thoughtfully, footnotes have been omitted from the narÂ­rative. Once upon a time the writer read that "footnotes are like little dogs running along harking at the text." He, therefore, places himself in the position of eliminating at least one criti-c:i: sm. Despite the many dangers attending omissions, an attempt is made herewith to identify some of those persons who provided assistance, both as friendly interviewees and as lenders of docuÂ­ments. These include Dr. Robert White, John Zumbro, Horace Grady Jones, Nliss E. Mai Saunders, Miss q'ommie Reynolds, John B. Brown, Judge Albert Williams, Q. M. Smith, Miller Lanier, Miss Catherine Clark, Preston Overall, Dr. C. N. Stark, Ivie Graham Holmes, Dr. J. E. Windrow, Dean N. C. Beaslô€Œ†ô€™¹y, Charles Parker Parsons, Robert Abernathy, Frank Bass, O. t. Freeman, Mrs. Bonnie McHenry, T. L. Huddleston, Mrs. Bernie NIoore, Earl Hinton, Miss Elizabeth Schardt, Ross Spielman, James Ridley, NIiss Margie Mitchell, Ennis Harris, and others. The photographs used herein were prepared for the engravers by Dr. Bealer Smotherman, head of the audio-visual department. The line drawings introducing each of the chapters are the work of j\l.(rs. Nora Smith Hinton. The writer also expresses his deep appreciation to Dr. Quill E. Cope, Dr. Howard Kirksey, Dr. WilÂ­liam Beasley, and NIrs. Mabel Pittard for reading, for suggesting certain changes, and for correcting portions of the manuscrir:>t. Much credit is due Dr. E. O. Hawkins and Eugene Sloan for their diligence in copy-reading and to John Bragg for lay-ont Acknowledgment â€¢ 229 and general consmlCtion of the volume. Accolades are due Mrs. Sue Smartt and Mrs. Lorene Sharp for their perseverance, deÂ­spite other pressing duties, in typing the manuscript several times. In addition to the information gathered from several indiÂ­viduals, materials, printed or otherwise preserved in a permaÂ­nent form, were consulted and frequently utilized. These inÂ­cluded all of the college bulletins (1911-1961 ); files of student publications including the Signal, N ormalite, Sidelines, Rebel, Still Voice, Opus, and Midlander; Faculty Minutes (1911-61 ); newspapers including the Nashville Banner, Nashv'ille TennesÂ­sean, Carthage Courier, Daily News Journal, and Rutherford CourietÂ·; House Journals of Tennessee; Senate Journals of TenÂ­nessee; Public Acts of Tennessee; Rutherford County Quarterly Court Minutes; Tennessee State Board Minutes; minutes of the four literary societies at the college; many additional manuscripts and unclassified documents, and several standard works in the area of education. Compiled materials on athletics in the office of Bob Brooks, college sports' publicist, were generously used. It is the contention of the writer of The First Fifty Years that the materials recorded are correct insofar as available data seemed to reveal. If there are errors, it is hoped that the chronÂ­icler of Th e Second Fifty Years- will make the proper corrections. .. .

Training School Physical Education Education Social Science Science Education Bioiogy Chemistry and Physics Education Electricity Business Manager Penmanship Industrial Arts Music Music Physics English Education Agriculture Foreign Languages THE ALUMNI ASSOCIATION Appendix â€¢ 241 1919-20 Summer 1925 1960-61 1955-61 1958-60 Spring and Summer 1 930 1956ô€…šô…¨¶61 1946-61 1957-61 1948-52 1933Â·61 Summer 1923 1911-34 Â· 1947Â·61 1946-61 Summer 1924 1920-25 Spring and Summer 1931 1957-61 Spring and Summer 1930 The first alumni association was formed in the spring of 1914 with Q. M. Smith serving as president. During the follOWing year, Mr. Smith, who was Principal of White County High School, Sparta, Tennessee, and a member of the 1913 graduÂ­ating class, wrote a constitution which was presented to the asÂ­sembly in 1915. This doct:J.ment has been preserved by Mr. Smith and is probably the only copy now ô€•€ô„© in existence. Article I states that "The name of this associô€•ô„…´tion shall be the Alumni AssociÂ­ation of Middle Tennessee Normal School." Article V, SectioI?- 3 specifies the type of annual meetings . It reads : "An Annual Dinner and Celebration shall be held on one evening during Commencement week, and at such . meeting an Oration, a Poem, and a Toast List shall be delivered .by members selected at the Previous Annual Meeting, or during the year "by the Executive Committee." . There is a possibility that the association met agairi in 1916 but no records are available. With the approach of the World - .

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 175
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: -- , 242 â€¢ The First Fifty Years War I years, meetings and other organized activities were susÂ­pended. There was no formal reactivation until the spring of 1926 although the college literature of the early twenties states that "The graduates of the Middle Tennessee State Normal School are organized into an association for mutual help and pleasure. The association meets annually during commencement week for the transaction of business." Although there is evidence that two or three meetings were held during these years, it is doubtful that any attempts at formal organization were made. Thosô€„¸ôƒ assembling on these occasions did so on short notice, probably upon the instigation of two or three ex-normalites who still retained the fervor of their school days. D. Henry Piper of Lafayette, Tennessee, was elected to the alumloli presidency in 1926. Mr. Piper was re-elected in 1927. WilÂ­liam Benton Judd became the secretary-treasurer during this same year and remained in this capacity until 1947. Because of ill health he requested to be relieved of his duties and was sucÂ­ceded by James Robert Abernathy. Homer Pittard followed Mr. Abernathy in 1960. The following is a complete listing of alumni officers during the four-year college period beginning in the spring of 1926. The program consisting of four pages is plinted on heavy 5 x 7 paper and carries the inevitable engraving of the Administration Building on the cover. r-Â· Appendix â€¢ 245 It is appropriateiy decorated with a bow of royal blue and white cord. The cover and the two inside pages are reproduced on the following pages in the exact format used in the original program. Note the uniquely composed "appetizing" menu. I .. .

Hutchinson,-'14 Fealty The Faculty - - Prof. Murphey The Programme Chorus - - - The Guests Ode Appendix â€¢ 249 BASEBALL HEAD COACHES, 1912-1961 Baseball, appearing on the Normal sports horizon during the spring of 1912, had the first organized team of any kind at the new institution. Professor Max Souby, popular history teacher, was the "coach." At least seven diamond performers during the first fifty years have entered professional baseball. Kola Sharpe, class of 1932, was probably the most successful of these. After a highly creditable tenure as a pitcher with Little Rock of the Southern Association, he advanced to the Chicago Cubs where he remained for four years. Other elder Raiders with professional experience include Charles "Bubba" Murphy, Jersey City; Bobby Tillman, PaGific Coast League; Dave Hall, Red Sox; Cromer Smotherman, Yankee system; Willard Lovelady, Chattanooga; and James "Jaybird" Hamblen, Blytheville, Arkansas. During the seasons of 1947, 1949 and 1950 Raider baseball teams reigned supreme in the Volunteer State Athletic ConferÂ­ence. The 1959 team was co-champion of the Ohio Valley ConÂ­ference. Coach of the 1961 team is Jack Deere, class of 1948 at State College. Serving also as end coach in football, Deere returned to his Alma Mater in 1958 after achieving highly successful records at central high schools in Giles and Franklin counties. Including Souby's firô€•‚ô„‰»{ year, the coaches are as follows : 1912 -Professor Max Soufiy 1941-42-Nance Jordan 1913-17-Alfred Miles 1943-45-No Organized Team 1918-19ô€»ô‡­ŽNo Organized T1eam 1946 -Nance Jordan 1920-24-Alfred Miles '" 1947-50-Durwood Stowe 1925-26-Guy Stephenson' 1951 -Charles "Bubba" Murphy 1927-32-Frank Faulkinberry 1952-56-Dr. Fran Riel 1933-3-5E. Nig" Waller 1957-58-Charles Greer 1936-3ô€¼ô‡±¯ohnny "Red" Floyd 1959-60-Buck Rolman 1940 -Herc Alley 1961 -Jack Deere BASKETBALL HEAD COACHES, 1913-1961 Although the Signal, first Normal student publication, makes reference to an organized basketball team in 1912, it is doubtful ....

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 179
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 250 â€¢ The First Fifty Years that there was any competition outside the intramural program. Alf Miles, the first coach, obviously placed little emphasis on basketball since only three games were scheduled for the 1913- 14 season and four for 1914-15. The absence of an adequate gymnasium probably contributed to this de-emphasis. An examiÂ­nation of the results of the 19 13-1-4 season proves most interestÂ­in g. Vanderbilt University won the first game of the season by a score of 53-5. The second game, with Castle Heights of LebaÂ­non, was equally as disastrous. The final score was 22-7. The reÂ­sult of the third and final game was most satisfying. Dixie ColÂ­lege (pi.e decessor to Tennessee Polytechnic Institute ) of CookeÂ­ville had the dubious honor of being the first loser in the basketÂ­ball history of the Murfreesboro Institution. An early Signal deÂ­scribes the event in these words : "This lot fell to Dixie College and herô€•ƒô„Œ they came-a good big bunch of freckled-faced comÂ­fed boys from the region of Cookeville, Tenn. The boys fought to the whistle-you should have seen them fight and heard the audience yell. And Dixie College departeck leaving us the Big end of a 27 to 13 score." Student Appendix â€¢ 253 publications of the period were extremely generous in reporting the results and the color of the games. As a result, the records are fairly complete for the first fifty years. During forty-six seasons ( including the student-coached team of 1912 and deducting three years of inactivity during World War II ) , there have been four undefeated, untied teams. Interestingly enough three of these seaÂ­sons have a kindred association of personalities although forty years separate the first and fourth perfect seasons. In 1917, JohnÂ­ny "Red" Floyd, an athletic refugee from a war-time VanderÂ­bilt, returned to the Normal as coach. His team won seven vicÂ­tories without a defeat. He left after the 1918 seasons but reÂ­turned in 19ô€•†ô„˜µ5, succeeding E. M. "Nig" Waller. That year, the Blue Raiders ( christened with the nickname the previous year ) were victorious with eight games and no defeats. One of the members of the star-studded backfield was a brilliant halfback by the name of Charles "Bubba" Murphy. Murphy returned to his Alma Mater as coach in 1947. Ten years later his team .. won ten games without suffering a defeat or tie. Presently, conference and athletic association memberships inÂ­clude the Ohio V:alley Conference and the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The college withdrew from the Southern Intercollegiate Association in 1949 and from the Volunteer State Athletic Conference ô€„‘ô…®n 1957. State College athletic officials, Eugene Sloan in particular, had been instrumental in forming the latter group in 1947. The prQbÂ­lem of scheduling sufficent games in the Ohio Valley for champÂ­ionship eligibility wis the principal impetus behind the withÂ­drawal. Cha!llp ionships in the various conferences are as folÂ­lows : 1935, 1936-SIAA; 1947, 1949, 1950, 1955, 1956, 1957- VSAC; 1956, 1957-VSAC; 1956, 1957-0VC; 1958, 1959-CoÂ­champions, OVC. Charles Murphy, the present athletic director and coach, graduated from State College in 1938. He became coach at Goodlettsville Tennessee High School and in addition played professional baseball with Jersey City for two summers. During World War II he was in the Navy with the rank of lieutenant. After the war, while in graduate study at Peabody College, he coached all sports at the Peabody Demonstration School. In 1947 he returned to his Alma Mater. His record in football during his fourteen-year tenure is one of the most remarkable in the counÂ­try for small college competition. The front row was gracefully deployed in the reclining, "harem-style" pose, typical of the day. Whether this team ever represented the school in a formal meet remains a matter of conjecture. CAMPUS SCHOOL DIRECTORS Like the dragonfly, the Middle Tennessee State College labÂ­oratory school has experienced three stages, insofar as designaÂ­tions are concerned. From 1911 to 1928, the literature referred to it as the ":Model School." Operating in the old East End School building in 192.8, it became the "Training School". In 1929 the school wasÂ·' moved to its present location. To further identify its program with _the college the name was changed to "Campus School" in 1957. Jt may 'be surmised that a great maBY years will have passed before the new designation becomes a common refereô€•‰ô„¥£ce pOint with the lay public. Even l;lt the half century, a few of the early "settlers" still refer to the buildingô€•Šô„¨ that rest at the city's eastern border as the "Normal" -and more often as "Teachers College". The laboratory school operated as an elementary school, grades one through eight, until the fall of 1934. During this year the ninth grade was added.; Departmentalization embraced the sev- ,

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 184
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 260 . , The First Fifty Years enth, eighth, and ninth grades. The first six grades remained as self-contained classrooms. The enrollment for the ninth grade during its first year was a modest twenty-fourteen boys and six girls. The following year the tenth grade was added. Enrollment in the four junior high school grades during the 1935-36 school year totaled one hundred and forty-nine. At the close of the academic year in the spring of 1947, the school returned to the elementary plan with eight self -contained classrooms. Until 1927 the destiny of the laboratory school was the reÂ­sponsibility of the education department head. Occasionally a hall principal was appointed to expedite routine matters. The ( first individual with the title of director and whose duties were those primarily related to the laboratory school was Dr. J. C. Waller: a graduate of Peabody College. The present director is Hilary Parker, fonner Superintendent of the Oak Ridge schools. Directors from 1928 to the present are : Dr. J. C. Waller 1928-37 Joseph Htlward 1952-54 Frank E. Simpson 1942-52 FALL ENROLLMENTS - 1911-1961 ';" No attempt is made here to estimate the number of individÂ­uals who have matriculated at the institution during the first fifty years. It would be truly an estimate, and probably a very poor one, because of circumstances prevailing from 1911 to 1925. Certain individuals, for example, attended the Academic DeÂ­partment ( High School ) , taught for awhile and returned sporadiÂ­cally during the following years. Some of the enrollments covÂ­ered the entire span of the Normal period. As a result, the traÂ­vail of early record-keeping created many duplicate and tripliÂ­cate records. Also student accounting for the summer institutes of certificate-hunters is almost non-existent. Johnson City Carl Yates . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .N ashville LIBRARIANS, 1911-1961 On Tuesday, March 25, 1958, the Andrew L. Todd Memorial Library was dedicated. Formerly housed in the building situÂ­ated near the center of the campus quadrangle, the library was moved to spacious new quarters in line with academic acceleraÂ­tion and increasing enrollments. Constructed at a cost- of $450,000, with an additional allowance of $40,000 for equipment, Appendix -265 the library provided ' shelving facilities for an expansion to over 150,000 volumes. At the half century it has a repository of 80,000 volumes and 550 periodicals. Each year during the past five years, 5000 volÂ­umes have been added. Using the open-stack policy, circulation has reached approximately 73,700 annually. Features of the liÂ­brary program include facilities for microfilm production and reading, a complete file of state-adopted textbooks, an audioÂ­visual room, and a model library for elementary and secondary schools. The Tennessee Room, an area dedicated to the colÂ­lection and preservation of a great variety of printed materials on Tennessee and about Tennesseans, has become a popular reÂ­search point. Also in the Memorial Library is located the inÂ­structional and laboratory spaces for library science. Sufficient credits ( 12 semester hours ) are offered to meet state certifiÂ­cation requirements. The east basement of this building houses the Regional Library. Miss Catherine Clark, Director of the Library, is a graduate of Tennessee College and of Peabody College and has completed additional graduate study at Duke University. Widely recogÂ­nized for her program at Middle Tennessee State College, she was president of the Tennessee Library Association during 1960-61. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 270 â€¢ . The First Fifty Years SECRETARIES TO THE PRESIDENT Although Horace Grady Jones is listed in the first catalog as secretary, it is doubtful that he ever typed a faculty directive or rested a secretary's pad on his knee. During the first two years it is likely that President Jones drafted faculty members and employed students to prepare correspondence and type reports. In 1913, Miss Edna Miller was employed as secretary and reÂ­mained in this capacity until 1917. Miss Bonnie McDonald, a bright young Normalite of nineteen came from the classroom to the President's outer office in 1918. In 1924, after her marriage to R. 'P. McHenry, she resigned but returned in 1926. At the close of the first fifty years she remains as secretary, her tenure 'encompassing forty-one years of the institution's existence. BeÂ­cause of. her adaptability, efficiency, and skill in human relations, "Miss Bonnie's" service was uninterrupted during four adminiÂ­strative transitions. Students as well as faculty members rememÂ­ber her reassuring smile just prior to the uncertainties sometimes attending those on the threshhold of the inner sanctum. Secretaries to the President who have served during the first fifty years are as follows : Miss Edna Miller - 1913-1917 Miss Lillie Warren - 1917-1918 Miss Bonnie McDonald - 1918-1924 Miss Lula Mae McDonald - 1924-1926 Mrs. Bonnie McHenry - 1926- - .. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The First Fifty Years: A History of MTSC
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Pittard, Homer
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Hinton, Nora Smith, illustrator; Smotherman, Bealer, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A history of the Middle Tennessee State College from its founding in 1911 as the Middle Tennessee State Normal School to 1961. Describes the political environment that led to its creation, early organization and administration, students and student activities, faculty and staff, campus planning and construction, etc. Also includes references to the history of the model school that later became the Homer Pittard Campus School

Introduction -- Conception -- Birth -- Staffing the school -- Early Normal years -- Growth and transition -- New status : teachers college -- Troubled years -- New status : state college -- Post war expansion -- At the half century and beyond -- Acknowledgements -- Appendices -- Index.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 2
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: $5.95 THE RAIDER FORTIES by Joe E. Nunley The Raider Forties is a true account of what the 1940s meant to a group of young men coming of age in Tennessee just prior to America's entry into the conflagration of World War II. It was a great time to be alive and young, a time when lifelong friendships and memories were formed. We relive the high drama of football games won and lost, dormitory life, teacher confrontations, trumpet playing, hilarious high jinks, first loves. The unclouded joy of the early chapters, by <fntrast, makes the meaning of war far more shocking and vivid than any conventional "war" novel could. War chang~s or ends the â€¢ lives of people we have come to know and care about-Bill Neely, redheaded member of the glee club, and Bill Burkett, football star and yearbook editor, don't come back. Some of the young men (from the same area and background as Sgt. Alvin York) survive and are decorated. The last part of The Raider Forties is an engrossing record of what happened to the survivors-educations finished, marriages made, careers begun-an unembellished picture of how rich and sweet "ordinary" life really is. The Raider Forties is not a mournful search for lost youth; it celebrates the past and the present, leaving the reader with a sehse of optimism about our young men, and thereÂ­fore America's future. Vantage Press, Inc. 516 West 34th St., New York, N. Y. 10001 t,

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: ., FIRST EDITION All rights reserved, including the right of reproduction in whole or in part in any form. Copyright Â© 1977 by Joe E. Nunley Published by Vantage Press, Inc. 516 West 34th Street, New York, New York 10001 Manufactured in the United States of America Standard Book Number 533-02861-2 This book is dedicated to the people whose trails once crossed on the college campus in Murfreesboro, Tennessee. More specifically, it is dedicated to Jim Butler Lane, whose leaf, like those of Q. M. Nooby and Shadow, slipped from the linden tree this year.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 6
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Introduction EACH GENERATION HAS its own uniqueness. Each is conÂ­fronted with social forces that are themselves unique, and each responds to the forces. In its response lies its real uniqueness. During April of 1974, circumstances of school business cast Jim Butler Lane, Jack "Old Folks" Deere, and lue toÂ­gether for three days and nights at the Franklin County High School in Winchester, Tennessee. During relaxed moments of the first day's meetings, we talked about events that were fairly current. By the end of the second day, bits of nostalgia had begun to slip into our occasional conversaÂ­tions ... memories of our college days at STC... memories of the freshman class of 1940. "Does the magnolia tree still stand in front of the old cafeteria?" "Who lives in Jones Hall now?" "Do you reluember when Bain and Bostic wrecked the motorcycle on the Lebanon Pike?" We reminisced. Each memory recalled opened floodÂ­gates for others. They tumbled out until the third day was over and it was time to go. "I didn't graduate until 1948," said Jack, "and Moody didn't leave until '49." "Yes," mused Jim Butler, "it took us nearly ten years to get through college and to fight World War II. Those were good years, though-rugged but good. I wish my kids

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 7
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: could know what it was like, the good til:;es and the tough times that we had. I wish you would write about them." Â«You are nominated, Joe," said Old Folks. So I looked over my shoulder and peered through the morning mists of many, many sunrises and saw again the Â«rugged but good" years at STC ... the Raider Forties. Contents PART ONE 1 I. The Forty Frosh 3 II. The Year Two 18 III. Summer of '42 34 IV. The Fall of '42 37 V. Departure 48 VI. Rehearsal 54 VII. Where Did All the Flowers Go? 62 VIII. Return 70 PART TWO TAPS 89

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: PART ONE , -

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 9
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: I. The FortY Frosh 'Neath ivied walls the students stride The humble and the haughty Intent upon their venture in This academic sortie. Narne them now and forevermore The Freshman class of Forty. But college jargon disallows An entry assignation, The finish is the surname of A student concentration. The "Class of Forty-Four" becomes Their official designation. IT IS MID-SEPTEMBER in i 940, and our freshman class gathers on the college -campus at Murfreesboro, Tennes~ee. There are more than two hundred of us, the largest group of freshmen the place has ever seen. We are from all over middle Tennessee and a few, for various reasons, are from the extremities of the state. Nashville and Murfreesboro furnish the largest portion of our group; West High School of Nashville either has the most or they make it seem that way. We small-towners are impressed. Don Wilson and I are from Chapel Hill, population 366. Both of us have seen the campus before, but never so 3

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 10
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: intimately as today. We stand in front of the main building with its massive columns and its huge metallic "wild geese" ventilators perched stimy on the roof. The building is the apex of a campus horseshoe with a boys' dormitory and the Science Building on the left and two dormitories for girls on the right. In the center of the open space is the squat MurÂ­free Library. The gymnasium and other centers of activity lie behind the main building. What a beautiful place-and so big! How long will it take us to find our way around inside it? We are only twenty-eight miles, geographically, from home, but five hundred miles socially. We are awed by it. This is STC, State Teachers College, the place that our former teachers have taught us to revere. This is where Mary Dalton and Sara Palmer have gone, where Dick Osteen, Roy Dowdy, B. H. Thompson and Pedro McBride have gone-the Nathan Bedford Forrest High School immortals.. It is the educational mecca that has acculturated my parents and a host of school-teaching relatives. Off the mountain benches and out of the coves they came, from the creek bottoms and the barrens of the Highland Rim. They returned smart chic, modern because they had studied at STC. For fiftee~ years it had been a four-year college granting, by legislative approval, a baccalaureate degree. Before that, it had been a Normal School, one of the state's three originals, with its sole purpose the production of teachers. It is from here that commencement speakers have trailed the narrow blacktop roads and dusty pikes to bring a touch of college culture to a host of small community high schools. It is from here also that the Chapel Hill IndepenÂ­dent Baseball Team has got its ringers. On summer Sunday afternoons, the kids from our town have stood under the pine trees in front of the Methodist church and peered anxÂ­iously up the pike for the dust swirl that announced the coming of our allies. Soon Dick Osteen's roadster would pull in by the church and park under the protection of a hackberry tree. Out of the side door and from the rumble 4 seat would climb our heroes, Emerson Hendricks, Charlie and Bob Kerr, Buck Hindman, and perhaps another college star that Dick had recruited. They had worn the college uniforms, and the STC across their chests Ineant nothing less than invincibility. On my first day in college, in fact within the very first ten minutes of that day, I am destined~ to meet President Q. M. Smith. I walk through the front door of the baseÂ­ment, past the two walls of mailboxes and into the hall. I recognize no one, but try my best to look like a sophomore. I walk up the back stairs and head toward the expected security of the gym. This is where I meet a tall, longÂ­striding, well-dressed man. Obviously he is the boss of something. I give. him a "howdy-do-sir" to show him that I am comfortable. "Young man, are you a freshman?" he says, and thrusts out his hand. A type of social reflex sends my hand to his, but the rest of me stops. "I am Q. M. Smith, president of this college," he says, and then with a certain amount of compassion that he has learned from similar encounters, he turns and continues on his route. Except for Governor Henry Horton of Chapel Hill, I had never met such a big man, in a political sense, and no one has told me that this particular one is a veteran of the World War and that he had been gassed and that his larynx had been damaged and that when he talks, the words come out Hke a painful souna of wagon wheels strainÂ­ing over big rocks in the ford across Hickory Creek. Surely he is joking. How can it be possible? He can't be president and talk like that! But he can. The gymnasiuln is locked but I am on speaking terms with it. This is where the high school teams that have surÂ­vived the district tournaments come for their big fling each year. They come when buttercups. are blooming and wild onions are pushing above the winter grass. They come from everywhere, princes and paupers, and jump eagerly irrto the arena. Isaac Litton, Willow Grove, Lawrenceburg, Ir- 5

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 11
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: ving College, Manchester, Alpine ... it is a basketball marathon. A few. months earlier, Forrest High had been here. Our boys had been the scourge of the district. BeasÂ­ley, Holton, Harris, Scott, and Tanner had devastated their opponents, and at 10:00 P.M. on a Monday night they had defeated their first tournament foe in the college gym. Coach Rollie Holden was proud to display his team in his own hometown and on the same floor where a few years earlier he had earned the big T that he wore on his jacket. It was customary for the college boys in Jones Hall to abÂ­sorb two or three of the high school teams during tournaÂ­ment time. Many of the Murfreesboro residents also kept players as their guests. We should have chosen to do the latter, but we didn't. By midnight we had learned much about dormitory life, and by 2:00 A.M. a few were still doing research. At 9:00 A.M. we met Father Ryan, of Nashville, in our second match. What a crowd they brought with them! The game did not go like the other games. Itch Curley, Angelo Varrallo and Louis Catagnanni did not play like our previÂ­ous opponents. By the end of the half we were behind. At the beginning of the fourth quarter, the smell of doom was upon us. But look! At each time-out they kneel and bow their heads and cross themselves. They are praying. They are getting help. Cheaters!!! Forrest High's basketball hisÂ­tory had peaked. A bell rings, just like in high school, and we troop into the auditorium. Everyone of us goes in, every student and every faculty member. Ed Turner and Billy Haynes, the two black janitors, stand inside the back doors. Ed, tall, graceful and wearing a black skull cap, and Billy with big eyes and a toothy grin, seem proud of their positions and associations. Billy has been here since 1933 and Ed helped President Jones open the place in 1911. Someone tells the freshmen to move to the front. Now we are identified. Amidst arrogant stares and haughty reÂ­marks from "other" people, we walk uneasily to the front. 6 The freshman football squad, twenty-six of them, is already there. They occupy the first two rows of seats and they are the in-group people of the freshman class. They have been here for two weeks and sport all sorts of scabs and bruises. They laugh and nod at each other over some inside joke and look at us with only slightly more feeling than did the upper classmen. We envy these smart alecs, but they don't look so hot. Bill Burkett has wrists like a girl, Jack Deere looks like a stork, and Mouse McCullough looks like a mouse. They probably just hold dummies for the varsity. Dick Russell waves to some girls from Murfreesboro. It is the only friendly gesture we see. Dean Beasley presides at this assembly. Most of us know him, for at some time or another he has visited our school. We are attracted to him. He tells us about registraÂ­tion and freshman orientation and he calls the upÂ­perclassmen by their first names. We are not sure what the title "Dean" means, but it implies a lot of rank to us. He introduces us to ASB President Charles Brown, who stands on the stage above us and speaks to the people beÂ­hind us. We get the feeling that we are ignored, except by the dean. Professor Baldwin plays the piano and we stand and sing the ahna mater. Hail STC all hail Our praises ring To thee, with one accord . . . It is beautiful. We learn the words quickly. We sing with the upperclassmen. Surely this will bring us into the brotherhood. At the conclusion, Charles raises his almighty hand from the stage and gives us a notion that the upÂ­perclassmen will not always ignore us. "At the half of tomorrow night's football game, you freshmen will gather in the south end zone." Explaining registration to the freshmen is about as productive as explaining football to a Chinaman. We do 7

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: learn that the school year is divided into quarters and that classes that meet on Tuesday and Thursday also meet on Saturday. Perhaps half of our group have a fair idea of what they want in the distant future. 1 am not in that half. 1 know 1 do not want a class on Saturday and that 1 do not want to be a teacher. The rest of my efforts are incidental. The college teachers sit behind a row of tables on the second floor and help the most mystified of us. Dr. Sims, Mr. James, Dr. Burkett, and Mrs. Edney are especially helpful, and Dean Beasley hovers like a mother hen over the whole affair. "Are you taking the two-year endorsement or the four-year program?" "I don't know." "What is yoqr major?" "I don't know." "When will you start your education courses?" "Aren't they all education?" "Go see Dean Beasley." Don Wilson knows. that he wants to be in industrial arts. O. L. "Nooby" Freeman, a square-jawed bulldog, is the teacher. Don reports to Nooby and Nooby fills out the entire registration card for him. Triumphantly, Don returns to my desk. 1 carefully weigh my confused state against the sudden appearance of light and ten seconds later copy Don's card. Ernest Williams, using the same logic, copies mine. Henry Ford copies his, and thus a pattern is set for the undecided. We report to the bursar's office in. the basement, adjoining the bookstore, and Mr. J. S. Holmes figures our fees and presents us with a bill. Fifteen dollars for registration plus four dollars for the student activity fee are the big blows. The lab fee in biology is one dollar and in industrial arts it is fifty cents. None of my three tenÂ­dollar bills from the First State Bank of Chapel Hill survive Mr. Holmes, and 1 have a meal ticket and the freshman beanie yet to buy. Jones Hall is the only dormitory for boys and it is filled. 8 The Moffitt House, located across the boulevard from the football field, houses some ordinary citizens and the overflow of freshman ballplayers. It is a three-storey brick residence of 1890 vintage with a small cook's house at the back. About fifteen boys live in the house, and Burkett, Bain, Bostick, Brooks, and Phillips live out back. Behind that house and facing a street live Mr. and Mrs. Alton HanÂ­cock. They rent one side of their house, three rooms, to college boys. Don and 1 move in there. Ashton Wood from Normandy and Mark Goodman from Brick Church take another rOOlTI. Two sophomores, Bob Thompson and Clyde White, are already there. One bathroom accommodates the entire house. For us four freshmen, it is our first experiÂ­ence at living in a house with an indoor bathroom. We enjoy it too much-too much for the sophomores. After much provocation at our prolonged stays in the bathroom and the narrow avoidance of open conflict, they offer us candy as a peace offering. We take it. It is spiked with Ex-Lax. Saturday night, September 22, 1940, Jacksonville State from Alabama invades our campus. We gather on the west side of Jones Field. Nearly four thousand people can crowd into the wooden bleachers and fifteen hundred more can be seated on the east side. Sophomore "Doc" Richards sits in the red-cedar press box and makes like Ted Husing. The freshmen sit on the north end of the student section. Every girl is required to bring a' boy, so w~ are escorted: Sara Morrow, Evelyn Carroll, Beth Orr, Katherine GillespieÂ­college is getting better by the minute! A dramatic entry by our heroic Raiders ... red, white, and blue uniÂ­forms . . . white stars on their shoulders . . . what mastodons of muscle! They carelessly toss their helmets to the sidelines and proceed to warm up before the adoring cheers of hundreds. We want to be a part of it. We grasp at fragments of identification. "Look at '01 Ug McCrory. He's so ugly they call him Double Ugg." 9

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 13
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Elbert Patty is captain." "They say he's married." "Gosh, how old is he?" "Did you know that Hudson goes with that goodÂ­looking Wysong girl?" The game . . . slashing runs by Billy Bryant . . . boomÂ­ing punts by Bobby McClintock ... Half time ... the Raider Band, with little practice, serenades us from the stands. "Primo" hits a trumpet solo, the Marines' March. We stand for "Hail STC, All Hail." Then, from the pressbox: "Freshmen, follow Ronald Fields to the south end zone. Remove your shoes, boys and girls, throw them in a pile. Go to the north end zone. On the signal, race to your shoes. Find them and put them on ... the last ten to leave the field will get five licks each with the board. And reÂ­Inember this: on next Monday night all freshmen boys will meet in the lobby of Jones Hall. Girls at Rutledge." Our Raiders, with a 46-6 victory, are on their way to the dressing room before the last shoes are successfully claiIned. "A freshman is lower than seven layers of whale maÂ­nure on the bottom of the ocean and must jump up to touch mud." "Say 'thank you sir' after he hits you and get fifty names on the paddle." Roger Smith ... kerwhop! "Thank you sir." Cowden McCord... kerwhop! "Thank you sir." Bill Evans ... kersplatt!! "Godalmighty ... thank you sir." The collection takes place in the lobby of Jones Hall. The "cerelnony" is on the second floor. "Keep that blindfold on." "Have you ever eaten out of one of these?" "Freshman, you have the distinct honor of being the first representative of your class to kiss Mr. Smith's rear. 10 We want to thank you, Mr. Smith, for joining us." "Ye-eh-eh-ess. " "When I finish tying this knot, freshman, you pitch that brick." "Don't let us catch you with that high school letter sweater on again." "Freshman, do you know where Blackbottom is?" The maples along Tennessee Boulevard turn yellow by the middle of October and the fence-row sassafras turns a fiery red. The air is nippy, the world is new, and the 1940 freshmen, welded by circumstance, feel a rendezvous with greatness. We have survived the hazing, we are taking the challenge of teachers and coaches, we are living away from home, and soon people will know about us. Bubber MurÂ­phy and Joe Troop ... so what! Albert Gore and Ed Bell ... has-beens! The Faulkinberry Boys, James BuchaÂ­nan, D. Harley Fite, Big Jim Conley ... the tales we hear of heroes past will fade into insignificance by the time we leave. But there is some question about when we will leave. We cannot articulate it, but there is a question. Did it begin in a classroom in Issac Litton, or Lebanon, or ColÂ­lege Grove when we wrote term papers on the Spanish Civil War and the teachers said, "Each side is trying out its equipment before a bigger show"? Or perhaps it was in 1938 when our teachers said, "A man doesn't buy a big fine carÂ· and leave it parked in his garage. " During our senior year in high school, the man in Europe drove his car out of the garage. The draft law is now in effect in America, and each night the radio brings us the distracting sounds of the bombing of London. SomeÂ­thing besides graduation is beckoning to us, beckoning from behind tomorrow. But at STC the harvest moon rises .full over the Readyville Hills, girls laugh in Rutledge Hall, the morning sun greets people, who greet people, who relish the thought that today is today. 11

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 14
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mark Goodman says the school should run a bus over on our street because there are so many of us walking. Mark is witty but shy, and he is so honest and straightforÂ­ward that he is unbelievable. "Tee" Faulkinberry walks home with us. She is the daughter of the late Coach Frank Faulkinberry and has been around college boys all of her life. Tee, while telling some tale, emphasizes a point by punching Mark on the shoulder. Such an intimate gesture leaves Mark devastated. He turns alternately red and white and avoids Tee for days. B.. B. Gracey III and Allan Swasey, rarely seen without tennis racquets, also tread our street, but most of the student traffic goes to and from the Moffitt House. A meal ticket costs five dollars and will last a week if you eat lightly. Each ticket has pages of coupons in 25-cent, 5-cent, and I-cent denominations. This ticket is good in the cafeteria and in the lunchroom. A favorite breakfast spot is Bock's Tea Room, across the boul~vard from Rutledge Hall. For a nickel you can get two doughnuts, and another nickel will get a glass of milk. This place is also a hangout for some of the locals, for George Bock, Jr. often works there. H. R. Anderson and Bob Young have rooms rented upstairs above the tea room. I think half of the students are working at some paying job. The cafeteria pays off in meals, no money, but the liÂ­brary pays wages, and the athletic scholarships are really work scholarships that pay expenses. The jobs vary in level of difficulty. William Burkett and Henry Frank Brandon run errands for Coach Midgett, and Maury Smartt walks around carrying a stick with a nail on the end of it, spearing magnolia leaves and threatening passing girls. Joe Gibson assists Coach Jordan with the physical education classes, but most of the boys are assigned outside maintenance under the supervision of Floyd Travis. Floyd has been an employee of the college since 1930 and is well acquainted with hard work. Football practice is a welcome relief after working a half day for Floyd. Whicher Phillips works nights 12 at Red Rose and Charlie Greer sells shoes at Goldstein's on Saturday. The best deal of all is to be one of Leon Bibb's .Y.A. boys. Wesley Gilley, Frank Shepherd, Joe Maddux, Moe Tolbert, and about forty others finance their college education in this manner. Mark Goodman and Don Wilson discover that an excellent way to exist on weekends is to substitute for one of the cafeteria dishwashers who is going home. Mark studies on weekends a';d Don spends his extra time courting Elaine Hedgecoth at Rutledge Hall. It is a good system. Football ... football ... football ... the frosh are magÂ­nificent and render a little embarrassment to the varsity in a couple of full-field scrimmages. Bill Burkett throws to Jack Deere or Whicher Phillips or Maury, but always there is the speed of Bill Bostic and the sheer power of Moody Bain. They go through their season undefeated but are tied by Morgan Prep School led by a Murfreesboro runt named Jim Butler Lane, who scores all of their thirteen points. Coach Wink Midgett's first season and the final game is with his alma mater, TPI. On Wednesday, the campus and the town are at a fever pitch. We gather in the auditorium. Old grads return, misty-eyed with campus memories yet breathing fire at the thoughts of Tennessee Tech. Nooby gives his "Eagle Meat" speech and we sing "Hail STC, All Hail." The next day sees a Thanksgiving classic. Burney Lee Tucker runs the potent wingback reverse-but this time he straightens and throws. Forty yards downfield, Billy Burch catches it in the end zone. We win. The days pass. Ed Tarpley's dramatic club fascinates us with Our Town and E. G. Monroe steals the show. LQrÂ­raine De Priest, Ralph Drye, and the campus queen, Nancy Wysong, star in Abie's Irish Rose and later in Romeo and Juliet. Bonfires, Lewis Brinkley's orchestra, the Princess Theater, the Brown Jug, the bootleggin' bellhop at the James K. Polk Hotel, De George hamburgers-going to colÂ­lege is the thing to do. The whole world is here. 13

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 15
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Miss Eva Burkett says that historians record the passÂ­ing events of civilization but it is the poet who describes the heartbeat of the people. She plays records of Robert Frost reading his own poetry. "Mr. Frost does very well," she says, "but Edwin Arlington Robinson does it better." In the Science Building, Mr. Davis gives a oneÂ­question test as soon as the roll is called, then launches into a biological discussion. We are attentive, for there is no other way to be in that class. "How many wings does a grasshopper have, Mr. JenÂ­nings?" "Two," says Craps. "When the roll is called up yonder you won't be there," sings Mr. Dav'is. We shudder. "How many holes does a hydra have, Mr. Brandon?" "One," says Hank. "And how many does a man ,have, Mr. Brandon?" We stop breathing. Hank pales, but sticks his tongue in the gap between his two upper front teefh, the gap made by Melvin Black during his Golden Glove days, and squeaks, "Two." He made it. The bell rings. We made it. Down the stairs ... outside ... hysterical laughter. "Henry Frank, you should get an A in arithmetic for that," quips Vic Frazier. Basketballs are thumping in the gymnasium. Wink's varsity practice in the afternoon and Nooby's freshmen at night. Greer Wiggins, the student manager of everything, gives the two new pair of shoes allocated to the freshmen to Fay Brewington and Maury Smartt. The rest of us get what the varsity can't use. Buford Turpin is captain of the varÂ­sity, Roger "Big Brew" Brewington is the gunner, and Jimmy Schleicher is the work horse. George Summers and Mac Carter skid on the floor because their shoes have lost their traction. Jim Lane transfers from Morgan and joins the frosh. 14 He shoots one back over his head in the first game. Maury pumps the ball with one hand, even free throws. Nooby says the rest of us will dip-shoot fouls, "just like pitching a sack of sugar up on a shelf." Boonie Simmons and Doris Smartt are our guards, but our invincible big man is Faye Brewington from Willow Grove. He thrusts the ball up through interlacing arms, turns the universal joint in his wrist, and swish. We win our first four, then a loss to VanÂ­derbilt freshmen. It is a preliminary game to the VandyÂ­Alabama game played in the Hippodrome. Vandy's Pinky Lipscomb scores 29 points and sets a Southeastern ConferÂ­ence record. Then, a three-day trip into Kentucky . .. travel with the varsity ... room with Jim Butler at the Murray Hotel. We go to a restaurant and listen to "South of the Border" on the nickelodeon. On our return, someone has turned on the third-floor fire hose and flooded the place. The STC basketball squad gets the credit. Q. M. Smith gets the bill. We get evicted from Murray. Wink and Nooby promise to kill whoever did it. The Forty Frosh win 12 and lose 4. We are arrogantly proud. Nooby says all of us put together are nearly as good as Big Jim Conley was. Mr. Gracey teaches agriculture and scouting. Rheumatism has captured his once agile frame so he plugs in a heating pad and sits on it while teaching. Someone raises chickens as a class project in this basement room while we take a course called "Feeds and Feeding." Surely the course deals with the number of nubbins to feed yourÂ· milk cow or whether to mix an armful of shucks with two pitchforks of hay. No, it is about formulae of proteins, carÂ­bohydrates, and things. We nearly flunk it. The class is not exciting. The ever-mischievous Maury reaches wtih his toe and unplugs the chicken brooder. The chickens get cold. They start cheeping. Joe Dill says, "I can't hear for these chickens." Mr. Gracey dismisses the class and examines the brooder. It is springtime, 1941, a~d high school tOl;1rnament 15

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 16
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: time in Tennessee. All roads between the Tennessee River and the Cumberland Plateau lead to Murfreesboro. ButterÂ­cups line East Main Street and ~od over the sidewalks on the campus. Visitors following their teams marvel at the beauty of the place and the completeness of its athletic facility. The gym is packed with 1800 people for each session. Noody passes some of us in as ushers. We wear the pullÂ­over sweater with 1944 emblazoned across our chests. Giant "Mama Bear" Brooks keeps order in the balcony. He walks between the railing and the seats looking for malconÂ­tents, silencing with a wave any overly enthusiastic high schoolers. Slender little William Burkett, probably the more dangerous of the two, walks behind him. William's entire sweater can hang between the "1" an'd the outside "4" of Mama Bear's. First Monday in April ... it is Mule Day in Columbia. Chief Valdez takes the STC Band to the parade... assemÂ­ble at the Fairgrounds . . . march across the Duck River Bridge . . . up the hill through Mink Slide . . . around the courthouse-preceded' by five thousand mules. Bruce Robinson invites everyone to his house to clean up their shoes. The ASCAP strike is on and the old songs cannot be played on the radio. New ones are rushed to the presses Â«Walking by the River," Â«These Are the Things I Love," romantic music for any year. A new theme enters the Hit Parade: "From Taps til Reveille," "The White Cliffs of Dover." The draft is plucking a few fellows from the campus ... "Goodby Dear, I'll Be Back in a Year." Abbottt and Costello' appear iri a movie called Buck Privates and we see that a year in a peacetime army will be fun. Still, the bombing of Britain goes on. Dogwoods bloom and the Raider baseball team gets into action. Jimmy Jackson beats Vanderbilt on a threeÂ­hitter, and catcher Horton Tarpley screams high tenor enÂ­couragement for nine full innings. It is a good season. Char- 16 lie Greer hits opposite field doubles to right while Bill Driver and Dave Adamson slam drives to left. The ineligible and inactive Forty Frosh grumble in the stands. Late in May, Vic Frazier and Jack Deere prevail upon Coach JorÂ­dan to give the frosh a shot at them. He does. They beat us 8-7. It is our last confrontation with upperclassmen. Graduation approaches. The seniors get sentimental. I guess they are not so bad after all, but they have had their day. Go on, fellows-we will take your places. Goodby, Kitty McCord, Boots Little, Double Ugg. Get that general store out of Jones Hall, Randy Wood. Go on and join the air force, Jimmy Kennon and Orbrey Moore. Why do Dean Beasley and Mr. Jones shake hands with them so fondly? Miss Burkett, Miss Monohan, Mr. Judd, why do you gather in clusters with them? We are here. 17

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 17
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: II. The Year Two The Forty Frosh look down the road At a distant Forty-Four And find their vision dimmed somewhat By the threatening sound of war. And though they sing sweet songs of fun They hear far off the cannons' roar. WE ARE BACK. We arrive a day before registration and have an initial reunion in the cafeteria. There are no more STC secrets. We know the place. "Hey, Dynamite." "Hey, Beth." "Are you ready to register, Williams?" "Let's get out of Miss Burkett's English." "O.K. I can't make a B in there with a pencil!" "Hey, Betty McCambell, did you learn to play tennis this summer?" "Reckon Nooby will let us in Mechanical Drawing?" "Say, Jim Butler, is Sue Campbell coming to school over here?" Moody Bain bangs out "Elmer's Tune" on the piano, and Greer Wiggins and Babe Young jitterbug. The gulf beÂ­tween 'us and the upperclassmen of a year ago has disapÂ­peared. We are still the freshman class of'40, but now it is '41 and we are a solid section of STC. We go to the auditorium. Dean Beasley welcomes us. 18 He uses first names and includes Inany of our group. Lanky Tom Townes is ASB president and he calls for the freshmen to come to the front. What a bunch! We snarl at them as they pass. They outnumber the sophomores, but the quality is poor. Look at the long necks and beady eyes. I wonder how they will like the paddle? Not a bad-looking bunch of girls, though. "Say, look at that one with the white sweater, DynaÂ­mite." "I'n vote for that one walking down the aisle. How about that, Old Folks?" "Yep. Like two squirrel heads in a 'backer sack." We get registered and go to Jones Hall. The stupid freshmen are still milling around. A few drift over to the dorm, carrying suitcases and pasteboard boxes, wearing the beanies. The longest-necked one is Tom Suddarth. The one walking like he is trailing a mule is Bryan Turner. The pigeon-toed one with the wavy hair and his chest run out is Bobby Joe Womack. Maybe we should increase the number of names on a paddle to seventy-five. ' In spite of the draft, more students are registered at STC than at any time before. There is more money availÂ­able. A few empty whiskey bottles begin to show around Jones Hall instead of the corn-silk-smelling fruit jars. The hosiery mill in Murfreesboro is hiring more people. So are the pencil mills in Shelbyville and the shoe factory at Lewisburg. Real wages, though, are being paid at TulÂ­lahoma, where an army camp named Camp Forrest is being built. The teachers say, "Hard times are letting up." The students say, "Times are getting better." Times are better. They are the best. We live in a warm, dry building ... no water to draw, no stove wood to split, no cows to milk, no cold outhouses, no parental calls for bedtime or breakfast. This is a time for fun . . . and schoolwork. Registration is over. Classes begin, and we old-timers survey the crop. The new girl population is attrac- 19

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 18
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: tive Elva McMahon ... Elizabeth Clements Carolyn Webb blonde Emma Deere from Lexington and in Rutledge Hall there is DePriest girl number four. I see her walking from Rutledge Hall to the Main Building. She glides gracefully and erect. Her silhouette reminds me of the distant horizon behind rugged Burdalson Knob and Riddle Top. I walk across the campus toward her. She ignores me. Her hair is the color of mixed butter and molasses. I keep walking and looking. She looks at me. lt is only a glance, a cold rebuff, like a stiff-arm from Moody Bain. But ... it is also a dare. Jones Hall is crowded and takes three to a room. Don, Dynamite Wood, and I move to the third floor. We redisÂ­cover classwork, the cafeteria, the gym and the football field . . . hiking and hitchhiking . . . Saturday classes and science labs... church at College Place... Sammy Kaye's "Sunday Serenade." I add another path to my trek through STC, to Rutledge Hall and Freshman Jessie DePriest. The Forty Frosh do not immediately overwhelm the football lineup. In fact, Mama Bear is the only one to start the first game. Several, however, play and William Bostic runs ninety-three yards from the line of scrimmage against Western Kentucky for the longest run in the school's hisÂ­tory. As the season progresses, Moody Bain, William BurÂ­kett, Jack Deere, Doris Smartt and Whicher Phillips move in. Freshmen are eligible for the first time. Pratt BurÂ­roughs, Tom Suddarth, and Bill Burkett's younger brother, Bob, earn letters. The Raiders go 4-3-1 for the season, with the last bitter contest fought on Turkey Day at TPI. The clear but cold day in Cookeville sees a packed stadium for this most famous of Tennessee small college rivalries. Margaret Taylor, Babe Young, and Burton Nelson have little trouble drawing yells from the visiting Raider fans. The Eagles score first but miss the extra point; then for nearly three scoreless quarters the two teams tear up the turf in the middle of the field. As time is running out in the fourth quarter, long, tall Gene McIntyre gets loose on a 20 pass reception and is stopped six inches from the goal. ViÂ­sions of victory dance in our heads. "Old Folks" snorts along the sidelines, '"Hodges can gain six inches against a brick wall." Bob Burkett is a sure bet for the extra. Seven to six. Alas! The counted chickens do not hatch. Hodges fumbles and Tech recovers. We lose. Henry Frank Brandon is injured in the Tech game. He gets a bruised kidney or whatever you get when a boney knee sinks up in your side. When the team returns to MurÂ­freesboro, they get unpacked a~ the gym and someone helps Hank over to the dormitory. Everyone departs for Thanksgiving at home. Friday morning finds Hank alone and hurting too badly to get out of bed. Saturday finds him the same way, plus starving. Sometime during the late afÂ­ternoon someone wanders in and discovers him. They go after a can of soup. Hank survives. The draft is getting to us now and the war in Europe is getting hotter. How much longer can England hold out? The Dutch fight the Germans again, as they had done in 1914, but the French government has shown the cloven hoof. Boys are dropping out of school. Some are enlisting in a preferred branch of service and some are going in the one-year draft. Don Wilson gets his call in November and leaves by the first of December. But for those of us who are nineteen, college is still a grand and glorious place, so we live life strongly and fully and with no long-range plans. It is the first of December, 1941, and basketballs are thumping once more, Freshmen are eligible in all sports, so we collect two hotshots frOlTI Loretto, James Simpson and Red Bailey. ElTIory Davenport and Gene McIntyre are left over from last year's varsity, but the Forty Frosh dominate the squad. Maury and Doris Smartt, Faye Brewington, and Hank Brandon quickly step into the limelight. We win the first game over a service team and go home for a weekend. That is where we are, most of us listening to Sammy Kaye, when we hear about the Pearl Harbor attack. . I return from Chapel Hill after dark. The light over the 21

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 19
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: main entrance of Jones Hall illuminates a pair of stuffed pajamas with stiff anns, a grotesque head, and the entire thing suspended by a rope around its neck. It is the artwork of J. B. Roberson and Joe Money, and above it is a sign saying, This Is for You, Japan. We keep our radios going and gather in excited groups. The coiled spring that we have been sitting on since high school days is now reo leased. We are being propelled toward ... somewhere. Our inability to seriously consider long-range plans is justified. Some of us miss the Sunday-night trek to Rutledge and Lyon Halls. There is a rumor that some of the fellows are not coming back to school at all. We listen to the radio through the night. News continues to come in, bringing us the realization that the impudent oriental nation is more potent than we thought. Another rumor has it that an attack on the West coast may come tonight. Perhaps there is a hidden force already in the Canadian Rockies. The radio news emphasizes the rumors. 1:00 A.M. Â«Do you think we ought to pull out for h9me?" Â«Might be a good idea." Â«No. Wait up." "I don't belive they are going anywhere." Â«I think I'll stay here till they take California." Â«I'm going to stay until they get to the Mississippi." Â«I'm sleepy. Call me when the Japs take Lewisburg." Monday, December 8, 1941. President Roosevelt calls the Congress together and war is declared against the Axis nations. Dean Beasley calls ail assembly at STC and tells us that the fat is in the fire, but it is not a tilne for illÂ­considered action. We interpret that as advice to not run out and join up. Most of us follow that advice. Although our patriotic ardor swells greatly with the smell of war, our parÂ­ticular affection for college life swells even greater. Some of the fellows with ilnminent draft calls leave. The rest of us slide back into our lovely world. 22 We win three of our first four basketball gaInes, then the quarter ends and Christmas vacadon begin. Back to our hometowns we go Smithville Mt. Juliet ... Water-town ... Shelbyville Tullahoma Woodbury. We visit our high schools, which are still in session, and talk mainly to the teachers. We marvel, however, at the growth of the girls who two years earlier had made different shadows. At Chapel Hill, the annual alulnni garne is played. A packed house is there to see Holton and Harris from Cumberland University, Scott from Vanderbilt, and a number of other former greats massacre the high-school team. Coach John I. Parker trots his frightened high schoolers onto the floor. They beat us. David Hailey from Difficult, Tennessee, near Car-thage, picked up the nickname of Slug. He moved t? Jones Hall with Henry Ford, his high-school buddy, dunng the fall of 1941. A few weeks later he became enamored of Emma Deere, who is the Rutlege Hall roommate of Jessie DePriest. This puts Slug and me to traveling the same trail. Many others travel a similar trail. Henry Ford and Frances West were married secretly in high school. So were Jack Deere and Rachel Moody. The two married girls live on the third floor of the dorm. Visitors are not allowed in the lobby before 6:00 P.M. nor after 10:00 P.M. It is not unÂ­common, therefore, in the late afternoon, to see the sidewalk in front of Rutledge Hall lined with pursuers while the pursued lean from open windows to give more cause for pursuit. '. . Billy McDonald is sweet-talking Martha Northern, and Bill Mitchell is whistling for Ginny Denton. Most of the conversations are pleasant, but occasionally the secretly married couples gener~te a little fire. "Henry Ford, you just better not go to Carthage this weekend." "I think I will," says Henry. "CRASH!" says a flowerpot as it explodes on the sidewalk. We back away from Henry. 23

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 20
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: From his old group he retains the powerful trumpet of Red eel and the clarinet of Larry Richards. There is much to do in college. It is a great time to be alive. Winter Saturdays at STC are not demanding nor are they boring. The mornings are for classes, the afternoons for play and nights ... ah, the nights. Coach Nance Jordan lives at the Moffitt House. He is a friendly giant, a former footbatl center at Vanderbilt, and he is one of our favorite teachers. Rainy Saturday afÂ­ternoons mean that he will meet us in the gym for a rough-and-tumble half-court basketball game. He likes it rough. We decide to flatten him. Shorty Buchanan and Dick Driver try it, but bounce harmlessly off. Kenneth InÂ­galls "innocently" charges into him and splatters to the floor. Jim Butler figures he can get him. He picks a blind side and from thirty feet out races in like a bowling ball. Coach Jordan shifts a massive hip. Jim flies through the air upside down. His heels hit above Coach Midgett's small office window. The back of his head breaks two boards of the wainscoating below. We help Coach Jordan carry Jim outside, and the cold rain on his face revives him. Ed Baldwin completes the work on a Ph. D. and beÂ­comes Dr. Baldwin, geography teacher. He is a very verÂ­satile man and often entertains at our chapel programs by playing the piano, rolling his Eddie Cantor eyes, and singÂ­ing. We enjoy him. Eventually he becomes chairman of a faculty committee that plans our cultural growth. We asÂ­semble each Tuesday and Thursday. The faculty provides the Tuesday programs and the students provide Thursday programs. On a Tuesday in March we are treated to thirtyÂ­five minutes of classical violin. The following Tuesday we listen to a cellist. On the next Thursday we retaliate. A new female entertainer' has just come upon the Grand Ole Opry scene in Nashville. She calls herself Minnie Pearl. She is invited. She comes on the STC stage and mortifies our faÂ­culty by yelling a corny, "How-deee." Take that, teachers! Miss Kathryn Monohan is a proud, aristocratic old "What's the matter with y;U, woman? Are you crazy?" "CRASH!" says flowerpot number two. "Air raid!" yells McDonald. Henry stalks back to Jones Hall. Lyon Hall is the largest girl's dormitory. That is whe Whicher Phillips courts Ruth Mary Shadow, and Jimm Jackson courts Babe Young, and Bobby Joe Womack court Elizabeth ClemÂ·ents. That is where Jimmy Summers, Mau Smartt, Laddye Royster, Burton Nelson, and Horto Tarpley play the field. That is where Miss Margie Mitche lives as resident hostess, but where Katie Gore reigns Mother Superior. Bryan Turner and Clyot Lane go t whichever dormitory seems to be the most promising at the moment. All kinds of wartime restrictions go into effect in January. More things are rationed than we knew existed. Gasoline and tires make the biggest news but, except for Clyot Lane and Whicher, we are all on foot anyhow. Man high schools and colleges cancel their athletic seasons. We are in the midst of basketball, however, and wish to conÂ· tinue. Dorris Smartt and Lloyd McMurtry are drafted and leave the squad. A few 'others leave so they can attend to more immediate business. Maury Smartt and Brewington bornb the goals and we finish with a 9-9 season. Ed Tarpley continues to produce outstanding plays, using the dramatic talents of Raikes Slinkard, Van Fox, Fenton Warren, Kate Miles, Sara Murphy and others. John Zumbro gives an unusual character portrayal in The Man Who Carne to Dinner. The men's glee club is loaded with talent. There is Bruce Robinson, Donald Knight, Bob Womack, and a first tenor from the shade of Short MounÂ­tain by the name of Robert Daniel. One special number is "By the Bend of the River," featuring a few solo notes from the fist-sized Adam's apple of Tom Suddarth. Chief Valdez has the best band he has ever assembled. From Lewis Brinkley's high-school orchestra he inherits Horace Beasley, Bucky Doster, and the trombone of Scobey Dill. 24 25

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 21
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: lady. She is one of the original faculty members. Born in Nashville during the Civil War, she has seen many of the events of American history about which she teaches. She atÂ­tends mass at the little white frame church at the corner of University and Lytle. It is not unusual for some of Miss Monohan's Protestant students to appear occasionally at mass with hopes that God and Miss Monohan are both faÂ­vorably impressed. She is very pleasant, but is supersensiÂ­tive to a Victorian code of boy-girl relationships. A couple of years earlier, John Bragg, then ASB president, had been placed under citizen's arrest by Miss Monohan and ushered into the dean's office. While talking to the ASB secretary, Becky Thurmond, he had put his hand on her shoulder. John's tenure in office and in school was maintained by Dean Beasley's uncanny ability to arbitrate such facultyÂ­student differences, but John fell forever from Miss MonaÂ­han's graces. We are being educated at STC. We are being acculturÂ­ated at STC. We are creating memories at STC. The first warm nights of spring. Ten o'clock curfew at the girl's dormitories. The aroma of wild onions stirred by the feet of boys returning from Lyon Hall floats through the open window of Jones Hall. Our night watchman, Snoopy Doop, wearing his old brown felt hat and long coat, stops in the circle of light in front of the library and peers through thick-lensed glasses at his reflection in the glass door. Bill Ross, the barefooted punter from Smyrna, is cutÂ­ting hair for a dime per head on the second floor. Frazier Daugherty and Wesley Gilley are describing the new planer in the wood-working shop. Moody Bain and McClinÂ­tock are wrestling in room 208. The smell of scorched wood seeps up from 105 where someone has set fire to George Grau's Qoor. Eleven o'clock. The lights go out in Rutledge and Lyon. Jones Hall keeps throbbing. Bob Womack and LadÂ­dye Royster thump each other with the boxing gloves. 26 Munson Hallums and James Maxey wait for the main event. From room 315, Cato White shouts a threat at Ed Hildreth for knocking on his door. Only a few lights are burning now, but low-tuned radios play, "Sleepy Lagoon"... "Stardust"... soft and sentimental.
