"We interrupt this program to announce that the Japanese have landed on Attu _in t?,e Aleutian Islands." A rap on the door by Bryan Turner. Hey Dynamite, are the Aleutian Islands close to us?" "Too damn close." Baseball takes over, and Coach Jordan puts on a show with his fungo bat. Outfielders strain to catch up with towÂ­ering flies. He drives one deep into center field but fleetÂ­footed Maury Smartt lopes along and unconcernedly catches it behind his back. Left-handed Greer Wiggins retires as athletic manager and takes over at first base. Joe "Hut Sut" Raulston COInplains that taking infield practice is hazardous because the crooked-armed first baseman throws curves. "Ironhead" Cartwright and Smartt hit the long balls, but' banjo-hitting Gene Cartwright bats .400 with singles to right. McIntire and Jackson throw the traditional out-drop while Rock Reed saws off bat handles with the screwball. Tennis brings out boy and girl players and boy and girl watchers. Jean Barber and Margaret Taylor dominate the girls' game, with Geda Gill and Mary Mize in hot pursuit. Marcus Charles takes on aU comers among the boys and wins. We loaf under the elms near the courts. It is election time in Murfreesboro. A car pulls up. We recognize the driver. He says, "Will you fellows do me a favor?" "Sure, what't' . "Just take these poll tax receipts and go vote for my candidate. " We go. On the return trip the driver says to Roger Smith, "Did you vote for Iny man, Smith?" "No," says Roger. 27

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 22
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: HWhy not?" "I don't know either candidate, but your man is crooked. " HOld Folks" Deere and Greer Wiggins return to their dormitory room at noon. Each bed is turned upside down. The dresser drawers are emptied in the middle of the floors and the dressers placed on the beds. Their room has been Hstacked." On the window sill is a note. HThe Green HorÂ­net has been here." Curses, threats, clean up. We laugh, but not too much. The next day Sid Huggins returns to a similar scene. Then Maury and Mouse find their room upset with Mouse's side in complete disarray. Who is the Green Hornet? The next week it continues. On the second floor, Dynamite and 1 lock our door and tell the janitor to loan his passkey to no one. We go to Rutledge Hall. We return at 10:05 P.M. What a mess! The Green Hornet has walked the outside ledge to our window and struck again. Days pass. The rampage continues. Some of the same rooms are revisited. Mouse sets a trap. He hides under a pile of dirty clothes in the closet. His roommate comes in and calmly stacks the Mouse side of the room. He writes the usual note and leaves. The Green Hornet has been identified. It is Maury Smartt. Mouse passes the word and when Maury returns his side of the room is vacant; no bed, no dresser,' no pictures, no chair, and no clothes. EveryÂ­thing is in a heap on the ground outside the window. Stuck on the wall with chewing gum is a note saying, HTo hell with the Green Hornet." An invitation from the Sigma Club, the male honor soÂ­ciety. 1 am already honored. The first sophomore ever to receive the call, they say. 1 write home for the eight-dollar initiation fee and hope my folks will send more. On the apÂ­pointed night, Dewey Pedigo and Dalton Stroop escort me to the New Science Building. Though the building is ten years old, it is the newest on the campus. The second floor 28 is for home economics, and in the central po~tion of that is a large, elaborate reception hall. This is where the colle?e puts on its finery. There are chandeliers and small whIte marble columns and huge slabs of ~ellow-poplarpaneling .to impress the visitor. This is where the Sigma Club holds Its formal meetings. Stroop and Pedigo take adyantage of my wide-eyed en-thusiasm and set me up perfectly. "We are sure glad to have you join us. A m~n with your academic record will ~~a~e us ~ ~n,~ m~mber. (They must not have noticed the D and C s MISS Burkett has pinned on me.) HMr. Frazier said your father was a charter member and he is proud you are coming in." (Oh well, it is time these teachers began noticing.) . We enter the magnificent room and Club PresIdent William Arrendale makes the introductions. The meeting starts. Two other candidates, James Harney and Wilson Patton, are seated in straight-backed chairs wtih me. 'Ye are told that the membership would like to ask us a few questions just to assure themselves that the selection comÂ­mittee had wisely selected. It starts slowly, then, "Would you please compare the English import of cotton in 1871 with the ,production of the same in Mississippi during the same year? HPlease explain why the Wall Street stock market was bullish during the spring of 1921." We are stunned. The questioning continues, bvt now the friendly faces that we had earlier seen are hard and cold, and the voices are reeking with sarCaSITI and apparent disgust at our ignorance. " HDo you believe in a double standard? . HWell, take about five minutes and explain your VIews on the subject." HDo you think that the vice-president under Buchanan was correct in his attitude toward the supreme Court?" HWhy?" 29

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 23
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Great day! I didn't know these fellows were so smart. We are given a five-minute break, then Patton and Harney are called in. Five minutes later I am asked to return. ArÂ­rendale says that Patton and Harney have been accepted, but !?e .membership ~ould like to question me further. WIll you please describe the effects of the Newlands Act of 1902?" "Well then, tell us why Canada rejected the reciprocity proposal of 1911. No?" "Mr. Nunley," says McBride Jones, "Is there some question that you can ask yourself and answer it?" ; Ernest Hooper follows with, "Mr. Nunley, are you sure that you graduated from high school?" (Cut the crap, ErÂ­nest.) Then Raikes Slinkard, "Mr. Frazier, I believe it is ob.vious t?at o~,r selection committee has been deceived by â€¢ thIs candIdate. I begin to heat up. (I may bust your big nose, ~aikes.) Van Fox says, "I have been on these juries _many tunes, but this is the most inept performance I have e.ver witnessed." (Van, you sonofabitch.) My tie gets too tIght and my face burns, then Pedigo cuts)n with, "I am em~arrassed about bringing him over here." (I'll kill you, Pe~Igo, as soon as we get outside.) McBride Jones starts agaIn (Damn you, McBride, just wait) but Mr. Frazier inÂ­terrupts. "Gentlemen, this is embarrassing to all of us. I was hoping that some of the intelligence of the father would have been transmitted to the son ... (No, not you too, Mr. Frazier!) ... but perhaps we should ask a few more questions. " "I'm ready to vote now," says Ernest. (That does it. The next one that cuts me is going to get hit and I am !?oing ~ut the door.) I stand up. William Arrendale says, We WIll now caucus for a minute." (To hell with the Sigma Club!) ~ tug at my coattail and a whisper from Evil-Eye Stroop, Cool down, Joe, they are kidding." I don't believe it. I am too far gone. The bastards huddle at the other end of the room .and I turn to the outside door, fully intending to slam the glass out of it. 30 Arrendale says, "Mr. Nunley, congratulations. You have been accepted by a unanimous vote. We were just kidding." I swallow a bit and croak, "Aw, hell, I knew you were all the time." It is late spring of 1942. The war has been going on for five months and we know that our wonderfully irresponsible moments of college life are ebbing fast. Still, there are the practical concerns of education. Another crop of seniors are busying theInselves with graduation plans. Ruth Tittsworth, Lucille King, and Allene Kerr will soon be vacating their jobs at the cafeteria. Roger Smith will join the marines. Fenton Warren, Tom Townes, Frank Shepherd and the rest will join sOlnething. Again the teachers talk to the seniors as if they are equals. Slug Hailey and I sit on the Rutledge Hall steps with Emma Deere and Freshman DePriest. The lilacs by the sidewalk have bloomed and gone. The foliage on all of the shrubs and trees is maturing to a deep, dark green strong with life vibrant and pleasing to the eye. A gust of wind moves sharply through the linden tree and a few leaves, jerked from their moorings, flutter to the ground. The wind passes on and the majestic tree that honors the front of RutÂ­ledge Hall lifts its boughs and resumes its majestic posture. Bryan Turr~er walks by, pushing the invisible plough handles. There are no stray girls on the front porch, so he moves on to Lyon Hall. Jim "Lane'rolls a walnut down the sidewalk at Elva. Out in the street, Clyot Lane gets his old Blue Goose cranked, and J. B. Roberson, Billie Green, and Beth Orr climb in. On the porch behind us, Billy McDonald and Martha Northern slap at each other around the huge columns. Inside the lobby, Hewlette Burton plays the piano while Edna Jackson, Elaine Stepp, and Marie Bone sing. Mary Mize walks in with her eyes crossed and the eyelids rolled up on matchsticks. The startled chorus chase her outside so she clowns for us. She has a letter from Skip Anderson in Australia. "Read it to us, Mary." 31

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 24
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "O.K. It says, "Dear Mary, ...m ... m ... m ... warm weather. Second page: . . .m . . . m . . . m . . . steak and potatoes for breakfast ... m ... m ... m ... and mmmmmmmmmmmm when I get back. Yours truly, Skip." "Well. What did it say?" "I just read it to you. Weren't you listening?" After supper the girls sign out and we walk to town. Down the boulevard and up East Main... past the Elrod residence, Brinkley's store, stately old Tennessee College for Women, with its forbidden sidewalks and giant oaks standing like sentinels before us. We cross the street and look at the photographs inside the viewing box in front of the Lively residence. We walk slowly, hoping that time will choose our cadence instead of its own ... past Miss MurÂ­free's tall green-shuttered house. The fragrance of flowers â€¢ and newly mown grass rises from the well-kept yards. Trees from either side of the street intertwine their limbs high above and an occasional car moves along beneath them. We cross back over the street at the James K. Polk Hotel past the police station, around the corner at Smiths' Drug Store. We are smitten, as we knew we would be, by the delightful smell of hamburgers and Â·onions from De George's. Johnny, standing in the doorway with an apron wrapped nearly twice around him, waves at us, then turns to talk to khakiÂ­clad soldiers who have come in. Before the courthouse Johnny Reb, standing on his eight-foot column of limestone, thrusts his musket before him and glares eternally at the north. We pass Stickney's Drug Store. More soldiers are on the sidewalk. They are either on-pass from some outfit in the Tennessee Manuevers or are waiting bus transportation to somewhere. We pay our twenty-five cents at the ticket booth of the Princess Theater and go in. We select seats at the back and away from the aisle. Carmen Miranda, with a headful of bananas, jiggles and sings to Van Johnson. We pay some atÂ­tention. We didn't expect the show to thrill us, but it is a place to go. 32 We walk back by another route, down East Lytle and across the campus of the Training School. It takes some time to cross this campus. There are the entrance steps, the merry-go-round, the terrace by the hedge, and the unÂ­lighted walk back to the boulevard. Fifteen more ~ovely minutes in the shadows' 'neath the linden tree. It IS ten o'clock. Mrs. Daniels comes to the door and rattles her keys. The girls go in. We walk silently back to Jones Hall. 33

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 25
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: III. Summer of '42 IT IS SUMMER, and Freshman DePriest stays in school. She must complete her two-year program for the elementary school certificate as each of her three sisters before her has done. Then she will teach school, repay the â€¢ original loan, and DePriest girl number five will come to college. As much as I would like to be socializing there, I will not go to summer school. My folks have moved back to the farm at Viola for the summer. There is work to be done and baseball to be played and-heck, summer school, like spring football, is just out of step with the natural sequence of things. Corn is shoe-top high in Fults' Cove and ready for the first scratching with a double shovel. Â¥y brother, "Jue," plows with an ancient black mule named Hamp, and I plow with a bay saddle horse named Charlie. Mulberries are ripe on the mountain benches, and squirrels are feeding early and late. I keep a steady supply coming in to our kitchen and will keep it up until our chickens get large enough to fry. At noon each day I slip the harness from Charlie and ride him to Mount Zion, a mile away, to the turn-around place for the mail carrier. There I pick up the mail and the daily paper, and while Charlie hits a running walk for home, I read a perfumed collegiate letter. Viola buddies Dave Hoover, Gordon Crouch, and Buck Mabry return from Tennessee Tech and we revive the Viola baseball team. We playa game at Morrison. Jack Whitlock, 34 a recent STC graduate, is managing their tealTI. He tells us that many of the college boys are joining the" Enlisted ReÂ­serve Corps. The advantage lies in being able to stay in school a little longer and then going directly into officer training. Each branch of service is making this offer. Hobart Massey, Jr., sends word for me to meet him in McMinnville. Hobart has been courting Otelia "Spider" Curtis since before he started shaving, and even though she attends STC and Hobart goes to the University of TennesÂ­see, the romance remains alive. "Let's go to Murfreesboro in my car and see the girls," he says. A once-a-week habit is begun, with part of the gasoline rationing stamps being generated by our farm. Tom Murphy only plays two games for Viola. He and Charles Smartt join the army. Tom writes that they are driving tanks and that it is very similar to driving tractors. E. L. Groves joins the air force. Alice Milstead starts a colÂ­lection of photographs of Viola's departing warriors and exhibits them on the walls of her general store.. Howard Bonner Ramsey and Teeny Murphy get marÂ­ried. CHIVAREE!! At eleven P.M. we descend on the RamÂ­sey house like a hail storm. Howard Bonner rides the rail and Teeny the tub all the way to the Milstead store. We are treated to candy, drinks, and cigars. Howard Bonner pays the bill. It is the first of July and we start plowing the same corn fields for the third time. We are laying it by. The stalks are taller than Charlie's ears and the blades stiff . enough to slice bare anTIs. It is hot. No air ripples the tops of the corn. Sweat lathers rise in frothy stremTIS from under Charlie's collar and works down his front legs and along the trace chains to his flanks. We emerge from a sweltering green tunnel and walk to the shade of a fence-row hackberry. From my shoes I elTIpty small lumps of dirt that have failed to crumble with the pressure of foot and leather. I hear the roar of an airplane. Charlie, with droopÂ­ing ears and heaving sides, is unconcerned. I am in- 35

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 26
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: terested. On its wings I read, U. S. Air Force. It streaks across Burdalson Knob and is gone as easily as I flip away a gravel. That guy up there is cool-well dressed, well paid-going to be a war hero. That does it. I am signing up as soon as corn is laid by. Summer school is over at STC and Freshman DePriest is back in Perry County. She writes that she had an unusual visit. Slug and Emma have stopped by. They are married and Slug has joined the air force. Doggone! September 1st, I gas up our '37 Ford pickup at the Viola Service Station. "Hoe-Handle" Gardner, a nineteenÂ­year- old footloose friend, says, "Where are you going?" "To Nashville to sign up." "I'll just go with you. Hey Marvin, tell Dad I've gone to join something." Across the street Alice Milstead searches for two more photographs. We get to Chapel Hill. Then, three flat tires later, we make it to the Customs Building in Nashville. "What are we going to join?" asks Hoe. "'Marines. " We go into the office, sign in, look at the beautiful uniÂ­forms and wait for the physical. Hoe-Handle has only one eye. He says, "The marines won't take me. Let's join the army and go in together." We walk down the hall to the army office. Same routine-the physical. They take lne, send Hoe-Handle back to Viola. 36

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 27
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: IV. The Fall of '42 Each day they hear the fury scream Far beyond the country's shore. The Forty Frosh depart the scene; There is no class of Forty-four. The sheepskin scrolls in strict array Await the Class of Forty-four. OW WE ARE on borrowed time; enlisted in a reserve corps, but on borrowed time. "Why did you join the navy, Dynamite?" "I've seen the army manuevers around here, and when it rains those fellows sleep in the mud." "Yes," says Turner, "but that mud is firmer than water. If an army truck breaks do~, you can walk out. How far can you walk on water?''> . "I can't even swim; and I'll take the navy," says Bohby Joe. "You can have the mud and C-rations," says the Green Hornet. "I'll take clean sheets .and ice cream in the navy." "Which navy did you join, Hornet-the Mexican?" Only one hundred twenty freshmen enroll, and the upper class nurnbers are falling. War work as well as miliÂ­tary service diminish our ranks. Q. M. pulls in our perimeters to keep the college going, for obviously, condiÂ­tions are going to worsen. He begins to negotiate for some 37

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 28
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: of the military training programs which could be housed on the campus. The legislature changes our name from State Teachers College to Middle Tennessee State College. EviÂ­dently, it is felt that the name "Teachers" may frighten some prospective students away. Already we have pre-law, pre-medicine and pre-dentistry, but now our curriculum is said to be broadened. The only effect this change has on us is that we try to cram four syllables into three beats for our Alma Mater. "My name is Jeneal Smith from Ahd-moah, TennesÂ­see," she says. "What's the matter with you, Dynamite? Are you sick or something?" ::Hey Dynamo, why don't you quit that silly grinning?" She has gone now, Dynamite, you can go back to work." The cafeteria dish-room gang becomes a close-knit one. We eat early, then retreat to our station before the dishes come in. Bruce Robinson receives the trays from the dining hall and drags them into a big sloppy vat. Bryan Turner and Norman Lane rack them for the washer; a cross-eyed black man named "Moe" drags them from the machine while Reece Smith and Dynamite Wood dry and stack them on the shelves. I am the silverware specialist. -For this work we eat free. Norman is a thin, delicate-looking, quiet freshman from Chattanooga. He is always there early and helps any of us who lag in our work. Turner is an everÂ­talking clown who keeps us all off balance because he is deadpanned. Smith is a tall, lanky freshman football player from Nashville who carries an aching back in~o the dishÂ­room after every practice session. The rest of us are oldÂ­timers. Mr. and Mrs. Bock have -closed their tea room across the street and are now managing the cafeteria. A lot of things happen at the cafeteria. Students gather early and sit on the front steps ... stand in the shade of the 38 magnolia tree . . . conceal a big rock inside a paper sack and leave it on the sidewalk for an unsuspecting freshluan to kick. When the door opens they file in and follow the food line with its assortment of items, wishing to select freely but restrained by the thin meal ticket or the limited cash on their tray. Judgment Day is at the cash register where Betty McCampbell surveys the take 'and renders an irrevocÂ­able decision on the cash register, supervised from near or afar by Mr. Bock. Tables are arranged for four diners, but sometimes groups pull them together, and sometimes ~ ~oner fi~ds ~ne for himself. Table hopping is a routine actIvIty. As In hIgh school a certain pecking order arises, resulting in some taÂ­bles ~ith dimmer welcome lights than others. The piano is located by the front door, and it is near here that Iuuch ac-tivity takes place. ". "All of you freshmen girls come over here, says KatIe. "Now, while Pepper plays the piano, you, Sue Squashes, sing 'Hail MTSC.' " Embarrassed freshmen Pat Hope, Blanche Cook, Mary Ruth Holman forget the words, are chastised, must repeat. Later, with no coercion, they sing again "Johnny Doughboy Found a Rose in Ireland." "White Cliffs of Dover." Trays begin coming in. Bruce swears as a broken glass under the suds cuts his hand. Turner adjusts the hot water in the washer, causing a spray to hit Dynamite and Moe. More swearing. Outside, Katie Gore and Burton Nelson collect a few "John Eggs" from the freshman class to herp the girls lead school yells. Puny cheering, lots of laughter. Norman Lane keeps the dishes coming while Mrs. Bock bandages Bruce. "Hey Tun-uh, think fast," says Smith a~ he sails a dish to him. The rusty old wa~her keeps splashmg. "Think fast Moe." Turner sails a plate to him. It hits the wall then the concrete floor. Moe protests, "You boys cut dat ~ut, I don't see too good." The ever-vig~lant Mr. Bock charges the seven of us with an~the~ plate. " " The music is better now. You II Never Know, Blue 39

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 29
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hawaii," "Miss You." The traffic subsides. Jeneal Smith and Joy Bragg go wheeling back to Rutledge Hall and Dynamite leans over the dish vat to watch them. We rush to dry and stack the dishes ... clean the washer ... sweep ... mop . . . and leave. Freshman initiation at Jones Hall is about as rough as it ever was. The sophomores, as usual, take the lead in it and this bunch is tough. Maybe it is because we beat the hell out of them last year. Several Murfreesboro students have enrolled, and they draw a lot of attention, but very special treatment is reserved for Bill Beasley, the dean's son. Bill is the recipient of every hazing trick that we know. He is humiliated, embarrassed, and somewhat wounded, but he survives. In Rutledge and Lyon Hans, Kay Dickens, Flo Eskew, Evelyn Jones, Bettye Browne and the others get the usual. They sing a few unusual songs, give some inÂ­dividual performances in the lobby, and eat peanut butter with their fingers from a slop jar. Freshman footballers George Fisher, Hilary Martin, and Jack "Axehead" Ye.arwood hope to win scholarships. Axehead has been given his books, but none of the three are on meals. They run out of money on Friday. Fisher, however, expects to receive a five-dollar money order from his mother in the afternoon mail. It doesn't come. TheyanxÂ­iously await Fisher's Saturday morning mail. Nothing. Saturday afternoon ... intestines growling ... desperaÂ­tion . . . walk to town . . . snatch a bag of oranges . . . reÂ­treat. Sunday ... all day, oranges. Monday ... six eyeballs on a mailbox. Nothing. Football practice on nothing but vitamin C ... last of the oranges. Tuesday morning ... the check arrives . . . big rush to the lunchroom . . . four dollars worth of sandwiches and milk. The male population at MTSC has become so depleted that only one senior, Emory Davenport, reports for football practice. This is our year, the Forty Frosh, but where are 40 we? Gone are Moody, Rock Reed, Old Folks, Dorris Smartt, Bostic, Henry Frank and the others. It is the freshman class of '42 that fills in and keeps the intercolÂ­legiate football program alive. Wilburn, the third Burkett from Watertown, is now on the squad and so is Bill NisÂ­bett, Bill Blackman, Sam Rawls, Glen Kinnard and Lyle Fulton. Rol Brown comes out of three years in mothballs and joins the squad. We have the numbers and we are enÂ­thusiastic, for we still have a tremendous weapon in the passing arm of William Burkett. Wink works on the patterns while Nooby sharpens the teeth of the linemen. The rules for blocking do not require a blocker who is protecting the passer to keep his hands in contact with his jersey. This tolerance is' made to order for freshman guards Hunter Reasonover and Hilary Martin, who are both boxers. Axehead is not a boxer, he just plays that way naturally. The season opens at Memphis State. The team travels by train and leaves at 6:00 A.M. The dormitories empty at 5:00 A.M. and we walk down the boulevard and up East ' Main toward the courthouse and the depot. The first blush of autumn is on the maples and the mists of dawn drift upÂ­ward as we walk. The band and cheerleaders lead the way, stopping occasionally for impromptu cheering. Many of the East Main residents, accustomed somewhat to unusual colÂ­legiate behavior, wave from front porches. At the depot the cheerleaders, J. B. Roberson; Pat Hope, and Burton Nelson cavort in the early daylight. Wink thanks us for seeing th~m off. Emory, speaking for the team, promises to return with scalps. Greer Wiggins gives Wink the current head count ... The train moves out, north to Nashville. We watch it disappear, envisioning the fury of our gladiators on the field at Memphis. Our radios in Jones Hall are ineffective. We cannot reach Memphis. But at 10:30 P.M., over a Nashville station and sandwiched between bulletins about the battle of Guadalcanal, comes our news. The Raiders have beaten Memphis State, 21-13. We can hardly wait for the morning 41

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 30
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: papers. They arrive at the cafeteria. Excited groups ... "read louder" ... Dutch Myer, head coach at Texas Christi~n University, has seen the game and is quoted as sayi~g that William Burkett gave one of the most dazzling passIng performances he has ever witnessed in college footÂ­ball . . . Suddarth and Mama Bear tangled the Tiger flanks . . . Reasonover and Axehead punished them in the mid-dle. That>--s showing them, by gosh! . This season and the next are the big ones Wink has been looking for. The '42 team is spectacular, but their ben~h is thin. Midway in the season the foe is Tampa, Flonda. Again we walk to the depot to see our undefeated Raiders off. Doc Richards and Burton Nelson watch the train pull away, then run to U.S. Highway 41 and start thumbing south. A day later and 800 miles away, the Haider football team detrains in the strange confines of Tampa. There to greet them are the resourceful Doc Richards and Burton Nelson. The game in Tampa appears to be lacking in fairness. Two Raider touchdowns are called back in each of the first two quarters. Wink shouts his displeasure to the officials. The box operator, near the sidelines, tells Wink to quit his griping. Hilary Martin rises from the substitutes' bench walks to the sidelines, and decks the box operator. Whe~ the extracurricular activity subsides, a Tampa resident comes out of the stands and gives Hilary a five-dollar bill. The first loss is at Tampa, 13-0, and there are injuries. On Monday, Greer Wiggins comes by the dishroom. "NunÂ­ley, \\link said for you to get your tail to the gym and dress out. We need somebody to scrimmage against." Crownover and I join the squad as cannon fodder specialists. William Burkett continues his passing magic while Bob, Whicher, and Hornet do the receiving. Jim Lane, Bill Nisbitt? and Bill Blackman add the running punch. Murray, Kentucky, gains a tie with us-our only other blemish until Thanksgiving Day. We are ready for them, but Bob Burkett gets a broken leg in the first quarter. It seems to pull our 42 stinger and we lose to Tennessee Tech. This pulls down the curtain on intercollegiate athletics in Murfreesboro, TenÂ­nessee, until ... farther away than we can see, or dare to think. Mr. Gracey becomes intramural director and Greer Wiggins, of course, is the student assistant. The school is divided into numerous luen and women teams with captains appointed and a point system devised for team and indiÂ­vidual awards. Touch football, basketball, and volleyball are our main events. To compensate for the complete lack of an extraluural activity, Rol Brown organizes a school basketball team to play against the service teams that seem to be sprouting everywhere. Our transportation for the away-games is furnished by the luilitary. They have the gasoline. Life in the dormitory continues to be good. We still live in comfort and we enjoy the delights of the campus. At 5:30 A. M. we cafeteria workers roll out' for work . .. shave splash a little bay rum on our faces, rose oH on our hair listen to the radio. News from the South Pacific and frOlu North Africa. Mainly we hear "String of Pearls, " "Jersey Bounce." Whicher Phillips' younger brother, Ray, is in the dorm. He gets a job in town that requires him to be there at 7:00 A.M. He has been late for work several times because he is a morning dead-head. He asks us to awaken him. We knock on his door until he anÂ­swers. We leave. He, goes to sleep. The next morning we get him on his feet and leave. He goes back to sleep . . . again we awaken him and drag him into the hall. Same reÂ­sult. The next day we drag him down the steps and leave him head down. Same thing. He loses his job. Penny crap games are in style on the third floor of Jones Hall, nickel and dime games on second, good-sized poker games on first. Not all of the participants are stuÂ­dents. Lots of fun and frolic of various sorts are in eviÂ­dence, much to the displeasure of President Smith, who makes an occasional unannounced visit. He drops a hint to 43

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 31
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: the dormitory council: "Straighten up." We don't hear too ~ell. Rutle?ge and Lyon Halls are the dorms we are really mtere~ted m. Doc Richards is chairman of the dormitory councIl and I am the junior class representative. Q. M. reÂ­quests a conference ... "Straighten up Jones Hall or I will close it and the dorm council will be the first to go." We hear him this time. Council meeting. We must call in the "problems" and ~av~ a father-s~n talk with each of them. Dh boy! A long lIst IS prepared. They are to come to Doc's room one at a time, for their talk. "Go get them, Joe." Good night! BudÂ­dies! Roommates! "Who is lecturing whom?" "... but I was with you at the time." "Who the hell do you think you are?" "I may tell Q. M. the full story." "I won't tell if you won't." "Wow!" It is over. Doc reports to Q. M. that the sinners are repentant. We get a stay of execution. January becomes the month for the second-floor war games. The fellows who have enlisted in the navy crowd into one room; the army must throw them out. Bruiser Kinnard and Charles Chitwood have joined the marines so they ch?ose either side. Doors are unhinged ... dres~ers s~o~ed Into the breach . . . torn clothing . . . sweaty bodies sl.Idmg on the concrete floor. We cannot dislodge the swabÂ­ble,~ ... they won the last game. They jeer, "Come and get us. Strategy huddle in the stairwell. "Let's throw Axehead in over their heads and while he fights we will rush them." A~ehead agrees and removes his thick glasses, which leaves h~m virtually blinded. Lyle Fulton and George Fisher get hIs arms, Turner and Smith, his legs. Joe Money gets under his stomach. Down the hall comes the human canÂ­nonball ... into the doorway he is thrown ... Alas! ...too high..For a second, Yearwood sticks there, impaled on the doorsIll. Then he drops. We bring wet towels, mop blood 44 from his face, tear off a shirttail to make a bandage. We get him on his feet. He puts on his glasses . . . sees Sam Rawls wiping blood, hair, and hide off the doorsill. "I don't even want to be in the same army with you sonsofbitches," he wails. The teacher education classes are not looked upon with great favor by the boys. Almost everyone suspects that they may sometime be called upon to teach school, but the boys cannot afford to admit it, and therefore postpone enrollÂ­ment in the alleged "schoolmarm" courses. Dr. Golightly, Dr. Lewis, and Dr. Waller are the classical educators with roots stemming directly from Columbia Teachers College in ew York. They have taught through the Normal period of this school's history and have known, to some degree, alÂ­most all of its graduates. The art of pedagogy, however, is lacking in appeal to prospective teachers, and especially to those who are only halfheartedly prospective. Miss Frizzell and Miss Mary Hall teach the how-toÂ­teach courses for elementary teachers, and therefore have almost completely female classes. Miss E. May Saunders teaches a vocal music course that is required of everyone who thinks they may teach. One of the standards for successfully completing the course is a solo rendition of a seldom-heard song while standing in front of the entire class, singing the do-re-mi's instead of its usual lyrics. This is not a course for the faint of heart. Most of the boys would pr~fer another freshman initiation night in Jones Hall. Even some of those who can sing, such as Joy Bragg, shed tears by the wailing wall in the basement when the day arrives for this performance. Professor Clayton Jalnes is a little different from the stereotyped education professor. He is a tall, well-dressed man who walks with a smooth, dignified stride and possesÂ­ses the uncanny knack of making each student feel he is talking to his favorite uncle. He teaches educational sociolÂ­ogy and does it with a solemn type of humor that smacks of reality and pleasantness and compassion. He is in great 45

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 32
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: demand among the midstate schools as a commencement speaker. The word gets around th~ campus that we should elect to take his class. In January an ice storm hits central Tennessee. It beÂ­gins in the afternoon with a mixture of snow and rain. Whicher's Model T becomes a mechanized sled as it steams around the circle from the gym to the boulevard. Boys and girls hang on to the rear bumper and Sid Huggins ties on a sled. Whicher picks up momentum down the boulevard . . . hits the reverse pedal. Everyone cartwheels except Sid. He ricochets off a tree. The stuff falls all night. The next morning the world is transformed into an arÂ­tist's delight. The ground is covered with three inches of snow and ice, and every twig on every tree or shrub is enÂ­cased. Walking from the dormitories is a hazardous trip. Students hurrying to beat the eight o'clock bell run, slide, fall, throwing books into the air, get up and go again. Around Rutledge Hall comes Miss Monohan, wrapped in overcoat, scarf, and galoshes ... carrying her grade book . . . stepping slowly . . . deliberately . . . knowing that she will be late, but no later than she can help, for duty must prevail. Mr. James rounds the other end of Rutledge Hall. The same mission . . . moving a little faster. Their paths should intersect near the west end of the Main BuildÂ­ing. Suddenly, the treachery of the ice claims Miss MonoÂ­han. She is down. She struggles to rise, but slips again. Gallant Mr. James goes to her rescue. He takes her arm to lift her. Miss Monohan looks up-it is a man!!! She recoils in horror. Mr. James, thinking that she has slipped again, reaches for the other arm. Miss Monohan strikes back at this attack. Then-treachery of all treacheries-the ice claims Mr. James. It claims him, not to fall freely upon its glistening surface, but full face downward upon the invioÂ­late body of Miss Monohan. Students standing in the west vestibule of the Main Building warming themselves by the radiators shriek in deÂ­light at the conflict on the ice. Boney stockinged knees 46 pump madly to escape while chaste arms thrash at the ravisher. Distinguished, but now undignified, masculine feet search wildly for traction that will help extricate him from this horrible situation. College boys and girls not yet inside their classrooms rush to the end of the building, summoned by the hysterical laughter of those in the vesÂ­tibule. Mr. James, in desperation, hurls himself to the side. His fiercely indignant partner scoots in the other direction. Mr. James makes it to his feet, retrieves his book, ignores further attempts at rescue, avoids the door at the vestibule, and stalks to the front of the building. Miss Monohan gets to her feet, picks up her grade book, vigorously crosses herself, and walks slowly to the hastily vacated vestibule. 47

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 33
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: V. Departure T'was underneath the linden tree They told each other they would see The time when dreams would more than be A hollow, haunting memory. The words came first, then they were gone, And fate was harsh in Forty-three. THE RADIO AND newspapers keep us informed. Things are still ripping on Guadalcanal. Americans are going into North Africa to help Monty catch Rommel, but even more pertinent news comes to us from the letters of the transÂ­planted Raiders. Bill Neely visits Fred "Hopalong" Cassity in Ireland. STC's Irish tenor, Joe Cain, is also there ... Orbrey Moore is flying in the South Pacific. A newspaper reports that a marine officer returning from the front on Guadalcanal kills two pigs. He jeeps them into a ravine and sends word for all Tennesseans to come to his barbeque. He is from Lawrenceburg-He is the indomitaÂ­ble "Ugg" McCrory. Intramural basketball, boys and girls, is played four nights a week. The teams are the Parakeets, Herons, CarÂ­dinals, Ravens ... the gymnasium is a fine place to go-it is the place to go. Freshman DePriest, a sophomore now, is a scoring magician in my biased opinion. She duels with Alice Arnold and Mary Alice Zumbro. Pat Hope, Jessie Baxter, and Bettye Brown also cavort on the hardwood. Chief ref- 48 eree is Moe Tolbert. Ex-football players, with tolerant officiating, become formidable basketball players. None is more formidable than six-foot-six-inch Tom Suddarth. There are some empty rooms in Jones Hall. The marines call in Bruiser and Chitwood. We continue our routine. The radios say, "From Natchez to Mobile" We interrupt this program to bring- "The blues in the night" We interrupt this program "Pardon me boys, is that the Chattanooga choo-choo?" We interrupt ... Even girls are leaving now as Carolyn Adams and Charlotte Stephenson join the Women's AuxilIary Corps. This surely must be our last quarter in school-studying claims too little of our time. Miss Tommye Reynolds feels that her math assignments should have our attention reÂ­gardless. Miss Burkett says that she expects the hall radiator outside her room to get warm whether or not Miss DePriest and I sit on it. Does she think that Shelley, ByÂ­ron, and Keats can compete with that situation on the radiator? In February, Mr. Smith lands the contract he was negotiating for. A company of air force cadets is brought to our campus. The Lyon Hall girls are packed into Rutledge Hall, and the cadets take over Lyon. There are neat, clean uniforms on well-fed future war heroes... students for the teachers to teach ... government tuition for Mr. Holmes ... and something else-a virtual deluge of men near Rut-ledge Hall. . "Just before we leave, these guys come in." "I don't think I like this," growls Dynamite. Jim Butler snorts, "Who sent for those bastards anyÂ­how?" We return from a weekend at home. Mr. Bock meets the dishroom gang. "Boys, you don't work here anymore. Air force regulations require permanent civilian help in the dishroom. I can use Ashton on the serving line, but only Moe qualifies for the kitchen." Damn the damned air force! The students finish their 49

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 34
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: evening meal, then carry their trays to the magnolia tree and pile them there in protest. Mr. Smith calls in the exÂ­dishwashers, says to cut the crap, he will try to find us jobs. I find an immediate way to survive, and Turner folÂ­lows my lead. I carry a fifty-cent piece in my watch pocket, go through the food line, select liberally, and give Betty McCampbell my half-dollar. She hits the cash register and drops the coin behind her---onto my tray. We go home for a weekend in March. The longÂ­awaited army letter arrives. "You are directed to report for active duty, 30 March '43, at Fort Oglethorp, Georgia." Twenty-four other Raiders get similar letters at their homes on the same day. The winter quarter is over at STC and the army reÂ­serve corps boys take their last civilian trip home-to Lebanon, Woodbury, Smithville ... to Columbia, Pikeville, Wartrace, Lewisburg, Chapel Hill. I drive to Forrest High School in the pickup truck accompanied by a six-year-old brother and a four-year-old dog who thinks he is a brother. It is the same familiar building and the same faculty, but the students are not the same. They are so young. I will leave for camp from Murfreesboro instead of Chapel Hill and will go there the day before. Classes for the spring quarter have begun. The army reserve corps return to the campus; not by government orÂ­ders nor by any school decree, but like moths to a lamp we return. Dynamite, Hornet, Bob, and the other navy reservÂ­ists believe they will have another quarter in school. Those awaiting the draft are on borrowed time. There is one more night for us. One last trip to Rutledge Hall ... and to other places ... and then to Rutledge Hall again. Finally, in Jones Hall, we talk. Our moods vacillate from the blues to exÂ­citemen~. Turner and Smith return, shouting a lot of soldier talk. Joe Money calls for us to come to his room and see how J. B. Roberson has decorated it. J. B. with a half pint 50 of paint and a pint of Cannon County shine, has created, in purple and pink, life-sized female nudes around his walls. Robert Jenkins says it looks like the Parthenon. "It is a good thing that you are leaving, J. B. " Breakfast at the cafeteria ... the same halfÂ­dollar ... Betty does her sleight-of-hand. I doubt that Mr. Bock is really fooled. We peer "into the dishroom at the hired help. "Keep 'em flying, Moe," yells Smith. We walk in small groups to the Main Building and unusual things begin to happen. Miss Burkett leaves her class and walks into the hall. "Mr. Nunley, when it is over, I will expect you back in my class." "Yes, ma'm, I will be there." Doggone! Scholarly Mr. Frazier steps into the hall and shakes hands with each of us. They are treating us like seniors . . . like we are graduating. Down the hall we conÂ­tinue ... Dean Beasley says, "Jim Butler, don't forget, all of you fellows be in front of the building at ten." Nooby stops on the stairs with the mail in his hand,' clamps on a cigar, and says to us, "It is going to be a short war now." "Yes, we'll take care of it." At the end of the hall stands Miss Monahan . . . anÂ­cient, dignified, smiling with a kind of radiance that we had not noticed or appreciated before. "I am proud of you boys. I am proud of all our. boys." We walk out on the campus. ''I'll never understand ,teachers," says Turner. It is about time to begin walk!ng to the depot. I go back to Rutledge Hall and Jiln Butler shouts from the front steps, "Did you hear about J. B.? Q. M. took one look at his room this morning and kicked him out of school." A few stragglers drift over to. the linden tree. Lt. Fred Phillips, McMinnville's all-American boy, on furlough, comes to see Joy Bragg. Freshman DePriest sews a belt strap on my pants as we sit on the dormitory steps. Then a procession begins. Down the steps of the Main Building comes most of 51

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 35
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: . the student body, the teachers, Chief Valdez, and the remÂ­nants of the college band. Doggone! They are going to the depot with us. We walk down the Boulevard, laughing, talking, singÂ­ing ... droves of us. We pass the Elrod residence . . . Brinkley's ... the Tennessee College for Women. Haven't we done this before? Maybe we are going to play Memphis State. No, we have done that. The street was flushed with autumn then, the maples were tossing down flutterings of yellow, but now the trees are clean with newÂ­ness and small green leaves are appearing for another cycle. Yells go up from our strolling parade. A 1936 ChevÂ­rolet comes down East Main. Suddarth, Bill Burkett, and Bill Blackman are driving to Chattanooga, their goodbyes have been said. They turn at the Central Christian Church and disappear to the south. Turner and Smith are the clown princes-they are escorted by a fleet of girls. Turner loudly promises Edna Jackson that he will be faithful to her. Then he promises Laura Dew Jones and Lucille Tittsworth. the same thing. Smith proclaims his eternal love to all of them but says his pledge has just been given to Miss Monohan. Joe Money and Jim Lane are not so vocal. We walk across the courthouse square where Joe McCrary and Donald Knight stop to speak to SOlne of the locals. J. B. looks up at Johnny Reb and tells him to shoot the first Japanese Yankee who comes by. At the depot we buy our tickets to Chattanooga, one way, and await the arrival of the train from Nashville. The band plays, "Those Caissons Go Rolling Along," "Anchors Aweigh," and the other service songs. We boo at all except the "Caissons." Dean Beasley and Mr. Smith stand on the steps of an empty boxcar and say the school's official goodby. Then Chief Valdez has the band play, "Hail STC, All Hail." That nearly ruins things. A regular epidemic of lumped throats and cinders-in-the-eye begins. Dr. Sims 52 calms things by announcing that he has decided to go with us. The train is thirty minutes late. A few more speeches . .. music ... thirty more minutes. People decide if the outcome of the war depends upon us and the L & N RailÂ­road, the cause is lost. They depart. Only our girl friends, a few navy reservists and the ever-present chaperons, Mrs. Grace Daniels and Miss Margie Mitchell, relnain. A few more quiet moments and the train arrives. There is time for just an affectionate touch ... a look ... a wish. We climb aboard, affecting debonair, flmnboyant entries into the car. Inside the bravado leaves us. We sit like zombies and the car lu~ches forward . . . slowly ... away. The heat is stifling. Our throats ache and the blood pulsates in our ears. The train moves under the viaduct at the edge of town. Our car is one mass of depression divided into twenty-two parts. Suddenly, Turner rises. His eyes are red as he announces, "Boys, by God, I'm tired of this army life." That dadblamed clown. "I've got a deck of cards," says Joe Money. We are on our way. 53

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 36
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: VI. Rehearsal FORT OGLETHORPE IS gluttonous. We are absorbed among thousands-separated, numbered, assigned to two-storeyd barracks. Within hours, we relocate each other. Then come IQ tests, physicals, skill tests, aptitude tests. A corÂ­poral on the permanent cadre tells us that Johnny Franks has scored highest on the IQ test of any recruit on record there. We look for the special treatment that we will get for being volunteers. We find it at 3:00 A.M. Report to the kitchen-sixteen hours of KP. After four more days, we get uniforms and we Inail our cankered civilian clothes home. Dave and Â«Honkey" Crouch arrive with the Tennessee Tech Reservists. Hobart Massey and the University of TenÂ­nessee Reservists report in. We go through more classificaÂ­tion procedures, dig a ditch across North Georgia, more K.P. Everyone works without shirts in the kitchen. A hundred and twenty KPs. Turner runs a bluff, gives a few commands. It works. He orders John Cathey, Jenkins, Cartwright, and me to the barracks and assigns other rookies to our jobs. When he goes to check on supplies, we all hide for a day. Two o'clock in the morning. William Burkett awakens me. Â«Suddarth and I have been called out. Tell the others to keep 'em flying." Donald Knight leaves the next day. We dribble out. '.. couple of days ... midnight ... "Cartwright, 54 Lane, Money, Nunley, Patterson, Roberson, Turner ... pack up." The train heads north. We go through a tunnel and Money recognizes Cowan, Tennessee. Great day! We are on the tracks for MurfreesÂ­boro. "Will it stop?" "Are you crazy?" I write a postcard to Bob Womack. We can see the town. We strain for a sight of Rutledge Hall. Jim Butler looks for his home; we think that we see them. I toss out the card. Jim Butler, with another attack of cinderitis, leans out the open window. Turner and Cartwright grab him. Hell, let's all jump. We don't. The train whistle moans in a long, wailing tenor, and we keep going ... north. I think this railroad car once carried reinforcements to Sherman outside of Atlanta. The seats are wooden, like church pews. We sleep ... gripe ... stretch ... gripe ... wait on sidings . . . meet other rookies . . . get cold. Two days pass ... Chicago keep going ... "What's north of. Chicago ~ .. Alaska?" Vast amounts of horizon ... night-fall. . . snow. . . we stop near a concrete loading dock and stare at a sign: Â«Camp Grant". Ray Patterson says, Â«This is a hell of a place to send a good Rebel." We stand around shivering until a truck pulls up. We are issued straw ticks and marched to a snowy straw stack, fill them up, carry two barracks bags and the straw tick until we come to rows ,of tents, divide into groups of six and occupy the tents. Money and I are together. We warm ourÂ­selves by a 60-watt light bulb hanging from the tent pole, put on more clothes, put the straw tick on a canvas cot and go to bed. Morning. "Where do we get our rifles?" Â«Rifles, hell! You are in the medics." "Medics? I never heard of medics." Â«Do you mean Tennesseeans don't get guns?" 55

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 37
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "What a helluva way to fight a war." Basic training. The first platoon is all Tennessee, inÂ­cluding the displaced Raiders. The other three platoons are from New York and Boston. An old war flares up. "Hey, plough jockeys." "Geezus Chriss, lookit the ridgerunners." "You guys from Tennessee put a rock in your right hand so you will know where to go on 'column right.' " "Go to hell, you damn Yankees." The army is short on hardware. We have no shovels, so we dig holes with hatchets and bucket lids. The C. O. says, "You soldiers write home and tell your folks to send you the biggest pocket knife they can find. You TennesÂ­seans just keep those you already have." We gradually begin to appear like soldiers . . . to each other. The noncoms and officers, however, cannot be pleased. They are worse than the upperclassmen of 1940, and they seem less than thrilled at having Tennesseans in camp. Obviously, we are in enemy territory. At night we gather at the latrine where there are three light bulbs and a coal stove. We swap m'ail-call news from MTSC. Burkett and Suddarth are in Arkansas, in the infantry. Johnny Franks has been assigned to a cooks and bakers school. Bob Womack got my card. There is no baseball team at school. The dadblaIned cadets are all over the place. The navy boys have moved out of Jones Hall and into the Moffitt House. Bill Neely has been killed in North Africa. Summer finally comes to Camp Grant, and we take a weekend in Chicago, the soldier's towq. Joe Money beÂ­comes the best soldier in the company. We complete our basic training with a flourish. The first platoon marches thirty-two miles in five hours. We thumb ourÂ· noses as the others drag by an hour later. The former college boys are offered a chance to go back to college on the AST program. I go temporarily inÂ­sane and reject the offer. "So long, fellows. Keep 'em flying." They go to North- 56 western and to the University of Chicago. I go to a new camp being built in a cornfield fifty miles fro~ ~aco~b, Illinois-Camp Ellis. I join an outfit well along In Its tramÂ­ing schedule. They lose me in the cook's bar~acks for days. Then they do a very illogical thing: they gIVe me a fur-lough. I grab a barracks bag and start walking south. Se."en miles later I catch a ride. The next afternoon, I walk Into the Moffitt House. I can find no one. Second floor empty, then-steps. An air force lieutenant opens a door and I "snap to," but . . . "Hulsey Ferrell, is that you?" "Nunley! Where did you come from?" " "I just got here. Am I supposed to salute you? "If you do, I'll hit you." "I can't find anybody; Hulsey." "Neither can I, but the place smells like they are here." We walk to the campus. Freshman DePriest has gone back to Perry County and is teaching a one-teache~ school on Marsh Creek. We meet Whicher Phillips, Doc RIchards, and a few others who have not yet been called in by. the air force. The navy boys are gone. I walk to the highway and hitchhike home. School has not yet started at Chapel Hill, so my folks are still on the farm near Viola and that is where I go. My parents, my brothers, my dog, the mules, Old Charlie, my milk cow; they all look good to me. Frying-size~ chick~ns are still ripe and the garden is at its peak. At VlOla, AlIce Milstead has a much larger collection of photographs on her shelves, but now there is a gold star above one. E. L. Groves has been killed in a plane crash. The navy reservists have been sent to different colleges for further education. Bob Womack is in school in New York but Ashton Wood and Maury Smartt are in the UniÂ­versity of the South at Sewanee, thirty miles from Viola. I call Jeneal Smith and tell her that my dad has enough gas 57

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 38
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: rationing stamps for me to make the trip to Sewanee. She catches a bus to McMinnville where I meet her, and we make the visit. They are expecting us. As we come into view of the stone columns marking the boundaries of the university, we see the two land-locked sailors. Dynamite recognizes the car and waves furiously. Hornet runs to a tree and leaps to a limb where he swings by one hand and scratches his ribs in monkey fashion. . I park"the car inside the campus and step out. "Hello, Dynamite. He passes me without seeing me. I turn to the monkey. "Hornet, you are looking great." "Joe, you must have gained fifty pounds," he says. "Yep, just about. I weigh 150." "You won't be hard to handle at all without those bones sticking out." Dynamite confiscates my car and Maury gives me the news. The navy boys are scattered everywhere. "Mama Bear" Brooks' orders finally came in officially. He had shakÂ­en hands with everyone once a week for three weeks of false starts. Orbrey Moore's plane is down somewhere in the South Pacific. I catch a bus to Linden, Tennessee and wait in the bus station for a ten-mile ride to the DePriest home. I go to sleep in a chair. Lorraine, driving the family car, stops and peers into the waiting room, sees only seven soldiers, drives on and reports me missing. Later, I hitchhike to the Cedar Creek road, ride three more miles on a farm wagon, walk the last two, and finally arrive in the shady yard at Buckfork-and there is Freshman DePriest. And the trip is worth it, worth it, worth it! The G.1. truck stops at the main gate of Camp Ellis and I get out. The guard gives me directions to my outfit, so I walk along the black dirt road. The dust of a dry SepÂ­tember, stirred by innumerable army vehicles, covers evÂ­erything. There are rows of temporary barracks and soldiers on a sunny Sunday afternoon playing touch football. A tall 58 and short couple are boxing between two barracks. The short one is being driven into the ground like a tent peg. I switch shoulders with my barracks bag and walk on. Then ... "Hey Joe!" The tent peg comes running to the street. "Jim Butler, doggone. I thought you were in college." "No," he said, "they busted up the ASTP and I got sent to this cornfield. I haven't seen any of the fellows since." "I came here from Grant, but let Ine tell you, I've just come in frOln furlough." "How lucky can you get! What is it like at the Normal School? Are the cadets still there? Are they playing foot-ball?" , We talk and talk and talk. I m'ust report to the C. Q. by 6:00 P.M., so I leave him. I feel much better about Camp Ellis now. With Jim Butler in camp, the Raiders just about outnumber the upperclassmen. I check in with my outfit. They only know my name, and I don't know any of them. I walk to the cook's barracks, the home for orphaned troops, and throw my barracks bag on my bunk. I notice a new occupant in the upper bunk, a sleeping, scrawny, redÂ­head. I check the name on his barracks bag: J. B. RoberÂ­son. The franking privilege extended to the military is of inÂ­finite importance, but even greater is the return mail. At Camp Ellis, we pool our notes and find that some of the fellows have changed jobs: The anny did not appreciate Reece Smith's aching back, so they sent him home. Air cadet Fount Watson, two weeks before a scheduled graduation, is busted out of the air force. His assigned flight had not included strafing orange groves in Florida. Fount joins the seabees. Cadet James Woodlee, while landing a lighter-than-air craft in Pensacola, is caught in a cross breeze and lands in 59

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 39
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: the bay. He becomes army private Woodlee. A near miss occurs at Red Boiling Springs, Tennessee. Mr. Moss, after returning from his mail route, decides to hitch his young team of mules to the wagon and haul a load of wood. Ordinarily he would expect Evan to do this before going back to college, but Evan is now ferrying planes up and down the east coast. He loads a rick of stovewood on the wagon and carefully drives his nervous young mules down the logging road to his barn. Suddenly a P-47, roaring like the king of tornadoes, drops over a hill and buzzes the road at tree-top height. Mr. Moss gets a quick look at the wing numbers before he and the wagon and the mules and the stovewood go in separate directions. Later he teleÂ­phones the sheriff who sends an official complaint to the air force. Two weeks later a letter of apology arrives at the Moss home. The errant pilot has been properly repÂ­rimanded. His name is Lt. Evan Moss, Jr., flying 300 miles off course. Summer fades, but before frost comes to Illinois we detrain from Camp Ellis and head east, a trainlo;d of med;cs. Our most dangerous weapon is a guard's night stick and on the flatcars are jeeps and GI ambulances, our meÂ­chanized equipment. News of the Italian surrender is in the papers as we pull onto a siding in Bristol, Tennessee. Cheering crowds gather around our train and pass cakes, pies, and fried chicken to us through open windows. We are puzzled, but grateful. An old man says, "Did you see the First Division?" J. B. says, "Mister, we haven't been anyÂ­where yet, but we are on our way." All over the United States, the training tempo picks up. The island-hopping campaign has started in the Pacific, and the ground war in Europe concentrates on the cold, muddy boot of Italy. The Raiders from Murfreesboro are in all stages of activity. Many are in action and many more are getting ready. Last furloughs are being taken by some, but on Attu, McClintock is dead; and so is Neely in Africa and Orbrey Moore in the South Pacific. 60 Whicher and Shadow get married in Denver. Elizabeth Clements meets Bob in Nashville and they marry. Babe Young and Jimmy Jackson do the same thing. Otelia Curtis and Hobart Massey marry two weeks before he departs for a port of embarkation. And, in a one-room schoolhouse 'neath majestic beech trees beside a creek in Perry County, Tennessee, the eighteen students joyfully accept a week's vacation. Their teacher has gone to marry a soldier. 61

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 40
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: VII. Where Did All the Flowers Go? or: The Word Seeps In The Forty Frosh have not been lost They stride to muster as before And join the grand parade of troops On June sixth's torn and bloody shore. Machine guns play the largo step For the fighting class of Forty-Four. THE MALE POPULATION of MTSC is gone now. Coach Midgett and Coach Jordan are in the navy and a relatively indifferent corps of imported cadets live in Lyon Hall. Only the faculty and the girls in Rutledge Hall are left to reÂ­member. And they do. From scattered place,s over the enÂ­tire earth, word from the Raider warriors somehow gets back to the campus. Letters, newspaper notices. Dean Beasley gets a V-mail from a marine resting in New Zealand who had met a sailor aboard ship who had talked with a pilot on Guadalcanal. And so it goes. The word seeps in. Miss Burkett, Mr. James, and Dr. Sims survey their female classes and know that these students are like none other who have attended here. Caught in the swirl of an intensely emotional time, they struggle with problems of the moment. Their study of English and history and biology is filtered through excitement of the day, through memories, arid for some through agonizing fears. 62 The fall of '43 becomes winter. No cleats have torn the turf of Jones Field, and the round ball is silent in the gym. Reverberations of collegiate excitement of 1942 have faded beyond recall. The big front doors of the Main Building open and shut swiftly as passing students seek to prevent the entry of December's cold air. But there is a coldness inside-it is inside the remaining students and teachers. Even the halls, more silent now than during the Normal days, seem to reÂ­flect one chilling thought: Where are they? And the word seeps in. Edgar Rogers and Clyde Cornwall ride the same bomber to their deaths over Attu. Arthur Scates, Allen Sewart, and Buddy Brantley are shot down in the South Pacific. Ed Free and Tom Hewlett are captured by the Japanese. Max Knox is missing in a flight over the MediterÂ­ranean and Lucian Durham is dead in North Africa. The Raiders are on all fronts and more are coming. Christmas sees a brief rejuvenation of former campus life as furloughs are granted to a few. Once again the Boulevard feels the falniliar feet of Bob Burkett, Bill BeasÂ­ley, Bob Womack, Marcus Charles, Jim Lane and the Green Hornet. But not for long. In January, Mary Helen Crawley and her Side-Lines staff dedicate the paper to the Raider men and women in se'rvice; more than 'six hundred of them. And in January, Billy Driver, Joe Gibson, Burney Lee Tucker and. Hank Brandon fly their fighters against the Japanese over New Guinea. Four new pilots, fresh from the States, climb out of a truck on an airfield near London. They report to the CQ and go to their assigned quarters. They are introduced to other members of their squadron and join them in listening to Lord Haw Haw in Berlin give his nightly radio perforÂ­mance. Suddenly, "I would like to send greetings to the new American pilots who arrived at North Hampstead AirÂ­field tonight. Especial greetings to Lt. David Hailey who 63

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 41
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: comes from Carthage, Tennessee. David attended a little Teacher's College at Murfreesboro and married Emma Deere while he was there. I hope you and your friends enjoy the little reception we are sending you, David." Air raid! A pale and shaken "Slug" follows the others to a shelÂ­ter. In June the Nazi dam that has contained the human torrent of Allied soldiers cracks at the Channel and erupts on ~he beach at Normandy. Fighting, desperate fighting, is takIng place. The hours of June sixth go by, and then another day, and another. Newsmen struggle to comÂ­prehend the enormity of the invasion and to broadcast the news. While back across the Atlantic in every city in the USA, and in every hamlet and every crossroads community, the women and men behind the scenes shudder at their th?ughts. It is no less true for the spot on the map in the mIddle of Tennessee. And there, the word seeps in. Eldridge Tipps, the towhead from Skinnum, dies on the .beach. A short while later Norman Lane, tending to the busIness of the wound~d, is killed by machine-gun fire. Shrapnel kills Pa.ul O.steen, and Bob Sarvis, after evacuating the crew from hIs cnppled bomber, rides it to his death in th~ ~hanne1. In the hedgerows near Brest, France, Sgt. WIlham Burkett, leading an infantry squad as he had led another squad against Memphis State, is killed by a sniper. The c~mpus people cling to sources of the news as they had done III other years when their players were in other co~tests.. But the sheer unreality of this game is shocking. It IS a bItter one, and the old Normal School is taking its lumps. Spring becomes summer, Vultee, du Pont, and the other factories in Nashville and Chattanooga throb to meet an ever-~ncre~sing schedule for production. Those people who deSIre hIgher wages in construction go to Anderson County and work under strange circumstances at Oak Ridge. But the pastoral scenes in Middle Tennessee reflect 64 an agricultural effort that is supreme. The mule, the tracÂ­tor, and the pickup truck command the countryside. There are no military maneuvers around Beech Grove and WarÂ­trace, for on-the-job training is being held in Europe and in the Pacific. A genuine world war is on. Young men are fighting other young men all over the blooming world. They are fighting in armies and fleets and divisions and brigades. Who are they? Who are the atoms in the fuel that furnishes the energy to drive on the great machine? General MacArthur commands the American effort in the Pacific. MacArthur is here and Nimitz over here and Patton over there and Clark right here. Someone decides that the island of Guam must be taken. The marines must do it. Ah yes, the marines. They are tough people; tough, fighting but faceless people ten thousand miles away. It's the First Brigade that goes in. The First Brigade? I know a couple of guys in the First, but they couldn't be at the front. But it's the "Raider Battalion" of the First. Wh~ that's the outfit Roger Smith is in! A platoon leader, in front of his men, in close fighting with rifles and grenades, recklessly and fearlessly drives a wedge into the Japanese line and is killed in the process. Others drive the wedge deeper, and Guam is eventually taken. The Americans have taken Guam. MacArthur has taken Guam. The marines .have taken Guam, and the First has had many casualties. A marine colonel says, "He was a good officer and he will get the Navy Cross." On a ship off the island, Jean Sarver says, "We played ball together back in the States." On the second floor of the Main Building at the Teacher's College, a gray-haired old lady tells her history class, "He was one of my good students." And on Salem Road, five miles from Murfreesboro, a farmer says, "He was my son. " In the air, on the land, and on the sea, the battles rage. "Old Folks" rides the convoy route across the North 65

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 42
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Atlantic. Wilburn Burkett and John Hitt ride the PT boats in the South Pacific. "Slug" Hailey flying with a P-38 squadron goes nonstop to Poland and return. It is the longest flight ever for fighter planes. Tommy Hudson is shot down over Paris and George Grau over Belgium. Wesley Gilley's infantry platoon is caught in an ambush in France and all are methodically killed. Near the Rhine, another American platoon is trapped and apparently doomed. The first volunteer makes the attempt to break out and is killed. So is the second. And the third. The fourth is mortally wounded but makes it to his lines and the platoon is re.scued. Back in the States, "Spider" Curtis Massey will receIve a posthumously granted Silver Star to stay forever with her memories of a two-week honeymoon. Troop ships pour across the Atlantic and thread their way through the German submarine wolf packs. Off the Azores, one ship accidentally crashes into another and Bryan Turner, the plowboy from Hurricane Mills, is killed. It is a grievous time, but grief for the dead cannot deter the effort. The attack goes on. C~rl Campbell and Jimmy Schleicher fly the Hump out of India. Paul Golden operates a weather station there and Donald Knight joins an outfit attempting to lay a~ oil pipeline through jungles, Japanese, and elephants across northern Burma. Winter comes again to the campus at Murfreesboro and a,~ old familiar figure departs the scene. Mr. "Snoopy Doop Woodruff, wrapped in his long brown overcoat and wearing his slouchy felt hat, sits down on the steps of the Main Building one night and dies there. Mr. Davis, Mrs. Ed~ey, Mr: Frazier and Miss Frizzel hold their teaching statIOns. MIss Monohan and Dr. Sims teach history to stuÂ­dents who have an immediate concern for history in the making. A saddened Mr. Gracey teaches his classes but thinks bf his son who has had his spine shattered by GerÂ­man shrapnel. The college is still operating. Dean Beasley and President Smith are running the show, as eternal as 66 Roosevelt, Churchill, and Stalin. It is the third December since the departure of the boys . . . and the word seeps in. The navy blasts the Japanese out of Leyte Gulf and they place General MacArthur back On Philippine soil. Patton's Third Army is running headlong across France. Things are looking better. The other team is cracking. The Raiders are marching down the field. Hail STC, All Hail! Moody is crashing through the line and Little Willie is throwing to Whicher and Bob. They are on their way to pay dirt. And then the hoped-for ease of an enjoyable Christmas is chilled by the news of the German counterattack. The Battle of the Bulge is on. Snow covers all of middle Europe and the ferocity of the German drive overruns American units dug in along the Belgian and Luxembourg borders. New troops from replaceÂ­ment depots are rushed forward while cooks, bakers, and clerks leave their jobs to fight for survival. Hilary Martin, deployed as an observer for artillery, is lost for two days behind the German lines. He finds his way back and is again overrun by the enemy. He calls in artillery fire on his own position. Axehead Yearwood vanishes behind the GerÂ­man onslaught. Jonah Fitch fires his BAR as if it were a .22 rifle. The bomber carrying Robert Smith from England on one of the saturation raids crashes into a crippled returning plane and both fall into the Channel. . By the middle-of January, the German drive is blunted and the Allied troops head for the Rhine. In February word seeps in from a spot on the map of the Pacific. The spot is called Iwo Jima. The navy frogmen go in first to wreck the underwater defenses and they lose the Nashville left-hander, Carl Yates. The bombardment lets up to allow the invaders to get ashore. Joe Jackson dives into a shell hole and lands on top of a high schoolÂ­classmate from Chattanooga. Captain Ug McCrory moves his company from the beach to the base of Suribachi. ElÂ­bert Patty directs artillery fire from a position neaby. The battle thunders on. The Japanese artillery cannot be dis- 67

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 43
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: lodged. The next morning Patty watches as the body of his old teammate, Ug, is dragged down to the beach. It is spring again, the fourth spring since the world caught fire. Beautiful spring in Murfreesboro. The butterÂ­cups line the front yards along East Main Street, and the lilacs bloom around Rutledge Hall. High schools in the Middle Tennessee area collect gasoline. rationing stamps and send their teams to the college campus for a tournaÂ­ment. For a few days and nights, the gym throbs again with excitement. But from afar ... the word seeps in. Ernest Hooper patches the wounded in New Zealand. Skip Anderson runs a supply dump in Australia. Burney Lee Tucker flies with the famed Black Sheep squadron, and Bob and Hornet join the invasion of Okinawa. In Europe the great German war machine collapses. Tommy Hudson is found injured but safe. George Grau has also made it. Patton's rampaging army liberates prisonerÂ­of- war camps, and among the prisoners is Axehead. The Germans must surrender and the Americans must go to the Pacif~c for that last drive against a goal-line stand, the dreaded invasion of Japan. The Japanese have become more than stubborn. They are fanatical. Suicide planes become a daily menace to the navy, and packs of midget submarines, each as potent as a baby rattlesnake, prowl the seas north of the Philippines. Near Luzon they sink the cruiser Indianapolis. The Japanese on Okinawa will not give up. They can only be exterminated. There are few prisoners, but by the end of June the island is secured. The next invasion must be that of Japan itself. Recent veterans of the European campaign recross the Atlantic to the Panama Canal. The new crop of trainees add "APO, San Francisco" to their addresses. The buildup inÂ­creases. It will be bigger than Normandy. It will cost a milÂ­lion men. WHAT WAS THAT??? 68 "They say it was no bigger than a football:" " "They say one airplane made the raid by Itself. "A whole city, twice as big as Nashville, got blown apart. " "Why didn't they hit Tokyo?" "Where did we get an egg like that?" "Do we have any more?" "They say Oak Ridge, Tennessee . . . The navy sends destroyers after the submarines th~t sank the Indianapolis. On August 9, the U.S.S. Johnn'te Hutchins finds thein, and a running, dodging, blasting fight begins. The deck officer directing the attack is Lt. A.B. Wood. Four hours later, the Johnnie Hutchins has sunk three sublnarines and has rejoined the fleet. Lieutenant "Dynamite" has fired the last shot in a naval engagement in World War II. The fire is out, and it is time to go home. 69

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 44
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: VIII. Return The battle song has ended now 'Neath ivied wall~ men walk once more But strewed across the decade is ' The phantom class of Forty-Four. In retrospect, they share one bond The Forty Frosh ... forevermore. IT'S OVER. WE are back. We wear our ruptured ducks and spend our mustering-out pay. I buy a civilian suit in McMinnville. It is gray and checked and beautifully differÂ­ent. Harry King gives me a matching tie, but I don't wear it. The white shirt collar must be open and unrestrained. The outfit looks too good to wear to the farm, so back into the duflle bag I go and out comes the GI stuff. After three years, nothing else at home fits. The old pickup truck still runs, so Freshman DePriest and I move with our three-month-old son to the cabin on the farm. My dog has been a war casualty. He had chalÂ­lenged a military convoy on the Horton Highway back at Chapel Hill and he never made it. I head for the mountain and mentally mark the mulÂ­berry trees as I pass them. It will be six more weeks before the berries ripen, but I have plenty of time. I'll be there when the bushy-tails arrive. I'll never leave here. I walk the wagon roads around the benches slowly, deliberately, 70 and affectionately. From the narrows along Riddle Top, I survey the Viola Valley, unscarred by anything in eighty years except farming tools. Its magl1ificent farms, among the best in Tennessee, are fairly bursting with spring growth. West of the Mount Zion cemetery I see "Mousey" Scott's house. It must pain his folks to see the rest of us come back, for they know that Mousey will stay forever in France. Down in Roger's Hollow a wisp of smoke rises as Harold Roger's mother shoves some wood into the kitchen stove. She knows she is not cooking for Harold. The Rogers family were pioneers in these mountains, and their descenÂ­dents had never traveled far from the hollow. Harold had been to McMinnville only a few times before he signed up. Then he went all the way to France and was killed there. I come off the mountain and walk among the huge white sentinels in the upper pasture. These were once the mighty chestnut trees, the providers of food, dye, rails, and shingles. They are all dead now and decaying. I walk home. Red Gaffin and Tom Murphy come by. They are planÂ­ning an organizational meeting for the Viola baseball team. We meet on Sunday afternoon. Agile Ben Wright goes to shortstop. He fields well but throws poorly-the bullet wound in his right wrist is healing slowly. Dave Hoover can hit but cannot run. Shrapnel has done irreparable damage to the calf of one leg. Batting practice begins. Gordon Crouch and Bob Ramsey "take their turns. Three months ago they were Corporal Crouch and Colonel Ramsey, but no one cares about that in Viola, Tennessee. Now it is summer. Farming, playing baseball, living with my small family and near my larger family, fishing, squirrel hunting; this is the life. But there is a small distracÂ­tion growing within me and within Freshman DePriest. When we read the newspapers we feel it. When we pass the McMinnville High School building we feel it. For me it beckons loudest as the dust and the sweat and the physical excitement of a baseball game subsides. I wonder if the others feel it. I have been home, but not completely at 71

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 45
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: home. I take the Greyhound to Murfreesboro. The bus stops in front of Brinkley's Store. I get off and walk up the bo.ule~ard .towards school. Ah, it is much better walking in thIs dIrectIon. It is the first day of summer school and the old Normal is humming with life. I turn into the campus entrance, between the stone columns where we had gather.ed only yesterday for our walk to the depot. And there IS Rutledge Hall, and at the corner is the walnut tree fro~ ~hich McDonald had shaken walnuts with one hand. I~ IS Just like we left it. Girls are walking along the sIdewalks, but I do not recognize them. Now I can see the Main Building, and ... there they are. In large numbers they are standing on the steps, on the sidewalk, on the grass, getting out of cars. The Forty Frosh and all the rest s~em to have collected for one grand reunion. Back slapÂ­pmg~, hand shaking, big talking: Hey, Dynamite, you old so-and-so." "Joe, you're another." "Hornet. " "Jack." "Axehead. " "Rock. " "J. B." It goes on and on. I I~ake it up the steps and push open the big doors. ImmedIately the familiar smell of school envelopes me F~oor polish, new books, the clean smell of girls, and th~ famt scent of chlorine from the first ice-water fountain I had ever known. There by the office door stands Dean Beasley; the de~n who knew us all by first name, now a little thinner and a lIttle grayer. "Joe," he says excitedly, "come in here." Doggone, maybe he is going to hire me to help run this place. After all, I have been . . . "Quick, over here by the window." I rush over and peer out. "Who is that one-the bald-headed one on the top step?" 72 "Why dean, that's Hank Brandon." "You wait here," he says, and he rushes out to greet Hank. He quickly returns and points to another and another and another and goes to the steps to meet each of them. Imagine that! After all these years, the sheer weight of numbers has caught up with him. He cannot handle all our names. I hold my administrative position by the window until he again returns and says, "Who are those two fat ones on the sidewalk; the two who are about half bald-headed?" I take a long look. "Great day, Dean; that's Jim Lane and Bob Womack. I'll see you later." I visit the bookstore in the basement and find Sara Morrow working there. "Did you and Jessie DePriest marry?" "Sure did and we have a son. How about you?" "Yep. I married Wiley Holloway." Later I learn that these questions are best left unasked, for 'Dear John and Dear Mary letters have also been written during the past three years. "Sara, how does a fellow sign up for the GI Bill?" "You take your discharge papers to Mr. Woodmore and he will fix you up. Since you are married and have a child, you will get ninety dollars per month. Your registration and books will be paid for- by the government." "Doggone. Going to school sure beats farming." Q. M. has kept the school alive during the war years. ow he readies the place for the returning veterans and the deluge of freshmen. He buys twenty-five surplus trailers and a couple of bathhouses from Oak Ridge.
