They are placed on block foundations in the alfalfa field behind the Science Building and are rented at fifteen dollars per month to the married vets. Evan Moss and Whicher Phillips beÂ­come the student managers of "Trailer Town." Automobiles are scarce. The latest models are still the '42s. My McMinnville buddy, Cecil Prater, sells me a 1934 73

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 46
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Chevrolet which has no floor i; front and no roof in the back. It has a makeshift pushbutton starter, and, best of all, it will run. It is a steal at $320. In July, Freshman DePriest and I pack our clothes and our young 'un into "Old Prater" and move back to STC. We drive past Rutledge Hall, past Jones Hall, and back of the Science Building; we occupy the prestigious trailer under Trailer Town's only tree. "Hey, Dynamite! This beats the heck out of rooming with you in Jones Hall." There are babies and diaper-filled clotheslines all over Trailer Town. Bob and Elizabeth have a toddler, Billy NelÂ­son and his English wife have one, Grace and Leonard Staggs have one, and Elbert Sullivan has two. Old Folks, Rock Reed, John Holt, Maury Smartt and Billy Gunn have not yet blossomed, but they help keep the herd together. The bathhouse is tremendously popular; men on one side and women on the other. When nightly card games get too rambunctious for a trailer, we move to the bathhouse. Going to class is easy now. The teachers tipped their hands years ago. The};' are human beings, somewhat like us. We have no need to rush to the back of the room nor to make smart-alec remarks nor to shy away from speaking to them. There is a different relationship. I guess they have changed, or maybe they have missed us, or maybe this is the way it should have always been. I have no difficulty in hearing Miss Burkett now. Poe and Lowell and Lanier are not competing for my attention with the lilac bushes near Rutledge Hall nor the radiator by the door. That battle, like World War II, has been won. The hen who hatched the duck eggs could not have been more amazed than our faculty at registration in SepÂ­tember of '46. The numbers are unbelievable and they look strange. From a paltry 300 in 1945, the school is now conÂ­fronted with 1,200. But more amazing than the numbers is the variety, especially the variety of freshman boys. There are the youthful eighteen-year-olds fresh from high school, 74 and there are battle-scarred twenty-year-olds who were deÂ­toured after high school. There are the older freshmen who had never considered college until after the GI Bill became available . . . and then there are us. Dean Beasley and the faculty devise new ways to accommodate everyone, and Mr. Woodmore and Mr. Holmes fight their way through a mass of veterans' papers. Wink and coach Jordan meet their football squad. It is the largest in size and in numbers ever assembled on Jones Field. It is different in other ways, too. The youngsters stand aside from the veterans, and among the vets can be seen balding heads, bloodshot eyes, scarred legs, and pot bellies bulging over drooping belts. The smell of tobacco smoke and stale beer hangs over the heads of luany. As Wink lines them up for calisthenics, Glen London, only three months out of Lewisburg High School, stands beside Fount Watson who earned his first Raider letter eight years ago. The coaching task is a formidable one. There is an informality on the campus that we accept and prOluote. White tee shirts are in vogue. We wear them to class and carry pencils in our neat khaki pants' pockets. There is also a new informality in our relationships with the teachers. Bob gets so informal that he refers to Q. M. as "Q." Dr. Shus kids everyone in his class and the veterans return it, but carefully. Big John Holt walks into the classÂ­room late. As he 'passes behind Dr. Shu's chair, he rubs Doc's bald head and says, "That feels just like my wife's leg." The undaunted Dr. Sims reaches up to his slick dOlue and observes, "Darned if it doesn't." Many new teachers begin work at the college, and a few of the old-timers disappear. Our old biology teacher, "Humpy" Davis, is dead. He, like Miss Burkett, repÂ­resented quality to us. They were smart and tough, but fair. Mr. Davis knew every leaf, bird, and bug on our camÂ­pus. He loved the migrating luonarch butterflies, and he could find the hidden egg-sac of the preying mantis. His 75

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 47
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: best teaching came from his favorite textbooks-the woods and the fields. He detested the automobile; he thought it sinister and threatening to life. Ironically he was killed by one in front of his house in 1944. Mrs. Elizabeth Stowe is added to the staff, and she teaches comparative anatomy. The major feature of this course is the dissecting of a cat. I did the earthworm, the frog, and the shark before the war, about a thousand men in hospitals during it, and now the cat. We must furnish our own. I catch mine on the side of the road near Readyville. Other students raid the alleys of Murfreesboro. The gas chamber and subsequent embalming reduces Rutherford County's cat population. Our class loses a few members too. One anonymous student deposits a cat cadaver, knife, and fork on the table in John Holt's trailer. Will Dunn Smith joins the staff as a social science teacher. Neil Wright is hired as chairman of the newly deÂ­veloped music department, and his wife, Margaret, teaches with him. The same arrangement is made for Richard Peck and his wife in English. Gene Sloan, a former corresponÂ­dent for the Nashville Banner, teaches journalism and law and becomes the first public relations man for the college. The place is having growing pains. The front steps of the Main Building is still the favorite loafing place between classes. Old neighbors and tennis partners, B. B. Gracey and Tee Faulkinberry, cannot loaf here. They are in wheelchairs. Shrapnel got B. B. and polio got Tee. Both give the appearance of courage and lightheartÂ­edness. In answer to the obvious question, Tee replies, "I was shot down over Berlin." The youngest freshmen are eager to hear war stories. They skirt the fringe of collected veterans straining to hear some personal reminiscence of heroism or gore. "Axehead, how did the Germans manage to capture you?" EighteenÂ­year- old ears tilt forward and eyes get wider. A known fighter like this must have taken many of them with him. "Well," says Axehead, "I'll just tell you." 76 Oh boy! "I was coming out of a French wine cellar with a bottle in each hand and two more under my arms. A German with a gun at the top of the steps said, 'Let's go to Berlin,. Yan~.' He made me mad, calling me Yank, but I went WIth hun anyhow." Heck. Nooby leaves the coaching ranks and goes into full-time teaching. Q. M. hires Elbert Patty and Durwood Stowe to help Coach Midgett and Coach Jordan with footÂ­ball. The squad inherits transfers Vic Varallo, Leonard Staggs, and Botchie McPeak. As practice moves along, Ralph Fleming, Jeep Hale, Joe Davis and Earl Glover, among the new talent, make their presence known, but ~he bulk of the squad is composed of those who played in 41 and '42. Fount Watson and Gene McIntire have seniority over everyone but the coaches. The September sun is hot, so Henry Frank Brandon wears his helmet during all of practice. Jim Butler Lane doesn't, and ~e picks ~p t~e nickname Blister-head. Bob Burkett and HIlary MartIn stIll have speed. Nisbett and Bill Blackman are still heavyÂ­legged runners. Axehead, Fount, and Chitwood are s~ill tough in the middle, but the anchorman for football ferOCIty is the rugged Moody Bain. Wink has dreamed up the Diamond T formation, which allows him more us~ of his many strong runners. The premier runner of the entire squad is Leonard Staggs. This five-foot-five, one hundred and fifty pound chunk is named Low-Butt by his observant teammates. As the season proÂ­gresses the Raider opponents give him many labels-all of them meaning trouble. There are many characters on the squad; joke-telling Billy Gunn, tale-telling Fred Grider, too-big John Holt, but the most unique is Bill Clark. Bill has -a singing voice like a radio star's and, though he is young: he refers to himself as "Old Will." He plays football, but he is not healthy. Two years of eating C-rations or something has left him with 77

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 48
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: hemorrhoids. He joins the B-squad under the tutelage of Jack Deere, and constantly badgers Jack to send him into the game. One afternoon at Austin Peay: HCome on, Old Folks, send Old Will in. He will whup those Austin wee-wees." HKeep still, Bill." HHell, Folks, tell'em to throw to Old Will in the flat and he will get you six." The banter on the sidelines continues until Jack, in self-defense, sends Old Will in. The play called is the pass in the flat. The ball hangs in the air. The receiver goes up to get it and two defenders wipe him out. Jack rushes out to the field as the players stand around the fallen gladiator. From the dusty turf comes a pained voice: HFolks, you better haul Old Will off. His bung-hole has done fell out." The coaches, with football astuteness heavily sprinkled with tolerance for the peculiarities of this group, put toÂ­gether a winner. A tie and a midseason loss to Maryville are the only blemishes on the record until Thanksgiving. Again, the Golden Eagles from Tennessee Tech burst our bubble. Q. M. calls Elbert Patty to his office and tells him that he is to coach basketball. HBut Mr. Smith," protests Elbert, HI haven't played since I was in high school." "I don't want you to play, Elbert. I want you to coach. " Every student owning a pair of tennis shoes tries out for the basketball squad. Patty puffs his pipe and meditates for a week, then dismisses all but fifteen. Even then the prospects are dismal. Hank, Hornet, and me are the seniors. The others are scattered through the academic ledger, but freshmen predominate. The wildest one is a package of elbows and knees from Flintville named Fuzzy Harmening. He has no respect for his elders. Early in the practice sessions, we baptize him in the bleachers and 78 against the wall, but he is indestructible. The starting lineup finally gravitates around Hank, Hornet, and Fuzzy. Patty feeds us pregame meals of hot tea, toast, and a poached egg. Those of us on the bench await our cue midst a rumbling chorus of growling stomachs. It hasn't taken the world long to recede to its prewar size. We are comfortable now, on the campus, but being a student again is not like it once was. I guess it is better. Different, anyhow. "Today" was the most important thought in those days. But now it is Htomorrow." There are things to be done, specific things, like jobs, paying rent, buying a car and assuming a responsible role in the comÂ­munity. The unreal vagueness of yesterday's tomorrow faded after Hitler and Tojo. There are no youth-consuming conflagrations to blind us to the future, but with the clearer view there comes a feeling of loss. Life at the old Normal School can no longer be the ultimate dream. We must move on, and this thought slowly rises to our consciousness as we move through our final college year. .. On the last night of 1946, an ice storm hits. New Year's morning finds Trailer Town with no electricity and the campus covered with ice and snow. The stuff blew in from the south and that is the side of the trailer where our door is located. We are sealed in. Jessie turns the doorknob while I lie on the floor and kick with both feet to break us out. The coal-oil heater finally gets going and we thaw out. In the parking lot,' Hornet and Bill Gunn pour hot water on the motor of Hornet's car, but their efforts fail. The motor won't even grind. I go sliding out to Old Prater. It looks like an igloo, and its topless back seat has a full load of the stormy stuff in it. We open the north side door, and while other curious people watch, I get in, open the throtÂ­tle and hit the makeshift starter button. The thirteen-yearÂ­old Chevy springs to life. For a couple of hours the most ancient vehicle on the campus thumbs its nose at the mulÂ­titude of stalled motors. Dynamite and Jeneal live in an apartment on the 79

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 49
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Boulevard. The wires are not dow;-over there, so I drive to their place to listen to the Bowl games on their radio. Q. M. has had wooden apartments built just north of Trailer Town. These are long one-story buildings, each conÂ­taining three apartments. The apartments have three room and they are heated by one coal-burning heater and a coal-burning cook stove. The first apartment is completed on January fourth, and that afternoon Bob Womack and I move our worldly possessions in. It takes 01 Prater only two trips to haul it all. Had it not been for the baby food and diapers, we could have made it in one. Trailer Town now becomes Vets Village. We sit in a huddle on the bleachers of the gym. Its too early to dress for practice. Tale telling begins and Fuzzy Harmening crowds closer. Someone will surely reveal his personal contribution to history this time. "Fitzpatrick," says Bob, "tell us a war story." Fuzzy steps to a higher seat. He can't miss this. Fitzpatrick was a flyer. He had bombed Berlin. "Well, a very ex-eiting thing happened to me in Europe," says Fitzpatrick. Yes, yes, say Fuzzy:s eyes. "I was in a room with seven women. "Ha, ha, ha," says the group. "Bunch of damned crazies," mutters a disgusted Fuzzy as he stalks away. "How did we win the war with a bunch of damned crazies on our side?" Patty puts five-foot-ten Vic Varallo on the other team's best scorer. Hank Brandon, our tallest man at. six-one, plays the post. Neither one can jump over the foul line, but they are tough near the floor. If the ball ever loses altitude, it is ours. Charlie Martin's flat feet ache. My legs throb from shin splints and so do Hornet's. Joe Jackson's legs are scarred from bullet wounds, but the rest of the squad, though short, is relatively healthy. We stagger on through the season and win a few. Brice Hall referees our game against an air training sta- 80 tion team. The gut-growling bench warmers hope to get in this one by the second quarter. Our best chances depend on an early lead, foul trouble, or a fight. Within the first three minutes Hank and their center go after each other. Oh boy! Brice will throw Hank out. More bodies hit the floor as Fuzzy and Vic dive in. Hot dog, I'll get four quarÂ­ters tonight. Charlie Martin, hoping to increase his odds of getting in, screaITIS at Wilburn Burkett, "Hit somebody Pudge, hit somebody." The fight ends. Brice evicts the guilty, three of ours and four of theirs. They forfeit the game, dammit, and leave. Some of our fellows go to De George's for a hamÂ­burger, others go to the Brown Jug for a hamburger or something. Hornet and I, domesticated now, walk obeÂ­diently back to Vets Village hoping to find a cold potato or something. To graduate with a teacher's certificate, you must do a stint of practice teaching. This is done at the Training School that adjoins our campus, which houses grades one through ten. Dynamite, Hornet, and I sign up for this course durÂ­ing the winter quarter. We walk over daily for two hours of supervised teaching. Dynamite does his teaching in history. Hornet and I alternate with the seventh- and eighth-grade boys. We teach health (with no textbooks) on one day and physical education the next. It is no easy job. These young pirates eat practice teachers for breakfast. They are exÂ­tremely sophisticated, and we are a couple of innocents. Lacking books, we 'attempt to create activities; most of them are disasters. Our only classroom success comes when Maury fakes twisting my thumb out of place (it has been loose for years) and then we get the little outlaws to give me first aid. During the same quarter Freshman DePriest and I deÂ­cide that we can schedule ourselves so that we can each atÂ­tend classes so long as one of us is at the apartment with Joey. This setup works like a relay. The one who baby-sits holds a sprinter's stance at the apartment door until the 81

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 50
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: mate returning comes into sight.Then, swish. We shout things like "pablum," "diapers," and "punch up the fire" as we pass. The Volunteer State Athletic Conference tournament is held at Cumberland University in Lebanon. Ten of the Tennessee colleges are represented. The favorite is David Lipscomb College, and we draw them for the opening night. Joe Black Hayes, the Cumberland football coach, diÂ­rects the tournament. He invites us to the pregame meal. Patty stays at the gym watching an earlier game. The CumÂ­berland cafeteria serves steak and potatoes with an unlimÂ­ited amount of milk. For the first time this season we find a pregame bonanza. We wipe it out and then proceed to knock off David Lipscomb. The next night Milligan finishes us. Patty's "worn-out warriors-pIus-Fuzzy" have a 13-8 seaÂ­son. It is the best percentage record ever for Raider basÂ­keteers. John Holt and Leonard Staggs have a brainstorm: "Let's ask Q. M. to let us have gardens." Q. M. likes the idea. He has Floyd Travis plow and disk a long strip out of the alfalfa field. It is divided into thirty-by-thirty-foot sections, and each family in Vets VilÂ­lage draws lots for a section. The gardens look small, but with only a hoe and a rake it is all of the land we need. The novices seek advice from the farmers. "What do you plant first?" "Will the onions make the cabbages smell bad?" "What will happen if the beans are planted upside down?" . A variety of horticultural designs develop. Some garÂ­dens are contoured for irrigation. Some have rows that are sunken and some are ridged like trenches. A conglomerate of seeds begin to sprout, then come the weeds and grass. As soon as we can differentiate, it becomes a point of pride that no hostile vegetation survives. Durwood Stowe coaches baseball. Our pitching staff is 82 a weird one. Rock Reed is back with his screwball, but with less control. Lefty Busby has speed but cannot locate the plate. Our only consistent pitcher is Joe "Mudhorse" Davis. Joe's top speed is about 40 m. p. h. He gets two strikeouts per game, but the batters cannot hit him hard. Staggs, Smartt, and Jim Cloyd cover the outfield like professionals, and they also furnish the big sticks. Coach Stowe puts Cromer Smotherman on first base. Smut is big, strong, and left-handed, but his hitting is poor. He usually fouls two shots to right, then strikes out. We playa few games, then go to Florence, Alabama, for a big one. It rains. We go to three different fields before find.ing one that will tolerate a game. Fred Grider and Hornet furnish the entertainment while the field is gassed and burned off. Grider said that he was such an ornery kid while growing up in Louisville that his folks moved one day while he was at school and didn't tell him about it. He said he lived a week off dimes that he stole from telephone ~~. , We beat Florence pretty good. There is a sinkhole in left field about the size of a wagon wheel. The umpires, in their haste to start the game, neglect to mention a ground rule for it. Staggs hits a pop-up that falls in it and he gets a home run. Smut finally decides what should be done with a bat. His first shot clears the right field fence on the rise. Later in the game he hits one that awes the crowd. Trees far beyond the outfield fence obscure the flight of the ball as it disappears toward Lookout Mountain. . The season is a good one. Now it is over, Â·and so are the final exams. We are graduating. Of the forty Frosh who walked wide-eyed onto the campus years ago, ten now don the baccalaureate robes and walk across the football field with the younger graduates to receive diplomas. Jack, Hank, Jim Butler, and the others claim more time on their GI Bill. Dynamite, Hornet and I bow out. It is not as sentimental a moment as I had thought it would be. I have too many other things to think about. But 83

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 51
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: ~he place has been home for so io~g, both in actuality III dreams. Lawrence Derthick, the speaker, talks of t new world to be molded by those who had won the w We sit on the front rows of the bleachers and stare at t springtime turf of Jones Field. A man's mind can real wander. There in the north end zone is where Burc caught the pass that beat Tech when we were freshmen. On the other end of the field is where Bostick took off t~at long run against Western Kentucky. It was raining t nIght when William threw to old web-footed Whiche D~an B~asley begins calling our names and we parade by shffiy, lIke a column of walking crows. I hope they don' decide to sing "Hail STC, All Hail." They might as we blow taps. Aw, heck! What am I thinking about? I've got borrowed truck waiting for me at the apartment. I am the newly hired assistant coach at McMinnville and I mus move Jessie and Joey there tonight. ::Let's go turn these robes in," says Dynamite. Where are you going after that?" ~'I've got a teaching job in Athens. Hornet is going to Chattanooga to work for duPont." "So long, Dynamo." "Keep 'em flying, Joe." Our jobs abs?rb us. We are not students anymore, but are now competing members of a productive society. I teach three classes of history, one of physical education, a,nd then I assist the head coach, Creed McClure, with football. My salary is $170 per month plus a monthly supÂ­plement of $30 for coaching. Jessie and I rent a house at the .end of a dead-end street for $30 per month, borrow furnIture from different relatives, and take our places in the community. . It is an exciting life. I begin to get the hang of teach. I?g, but my fun is in the afternoon. Boy! It's hard to be. lIeve that I get paid for doing something that I like so well. We practice until dark each day and I think about it after 84 at. I also subscribe to the Nashville paper and I read bout the Blue Raiders. Coach Midgett has retired to the classroom and the ew coach is the STC athletic hero of the thirties, "Bubber" urphy. His staff consists of Patty, Stowe, and Joe Little. early all of the squad that completed the '46 season is back for '47. In addition Bubber locates two freshmen, John Cox and Jim McCoy, who become instant successes. Hank randon and Leonard Staggs are the captains, and during he fall Raider fans throughout Tennessee are thrilled to ead of the victories. Old Folks, Blister-head, Nisbett, Axehead, Moody-the same names from other years are till there. The old Normal is in good hands. Only a loss to aryville mars the record. At Cookeville our old nemesis, TPI, is having a good season too. Thanksgiving Day is the season's crescendo for the two great rivals. Six thousand fans, the largest crowd ever at Jones Field, gather for the finale of the 1947 season. Bubber has used the running power of the short-punt formation all seaÂ­son, but in this game the passing is most effective. Vic catches two touchdown tosses, and Wilburn Burkett runs ror another. The Raiders thoroughly defeather the Eagles ror a 19-0 win. This is the best season since 1935, when Bubber, as a player, had sparked an undefeated team. ExÂ­paratrooper Moody Bain has been a notorious runner, but during the '47 season he becomes even more sensational as a linebacker. The Side-Lines establishes an athletic award and names Moody as the first winner. Days become weeks ... 'and months ... and the daily events at MTSC fade from our sight, surfacing only when we read about the place or when we meet someone who has been there. Or when we return for special occasions. But the place still throbs with youhg life and the thrill of adventure. Miss Burkett and Dr. Sims teach their classes as before, Dean Beasley worries with the names of an eveÂ·rÂ­increasing enrollment, and boys and girls still stand beneath 85

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 52
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: the linden tree in front of Rutle~e Hall. Smut has signed with the Yankees and is playing first base at Kansas City. Two super athletes, Maxie Runion and J. B.. Proctor, transÂ­fer in from UT and the most uninhibited character of them all, Lew Aaron, becomes Bubber's student manager of all sports. The stories seep out to those of us who have ears attuned to them. And now it is September 1948. Leonard is coaching at Lawrenceburg, Jack at Pulaski, and Jim Butler at Oneida. Midst the excitement of our own seasons we hear the disÂ­tant sounds from the college campus. Saturday... twilight. I park my '37 Chevrolet near Jones Hall and walk over to the tennis courts. There are Old Folks and Jhu Butler telling each other about the imÂ­possible coaching tasks that confront them. "You fellows got here a little early, didn't you?" "Yeah, thought we might look around before the action starts." "Have you seen Moody?" "He came by a minute ago. He's coaching the B team this year. Finally ran out of eligibility, but he won't graduate until after the winter quarter." "I guess that will finish our class." Tennis players get in their last licks and collect for the walk to the cafeteria or to the donus. Fuzzy Harmening comes out of Jones Hall on his way to the cafeteria and he spots us. "Hey," he shouts. "I thought we got rid of you old dogs. " "We were afraid somebody might hurt you, Fuzzy. We came over to take care of you," says Jim Butler. "Don't give me that stuff, Blister-head. You just stayed here so long that you think you own the place. It's not bad around here now that you fellows have cleared out. After old Bain leaves, I guess we will have it first rate." "Go on to the cafeteria, Fuzzy," says Folks. "You're ruining my supper." 86 Fuzzy, still laughing because he had put us in ~ur place disappears around the coriler of the gym. It IS a well-~orn path that he travels. Generations of Jones H.~ll boys have traveled it. Each had its own future and ItS own past. Each had also been sonfronted with its own unique today. The boys who wo~ked in the dishroom were like that, and the path had once been theirs. Wink COlues out of the Main Building and walks toÂ­ward the end of the stadiulu. He must have worked late at his office and is now walking hOIue. He lifts a hand at us and continues. A wisp of fog lifts from the north end of the field as the cooler evening breeze stirs over the warm sod. I wonder what Wink thinks about as he walks by the footÂ­ball field. His coaching days are over, but surely he feels the tingle of excitement in the air. May?e he looks ~t t~e field and doesn't see it, or luaybe he delIberately aVOIds It. He must see it ... either way. Maybe now as h~ walks without feeling his steps, he sees his pla~ers wan~lng ~p, their beautiful red, white and blue unlfonus glIstenIng, under the lights and contrasting with the gree~ tur~. He calls them together in the end zone. The crow.d IS anXIously awaiting his starting lineup. Now he calls theIr .names, and through the luists of thue they trot out for the kICkoff: at center, Arthur Scates; at guards, Roger Smith and Robert Fry; at tackles, Bob Sarvis and Carl Yates; at ends, Clyde Cornwall and Paul Osteen; at blocking back, Bobby McClintock; at wing, Jimmy Schleicher; at fullback, Willialu McCrory; and at tailback, his nephew, William Burkett. . . It is a good team-position by position-a WInnIng team, an immortal team. I guess for Wink they will grace forever the grass of Jones Field. . Lew Aaron throws a switch and the east lIghts come on, flooding the field with brilliant illuluin~ti?n. The first spectators luove through the main gate and It IS today once more. 87

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: SIDNEY ARNOLD Sidney came to STC in 1940 from Wheat, Tennessee, but he left the next year for the peacetime army. Before his one year of service was up, the Army went on wartime status. He went into action early in 1943 and his company was the first to enter Biserte in North Africa. He was cited for bravery and given a battlefield commission in April of '43. He was soon promoted to the rank of first lieutenant but on June 30, 1944, he was killed in Italy while fighting against a German tank. l;loY D. BASS October 5, 1908 Roy was born October 5, 1908, at Liberty, Tennessee, and he attended school at Liberty. After attending STC he worked at several jobs and then enlisted in the U. S. Air Force on November 10, 1939. He rose to the rank of masÂ­ter sergeant and was in action and wounded at the Battle of Guadalcanal. More serious than the wound was the rheumatic fever he contracted there. He was returned to the States and was hospitalized at Brooks General Hospital, San Antonio, Texas, where he eventually died. Roy was buried at the Salem Ce~etery at Liberty in DeK~lb County, Tennessee. His nearest surviving relative is a sister, Mrs. T. D. Lawson of Liberty. 91

During his military service he con tracted aplastic anemia. He was hospitalized at Millingto Naval Base, Memphis, Tennessee, and died there. He . buried in Murfreesboro. HAROLD "BUDDY" BRA TLEY December 16, 1919-November 20, 1943 Buddy was born in Shelbyville and graduated from Central High School there. He came to STC in the fall 0 '40 and majored in science. He joined the Raider Band under Chief Valdez and became the drum major. After the war broke out he joined the Naval Reserve Air Force and went on active duty in March of 1942. Buddy's first training was at Great Lakes and eventuÂ­ally he was assigned to the 5th Fleet in the Pacific. He was a turret gunner and was killed in November, 1943, over Makin in the South Pacific. They were bombing an ammuÂ­nition dump and his plane was blown up in midair. His body was recovered and eventually buried at Shelbyville, TenÂ­nessee. He has two sisters, Lilliam Brantley Martin and Mildred Brantley Kemper. WILLIAM WAUFORD BURKETT, JR. CORNWELL "~lipH Cornwell attended Issac Litton High School in NashvIlle and came to STC in 1935. He was a popular stuÂ­dent and played both freshman and varsity football here. He graduated in 1940 and entered the Army Air Corps shortly after. He was commissioned and became a navigator on a B-17 crew which trained in Idaho. The flight in which he was a member was sent to Alaska to fight the Japanese. On. the second day after his arrival, his plane was sent into actIon near the is Ian d--. of Attu. The plane and crew disapÂ­peared and were not heard from again. LUCIAN DURHAM Lucian was from Murfreesboro and attended STC in 1931. Prior to the war he worked for the City Water ComÂ­pany. Corporal Durham was killed in the North African Campaign in early 1943. ROBERT C. FRY "Polly" Fry was from Old Hickory, Tennessee. He came to ST<? in 1937 and, among other things, played footÂ­ball here. LIke so many others of his era he quit school beÂ­fore. ~raduation and join~d the Army Air Force. During the LOUIsIana maneuvers of 42 he was killed in a plane crash. 94 THOMAS WESLEY GILLEY April 14, 1921-February 20, 1945 Wesley grew up in Morrison, Warren County, TennesÂ­see. He was a sharp-eyed, quick, young man who excelled in anything he went after. He was a member of an outÂ­standing high school basketball team, and, as in most small towns, their names were common. They had two Praters at guards, two Gilleys at forwards and Lusk at center. He came to STC in 1939 and worked his way through on the YA program. He was a forward on their championship in-tramural basketball team. ' . . Wesley was drafted out of college in late 42 and dId infantry basic at Camp Breckinridge, Kentucky. He went into action in Southern France as a staff sergeant and on February 20, 1945, he and thirty others were sent on a mission to destroy a pocket of Germans. All thirty of the Americans were killed in an ambush. . Wesley is buried in St. James Cemetery, France. He ~s survived by a sister, Helen (Mrs. John Jacobs). THOMAS R. In August of '42 he entered the service and trained at Camp Howze, Texas and Camp Roberts, California.; .Sgt. Hicks went overseas with the 330th Infantry and was kIlled in France July 11, 1944. His parents were Mr. and Mrs. Willard D. Hicks and they had four sons in the conflict at one time. LEWIS A. KEY Lewis Key was the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ed M. Key of Hartsville. Ii d an . ven t en .e was I.n atuate with flying and spent much of his spare tnne takmg lessons at the local airport. He joined the Air Force and went to Kelly Field where he flew pursuit planes. The plane and all eo Ie aboard were lost in a storm over the Meditterranean. p p NORMAN WENDELL LANE January 4, 1924-July 7, 1944 One of several brothers from Hamilton County who came to school at STC, Norman was born at Birchwood ~ear Chattanooga, and attended Birchwood High School' e came to college in the fall of 1941 and made th d' to th d t . h h e para e e epo WIt t e Army Reserve Corps in March of ~~~. He was a member of our close-knit dishroom frater- 96 I don't know whether Norman just naturally grew up quiet boy or got that way because of the loudmouths he met in college. At any rate, he never made a ripple in the prescribed orderly waters of the campus. He was a teacher's delight because he was a good student and an especially well-behaved student. When his mother died while he was a youngster, he became the boy who did the household duties, which helped hold the family together. aybe that is why he worked so well when he joined us in the cafeteria dishroom. He was attentive to his duties there, but watched with amusement the antics of Turner and Smith. The anny made a medical corpsman out of him, and rightly so. If a good medic is one who can remain deÂ­tached from the war and yet efficiently tend to the wounded, then the nonviolent Norman Lane was one of the few who was correctly assigned. Norman's earlier training was in Camp Barkley, Texas, and Camp Reynolds, Pennsylvania. He won regimental honors at Barkley for being the outstanding soldier. He went overseas in time for D-day, and though I do not know if he went in on June 6, he was there early. His last asÂ­signment was with Company A, 315th Medical Battalion. On July 7 he was killed in Normandy by German gunfire while retrieving the wounded. A letter from his platoon sergeant referred to him as '~one in a thousand." That is the way we knew him at SrC. . Norman's survivors are a half-brother, Malcolm De Friese, and brothers Bryan, Marvin, Darwin, and Quentin Lane. He was first buried in France but later transferred to Mcinturff Cemetery at Birchwood, Tennessee. RUFUS K. LOCKER Lt. Rufus King Locker listed as next of kin his sister, Mrs. T. K. Smith of Fayetteville, Tennessee. He went to high school at Fayetteville and later attended Morgan Prep 97

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: School in Petersburg. He came to STC in 1938 and played fresh~an football. He left after one year and later joined the air force. ROBERT JOSEPH MCCLINTOCK February 15, 1918-May 29, 1943 Bobby was from CornerSVille, Tennessee, in Marshal County. !Ie w~s an outstanding athlete and graduated from CornerSVIlle HIgh School in 1938. He came to STC that fall ~nd played both football and baseball for the Raiders. DurÂ­Ing the turmoil of indecision follOWing the outbreak of war, Bobby dr.opped out of school and married Jerri Houston. . He went mto the Army in late 1942. From. Fo:t Oglethorpe, Georgia, he went to Fort Or?e, CalIfornIa, and trained in the engineer corps. He was assIgned to ~ompany D, 50th Engineer Battalion, and sent to the AleutIan Is.lands. ~obby's particular company was sent to Attu to budd an aIr base in an area thought to be ~Ieared of all Japanese. During the night, their lines were Infiltrated by the enemy and most of the men of the comÂ­pany, including Bobby, were killed. . Mr. R.. J. McClintock, Bobby's father, survives as do hIS three SIsters, Mrs. Alfred Glenn, Mrs. Clyde Hipps and Mrs. Mirle Straw. WILLIAM "Uc" MCCRORY January 4, 1916-February 25, 1945 During the decade of the forties no other Raider with the possible exception of Moody Bain, so typified toughness as dId Ug McCrory. To those of us who saw him first in the 98 fall of 1940, there is still a feeling of awe. He was a neat dresser, six feet tall, and he wore shirts that emphasized his squared shoulders and deep chest. His muscular face was carved from Vermont marble and topped with reddishÂ­blond hair. Cold azure eyes glared down at all freshman boys but thawed quickly for the girls. He was a moviemaker's dream of the American Inarine and his life story was just as typical. Bill McCrory lived in Lawrenceburg, Tennessee, and graduated from high school there in 1934. He was in and out of college at STC for the next several years, finally graduating in the spring of 1941. Sometimes Ug worked to finance his return to college, and sometimes he traveled. Though he had few confidants, some say he rode the rails from coast to coast. As a student he did it all. He sang in the men's choral group and he was active in dralnatics. In baseball he was a hard-hitting outfielder and in football he was a doubly hard-hitting fullback. Shortly after the bombing of Pearl Harbor, Ug jO,ined the marine corps. He went through basic training at Parris Island and officer training at Quantico. He went overseas early to New Zealand and then fought through Guadalcanal and other islands. Eventually he became company comÂ­mander of Company A, First .Battalion, Ninth Regiment of the Third Division, USMC. To those of us who were not there, the Battle of Iwo Jima must have been adequately described as our toughest, for it was there that the Japanese killed Ug McCrory. The following is a quotation from a column written by Sgt. Red O'Donnell and entitled "Men Under Vicious Attack." Officers and enlisted men who were near Capt. McCrory when he was hit by an artillery shell, exÂ­plained that his company had suffered many casualties during a vicious all-day attack against a formidable enemy defense. They said that prior to digging in for the night, Captain McCrory learned that the com- 99

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 60
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: pany's right flank was exposed, presenting a serious defensive problem. He made a complete survey under intense small arms, mortar, and artillery fire, and so arranged the defensive position that the troops were afforded ample protection. Wllile returning to his foxhole after the mission, he was hit by a shell fragÂ­ment. Comrades ran to his rescue but his death was almost instantaneous. Ug had married Elizabeth Brown. She and his brother Raymon, are his survivors. He was fIrst buried in Kagan Ret: to, the 3~d Marine Division Cemetery on Iwo lima. Today the remams of the rugged Raider lie in Grave 544 Section E, National Cemetery of the Pacific, Hawaii. ' ORBRY H. MOORE June 28, 1919-November 2, 1943 Orbry grew up on North Maple Street in Murfreesboro, and attended CentraLHigh School. In the fall of 1938 he entered college at STC and graduated in the spring of '41. Orbry was a tall, beak-nosed, sallow-faced, towhead who did ~ell in everything he tried. He was one of Nooby Freeman s better woodworking students. While the freshmen were struggling with the traditional cedar chest Orbry was helping them and turning out furniture like ~ factory at the same time. He had many interests. His secÂ­ond favorite activity was music. He played the sax and played it well. His favorite activity was courting Sara Johnson from Shelbyville. He entered the army air corps in September of '41 and got his wings at Maxwell Field. He and Sara were married in November of '42. He went overseas to the South Pacific with the 345th Group, 501st Squadron of the Fifth Air Force. On November 2, 1943, during air action at Rabaul Harbor, New Guinea, his plane was damaged. Some observÂ­ers reported seeing it land safely on the beach of an island 100 thought to be unoccupied. Nothing else was ever heard of him.. The Air Force conducted an extensive search for him, and after the war Sara conducted her own search, to no avail. He was officially declared dead by the Air Force on January 21, 1946. Besides Sara, Orbry's parents, Mr. and Mrs. T. A. oore, survive and live in Crossville, Tennessee. He also has one sister, Mrs. Avis Moore Karaberis. WILLIAM D. NEELY III 1920-1943 Bill Neely was born January 26, 1920 near MurfreesÂ­boro, Tennessee. He attended school at Smyrna and graduated frOln high school there in 1939. That fa~l he enÂ­rolled at STC and studied there for two years. BIll was a slender redhead, a member of the male chorus, and a good student. When the civilian pilot training program was instiÂ­tuted at STC in 1941, he and his buddy, Jimmy Gregory, enrolled. They graduated with several other students who also became pilots during the war. Bill and Jimmy joined the army air corps in September 1941 and were together from their basic training at RanÂ­dolph Field to enemy action in North Africa. Bill was the pilot of a P-38 and participated in twentyÂ­five missions over enemy-held territory, mainly escorting bombers. On May 22, 1943, his part in a raid brought a ciÂ­tation from Major General James Doolittle which read in part: As leader of a flight escorting B-17s on a bombing misÂ­sion over Bo Rizzo, Sicily, Lt. Neely, discovering that two aircraft of his flight had been set on fire in the vioÂ­lent attack of a superior number of enemy fighters, went to the rescue of his comrades: After breaking up the attack of two ME 109s on one P-38, he then unhesitantingly went to the rescue 101

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 61
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: of another pilot whose plane had'lost the use of one of its motors. By expert flying and skillful fighting, Lieutenant Neely drove off two other Mel09s and brought him safely to base. For this extraordinary achievement, saving one life with complete disregard for his own safety, Lieutenant Neely drove off two other MEI09s and self and the armed forces of the United States. As leader of a flight escorting B-17s on a bombing mission over Bo Rizzo, Sicily, Lt. Neely, discovering that two airÂ­craft of his flight had been set on fire in the violent attack of a superior number of enemy fighters, went to the rescue of his comrades. After breaking up the attack of two ME 109s on one P-38, he then unhesitantiilgly went to the rescue of another pilot whose plane had lost the use of one of its motors. By expert flying and skillful fighting, Lieutenant Neely drove off tWo other Me 109s and brought him safely to base. For this extraordinary achievement, saving one life with complete disregard for his own safety, Lieutenant Neely has reflected great credit upo,n himself and the armed forces of the United States. Bill was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross, the Air Medal, and three Oak Leaf clusters. Later in May, while flying in a training mission with new replacements and in a simulated dogfight, he went into a dive and did not pull out. It is unknown what happened. Bill is buried in Tripoli, North Africa. SAM T. NISBETT JR. 1917-1942 Sam was born in Murfreesboro but moved with his family early in life to Louisville, Kentucky. Ida Florence, the sister, was six feet tall. Younger brother Bill was six-four and Sam was six-six. Bill became an outstanding Raider fullback in 1942, but by then Sam was a lieutenant in the infantry.. Sam's outfit trained at Fort McClellan and he receIved his overseas shots there before a scheduled departure. AlÂ­most immediately he contracted leukemia and died within a few weeks. He is buried in Evergreen Cemetery, MurÂ­freesboro. PAUL OSTEEN 1909-1944 Paul was a member of the middle Tennessee Osteen family that has produced many scholar-athletes and is still doing so. During this period ~is older brother, Dick, was captain of both the football and basketball teams at STC. After his sophomore year, he transferred to the Murfreesboro school where most of the Osteens have since matriculated. Paul married Marie Vader and they moved to Detroit, Michigan. They had one child, a daughter, Leslie Anne (now Mrs. Jon Martin). In January of 1944 he was. ~rafted and sent to Fort Sheridan, Illinois, for infantry trammg. A few months later he was sent overseas as a replacement. During the battle for St. Lo, France, ~n A.ugust ~944, he was struck in the chest by shrapnel and dIed ll11medlately, three months before his thirty-fifth birthday. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 62
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: STC in 1934. Upon graduation in 1938 he worked for a while, then joined the army air corps. He received his commission on November 1, 1941, and went to Bradley Field, Connecticut, to fly reconnaissance planes. He marÂ­ried Miller Lovell of Nashville and they moved to Denver when he was transferred to Lowry Field. Shortly after that, while on a training flight, his plane crashed and burned. WALTER PINNELL Walter was from Nashville and he attended STC durÂ­ing the 1939-40 term. He left to join the air force and was later commissioned as a pilot. During the summer of '43 his plane crashed while on a training maneuver in Virginia and he was killed. J. W. REEVES, JR. -1920-1944 John Winston Reeves, Jr., lived on the Halls Hill Road out of Murfreesboro and he attended high school at Kittrell. He came to STC for the 1938-39 school year and then left to work. He enlisted in the air force in 1942 and got his wings at Lackland Air Force Base in Texas. He was sent overseas to the European Theatre, and on August 22, 1944, he participated in a massive air raid over Hungary. His plane was hit by enemy flak and was last seen as it dropped out of formation. The VFW Post, 4575, in Murfreesboro is named the Smith-Rogers-Reeves Post. It honors three local boys who were also former students at STC. They were Roger Smith, Edgar Rogers, and J. W. Reeves. None of the three were married. J. W.'s nearest survivor is a sister, Mrs. Sherry Gipson, Rt. 8, Murfreesboro. He was buried in the United States Military Cemetery at St. AvoId, France. 104 EDGAR LELAND ROGERS, JR. August 22, 1919-June 4, 1942 Edgar lived at 444 East- College Street, Murfreesboro, Tennessee, and attended Central High School. He was tall and good-looking and attracted the attention of many girls. He was also gregarious, and among his best friends were Dick Stickney and Gerald Cohen. Together they organized a high school fraternity in 1936. "Booger" was mechanically inclined and could repair anything. He worked sometimes with Jimmy Smith in radio repair and sometimes at the Stickney-Griffith Drug Store. He, entered STC in 1938, and among his acquaintances was Clyde "Slip" Cornwell from Nashville. Booger entered the army air corps in August of 1941, taking his training at Keesler Field and at another field near Boise, Idaho. He became a flight engineer, and before leavÂ­ing for Alaska in the spring of '42 he became a member of a B-17 crew that had as its navigator Slip Cornwell. The second day after arriving in Alaska, Edgar wrote his buddy, Dick Stickney, a prophetic letter announcing his belief that he would never return. The next day two B-17s went on a bombing mission to destroy a Japanese aircraft carrier at Attu Island. The first bomber returned. The plane carrying Edgar and Slip was never heard from again. either was the Japanese carrier. Two sisters survive: Frances (Mrs. John Alderman) and Octavia (Mrs. JamesÂ· Woodward). ROBERT J. SARVIS July 4, 1917-July 25, 1944 Bob was born in Sarnia, Ontario, on the fourth of July. His parents moved to Nashville and he attended high school at Hume Fogg and worked part-time at Whiteway Laundry. He came to STC in 1937 and graduated in the spring of 1941. 105

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 63
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bob was a strong and handsome fellow who played tackle on the football team, worked for awhile for Minor Bragg, and courted Juanita Hindman. Upon graduation he went to work for the National Life Insurance Company in Nashville. Shortly after Pearl Harbor he joined the Royal Canadian Air Force, and shortly after that he married Juanita. After receiving his primary training in the RCAF, he was sent on detached service to the U.S. Army Air Force. His rank was captain and he was a pilot in the Lancaster bombers. His first combat mission was on D day. The mission on which Bob was killed was a massive bombing raid, July 25, 1944, over Stuttgart, Germany. He had finished his run and was returning when his plane was attacked by German fighter planes near the Normandy coast. His plane was shot down and he ordered the crew to bail out. The last crew member to jump reported that Bob was still at the controls. It is thought that he was hit by shots from a fighter plane. The wreckage fell into the chanÂ­nel and his body was never recovered. Bob is survived -by one brother and three sisters. Juanita died in 1970. ARTHUR J. SCATES June 20, 1920-July 9, 1943 Arthur "Snooks" Scates was from Union City, TennesÂ­see. He came to STC in 1939 to play football and he did just that. He was a medium-sized fellow, with unruly blonde hair, blue eyes and a big Roman nose. As a single wing center in the pre face-guard days, his nose was conÂ­stantly skinned. When the student flying classes opened, Scates enrolled and flying became his second passion. Just before school started in the fall of '41, he joined the air force and went to Hicks Field. He received his wings at Randolph Field in January of '42 and became a bomber pilot. 106 Snooks requested a combat assignment and was sent to North Africa. He flew a B-24 Liberator which he named Stella for his mother. In July 1943 he was in a flight which left Libya and met enemy planes near the northwest coast of Crete. His plane was shot down in the Mediterranean and his body never recovered. First Lieutenant Scates was with the 201st Combat wing of the Eighth Air Force. He is survived by four brothers and four sisters. JAMES L. SCHLEICHER February 18, 1921-]une 26, 1944 Jimmy was born in Nashville and attended high school at Goodlettsville, where he was coached by Bubber MurÂ­phy. He came to STC in 1939 and left in 1941 to join the air force. Jimmy, like many athletes of his day, played all three sports while in college and he played them w~ll. He was a good-looking fellow with black curly hiar, qUiet \md soft-spoken. He seemed to take little delight in the hazing of freshmen during the fall of 1940, which evoked a feeling of gratitude from those who were served. JimlllY ranked number one in a class of 200 when he graduated from flight school at Randolph Field. He ser~ed as a flight instructor at Turner Field and at Lawrence FIeI? in Illinois. Then he ca~lle to Smyrna, Tennessee, for hIs pilot's training in B-24s. On a flight beÂ­tween India and China his plane was destroyed. SubÂ­sequent investigation revealed that the plane had been sabotaged. . Captain James L. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 64
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: EDWARD S. SEWARD July 6, 1923-0ctober 15, 1945 Ed was born near Murfreesboro and attended school here. He graduated from Central High School in the spring of 1941 and enrolled at STC that fall. He was a good stuÂ­dent, and though he was not in college long enough to deÂ­velop a major, he did well in both English and biology. Ed entered the air force in January 1943 and trained as a medic at Fort Benjamin Harrison, Indiana. He debarked from the states at Camp Kilmer and went to New Zealand where he was assigned to the Headquarters Squadron of the 13th Air Force. During the South Pacific campaign, Ed was on GuadalÂ­canal, the Mariannas, and was awarded a special commenÂ­dation for "duties performed while under fire in combat" on Bo~~eo: At the end of the war he was sent to Leyte, PhIlIppIne Islands, to await transportation home. While there he volunteered to serve in the medical facility located alongside an airstrip. An Incoming plane missed the landing strip and hit the building. Sgt. Ed Seward was killed in the crash~ Ed was buried in the USAF Cemetery on Leyte. In August 1948, his remains were returned to Murfreesboro and interred in Evergreen Cemetery. His parents, Mr. and Mrs. James T. Seward, still live in Murfreesboro and he has one sister, Mrs. M. C. Rone. ' ALLAN SEWART, JR. Allan was a student at STC in 1934-35. He was a native of Nashville and had attended Hume-Fogg High School t~ere ..He graduated from the Army Air School at Randolph FIeld III 1936 and served in Panama and in Hawaii before Pearl Harbor. He was in the Battle of Midway. Later, while serving as a squadron commander in the Solomons, he was 108 killed on November 18, 1942. During his brief, but he!~eÂ­fight against the Japanese, Major Sewart was awarded every possible decoration except the Congressional Medal of Honor. The air base at Smyrna, Tennessee, was named in his honor. ROBERT K. SMITH August 22, 1925-January 29, 1945 Robert was typical of the young fellows who were in high school during the war. He wanted to get into action. He graduated from Rockvale High School in May and started to ~ollege at STC in September of 1943. A few days before his eighteenth birthday, he enlisted in the army air force. He was allowed to finish the fall quarter. Robert became part of the gun crew on a bomber and was sent to England to fly with the Eighth Air Force. DurÂ­ing the continuous air raids of January 1945, he served as a lower ball turret gunner. On January 29, his plane was leading in a squadron formation. Shortly after takeoff, a crippled plane returning from a mission over Germany flew into the path of the squadron. The plane in which Robert was flying manuevered to miss the crippled plane, but colÂ­lided with another plane and crashed. Robert Smith's survivors are his parents, Robert R. and Etta H. Smith, and two sisters, Margaret Ann Smith and Muriel Smith BransonÂ·. Robert is buried in the Stones River National Cemetery at Murfreesboro. . ROGER EASTMA SMITH January 19, 1921-July 21, 1944 Roger grew up at Overall, Tennessee, five miles out of Murfreesboro on the Salem Pike. He attended Central High in Murfreesboro. He was the stereotype of the big, 109

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 65
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: strong, straightforward, pink-cheek~d country boy, and for good reasons. He came to STC in the fall of 1939 and found all aspects of college life to his liking. He was a popular student leader, but the activity that fit him best was footÂ­ball. Roger was a guard-quick, strong and aggressive. He enlisted in the marine corps reserve and went into active duty upon graduation from college in 1942. He did his basic training and officer's training at Quantico, then served at Camp Lejeune until April, 1943. He' went overÂ­seas to New Caledonia and was assigned to the "Raider BatÂ­talion" in the First Provisional Brigade. Later he became a platoon leader in the famous 4th Marines. Roger was killed on Guam, and among his various commendations and medals was the Navy Cross. The folÂ­lowing is taken from that citation: For extraordinary heroism as mortar platoon leader atÂ­tached to the First Division, Fourth Marines ... in acÂ­tion against enemy Japanese forces on the island of Guam in the Marianas... Islands on 21 July, 1944. MovÂ­ing his mortar platoon up from the beach in the rear of advancing riflemen, First Lieutenant Smith observed a wounded rifleman lying close to a hostile pillbox and, halting his men, fearlessly advanced to the aid of the marine under a continuous barrage from the Japanese emplacement. Engaging the enemy with rifle fire and hand grenades, he held his' position despite the fierce oppositjon and attempted to neutralize the pillbox with a flame-thrower, but failing in this, continued to move up on the enemy while firing his rifle, and although mortally wounded during the bitter hostilities, sucÂ­ceeded in silencing the hostile gun-battery. By his deÂ­termined initiative, valiant fighting spirit, and resolute fortitude in the face of terrific odds, First Lieutenant Smith contributed materially to the ultimate success of our forces in recapturing this vital stronghold, and his unwavering devotion to duty throughout was in keepÂ­ing with the highest traditions of the United States Naval Service. He gallantly gave his life for his counÂ­try. 110 The nearest surviving family member is Lucia, his sisÂ­ter, who was herself a bright light among the Forty Frosh of STC. She is now Mrs. Allen Muse of Nashville. Roger was first buried on Guam, but lies today in Evergreen Cemetery in Murfreesboro. RUFE ELDRIDGE TIPPS 1918-1944 Eldridge was born at Skinnum in Lincoln County. He graduated from high school at Blanche and the.n went to David Lipscomb College, where he roomed WIth Oakley Jennings .. He completed an AA degree and transferred to STC in 1940. He was one of the NYA boys and played on their crack intramural basketball team. In October of his senior year, he was drafted during the "Goodby Dear, I'll Be Back in a Year" stage. Two months later came the bombing of Pearl Harbor. Eldridge became an artilleryman, training at Camp Wheeler, Georgia, and Fort Sill, Oklahoma. His unit was attached to the 90th Infantry Division and they went in early in the invasion of France. He was killed eight days after D day near Cherbourg, France, and was eventually buried in River View Cemetery in Fayetteville, Tennessee. His parents, Mr.. and Mrs. Rufe A. Tipps, live near EsÂ­till Springs in Franklin County. Other survivors are his sisÂ­ters, Mrs. Lawson Jean and Mrs. Martha Ann Schiber, and brothers T. J. and Robert Tipps. BRYA TURNER, JR. 1923-1945 01' Turner looked like he was born twenty-one years old, and I guess to us he will forever be twenty-one. He was a farm boy from Hurricane Mills and attended high school at Waverly, where he played basketball and III

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 66
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: graduated among the top 10 percent of his class. He was tall, bony, sandy-haired and deadpan. He walked with a farmer's stride and had hands that could wring sawdust frOIn plow handles. The characteristics that endeared him to the campus were his solemn wit and his complete indepenÂ­dence. Bryan came to STC in 1941 and roomed on the second floor of Jones Hall. He became a chemistry major and maintained better than a 3.0 average. His favorite form of recreation was half-court basketball, but second to that was his nightly tour of the girls' dormitories. There were no strangÂ­ers to Turner. When he joined the "dishroom gang" in the cafeteria, action picked up and the work became pleasurÂ­able. Turner joined the Army Enlisted Reserve Corps in '42 and made the March march to the depot. He was first to greet the exiled J. B. Roberson on the Boulevard and told him that he and Moe together would get him back in school after the war. From Fort Oglethorpe he went to Camp Grant, Illinois, with a'" bunch of us for basic training as a medic. Nothing was difficult for him except marching. The platoon stayed out of step with him. He had walked too long behind a mule. He went to Northwestern on the AST program and later went overseas as a replacement medic. Off the Azores Islands in the fall of 1944, the transport ship that was carryÂ­ing him collided with a French aircraft carrier and Bryan was killed. After the war, I visited his mother and I received Christmas cards from her for more than twenty years. She was the type who needed a tombstone for a source of mourning, but she had none. Turner was lost at sea. She showed me letters that she had from two of the girls he was engaged to while in Chicago. While traveling with an independent basketball team in 1948, and while old war stories were still new, Joe Spain told me that he had been on deck one night when his ship collided with another off the Azores. He said that some of 112 the men were killed instantly, but others were drowned when the compartment was sealed to keep the ship afloat. There is no way of knowing how Turner went, ?ut I. can imagine that he was writing duplicate letters to flYe differÂ­ent girls that night. I suspect that the old plowboy literally went down swinging. LEONARD H. WHITE Leonard graduated from Macon County High in Lafayette, Tennessee, in 1938 and came to STC that' fall. He was an industdal arts major and became a st~dent foreman on the NYA job. He helped in the constructIon of the current industrial arts building. In April of 1942 Leonard was induc~e? into the army and sent to Fort Eustis, Virginia, for traInIng: He went to England as a top sergeant in Septembe~. of 43 and ,~ent into action on D day. He survived the longest day but was killed in France on December 4. His wife, Thelma Yearwood White, and one son survive. ALTO F. WHITLOW Alton Whitlow came to STC in 1936. His home was in Savannah, Tennessee, and he first attended college at Union in Jackson, Tennessee. He married Fanny B~rbour. He went into the army early and became a sergeant in the infantry. He was killed in France in October of 1944. LEE CARLTON YATES 1918-1945 Carl Yates was born in Nashville and attended Central , High School. He graduated in 1936 and enrolled at STC that fall. He was a big, strong, left-handed fellow who 113

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 67
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: played either guard or tackle on the Raider football team for four years. He was also a baseball pitcher. Carl lived part of the time in the Moffitt House, and he kept a motorcycle there. Sometimes he would ride into Nashville and return with his high-school flame, Nancy Burge, on his bike. In 1942, Carl married Nancy and joined the navy. He was commissioned in 1943. He became a member of an underwater demolition team and in this capacity he went into the Battle of Iwo Jima in February 1945. The frogmen had to work before the shelling began. It is thought that Carl was shot by a sniper from the conning tower of a Japanese submarine. Lt. (J.G.) Yates and Nancy had one son, Carl Burge Yates. There is a billboard on the interstate south of Nashville, Tennessee, that reads, Murfreesboro, Home of Middle Tennessee State University. Below that is an adÂ­dendum: And the Blue Raiders. There must be a thousand similar signs throughout the United States, each designating to the traveler a point of pride located in the near vicinity. The sign informs the traveler, but to the reminiscent it says much more. To "Old Folks," Jim Butler, and me, it flashes fragments of memories of our own intimate association with STC. Jim Butler called them "the rugged but good years." We were in the generation of the forties. The generaÂ­tion scolded in retrospect by sociologists who say that the expected postwar leadership did not surface from the forÂ­ties. But what do they know? Born as the twenties began to roar, nurtured by the bare-boned thirties, we came of age in the forties. Entering STC w.as a gigantic step into a new world. It was the land of jubilee, but shortly after we saw it, the world flamed up and we were gone. During the ensuing years, our goal was "return," and return was symbolized more perhaps by the 114 college campus than by anything else. We felt for those who died in that melee. From Connie Owens in the spring of '42 to Ed Seward in the fall of '45, the memory of each Raider lost was impressed indelibly upon us, not so much because they died, bl:lt because they could not return \ Return was satisfying, almost to the degree of complaÂ­cency, and then social and scientific changes came upon us with bewildering speed. Another war was fought and it was designed for a tie. Our own kids fought still another, in which only loss was possible. Today we see another generaÂ­tion on the campus. Another unique group of kids with their own yesterdays and their own tomorrows before them. They look at us as strangely as we once looked at Mr. Frazier, or "Nooby," or Dean Beasley. They are responding to their 'decade even now as we responded to the forties. Good luck, kids. Keep'em flying. 115

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 70
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: About the Author Joe E. Nunley has been a unlversity professor in his native Tennessee for the past fifteen years. Formerly a high school coach and teacher, he is interested in historical research, in particular as it relates to his immediate region and to his beloved Middle Tennessee State University. Dr. Nunley's gift for spinÂ­ning the bizarre tale and his compassionate rendering of human foibles have placed him in demand as a platform speaker and as a writer. The innate formula has been delightÂ­fully applied to his saga of The Raider Forties.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page 71
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Author: Joe E. Nunley on left

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Raider Forties
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Raider Forties recounts the experiences of a group of young men who attended Middle Tennessee State College prior to World War II--ten of whom left to serve in the military. It traces the lives of those who returned and commemorates those who did not. Many professors and other campus personalities are discussed as well
Part 1. The forty frosh -- The year two -- Summer of '42 -- The Fall of '42 -- Departure -- Rehearsal -- Where did all the flowers go? -- Return -- Part 2. Taps.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: State Senator Thelma Harper, keynote speaker at the 2003 Founders Day lunÂ­cheon celebrating the 25th anniversary of the women's center, said there "should not be any more 'firsts' for women" because we should have moved past that and become leaders in all things. continued versity. [We encouraged] returning stuÂ­dents, women who had been out of school or who had never attended college, who ' had maybe problems at home and that kind of thing-it was more of a referral service in the beginning." The group also pushed for a secure campus environment. In response to. physiÂ­cal attacks on women, the center lobbied for improved campus lighting, safer landÂ­scaping, and an escort service. "The first women's center was just a room in Jones Hall, totally staffed by volunÂ­teers. Faculty members worked there on their own time outside of teaching and ofÂ­fice hours," says Janice Hayes, professor of Educational Leadership and founding memÂ­ber. In 1999, because ofincreasing demand, the director and the' secretary went from part-timeto full-tilIle status, and the cenÂ­ter's budget increased dramatically. Today, the JAWC is housed in the James Union Building and has a full-time staff of two, a graduate assistant, and several student associates. been at the university for the same length of time. The evidence of bias was comÂ­pelling. A complaint was filed with the EEOC for equal pay; federal representaÂ­tives reviewed the information and conÂ­ducted interviews. As a result, 35 women received a total of $50,000 in back pay and salaries were adjusted. "We all need to remind [young women that] they're standing on the shoulders of women who've gone before them and who took chances with their careers," says Margaret Scott, a founding member and retired associate professor and librarian. "Why would a woman with the same credentials not get paid the same as her male counterpart? It just doesn't make sense." ':June's gift was not only that she was willing to rectify the pay inequity but willÂ­ing to work until changes were made," says founding member Faye Johnson, assoÂ­ciate professor of Sociology and AnthroÂ­pology and assistant to the executive vice president and provost. "She had the capacÂ­ity to stay with it, work toward a solution, and then move on, defining and then reÂ­defining the goal." In June of 1977 the first women's center opened at MTSU. Under the name WISE [Women In Service to Education], the center was run by CFAW volunteers. This early incarnation helped acclimate and prepare returning women students, started a campus daycare center, and proÂ­moted campus safety. WISE changed its name to WIRC [Women's Information and Referral Center] in 1984, and in 1985 it became the June Anderson Women's Center [JAWC]. It is the largest and oldest university women's center in the state, one year older than Vanderbilt's. Margaret Scott recalls, "We had hoped it would be a center where we could help women students adjust to life at the uni- I-I fields, even endowing a scholarship for women in nontraditional roles. She identiÂ­fied about 25 fields traditionally domiÂ­nated by men. "What we're doing is trying to help women help themselves," Anderson said in a 1982 Daily News Journal article. "We'll be providing small grants to women 23 years old and older who desire to purÂ­sue nontraditional programs of study." "She was fearless and tenacious. When she wanted something, she wouldn't quit until she achieved it," said the late Esther Seeman, director of the Japan Center of Tennessee and professor of political science. ':June was very energetic and assertive about things-totally interested in the welfare of women on campus," says Ordoubadian. It helped Anderson to have the force of federal law on her side. Only with the adoption of Title IX in the Education Codes of 1972, which included the statement, "equal access to education programs," did women begin to realize their full career potentials. That simple but powerful phrase inspired women in all walks of life to pursue careers in medÂ­icine, law; engineering, architecture, and other male-oriented profesÂ­sions. In 1975, Anderson andothers on campus formed CFAW to provide support for MTSU women. Women educators were voicing concerns about salary discrepancies based solely on gender. Along with other foundÂ­ing members, Anderson conducted a study that demonstrated discrimination against women at MTSU. They compared women's salary information with that of male educaÂ­tors who had the same credentials and had Bene Scanlon Cox, left, and June Anderson in a photo from the JAWC archives. "She was fearless and tenacious. When she wanted something, she wouldn't quit. .. " who only speak Qf change, Anderson actuÂ­ally did something about it. ':June was very interested in making things easier for women-to make it easier for them to do what had been so difficult for her," says Margaret Ordoubadian, assoÂ­ciate professor of English and one of the founding members of Con-cerned Faculty and Administration Women (CFAW). "In that sense, every woman on campus is indebted to her." Anderson, in the maleÂ­dominated field of sciences, had confided to OrdouÂ­badian that since she was an only child her father probably treated her like the son he'd never had by encouraging her to be more adventurous in her career choice. Anderson sought to encourage other women to choose male-dominated 4 MTSU MAGAZINE â€¢ FALL/WINTER 2002 The June Anderson Women's Center is a daily reminder of a"urrreal as it may seem today, just 25 years ago most women couldn't get a bank loan without a male cosigner, women working fulltime earned 59 cents to every dollar earned by men, and marÂ­ried women were not issued credit cards in their own names. Help Wanted ads in many newspapers were still segregated between women and men, even though the Equal Employment Opportunity ComÂ­mission had ruled the practice illegal in 1968. Imagine being a woman educator at MTSU in the 1970s with very little hope of tenure. Think of working for a significantly lower salary than male teachers in the same department with the same credenÂ­tials working the same hours. Few women were full professors, served on committees or worked in administration. ' Do those days sound unfair? June S. Anderson knew they were, but unlike some
